fields.headline: Website of the week
fields.standfirst: www.grandtrunk.com
fields.trailText: www.grandtrunk.com
fields.body:
A top-hatted Englishman riding on an elephant with a couple of natives? It's not just elephants, darling. Bruce Palling, who used to work for the BBC and Tatler, has set up Grand Trunk and Western & Oriental Travel and invited his wife to edit the newsletter and website.

It sounds just like A Passage to India. Doesn't it? Forster would have adored it. Bruce has been so clever. He's only chosen first-rate places in Indonesia, Mexico, Morocco, Bora Bora etc - the kinds of places where it's so important to find a good hotel.

So many places that used to have big reputations turn out to be dreadful. Quite. But you really must try the Amanpuri in Phuket. They have a gorgeous boat with the most amazing staff.

I'm sure I would adore it, sweetie, but the taxman has been utterly horrible this year. Darling, the cheapest rooms are only £340 a night - simply let me know when you want to go and I'll lend you the Learjet.

fields.headline: Museum pieces
fields.trailText: It's still too cold to loiter outside for long in most of these cities. So take refuge in a museum, but make sure you go prepared.
fields.body:
It's still too cold to loiter outside for long in most of these cities. So take refuge in a museum, but make sure you go prepared.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York
Fantastic stuff. The Explore and Learn section is particularly useful if you intend to bring unwilling children to the museum.

For more NY museums: NYC.gov

The Prado, Madrid
Disappointing, with the exception of the "What is there to see?" tour. Click on the Visits icon to find it.

For more: Spain tourism

Rijksmuseum, Amsterdam
A tricksy, cumbersome effort with little to recommend it.

For more: VisitHolland.com

The Hermitage, St Petersburg
Most Russian websites will either crash your browser or load too slowly to be of much use. This one, however, is maintained by IBM and is enormously impressive. You can admire the view from the roof of the Winter Palace and examine the Gold of the Nomads at different scales.

National Museums of Scotland
Six national museums - the Royal, the Museum of Scotland, of Flight, of Costume, of War and of Scottish Country Life, which opens next summer - are hosted here. (The Museum of Piping, perhaps understandably, is mentioned only in passing). All are substantially cheaper than their London equivalents, with a family pass costing £15.

Uffizi, Florence
Very ponderous to download and scarcely updated since its launch in 1996, the Uffizi's site is nonetheless compelling. Some of the paintings are reproduced, some not; it's pleasantly haphazard.

For more Italian museums: Italian tourist board

The Art Institute of Chicago
Showcases a number of paintings and objects; to explore the galleries, you'll need QuickTime 4, which can be downloaded quite easily. Watch out for the 2001: Building for Space Travel exhibition, which opens in March. The children's section is good; kids can e-mail a lion called Artie with questions about the museum.

For more: City of Chicago

Tokyo National Museum
Among its collection, the National Museum has pieces from all over Asia, including ancient calligraphy, lots of ceramics and terracotta tomb figures.

For more: Japan travel updates

Louvre, Paris
You can avoid the long queues that snake around the pyramid during the high season in the French capital by buying your tickets in advance via a link on this site. But by far the most exciting feature is the extensive collection of QuickTime videos, which enable you to examine the Venus de Milo from every angle.

fields.headline: Mighty Aphrodite
fields.standfirst: Cyprus, home of the Greek goddess of love, has been seducing travellers for thousands of years. Paul Gogarty is no exception
fields.trailText: Cyprus, home of the Greek goddess of love, has been seducing travellers for thousands of years. Paul Gogarty is no exception.
fields.body:
The hire car crested the pass at Drouseia, and the Akamas peninsula, dappled in gorse, rock rose and olive trees, stretched out in the late afternoon sun. Chrysochou Bay curved away to the east, and curtains of uninhabited cinnamon-coloured hills ran all the way to Cape Arnaoutis.

Like every other time I'd visited the Akamas, it felt like a homecoming. And this time home was the Anassa hotel, opened a couple of years back.

As the first major tourist hotel to open in the island's sensitive north-west corner, the Anassa set off warning bells for conservationists who for two decades had been vainly trying to get the island's last undeveloped coastline designated a national park.

Many who were against the project now accept it as the island's most environmentally-friendly hotel, but just about everyone - apart from developers with vested interests - agreed that a moratorium on new building should be reimposed in the area. Unfortunately, new legislation passed last summer is to allow "controlled development" in the area. (In Cyprus "controlled" and "development" go together like oil and water.)

The fear is that the island's final wilderness area will soon become just another chunk of the concrete slick that has steamrollered through Ayia Napa, Larnaca, Limassol and Paphos. Our visit to the Anassa, therefore, felt like both a beginning and an end - I'd certainly advise you to get there fast before the building starts and roads instead of mule tracks criss-cross this Cypriot Arcadia.

For the past 13 years or so, my family have holidayed here almost every spring or autumn, seduced by an island that basks in 240 sunny days a year, is inhabited by the some of the friendliest people on earth (virtually all of them English speaking), is dotted with Byzantine churches and mountain orchids and fringed by an incomparable coastline.

The Anassa lay with its toes dipped in golden sands, knee deep in spring wild flowers and indigenous herbs, a slingshot from where Aphrodite - goddess of love and beauty - bathed with her nymphs (the grotto, half hidden behind a tangle of vines, is still there). Pretty villa-style rooms dappled the grassy knoll overlooking three pools that swam their way down the hillside in tiers to the sea.

Once we'd unpacked, my two children set off for a free introductory scuba session in the pool and then promptly signed up for the four-day PADI Junior Open Water Diver course. Their instructor, Hans, had left his native Holland and pitched his tent on this self-same beach 20 years earlier and, as he put it, simply "forgot to go home". And so while Larne and Max spent days practising fin pivots on the ocean floor and exploring the underworld of offshore islands, my wife and I settled in to the Anassa.

Inside the main building, modelled on the hilltop monastery of Chrysorrogiatissa, Roman mosaics, Venetian frescoes, and Islamic fountains bear testimony to the island's successive colonisations. Here, too, are concealed the heated indoor pool, spa and squash courts which are helping establish the Anassa as a year-round Mediterranean destination.

In such sunshine, however, it seemed insane to be inside so, on our first day as empty-nesters, we spent three hours over a seafood lunch at our favourite restaurant, Psaropoulos, at nearby Latsi harbour.

The next day, we left before the children did, walking the Adonis Nature Trail, which started just a couple of kilometres from the hotel. With the air thick with pine, juniper and oregano, and an owl not yet turned in for the night, we walked a sublime five-mile switchback, resting in a glade known as Pyrgos Tis Rigenas (Shelter of the Queen). It was here that Aphrodite liked to take an afternoon nap after frolicking with her nymphs. Above us spread the broad canopy of an oak several hundred years old. Beside it, a monastery, considerably older, slowly crumbled quietly back into the earth.

On the Friday, we all finally spent a day together, hiring a boat to go snorkelling in the deserted bay of Fontana Amorosa (Spring of Love). There, we discovered countless fragments of amphora laying on the seafloor left by Phoenician, Roman or Greek sailors who collected water from the nearby spring (now dry).

Legend claims that by drinking from the spring, the lovesick sailors (a common curse of those visiting Aphrodite's island) would be cured of their infatuation. I thought back to my visit to Fontana Amorosa earlier in the day and felt relieved I had never visited when the Fountain of Love was still flowing. I don't want to be cured.

The practicals

Argo Holidays (020-7331 7070) offers seven nights B&B at the Anassa from £709pp including flights and transfers. A studio suite from around £107pp per night can be booked through Thanos Hotels (020-8445 5111). Cyprus Airways (020-8359 1333) has return flights to Paphos from £182. Cars can be hired from Petsas (00 357 2 662650) from £17 per day including insurance and taxes.

webTitle: Damien Flood: Mobile phone | Three crystals | Bath salts

fields.headline: Damien Flood never travels without...
fields.trailText: Mobile phone | Three crystals | Bath salts
fields.body:
A necessity: It's predictable I know, but I can't be away without my mobile phone. It's clichéd I know, but I'm constantly chatting. I'm always on the phone to someone and I'd never be without it.

A lucky charm: I've got three crystals that I take away with me. One is a bluey aquamarine colour, another is silver, and the other one is purple. They represent health, luck and love. I don't know much about crystals but I like them and they seem to work.

A luxury: I love baths. If I could I would take a bath and all my bath salts and candles away with me.

A bath is the best thing ever. Touring means hard work and long days and it's great to sink into one at the end of the day.

If only: A piano. I love Stevie Wonder, soul, jazz - a total mixture really. I'd keep it in my hotel and play it whenever I could get a moment.

 Damien Flood is starring in RENT which is currently on tour. For dates, visit www.rentontour.com

webTitle: Get me to the zoo on time

fields.headline: Get me to the zoo on time
fields.standfirst: Living in dread of a conventional wedding?  Max Riddington finds there are plenty of unusual places where you can tie the knot
fields.trailText: Living in dread of a conventional wedding? Max Riddington finds there are plenty of unusual places in the UK where you can tie the knot...
fields.body:
Naworth Castle, Cumbria

The Old Library of this atmospheric early Tudor castle provides a perfect setting for a wedding. The bridal suite was Lord William Howard's bedroom and dates back to the 16th century. It includes every castle speciality - a four-poster bed.

 Naworth Castle, Brampton, Cumbria, CA8 2HF (0169 773 229, www.naworth.co.uk). Prices vary according to individual requirements.

Combe House Hotel, Devon

A Grade 1 listed manor with mullioned windows and high ceilings. The food is fabulous and the 3,500 acres of beechwood and parkland extends into Gittisham, described by Prince Charles as "the ideal English village".

 Wedding prices on application to Ruth and Ken Hunt, Combe House, Gittisham, Honiton, Nr Exeter. (01404 540400, www.thishotel.com). B&B from £120 a night per double.

The Bass Museum, Burton upon Trent

The first brewery in Britain to be licensed for marriages, the happy couple can arrive by a dray drawn by shire horses and even commission a bespoke brew from the 20s working micro brewery to toast their special day.

 Sharon Stokes Bass Museum PO Box 220 Horningoow Street Burton On Trent DE14 1YQ (01283 513663, www.bass-museum.com). Wedding breakfast from £15.50. Venue price on application according to requirements.

London Zoo, Regent's Park

Hold your informal drinks receptions in the Reptile House; in summer, be brave and have a barbecue on the Lion Terraces. Greater formality is found in the Prince Albert Suite, which accommodates 240 and overlooks an illuminated fountain with live animals as a backdrop.

 Contact Antonia Sargent, London Zoo, Outer Circle, Regent's Park, London NW1 4RY (020-7449 6381, www.londonzoo.co.uk). Prince Albert Suite hire from £2,000 plus vat. Bespoke wedding packages upon request.

Old Trafford, Manchester
Kick off married life in the Premier Suite where they specialise in both evening buffets or formal sit-down wedding breakfasts.

 Sir Matt Busby Way, Old Trafford, Manchester M16 0RA (0161 868 8300, www.manutd.com/cater/weddings.sps). Bespoke packages available on request.

Silverstone, Northampton

Start married life beside the racetrack's start/finish Line. Tours of the pits and garages may add to the excitement of the big day.

 Contact Nicola Thompson, Silverstone, Towcester, Northamptonshire, NN12 8TN (01327 320298 www.silverstone-circuit.co.uk). Price varies according to requirements. Food from £15pp.

The London Palladium

Love is full of drama, so why not begin married life in a theatre? Built in 1910, this opulent building has four wedding locations for a maximum of 120 guests. Choose between the Hall of Fame and the Cinderella Bar

 Contact Sean Curtis, Argyle Street, London, W1V 1AD (020-7379 4981). From £40pp.

National Showcaves Centre, Wales

Fancy saying "I do" 550ft below ground in the Brecon Beacons National Park? Then it's down to Cathedral Cave exchanging candle-lit vows with stalactites, flowstones and an underground waterfall. Up to 28 guests can soak up this unique atmosphere.

 Contact Sarah Reynolds, Abercrave, Swansea Valley, Powys, SA9 1GJ (01639 730284, www.showcaves.co.uk). From £350 for cave hire.

Trevigue Farmhouse, Cornwall

Situated in a hollow on the same Cornish cliffs where Thomas Hardy romanced his wife, Emma, over a century ago, this 15th-century farmhouse is built around a cobbled courtyard. Weddings for up to 30 people have the cliffs as a dramatic backdrop.

 Trevigue Crackington Haven Bude Cornwall EX23 0LQ (01840 230 418) From £300.

Monkey Island, River Thames

Surrounded by Grade 1 listed buildings - The Temple and Pavilion - both dating back to The House of Hanover, this whole island can be booked exclusively. To make that sweeping entrance and exit, there is a helicopter pad and boat moorings.

 Monkey Island, Bray on Thames, Berkshire SL6 2EE (01628 623 400, www.monkeyisland.co.uk). Exclusive use from £10,500. Island 'package' from £105pp.

Brighton Pier, Sussex

As English as the Channel, the Victorian Pier is an icon of art and engineering. The usual wedding breakfast is available but push the boat out and go for the special - fish, chips and champagne. Personalised rock available.

 Contact Julia Gallagher, Madeira Drive, Brighton, East Sussex, BN2 1TW (01273 609361, www.brightonpier.co.uk). Meals from £10. Venue price on application, according to individual requirements.

HMS Warrior, Portsmouth

Part of Queen Victoria's Black Battle Fleet and retired from seafaring in 1883, the ship starred in Ralph Fiennes and Cate Blanchett's 1997 film Oscar & Lucinda.The captain's cabin and officers' half deck are licensed for a civil ceremony.

 Contact Corinne Marshall, HM Naval Base, Portsmouth, Hants, PO1 3QX (02392 778604, www.hmswarrior.org). From £535.

New Mill Restaurant, Hampshire

Recorded in the Doomsday Book and nestling along the banks of the River Black water, this restored mill has a fully working water wheel.

 Contact Mark Mulrainey or Judi Scade New Mill Road, Eversley, Hampshire, RG27 0RA (0118 973 2105, www.thenewmill.co.uk). Exclusive use from £10,500; Island "package" from £105pp.

Ness Botanic Gardens, Cheshire

Say it with flowers at the Rose Gardens, Water Gardens, Rock Gardens or Glasshouses.

 Mrs Hall Ness Botanic Gardens, Ness Neston, South Wirral, CH64 4AY (0151 353 01230 www.merseyworld.com/nessgardens). From £150.

Stapleford Park, Leicestershire

This beautiful country house is where John Major's daughter held her wedding reception. And when you step inside the exquisite Orangery and Grand Hall, it's easy to see why. There's also an inviting 22m indoor pool and Clarins spa providing a range of relaxing pre- and post-nuptial treatments.

 Stapleford Park Near Melton Mowbray Leicestershire LE14 2EF (01572 787 522, www.stapleford.co.uk). Exclusive use from £13,500, house rooms from £165, state rooms from £250.

Merchant Adventurers' Hall, York

Perhaps the finest medieval guild hall in Europe. The timbered Great Hall is a stunning venue for up to 180 wedding guests. The large gardens overlook the River Foss.

 Contact JG Finlay, Fossgate, York, YO1 9XD (01904 654818, www.theyorkcompany.sagenet.co.uk). From £500 for hall hire.

Delphi Lodge, Galway

Built by the Marquis of Sligo in the mid 1830s as a fishing lodge, the house rests in 600 acres of land. Incredible views over Fin Lough make this spot irresistible.

 Contact Peter Mantle, Delphi Lodge, Leenane, County Galway (095 42211, www.delphilodge.ie/). Rooms from £30pp, including full Irish breakfast.

The Georgian Manor House, Gloucestershire

Standing behind the parish church and set in 15 acres with a mill, lake and dovecote, weddings here can't help but be elegant.

 Contact Bill and Diana Herford, Upper Court Kemerton Tewkesbury Gloucestershire GL20 7HY (01386 725 351, www.sawdays.co.uk). Rooms from £42.50pp.

The Feathers Hotel, Oxford

A townhouse hotel with a Michelin-starred restaurant, labyrinthine corridors, original staircases, stone floors and huge log fires. Hot air ballooning and chauffeured punting can be arranged.

 Contact Martin Godward Market Street Woodstock Oxfordshire OX20 1SX (01993 812291, www.feathers.co.uk). Rooms from £109pp. Suites from £235.

The Manor House Hotel and Golf Club, Wiltshire

This magical 14th-century house has the river Bybrook and magnificent ancient woodland as part of its lush 365 acres, nestling on the edge of the historic village of Castle Combe.

 Manor House Hotel, Castle Combe Chippenham, Wiltshire SN14 7HR (01249 782 206, hotels.co.uk). Rooms from £205pp. Also available on an exclusive basis with an extra row of cottages for extra guests.

Inchcolm Abbey, Scotland Situated on the Island of Inchcolm on the River Forth between Edinburgh and Fife and known as the Iona of the east, the abbey is part of a group of monastic buildings founded in 1123 by Alexander I. The cloister and chapter house are suitable for inti mate ceremonies. The island is reached by ferry.

 The Abbey is open from Easter to October. Prices from £250. Contact Colin Aston, Torwood, 6 Forkneuk Road, Uphall, West Lothian, EH52 6BL (01506 852296).

Abercromby Place, Edinburgh

One of only 20 complete Georgian houses remaining in the city and once home to William Playfair, the famous Scottish architect. There are nine guest rooms and the dining room seats a house party of 20 .

 Contact Eirlys Lloyd, 17 Abercromby Place Edinburgh EH3 6LB (0131-557 8036, www.abercrombyhouse.com). From £45pp.

The Grange, Fort William

On a hillside by a loch. Watch the boats over breakfast then take the cable car to Ben Nevis. There's a French oak bed to snooze in afterwards and the sherry will warm up frosty toes.

 Contact Joan and John Campbell, The Grange Grange Road, Fort William, Inverness-shire PH33 6JF (01397 705 516) From £35pp.

Lyndale House, Isle of Skye

This 300-year-old Tackman's house is hidden down a bluebell-flanked private drive. The double en suite has a heated floor in the shower room as well as a private sitting room.

 Contact Mr and Mrs Ridsdill-Smith, Lyndale House, Edinbane, Isle of Skye, IV51 9PX. (01470 582 329). From £40pp.

The Royal Scotsman Train

Travelling in style through the highlands, all you have to supply is the minister. The atmosphere of times past may compensate for the fact your wedding night has to be spent in twin beds. There's a limit of 36 passengers.

(01404 540400, www.thishotel.com). B&B from £120 a night per double. Wedding breakfast from £15.50. Venue price on application according to requirements. fields.headline: Ask a fellow traveller
fields.standfirst: Doug Stratton wants to go on a low-cost, low-impact trip to Zambia or Zimbabwe to see the total eclipse on June 21.
fields.trailText: Doug Stratton wants to go on a low-cost, low-impact trip to Zambia or Zimbabwe to see the total eclipse on June 21.
fields.body:
There is a backpackers hotel in Lusaka, Zambia called Chachacha's and they can pick you up on arrival at Lusaka airport. There are cheap dorms or you can camp in a safe garden. They even have cooking facilities so it should fit a budget trip. They provide heaps of travel information and you can get anywhere from there easily.
Louise Kerbiriou

I did a well organised safari with Drifters Adventure Tours (PO Box 48434, Roosevelt Park, Johannesburg 2195, South Africa (+2711 888 1160, drifters@drifters.co.za).
Rachel DeLisser

The ideal would be a camping journey with Harry Steyn of Oasis Safaris (020-8766 6405, judith@oasis-safari.com, www.oasis-safari.com)
Tanya & Edmund Hoare

Dragoman (01728 861 133, www.dragoman.co.uk has places available on its five-week trip from Nairobi to Harare departing May 28, spending June 21 40km north of Lusaka. The tour costs £1,055 plus $485 (£330) kitty and includes transport, meals and crew. International flights extra.
Amanda Hammerton

Doug Stratton can organise his own trip. He can fly to South Africa on SAA (020-7312 5000) and then up to Zambia on Nationwide (the regional airline) or to Zimbabwe on Air Zimbabwe (020-7491 0009) to Harare and on to Victoria Falls. He can book his own accommodation using the guides published for the Automobile Association of South Africa, available here in the UK from 020-8954 4672. There are many amazing places to stay at under £50 per night.
Vanessa Sand

This week's question

Can I get a ferry to either Portugal or southern Spain from the UK?
Katherine Gaylarde

If you have questions or advice, please write to: Ask a fellow traveller, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Or e-mail: ask.a.fellow.traveller@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Travelogue
fields.trailText: Brochure awards
fields.body:
Brochure awards

The Guardian is seeking entries for the 10th annual Best Brochure Awards. A panel of judges will be reviewing brochures in five categories: summer; long haul; short breaks; special interest and skiing. Tour operators are invited to enter. Please send one copy of each brochure (specifying the category) to PO Box 240, Twickenham TW1 1SE. The closing date for entries is March 11. These awards are run in conjunction with the Guardian and Observer Travel Awards, which are based on questionnaires completed by thousands of readers.

Change of schedule

Continuing unrest in Israel has persuaded Airtours Sun Cruises to amend the itinerary of its Egypt and the Holyland cruises on board Seawing this summer. The seven-night cruises have been renamed Egyptian Explorer and has replaced ports in Israel with two in Turkey. For further information call 08701 577775.

Valentine treat

For 24 hours on Wednesday, Valentine's Day, every seat booked online at www.buzzaway.com to "romantic" destinations in Europe is being sold for £24 one way including taxes. The flights can be taken between February 26 and March 31 and the cities chosen are Berlin, Bordeaux, Frankfurt, Marseilles, Milan and Paris. Fares include all taxes. Flights cannot be taken on a Friday or a Sunday. Buzz is now selling all tickets one-way.

Let's dance

Weekend breaks to the major clubbing capitals of Europe and the US are now available through www.lostweekends.co.uk, combining Travelscene weekend breaks with the latest guide to the club and bar scene in nine cities: New York, Amsterdam, Barcelona, Madrid, Berlin, Prague, Reykjavik, Dublin and Paris.

Helping hand

Hit the Ground 2001, a brochure to help young people plan their big trips, has been launched by usit Campus, the student and young people travel specialist. It is available at their 49 stores or by calling 0870 240 1010 (www.usitcampus.co.uk).

Home comforts

Two hundred and six private homes are included in the latest edition of Wolsey Lodges' brochure. This is a consortium of homes, ranging from quite grand country houses to more modest abodes, where guests are entertained as family and often dine with their hosts. For more information, tel 01473 844058 (www.wolsey-lodges.co.uk).

fields.headline: It's a carve up
fields.standfirst: Martin Bell on how to take corners with ease
fields.trailText: Martin Bell on how to take corners with ease.
fields.body:
Carved turns have been used by ski-racers for decades as the most efficient way of getting through racecourses. But in the mid-90s, the introduction of curvier-shaped "carving skis" made carving accessible to all. Nowadays, "carving skis" are simply known as "skis" - because they're the only kind that are available.

Of course, it was always possible to carve turns with the old "straight skis", but it required huge leg strength to generate the enormous pressure necessary to bend them into the right curved shape for carving. This shape was called "reverse camber". Now, when one of the modern, hourglass-shaped skis is tilted over on to its edge, there is a large gap between the ground and the ski, just under the binding. Then, all the skier needs to do is to gently pressurise the ski by standing on it; the gap will close, and the ski will bend easily into reverse camber.

There are many benefits for non-racing skiers who learn to carve. First and foremost, it's more fun! A carved turn will glide you around a corner without any loss of speed, whereas a skidded turn (the opposite of carving) will always slow you down. Secondly, a carved turn can increase your efficiency in getting around the mountain: if you're facing a sharp turn followed by a long flat, a carved turn will help you to carry more speed and cut down on skating and poling. Thirdly, a carving ski is much more stable than a skidding one, and will slice its way across icy patches like a train on rails.

The best introduction to carving is to traverse across the hill, with your downhill ski well tilted on to its uphill edge, and with your upper body leaning well out over that downhill ski. A wide stance will help with this exercise. As you set off, your downhill ski will track along its edge, and start to carve uphill - if you can manage this, congratulations! You have already performed part of a carved turn. The next exercise, still working in a traverse across the hill, is to try alternating between sideslipping down the hill and carving across it. This will teach you how to go intentionally from skidding to carving (and vice versa).

Soon, you'll be ready to carve an entire turn. You must choose extremely flat terrain for this, because a carved turn will not kill off any of your speed. Just tilt your outside ski on to its edge, lean out over it with your upper body, and set off. You must be patient and wait for the ski to carve around of its own accord. The most common mistake is to try to pivot the ski around with your foot. Once you've managed one of these basic carved turns (known as "railroad turns" ), you can try to make the transition into the next turn by shifting your weight across on to the other ski and tilting it.

As you start to carve railroad turns at a reasonable speed, you must keep a wide stance by keeping your outside leg extended away, out from under your body. If you allow your outside foot to get pushed in, so it's directly below your body, you may lose your balance and topple outwards, as centrifugal force tries to push your body towards the outside of the turn. As you keep that outside leg extended out at an angle, keep your hips dropped towards the inside of the turn, while the upper body remains upright. This is called "hip angulation" , and will put you in a strong position to resist that centrifugal force. Your outside leg should be fairly straight, with just a slight bend at the knee, so that you can use knee angulation to fine-tune your turns. (Hip angulation pro vides the power; knee angulation provides the control.)

Hip angulation will be easier to achieve if you keep your shoulders turned slightly away from the direction you're turning ( "counter-rotation" ). If you turn your shoulders in the same direction as you're turning your skis ("rotation"), strong hip angulation, and good carving, will be impossible.

At first, you'll probably find that your inside ski is just resting flat against the snow, with only 10-20% of your weight on it, acting as a "stabiliser". But as you gain confidence, you'll learn to edge the inside ski to the same angle of tilt as the outside ski. The inside leg will always have to be much more bent than the outside leg, and as you go around a turn, you'll learn how to "soften the outside leg" and bend it even further, allowing your hips to drop even closer to the ground. This is necessary in each turn, because the forces that you are trying to resist do not stay constant around the turn; in fact, they build up during the turn, reaching a maximum as you finish off the turn, cutting sharply across the hill.

To make the transition into the next turn, you need to utilise the springiness of your ski, to shoot your feet across, under your body, so that your legs end up extended out to the other side. In an instant, the new outside ski will bite and start to carve, and the new turn will be under way.

Carving becomes easier as you go faster, because your skis will respond quicker. But novice carvers should begin on flatter terrain and at lower speeds, before building up gradually, always taking care to maintain the correct body positions.

 Martin Bell is running ski courses for intermediate skiers this season in Vail & Breckenridge, Colorado. For more information, call 0170 8224080 or e-mail: vailresorts@clara.co.uk

fields.headline: Mad Mex
fields.standfirst:
On the eve of London Fashion Week, Helen David goes in search of inspiration for future English Eccentrics collections

Special report: London Fashion Week 2001
fields.trailText: On the eve of London Fashion Week, Helen David goes to Mexico in search of inspiration for future English Eccentrics collections.
fields.body:
We flew to Mexico City via Madrid, which meant that my boarding pass bore the evocative legend "MAD MEX". I took this to be a good omen.

Why Mexico? Every few seasons, a designer needs fresh ideas. For me, ideas are usually sparked off by researching a particular person or by travelling.

When I choose a person, I like to investigate their sense of style and character. When it's a place, I like to see how the local culture uses colour and imagery. In choosing Mexico, I hoped to combine both my fascination with the painter Frida Kahlo and my love of colour.

Frida Kahlo was a Jewish Mexican who believed she imbibed her Mexican Indian nature from her wet nurse. A beautiful woman with complicated hairstyles and a monobrow, her small paintings are essays in magic realism and personal pain. The Tracey Emin of her day, Frida's work reveals almost much too much about her. She was married to the famous painter, Diego Rivera. They were both communists, and Frida had an affair with Trotsky when he visited Mexico.

The first place we went to was Frida's house in Coyoa-can, a pretty suburb of Mexico City. We were immediately struck by its colour, a bright blue like Yves St Laurent's house in Marrakech. It has a wonderful kitchen, decorated in yellow and blue with a tiled range. Frida had a playful decorative sense, but was not at all bourgeois, most items being very simple.

The best collection of her paintings is in the Delores Olmeda Museum in the Xochimilco area. Delores was a wealthy patron and lover of Diego. It is like a home in a Gabriel Garcia Marques novel, four-sided around a courtyard with its own chapel. Magenta bougainvillea is tangled around the trees and the place is full of small schoolchildren on cultural outings and peacocks strutting across perfectly-tended lawns.

Frida and Diego worked in two studios in the San Angel area, decorated in blue and pink, respectively, with a glazed bridge connecting the top floors. Frida's building is strangely bereft of anything but a few family photos, but Diego's has a collection of huge Day of the Dead papier-mché skeletons and sinister dolls.

But Mexico City is not somewhere to spend much time, being both highly polluted and dangerous. A sign in our hotel, the wonderfully 60s Camino Real, warned us only to use taxis recommended by the hotel.

We flew off to the state of Chiapas, to a small town called San Cristobal de Las Casas, the centre of a series of villages of indigenous people of Mayan origin, the Tzotzils and Tzeltals.

Our hotel was the colonial-style Casa Mexicana, which featured a central glazed courtyard housing a tropical garden and fountains. The beams in the main room were festooned with Day of the Dead tissue-paper cuts.

San Cristobal has a daily craft market where the villagers come to sell brilliantly striped blankets, hand-embroidered place mats and tablecloths, hand woven runners and embroidered huipiles. The women and children are dressed in fantastic colours. Each village has its own style.

On Sunday at the fruit and vegetable market, the produce is carefully-arranged in pyramids, like offerings to a deity. We were amazed at the men's costumes - pink woven tunics embroidered with brightly-coloured flowers and animals and magical symbols.

There is a very special place in San Cristobal called Na Bolom, once the home of a Danish couple Trudy and Frans Blom, now a museum and a centre for aiding the Lacandon and other indigenous groups who live in the jungle in eastern Chiapas. Frans was an archaeologist who dug at Mayan sites, while Trudy studied, photographed and worked tirelessly to protect the Lacan don people. Diego and Frida often visited them for boozy holidays, and the bottles they drank then are now used to edge the garden borders.

Na Bolom contains a tree nursery, a library of anthropological and archaeological books and a medical wing for treating Lacandon people. It is also a good place to find guides who can organise tours. Ours was called Pepem. A Tzotzil whose parents died when he was a child, he was brought up in Na Bolom by Trudy and taught to speak Spanish and English. He took us to the villages of San Juan Chamula and San Nicholas.

In Chamula, in preparation for the Day of the Dead, the graves in the churchyard had all been dug over and the crosses repainted in colours appropriate to the person buried there. Sadly, many were sky blue, the colour for young men. Pepem told us that many Chamulans die young through alcohol poisoning.

The saints in the church are dressed in local costumes. At some point, the local shaman decided that Coca-Cola was holy because the burps it induced helped to expel evil spirits from the body. In church, people were swigging from huge bottles of Coke while they prayed. Fresh pine needles were strewn on the floor and strong incense was burning. Smoking is also permitted in church, as is the consumption of "posh" a strong locally distilled drink made from sugar cane.

The church in Chamula has broken with the Catholic church and now has its own religion. The arch over the front door is painted to resemble a rainbow, the Mayan symbol of entry to the afterlife. Mayans believe that Sun, Moon and Earth correspond with body, blood and "vegetable" parts of a human. The vegetable part is hair, which they save whenever it is cut because they believe they will only be allowed into heaven with all the hair they have ever grown. We noticed how carefully the women style their hair, interweaving colourful ribbons into their plaits and often finishing them off with tassles, a practice that Frida copied.

San Nicholas is a wealthier area with a fertile valley farmed on a communal basis. The mother of a family we met was weaving on a back-strap loom. Her daughters were all embroidering complicated designs on to white cotton. The father and son weren't engaged in this because it's viewed as women's work, the men's time being spent working the land.

Our last stop was Oaxaca, pronounced "Wahaka", where the build-up to the Day of the Dead begins in early October and culminates in a two-day festival on November 1 and 2.

The origins of the Day lie in a pre-Christian festival when the souls of dead relatives would be lured back to life by offerings. Death is laughed at as the Mexicans dance and images of skeletons engage in the activities of the living. One grave had a model skeleton playing music. The man beside it told us it was the grave of his grandfather who had been a musician.

The feeling in the cemeteries is generally one of celebration. People play guitars, sing songs and drink mezcal. Of course, if the deceased is a child, the occasion is much sadder, and the sight of a toy plastic truck and some biscuits on a grave tended by a young couple was very poignant.

All homes have shrines where the favourite food and drink of the dead person are laid out. These shrines and the graves are decorated with masses of marigolds and deep pink coxcombs.

Markets sell little sugar skulls decorated with sequins and coloured icing, and Day of the Dead bread - big sugary loaves with depictions of tiny saints' heads in the dough.

Every niche in the four outer walls of the main city cemetery contained a candle, lit in memory of a dead person, even though some had died more than a hundred years ago. Shrines had been erected and decorated all around the colonnaded edges of the cemetery. Often they were dedicated to national heroes, footballers or politicians. The air was thick with a burning incense called "copal", and little boys threw firecrackers into graves.

People were friendly, although I felt a little intrusive, snooping around the cemeteries watching families in their private moments. Several people offered us swigs of mezcal and chatted to us about the festival. One man told us that after three days the people eat the food and drink that had been set out for the dead, but it has no taste as the spirits have consumed the flavour.

We spent only nine days in Mexico, but I felt I had gained an insight into the background of my heroine and experienced some profound aspects of the Mexican culture. I knew that my visit would inspire me for more than a single fashion season, and I couldn't wait to get out my sketchbook and paints.

The practicals

webTitle: Who lost their heart in Peru?

fields.headline: I lost my heart in... Peru
fields.standfirst: Peter Searles
fields.trailText: Peter Searles
fields.body:
Why? I was in the Tambopata Reserve in 1986 when it was virtually unexplored. I was desperate to get to the Amazon, and spent ages hunting round all these travel companies but the best I could come up with was $500 for five days' piranha fishing. Then I met this crazy Swiss film-maker in a bar, he had a boat and he agreed to give me a ride for $100. We headed south to Juliaca, then hitched a ride in a lorry with all these Indians. We took a red dirt track into the Amazon itself, and three days and 50 punctures later, we arrived. We set off down this river and 10 days later we emerged. The scenery was spectacular.

What is the best thing? Dawn and dusk. It's just the sounds - the cicadas, the frogs, the howler monkeys. And there was one day we came round a bend in the river and there were hundreds of macaws all pecking at the mineral-rich clay. At the sound of a clap, the sky was suddenly full of green, red and yellow. And once we saw a jaguar. It was the middle of the night and we couldn't sleep because all we could hear was the "gree, gree, gree" of the baby crocodiles. We saw the jaguar on the opposite bank -the cats come down to eat the baby crocs. He took one sniff at us and slunk back into the trees.

My advice: Don't swim in the Amazon without trunks. There is a tiny fish called the candiru which is attracted to warm orifices. It swims up, but then finds it can't get down again because it has all these hackles which open like an umbrella on the way up.

How do I get there? Guerba Adventure and Discovery Holidays (08700 54 91 91. www.guerba.co.uk runs an Andes and Amazon Explorer tour on selected dates throughout the year from £925 per person (land-only price).

 Peter Searles's show Hey Gringo! Through Peru, is at the Soho Theatre, Dean Street, London, March 1 and 2. Tickets are £10, concessions, £8.

fields.headline: Cuba libre
fields.standfirst: High on a heady cocktail of wild music, strong drink and Havana's crumbling elegance,  Nick Davies loses his passport and finds love
fields.trailText: High on a heady cocktail of wild music, strong drink and Havana's crumbling elegance, Nick Davies loses his passport and finds love.
fields.body:
It happened sometime after midnight on December 31 - after the food had run out, but while the wine and the rum were still bubbling over the bar, probably around the time that the salsa band finally took off into orbit and the whole room went with it in one collective dance of perspiration - just around then, I fell in love.

I would have fallen for her in any place at any time, but this night was special in several ways. This was not just New Year's Eve, it was Millennium Eve. While the rest of the world had held its millenial celebrations 12 months earlier, Cuba had held on in a symbol of its proud isolation, preferring to wait until the arithmetically correct deadline, December 31 2000, before letting rip.

Futhermore, this was Havana where, on any evening, it is alarmingly easy to feel romantic. Cubans look happy, act happy, and that's catching. They have also created the most sexually liberated culture I have ever come across. The hedonistic atmosphere is helped by the warm climate and the natural beauty of the island. This is a country the size of England, with a population only as big as London, surrounded by long, clean beaches with nothing but palm trees and hammocks for company.

In terms of the architecture, the buildings may be crumbling, but they have a charm that is unlikely to fade. The particular building where I first met her, was steeped in grandeur. It felt almost like a trespass to go in through the heavy wooden door from the street, into the deep, dark hallway (dark because it was night, and there seemed to be no electricity on the ground floor) and to gaze up at the remnants of old wealth.

The tall stone pillars and the ornate carvings were just visible around the ceiling. I climbed the dusty, narrow staircase, ducking down through several tiny doorways; up past the dim yellow light of cramped apartments, where Cuban families sat with their TVs; across a roof space, to the upper floor, through a heavy double door, into a place like magic. Here, there were three or four interconnecting rooms with dark wooden tables, all lit by dozens of wax-encrusted candles, the walls covered with paintings and old photographs and an antique wooden clock and theatrical masks. The air was filled with the sound of gentle, romantic music.

They call this place La Guarida. The Cuban intelligentsia know it well, if only because Tomas Gutierrez Alea, the most creative of Cuban film directors, shot scenes for his Fresa y Chocolate (Strawberry and Chocolate) here in 1993. Hardly anytourists know of the bar's existence unless they observe the first rule of travel in Cuba: burn the guidebook and, instead, trust the locals to show you the way.

That's another part of the romance of the place - the improvisation... chaos would be a better word. By the time, the sun finally rose and rescued Havana from riot, I had found love in La Guarida but I had lost my jacket, my passport, my brother, two English friends and four Swedes, all of whom had disappeared into the night. You have to go with the flow. Time-servers and knee-benders should stay away. People go to Cuba and fall in love with it (or, indeed, with each other) because it's a place of self-indulgence, and constantly fascinating.

I promise you that you will never encounter a place of so many riddles and paradoxes - there is considerable personal poverty, yet there is a striking absence of crime; this is a one-party state and yet voter turn-out is three times as high as, for example, the United States; it is a society born out of violence but with one of the most pacific populations in the world; a country which has been corrupted, exploited, invaded and sabotaged by the US but which chooses the American dollar as its currency. Indeed, the whole business of the relationship with the US is one mighty paradox.

Here is the Land of the Free supposedly protesting Cuban infringement of human rights, such as the right to travel, by infringing the human rights of its own citizens to visit or trade with the island. Here is the most powerful capitalist nation in history refusing to supply goods and services to a society whose primary reason for existence is to avoid capitalism in the first place.

Millennium night at La Guarida was full of its own riddles. The owner, Enrique, stepped into the candlelight to explain that this was not a meal. This was an artistic experiment - an attempt to recreate a scene from Fresa y Chocolate in which the two central characters eat a five-course feast (itself based on a meal described by the great Cuban poet Jose Lezama Lima in his 1966 novel, Paradiso), the premise being that all who eat become great thinkers and writers.

It took three hours and some of it was truly strange - fried banana soup with popcorn croutons; seafood souffle; asparagus and beetroot; turkey and yucca, plantain and rice; coconut ice cream in half a pineapple. And, all the time, the wine kept coming, and then the rum and, at some point on the way through, the gentle classical music gave way to live salsa, and then it was midnight and, outside in the streets, there was the sound of mighty splashing as all the Cubans threw open their windows and washed away the bad spirits of the old year by chucking buckets of water into the air. Then we pushed back the tables, the salsa band went wild, and the singer was like a monkey - muscular and primitive and sexual in every tiny movement - and the music was loud and frantic. It was one of those times when everyone in the room is all part of the same dance - it got hotter and faster and wetter and wilder and, for a split second, the crowd of dancers parted and there she was, and I reached out for her and... who wouldn't have fallen in love?

She should not even have been there. She was American, and, under the terms of the US Trading with the Enemy Act, American citizens can be fined up to $250,000 and jailed for up to 10 years for spending a single dollar in Castro's country. She had come in under the wire, through Mexico. Somehow, that made her even more romantic. By the time I realised I had lost my passport, we were a perfect couple - she in trouble with the US, me with Cuba (I'd lost my visa as well as the passport). A match made in Havana. Go with the flow.

Sometime close to dawn, we drifted back to my hotel. More riddles. If she had been Cuban, they would not have let her in: a society that fought a two-year guerrilla war for the right to its national self-esteem now bans its own people from numerous tourist facilities and areas.

Perhaps the bigger paradox here is the most familiar one in world tourism: that travellers visit places because they are different only for their presence to erode the very difference that attracted them. For example, people go to Havana for the salsa bands. And yet the horrible truth is that some of the bands in central Havana are now starting to play songs such as Yesterday, by the Beatles, and a version of Frank Sinatra's My Way and some Muzak version of that Paul Simon song about how he'd rather be a tortoise than a snail - and they are doing it to please us.

Even worse, if you ask Cubans where to go for salsa, there are some (the ones who have most contact with tourists, like hotel staff and taxi drivers) who will direct you to posh hotels where they stage nauseating "international spectacular" floor shows - lots of women with high-cut outfits and pink feathers in their hair, lurching around like stoned swans and grinning like skulls.

But all is not lost. Real Cuba is still there - you just have to push a little to find it. One good example: there is an extraordinary alley in central Havana that has been taken over by a brilliant artist, Salvador Gonzales. He has painted the whole place with wonderful murals and strange epigrams, based on the old religions that were imported to Cuba by slaves from West Africa. He has a gallery there and, once a week (currently on Sundays, but it could change) Cuban musicians meet there to boogie. Salvador is usually there, and he likes to talk (and to sell paintings). It's worth going, but my guidebook failed to put the street on any of its maps, got the name of the street wrong, indicated the general location of the street and got that wrong, too. (See panel for the best directions you'll get.)

Sometime the next day, my brother returned with my jacket and my passport and his own strange tale of adventure; and one of the Swedes I had lost, who works in the music industry, went back to La Guarida and gave the salsa band a recording contract. Go with the flow. That's Cuba. That's romance.

Salsa, disco, and where they mix a mean mojito

Drinking

In old Havana, head for two parallel streets, Obispo and O'Reilly, and, among a dozen good bars, look for Lluvia de Oro, Cafe Paris and O'Reilly's. All have live bands - the one at Café Paris is currently the best. One more street across, in Empedraco, is La Bodeguita del Medio - expensive but surprisingly unspoiled considering it is the place where Hemingway drank his daily dozen mojitos (rum with sugar, limejuice and mint) and is, therefore, on every single tour route. For quiet contemplation, go to the Inglaterra Hotel in Parque Centrale and watch the chaos on the streets from the refuge of the terrace. If you sit at the southern end, you will get your drink much quicker.

Dancing

Salsa in the bars. Alternatively the discos with mostly Western music are a taxi ride away from old Havana, and most of them are awash with young Cubans, looking for excitement and also for dollars. None of them gets going until after 10pm. The disco at the Commodoro Hotel is currently the biggest and busiest. Also, try Johnnie's, at Ave Primera and Calle Zero, also known as Bar Uno. If you insist on seeing floor shows, they are in most of the posh hotels, particularly the Riviera and the Melia Cohiba. Outside the hotels, the most expensive is the Tropicana ($60); the cheapest is the Cabaret Nacional next to the Inglaterra.

Eating

Cuba is not famous for good food. The best fun is to explore the paladares, private houses licensed to sell meals. For a dollar, any hustler on the street will take you to one. You don't have to stay - some are great, some are best forgotten. The greatest and most magical is La Guarida, so magical that it is tempting to protect it by withholding its address... but here goes: Calle Concordia 418. You can phone for a reservation on 637351. Aries near the university at Ave 27 de Noviembre 27, no 456, is another good spot. Los Amigos, Ave M and Calle 19, is quick, clean, reliable. Escorpion, down the road at Ave M and Calle 17, is quick and clean and worth visiting if only for the soap opera sounds of the Cuban family just upstairs.

Sleeping

The cheapest and most interesting option is to use a casa particular, a private house licensed to rent out rooms. Look for signs and for a blue triangle on the door, or follow the hustlers. Expect to pay no more than $25 a night. Check that the hot and cold water are working. If you use an unlicensed place and anything is stolen, you may have trouble getting a police report for your insurance claim. There are comfortable hotels in old Havana, but a lot of rooms suffer from 24-hour street noise. The Inglaterra is the most characterful, but it is badly run and suffers from lots of internal noise along its marble corridors as well as the street sounds. The Plaza has quiet rooms on an inner courtyard, but the rest are noisy. The Sevilla has the best swimming pool (if you look like you own it, you can walk in and use it even if you are not staying there). The Cientifica is cheap, characterful but dowdy.

Special places

Museo de la Revolucion, a couple of blocks north from Parque Centrale: collection of artefacts and records of more than a century of Cuban nationalist struggle.

Museo Jose Marti, inside the Marti monument on Plaza de la Revolucion - the dedicated life and early death of the father of Cuban nationalism. Almost entirely in Spanish, very clearly laid out.

Callejon de Hamel - the elaborately painted alleyway home of the renowned Cuban artist, Salvador Gonzales. From Calzada de Infanta, walk down San Lazaro towards the sea; turn right on Arambura; Hamel is the explosion of colour on your right.

Day-trips

Maria La Gorda - idyllic beach and cheap hotel on the western tip of the island. The Bay of Pigs - south east of Havana, where you can get a casa particular on the beach at Playa Larga, within three paces of the sea (Try Fidel Fuentes, tel 059 7233, or just ask any local). Trinidad - old colonial town with cobbled streets and lovely houses.

The practicals

Interchange (27 Stafford Road, Croydon, Surrey CR0 4NG , tel: 020-8681 3612 has short breaks to Havana and other areas of Cuba from £609pp twin share or £642 single including direct BA flights from Gatwick. fields.bodyText: It happened sometime after midnight on December 31 - after the food had run out, but while the wine and the rum were still bubbling over the bar, probably around the time that the salsa band finally took off into orbit and the whole room went with it in one collective dance of perspiration - just around then, I fell in love. I would have fallen for her in any place at any time, but this night was special in several ways. This was not just New Year's Eve, it was Millennium Eve. While the rest of the world had held its millenial celebrations 12 months earlier, Cuba had held on in a symbol of its proud isolation, preferring to wait until the arithmetically correct deadline, December 31 2000, before letting rip. Futhermore, this was Havana where, on any evening, it is alarmingly easy to feel romantic. Cubans look happy, act happy, and that's catching. They have also created the most sexually liberated culture I have ever come across. The hedonistic atmosphere is helped by the warm climate and the natural beauty of the island. This is a country the size of England, with a population only as big as London, surrounded by long, clean beaches with nothing but palm trees and hammocks for company. In terms of the architecture, the buildings may be crumbling, but they have a charm that is unlikely to fade. The particular building where I first met her, was steeped in grandeur. It felt almost like a trespass to go in through the heavy wooden door from the street, into the deep, dark hallway (dark because it was night, and there seemed to be no electricity on the ground floor) and to gaze up at the remnants of old wealth. The tall stone pillars and the ornate carvings were just visible around the ceiling. I climbed the dusty, narrow staircase, ducking down through several tiny doorways; up past the dim yellow light of cramped apartments, where Cuban families sat with their TVs; across a roof space, to the upper floor, through a heavy double door, into a place like magic. Here, there were three or four interconnecting rooms with dark wooden tables, all lit by dozens of wax-encrusted candles, the walls covered with paintings and old photographs and an antique wooden clock and theatrical masks. The air was filled with the sound of gentle, romantic music. They call this place La Guarida. The Cuban intelligentsia know it well, if only because Tomas Gutierrez Alea, the most creative of Cuban film directors, shot scenes for his Fresa y Chocolate (Strawberry and Chocolate) here in 1993. Hardly anytourists know of the bar's existence unless they observe the first rule of travel in Cuba: burn the guidebook and, instead, trust the locals to show you the way. That's another part of the romance of the place - the improvisation... chaos would be a better word. By the time, the sun finally rose and rescued Havana from riot, I had found love in La Guarida but I had lost my jacket, my passport, my brother, two English friends and four Swedes, all of whom had disappeared into the night. You have to go with the flow. Time-servers and knee-benders should stay away. People go to Cuba and fall in love with it (or, indeed, with each other) because it's a place of self-indulgence, and constantly fascinating. I promise you that you will never encounter a place of so many riddles and paradoxes - there is considerable personal poverty, yet there is a striking absence of crime; this is a one-party state and yet voter turn-out is three times as high as, for example, the United States; it is a society born out of violence but with one of the most pacific populations in the world; a country which has been corrupted, exploited, invaded and sabotaged by the US but which chooses the American dollar as its currency. Indeed, the whole business of the relationship with the US is one mighty paradox. Here is the Land of the Free supposedly protesting Cuban infringement of human rights, such as the right to travel, by infringing the human rights of its own citizens to visit or trade with the island. Here is the most powerful capitalist nation in history refusing to supply goods and services to a society whose primary reason for existence is to avoid capitalism in the first place. Millennium night at La Guarida was full of its own riddles. The owner, Enrique, stepped into the candlelight to explain that this was not a meal. This was an artistic experiment - an attempt to recreate a scene from Fresa y Chocolate in which the two central characters eat a five-course feast (itself based on a meal described by the great Cuban poet Jose Lezama Lima in his 1966 novel, Paradiso), the premise being that all who eat become great thinkers and writers. It took three hours and some of it was truly strange - fried banana soup with popcorn croutons; seafood souffle; asparagus and beetroot; turkey and yucca, plantain and rice; coconut ice cream in half a pineapple. And, all the time, the wine kept coming, and then the rum and, at some point on the way through, the gentle classical music gave way to live salsa, and then it was midnight and, outside in the streets, there was the sound of mighty splashing as all the Cubans threw open their windows and washed away the bad spirits of the old year by chucking buckets of water into the air. Then we pushed back the tables, the salsa band went wild, and the singer was like a monkey - muscular and primitive and sexual in every tiny movement - and the music was loud and frantic. It was one of those times when everyone in the room is all part of the same dance - it got hotter and faster and wetter and wilder and, for a split second, the crowd of dancers parted and there she was, and I reached out for her and... who wouldn't have fallen in love? She should not even have been there. She was American, and, under the terms of the US Trading with the Enemy Act, American citizens can be fined up to $250,000 and jailed for up to 10 years for spending a single dollar in Castro's country. She had come in under the wire, through Mexico. Somehow, that made her even more romantic. By the time I realised I had lost my passport, we were a perfect couple - she in trouble with the US, me with Cuba (I'd lost my visa as well as the passport). A match made in Havana. Go with the flow. Sometime close to dawn, we drifted back to my hotel. More riddles. If she had been Cuban, they would not have let her in: a society that fought a two-year guerrilla war for the right to its national self-esteem now bans its own people from numerous tourist facilities and areas. Perhaps the bigger paradox here is the most familiar one in world tourism: that travellers visit places because they are different only for their presence to erode the very difference that attracted them. For example, people go to Havana for the salsa bands. And yet the horrible truth is that some of the bands in central Havana are now starting to play songs such as Yesterday, by the Beatles, and a version of Frank Sinatra's My Way and some Muzak version of that Paul Simon song about how he'd rather be a tortoise than a snail - and they are doing it to please us. Even worse, if you ask Cubans where to go for salsa, there are some (the ones who have most contact with tourists, like hotel staff and taxi drivers) who will direct you to posh hotels where they stage nauseating "international spectacular" floor shows - lots of women with high-cut outfits and pink feathers in their hair, lurching around like stoned swans and grinning like skulls. But all is not lost. Real Cuba is still there - you just have to push a little to find it. One good example: there is an extraordinary alley in central Havana that has been taken over by a brilliant artist, Salvador Gonzales. He has painted the whole place with wonderful murals and strange epigrams, based on the old religions that were imported to Cuba by slaves from West Africa. He has a gallery there and, once a week (currently on Sundays, but it could change) Cuban musicians meet there to boogie. Salvador is usually there, and he likes to talk (and to sell paintings). It's worth going, but my guidebook failed to put the street on any of its maps, got the name of the street wrong, indicated the general location of the street and got that wrong, too. (See panel for the best directions you'll get.) Sometime the next day, my brother returned with my jacket and my passport and his own strange tale of adventure; and one of the Swedes I had lost, who works in the music industry, went back to La Guarida and gave the salsa band a recording contract. Go with the flow. That's Cuba. That's romance. Salsa, disco, and where they mix a mean mojito Drinking In old Havana, head for two parallel streets, Obispo and O'Reilly, and, among a dozen good bars, look for Lluvia de Oro, Cafe Paris and O'Reilly's. All have live bands - the one at Café Paris is currently the best. One more street across, in Empedraco, is La Bodeguita del Medio - expensive but surprisingly unspoiled considering it is the place where Hemingway drank his daily dozen mojitos (rum with sugar, limejuice and mint) and is, therefore, on every single tour route. For quiet contemplation, go to the Inglaterra Hotel in Parque Centrale and watch the chaos on the streets from the refuge of the terrace. If you sit at the southern end, you will get your drink much quicker. Dancing Salsa in the bars. Alternatively the discos with mostly Western music are a taxi ride away from old Havana, and most of them are awash with young Cubans, looking for excitement and also for dollars. None of them gets going until after 10pm. The disco at the Commodoro Hotel is currently the biggest and busiest. Also, try Johnnie's, at Ave Primera and Calle Zero, also known as Bar Uno. If you insist on seeing floor shows, they are in most of the posh hotels, particularly the Riviera and the Melia Cohiba. Outside the hotels, the most expensive is the Tropicana ($60); the cheapest is the Cabaret Nacional next to the Inglaterra. Eating Cuba is not famous for good food. The best fun is to explore the paladares, private houses licensed to sell meals. For a dollar, any hustler on the street will take you to one. You don't have to stay - some are great, some are best forgotten. The greatest and most magical is La Guarida, so magical that it is tempting to protect it by withholding its address... but here goes: Calle Concordia 418. You can phone for a reservation on 637351. Aries near the university at Ave 27 de Noviembre 27, no 456, is another good spot. Los Amigos, Ave M and Calle 19, is quick, clean, reliable. Escorpion, down the road at Ave M and Calle 17, is quick and clean and worth visiting if only for the soap opera sounds of the Cuban family just upstairs. Sleeping The cheapest and most interesting option is to use a casa particular, a private house licensed to rent out rooms. Look for signs and for a blue triangle on the door, or follow the hustlers. Expect to pay no more than $25 a night. Check that the hot and cold water are working. If you use an unlicensed place and anything is stolen, you may have trouble getting a police report for your insurance claim. There are comfortable hotels in old Havana, but a lot of rooms suffer from 24-hour street noise. The Inglaterra is the most characterful, but it is badly run and suffers from lots of internal noise along its marble corridors as well as the street sounds. The Plaza has quiet rooms on an inner courtyard, but the rest are noisy. The Sevilla has the best swimming pool (if you look like you own it, you can walk in and use it even if you are not staying there). The Cientifica is cheap, characterful but dowdy. Special places Museo de la Revolucion, a couple of blocks north from Parque Centrale: collection of artefacts and records of more than a century of Cuban nationalist struggle. Museo Jose Marti, inside the Marti monument on Plaza de la Revolucion - the dedicated life and early death of the father of Cuban nationalism. Almost entirely in Spanish, very clearly laid out. Callejon de Hamel - the elaborately painted alleyway home of the renowned Cuban artist, Salvador Gonzales. From Calzada de Infanta, walk down San Lazaro towards the sea; turn right on Arambura; Hamel is the explosion of colour on your right. Day-trips Maria La Gorda - idyllic beach and cheap hotel on the western tip of the island. The Bay of Pigs - south east of Havana, where you can get a casa particular on the beach at Playa Larga, within three paces of the sea (Try Fidel Fuentes, tel 059 7233, or just ask any local). Trinidad - old colonial town with cobbled streets and lovely houses. fields.headline: Lock and wire
fields.trailText: Lifeventure's new portable lock and wire has many uses, from securing a bicycle or a snowboard to a suitcase or rucksack.
fields.body:
I'm told that theft and damage to luggage is soaring. Have you got any useful tips about security? Yes, more luggage is being made with built-in security features, but why don't you get Lifeventure's new portable lock and wire, which has many uses, from securing a bicycle or a snowboard to a suitcase or rucksack.

How does it work? The wire itself is a 0.9m length of multifilament, twisted steel wire. Each strand has been individually reinforced, and the overall length of wire is covered in a thick plastic coating, which prevents it from weathering as well as providing it with an extra thickness layer for security. At each end is a locking loop through which the padlock is attached. These loops are stud-clamped together with oversized closures: practically impossible to undo.

It sounds a bit bulky. The lock and wire comes in a zippered neoprene case that packs away. It's only 7cm in diameter and weighs less than 100g.

And is it really secure? The combination lock is enclosed in an anodised-steel super-tough casing, which should deter most thieves.

Where do I get one? They are available at most travel and outdoor specialists such as Snow + Rock (0845 100 1000) and Trek & Field (01268 494444). Both have nationwide shops and mail order. It costs £11.95.

fields.headline: Snow conditions
fields.standfirst: Most resorts, both in Europe and North America, have seen some new snow, so the conditions should be good.
fields.trailText: Most resorts, both in Europe and North America, have seen some new snow, so the conditions should be good.
fields.body:
Austria

The best conditions in Mayrhofen (***) can be found on piste. Excellent conditions iin Obergurgl (****) and Lech (****).

France

Méribel (***) has good skiing to offer. The best conditions are in Tignes (****) and Val Thorens (****).

Switzerland

The on-piste conditions in Verbier (****) are excellent. Zermatt (****) has equally good conditions.

Italy

Bardonecchia (***) has some great skiing both on and off piste. Conditions excellent in Cervinia (****).

Andorra

Even after several days of sun, the pistes are holding up well in Soldeu (***) and Pas de la Casa (***).

North America

Fresh falls in Attitash Bear Peak, New Hampshire (****), Killington, Vermont (****), and Breckenridge, Colorado (****).

In Canada, Whistler (****) has some good off piste especially on the higher runs.

Liz Russell
The Ski Club of Great Britain

Key to conditions: No snowflakes = a serious lack of snow - no lifts open. * = poor snow conditions, very few lifts open. ** = conditions reasonable, some slopes in poor condition. *** = plenty of good skiing.**** = good conditions. ***** = fantastic on and off piste.

fields.headline: Travel tip
fields.trailText:
A number-combination lock is better that a padlock for securing luggage and cheap accommodation. You don't have to fumble for a key and they cannot be picked as easily. And when leaving your bag in a beach hut, you don't have to tie the key on a piece of string to your bikini.
Vicky Bowditch

fields.headline: Somewhere in Britain
fields.standfirst: Chislehurst Caves | Clwydian Way | Glasgow amphibious tour | Kings of the North Sea exhibition | The Royal Academy of Arts | Town and Crown exhibition | Solway Firth
fields.trailText: Chislehurst Caves | Clwydian Way | Glasgow amphibious tour | Kings of the North Sea exhibition | The Royal Academy of Arts | Town and Crown exhibition | Solway Firth
fields.body:
Going underground

Escape the wet Sunday afternoon drear on a 90-minute tour of Chislehurst Caves that goes to parts of the system not usually open to the public.

 Caves and cafe open Wed-Sun, 10am-4pm for regular 45-minute tours (£3/£1.50). Sunday tours at 2.30pm. Open daily during school holidays. Old Hill, Chislehurst, Kent (020-8467 3264).

The Wales way

Dip into the new long-distance walking trail, the 122-mile Clwydian Way running from Prestatyn on the north coast, along the Clwydian range of hills to Llangollen.

 Details in a route guide from bookshops, The Clwydian Way - Long Distance Trail (£5.95) produced by The Ramblers' Association. Information: 0151-653 3612.

Quack city

The new way to see Glasgow is on an amphibious tour operated by Glasgow Ducks. The 90-minute tour leaves from George Square and takes in the heart of the city and West End, before heading for nearby Renfrew for a splash down and return voyage.

 Due to weather considerations, until Easter the tour only runs given sufficient numbers. £11.50/£7.50. 36 North Hanover St, Glasgow (0870 013 6140).

Sea it now

Burial treasure, gold jewellery and mysterious carved stones from the period AD 250-850 are on show at the Kings of the North Sea exhibition.

 Until April 1. Open Mon-Sat 10am-4.50pm. Sun 12pm-5pm. Free. Laing Art Gallery, Newcastle upon Tyne (0191-232 7734).

Eternal art

Celebrate the achievements of Caravaggio, Rubens and their late 16th-century contemporaries in The Genius of Rome 1592-1623 at The Royal Academy of Arts.

 Until April 16. Open daily 10.am-6pm, Fri 8.30pm. £8/£2.50/8-11yrs £1.50. Burlington House, Piccadilly, London W1 (020-7439 7438).

Royal visit

Enjoy the Town and Crown exhibition (free) above the Windsor tourist information centre and pick up a self-guided heritage trail (50p) while there. Then take a stroll along the River Thames, take a walk around Windsor Great Park (free) and stroll the Long Walk from the castle. Finish with the Stanley Spencer Gallery in nearby Cookham village (£1).

 Windsor, Berks. 01753 743900.

A rare tweet

Guided and self-guided walks around the Solway Firth are being organised by Carlisle Bird Society. Attractions include wildlife art exhibitions and lectures.

 February 10-25. Opening times and admission charges vary. Various Venues, Carlisle, Cumbria (01228 625600).

fields.headline: Ski tips
fields.trailText: Equity Total Ski launches an online operation, how to combine days on the slopes with evenings at the card table, mixing glacier skiing with hiking and horse riding, and how to organise a do-it-yourself holiday to America.
fields.body:
* Equity Total Ski has launched an online operation called www.rocketski.com. Unlike its parent company, which offers all-in deals including ski passes, instruction and equipment hire, rocketski.com is aimed at customers who may only want part of the package.

* Combine days on the slopes with evenings at the card table. Peterborough-based Alpine Bridge (01733 552214, www.alpinebridge.co.uk) is running one more week in the mountains this winter, starting on March 24 in the French resort of Champagny-en-Vanoise. Those seeking to hone their bridge technique, get pointers from international player Trevor Pomfrey. The holiday costs £525, including flights from Manchester or Stansted and full board hotel accommodation. Travel arrangements are handled by Handmade Holidays, a member of the Association of Independent Tour Operators.

* Mix a little glacier skiing with some Alpine hiking and horse riding this summer. A new programme in French ski resorts with glacier slopes has been launched by Erna Low (020-7584 2841). In Tignes, for example, there are 20km of piste on the Grande Motte glacier. Weather permitting, the ski area is open in the mornings - it tends to be too slushy after lunch. The firm offers a week in an apartment sleeping four from £431 at the Residence Village Montana. An apartment for 6-8 people in La Plagne, where an adult summer ski pass costs around £40, starts at £460. These prices include Channel crossings by ferry or Eurotunnel.

* Organising a do-it-yourself holiday to America's less familiar resorts can cost less than you might fear. Sun Valley does not attract many British skiers, which is a pity since it combines fine skiing with a rich history. Built to persuade leisure travellers to ride the Union Pacific railroad, it became a hang out for Hollywood stars such as Clark Gable, Gary Cooper and Ingrid Bergman. Ernest Hemingway, who shot himself in nearby Ketchum, finished writing For Whom the Bell Tolls at the Sun Valley Lodge. The Idaho resort offers some good deals next month, when seven nights' accommodation and a five out of six days lift pass costs from around £345. For further information and central reservations call 001 208 726 3423. Trailfinders (020-7937 5400) offers a £314 return fare to nearby Boise from Heathrow via Chicago or San Francisco - but you must book by February 28.

fields.headline: Vaz 'broke code of conduct'
fields.trailText: The fate of the embattled Europe minister, Keith Vaz, is hanging in the balance while the divided            Commons standards and privileges committee decides whether to uphold a guilty verdict that he            broke the MPs' code of conduct in recommending an honour to a Labour donor.
fields.body:
The fate of the embattled Europe minister, Keith Vaz, is hanging in the balance while the divided Commons standards and privileges committee decides whether to uphold a guilty verdict that he broke the MPs' code of conduct in recommending an honour to a Labour donor.

The parliamentary commissioner, Elizabeth Filkin, the Guardian has learnt, has found that the minister broke the code by not revealing a financial connection with City solicitor Sarosh Zaiwalla. Ms Filkin in her report to the standards committee has cleared the minister of more than 10 other charges.

In a similar, but more clear-cut case a year ago, MPs on the committee ruled against Tony Baldry, Conservative MP for Banbury. Mr Baldry had to apologise to the Commons.

However the circumstances - which both involve recommending an honour for Mr Zaiwalla - are considerably different.

In breach of the MPs code of conduct, Mr Baldry failed to disclose he was the personal beneficary of a pounds 5,000 loan from Zaiwalla when he put his name forward to the Lord Chancellor's department . Mr Vaz's financial involvement totalled not more than pounds 450 and was paid to his office in donations in 1993 and 1994. In both cases Mr Zaiwalla said he had no knowledge he had been recommended.

Mr Vaz has been cleared by Ms Filkin on everything else - including the most serious complaint brought by Andrew Milne, a former solicitor in Mr Zaiwalla's firm, that the minister received and failed to declare up to pounds 2,000 donations in the parliamentary register of interests.

The sticking point emerged earlier this week when Mr Zaiwalla gave evidence to the committee and protested his innocence over his recommendation for an honour. It has added to the delay by the committee in reaching a decision whether to endorse Ms Filkin's report. Mr Zaiwalla told the Guardian: " I had no idea I had been recommended for an honour by Mr Vaz and I think he is completely innocent as well."

Last night the Guardian obtained two letters sent to Ms Filkin by Mr Zaiwalla - revealing in detail his version of his relationship with Mr Vaz and protesting about Mr Milne raising the allegations against the minister.

In a letter dated February 8 last year sent to Ms Filkin and copied to Tony Blair, Lord Irvine, the lord chancellor, Betty Boothroyd, the then speaker, and Mr Vaz, Mr Zaiwalla says: " I have at no time made any payments to Mr Vaz MP or his parliamentary office."

Five months later in another letter to Ms Filkin he redraws the statement saying his accounts department paid pounds 250 to Mr Vaz's office in January 1993 which he says is shown as a donation. He also discloses in September 1994 he made a payment of pounds 200 to Wildberry for advertising in a calendar "which was connected with Mr Vaz".

In his first letter he says that he has known the minister for 15 years. "I have sponsored or taken a table at various Asian and charity events which Mr Vaz has also supported. I believe in 1993 or 1994 Mr Vaz asked me if I would help out one such charity. I agreed to make a contribution of pounds 1,000.

The code of conduct requires MPs "in carrying out public business, making public appointments, awarding contracts, or recommending individuals for rewards and benefits, holders of public office should make choices on merit".

Mr Vaz's lawyer Geoffrey Bindman said yesterday: "In fairness to Mr Zaiwalla, it should be made clear that he has been consistent throughout the inquiry in stating that he has never made any cash payment to Mr Vaz or any other payment to him personally or for his personal benefit. Mr Vaz, of course, has confirmed that he has never received any such payment."
