fields.headline: Bulldog Blair
fields.standfirst:
Campaigning as a patriot will win both the election and a referendum on the euro

Special report: election countdown
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Campaigning as a patriot will win both the election and a referendum on the euro.
fields.body:
One good reason not to do anything for too long is the danger of becoming a prisoner of your own propaganda. After advising Labour on advertising and broadcasts at four general elections, my advertising agency, BMP DDB, and I are not involved in the fight this time.

In politics it is the public "line to take" that can inhibit private thinking. It would be a foolhardy politician who appeared to take the voters' endorsement for granted, but this must not prevent planning in private on the basis of the most likely outcome.

So, can I deal with the charges of complacency first? Nothing is certain. I take nothing for granted. Vigilance is vital. It is necessary to plan for the worst case. Nevertheless, the Tories are 12 points behind. They would need to be at least five points ahead at this stage to stand a realistic chance.

There might be another fuel crisis right up against the date, something else unexpected, a more substantial scandal in the government than the Hinduja affair. However, if we can't examine the likely for a moment, it will inhibit the planning that could get the most from a victory.

If Labour win, they will have a much tougher fight to win a referendum on the euro. There is something like a two to one majority against. This may well get worse, as the Tories will spend the election banging on about saving the pound and wrapping themselves in the union flag even more than usual. While this might not do them much good in the election itself, which is about plenty else and Labour can point to the promise of a referendum on the issue, it will stoke up xenophobia even further. Are there ways that Labour could go about their election campaign that will be conducive to an easier fight in the referendum?

We all know the British are a conservative lot. Change is difficult to sell (difficult for Labour for 18 years and now pretty tough for the Tories). "If it isn't broken, don't mend it" is a sentiment basic to the British psyche. The pound doesn't look broken, so why abandon it to join in with a lot of foreigners in a fairly untried (and so far unsuccessful) currency? The antis have the status quo and that's a very powerful thing to have in this country.

Bob Worcester of Mori, in his excellent pamphlet on the 1975 referendum, reminds us that it is not a subject about which most people feel confident. They have their prejudices (amply reflected in current polling) but will defer to advice when the issue becomes real in an actual campaign. They will compare the responsible, mainstream, leaders with their "starry-eyed" opponents and take the advice of the saner looking group. But this won't happen until there is a date to vote. Until then people won't seriously engage their brains on the issue. You can't have the campaign before the campaign, as no one will be listening.

However, the government can create the circumstances - in the general election campaign - that make a referendum victory more probable. The clue as to how they can do this is in the interesting contrast between "wanting" to be in the euro and feeling membership to be inevitable. Most don't want it, but most think it inevitable.

If entry can be seen to be a continuum, an inexorable part of British growth and prosperity, then it can be represented as the "no change" route and the alternative made to look like a risky change. If the sensible people who brought you four years of steady growth say this is the way to continue that steady growth, it might gain reluctant support and inhibit support for a jump into the unknown of increasing separation from Europe on the advice of a band of zealots.

For this to be the scenario, the government must take steps to be seen to own two things: economic growth and the British interest.

The Tories, when in power, were very good at blaming the world economy for downturns and reaping the electoral benefit from upswings. Labour mustn't let the past years' steady growth seem just an inevitable part of world improvement, Labour must associate itself closely with growing prosperity. It should provide the platform from which they claim the right to be re-elected.

Nor should Labour allow the Tories to get away with their old trick of seeming to own patriotism. Not only is it very wrong that they should get away with so partially owning the flag, but it leaves Labour looking weak in pursuit of British interests. That, in the context of the euro, makes us seem to be giving in to foreigners when actually we are seeking the best conditions in which to maintain and boost our growth - an even playing field and an end to the disadvantages of currency fluctuations - that hold back business success.

If their support is to be gained, it is vital that the electorate see entry to the euro as a means for Britain to have a better crack at making gains, not as a wimpy liberal desire to be nice and agreeable. They need to be reassured that their government is determined to score for Britain.

Labour have a marvellous track record of creating the conditions for Britain's solid economic growth. They should stand for re-election on that record. It's still the economy, stupid. It remains the case that the majority of unideological voters are looking for the most credible case for providing financial improvement for them and their families. They know that needs national economic growth. And it is so much better to stand on this than to focus too much on the endless arguments on achievements against targets on health and education, where large groups will always remain unsatisfied.

Concentration on this government's role in creating economic success is the best way of stealing for Labour what has been the very raison d' être of the Conservative party in the eyes of the electorate. Ensuring that the Tories cannot outflank Labour by their usual trick of appropriating the flag - associating the government vividly with Britain's national interests - bolsters the perception that fighting our corner internationally has been the cause of Gordon Brown's economic success.

Happily, the best way of preparing for a probable euro campaign is also the best way to securing a substantial majority in the general election.

 Chris Powell is chairman of the advertising agency BMP DDB.

webTitle: Fifty ways to please your lover

fields.headline: Fifty ways to please your lover
fields.standfirst: Saying it with flowers is unlikely to get the pulse racing when you can spend time with the one you love sipping punch in the Cayman islands or snuggling up on top of the Empire State Building.
fields.trailText: Saying it with flowers is unlikely to get the pulse racing when you can spend time with the one you love sipping punch in the Cayman islands or snuggling up on top of the Empire State Building.
fields.body:
With Valentine's Day just around the corner, love is in the air. Show your sweetheart he or she means more than a box of chocolates by whisking them away for a holiday romance they'll never forget.

1 Get away for a weekend of self-contained heaven in one of Bodysgallen Hall's 15 cottage suites near Llandudno, North Wales. Breakfast is brought to you in the morning, while dinner is a short stroll through aromatic herb gardens to the 17th-century manor hotel's restaurant.

 A cottage suite weekend break costs from £115pp per night, including breakfast, dinner and a bottle of champagne. Call 01492 584 466 for reservations.

2 Take a romantic cruise along the Norfolk Broads on the two-berth Bel Air. Nicknamed the Love Boat, she features a four-poster bed, Jacuzzi, central heating, fireplace, TV, video, microwave and even a saloon area with red heart-shaped sofa.

 One week on the Love Boat with Hoseasons Boating Holidays (01502 501 010) costs from £410 per couple. Available immediately subject to weather conditions.

3 Follow the example of Madonna and Guy by escaping to Skibo Castle, Dornoch, for the ultimate highland fling. For complete privacy, stay at the Dairy in the hotel's grounds. The cottage features original turn-of-the century tiles, a mini library in the bathroom and living area with period furniture. Candlelit dinner and champagne can be delivered to your door.

 From £480 per night, including meals, drinks and all activities. Call 01862 894 600 for reservations.

4 According to legend, the Giant's Causeway on the north coast of Northern Ireland was built by local giant Finn McCool as a pathway across the Irish Sea to his sweetheart on the island of Staffa.

 Three nights' B&B at the 17th-century Bushmills Inn, ideally situated for exploring the causeway and north Antrim coast costs £248pp with Cresta Holidays (0870 33 33 303) including flights. Car hire can be arranged from £23 per day.

5 Stylish couples will love Combermere Abbey's 11 cottages near Whitchurch in Shropshire, decorated with furnishings by the likes of Ralph Lauren, Jane Churchill, Mulberry and Les Olivades. The cottages are set in 1,000 acres of private estate, but the abundance of candles, four-poster beds and open fires might just keep you indoors.

 From £209 for two nights' self-catering. Call 01948 662 876 for reservations.

6 The Reverend Purnell-Edwards built the Temple, a Grade I-listed folly in the grounds of Stancombe Park, Gloucestershire, as a secret rendezvous for trysts with his gypsy lover. You can snuggle up in the huge Chinese bed, tucked away behind heavy red curtains.

 Three nights' self-catering at the Temple costs £508, available through Rural Retreats (01386 701 177).

7 The lonely romanticism of North Lees Hall in Derbyshire was the inspiration for Mr Rochester's house in Jane Eyre, and the legend of a mad woman perishing in a fire at North Lees is thought to be the source of his wife's dramatic demise. Act out your own costume drama in Apartment I, complete with wood burning stove and four-poster bed.

 North Lees Hall can be rented through the Vivat Trust (020-7930 8030); a three-day self-catering break costs from £245.

8 Only a 35-minute flight from London, Guernsey makes a perfect island getaway with spectacular cliff walks, over 30 secluded bays and beaches, and more than 60 seafood restaurants serving local oysters.

 Three nights' B&B at Hougue Du Pommier, a converted 18th-century farmhouse hotel, costs from £232 with Channel Islands Direct (0870 789 3339) including flights.

9 Play make believe in your own miniature chateau on the edge of Gainsborough Park in Lincolnshire. An 18th-century folly set in acres of parkland on the River Trent, it comes complete with carved stone balcony, antique mahogany bed and books of poetry to provide inspiration.

 A weekend self-catering break at The Chateau costs from £315 through the Landmark Trust (01628 825 925).

10 Voted one of the most romantic hotels in England by the AA, Linthwaite House is set in 14 acres of landscaped gardens in the Lake District. No country house swags and bows here - canopied beds, wicker furniture and Ralph Lauren furnishings come courtesy of Amanda Rosa of Malmaison and Gleneagles fame. Having set the scene for romance, Linthwaite House can even host the grand finale - The Wedding Day - with part or exclusive use of the hotel.

 From £99pp per night including breakfast and dinner. Call 015394 88600 for reservations.

11 The 16th-century Crazy Bear hotel in Stancombe, Oxfordshire, is a riot of colour, design and eclectic style. The only problem is how to choose from the nine suites: will it be beamed ceiling, seductive red walls and zebra carpet, black with silver ceiling and mirrored bathroom, or tile-floored with free-standing bath at the bottom of the queen-sized bed? The decision is yours.

 A suite costs from £150 per night including breakfast. Call 01865 890 714 reservations.

12 Cruise the country lanes of East Anglia with your baby in one of the Grand Touring Club's seven classic cars, including an Aston Martin DB6, a Jaguar E-type roadster and a Triumph Stag. Pack a picnic, fill the boot with champagne and you're ready to go.

 Prices start at £ 250pp for a three-night break including car hire, insurance and area route maps. Accommodation can be arranged on request. Call the Grand Touring Club (01449 737 774) for more information.

13 Country house hotel meets urban cool at the one-of-a-kind Babington House in Frome, Somerset. Bathrooms are the size of an average urban singleton's flat and come stocked with oversized bottles of the hotel's in-house spa products - Horny Cow aphrodisiac bath oil is a particular favourite. If it all goes well, there's even a private chapel, where Zoe Ball and Norman Cook tied the knot last year.

 From £235 per night. Call 01373 812 266 for reservations.

14 Down pints of the black stuff then return to the Morgan, a slick and stylish hotel in the heart of Dublin's Temple Bar. Described as a luxury hotel experience without the frills, the huge, simple rooms have six-foot beds and a lounging area with sofa plus CD player, satellite TV and video - as if you'd need help to pass the time.

 From £130 per night. Call 0800 169 8817 for reservations.

15 If you do like to be beside the seaside, head straight to the Hotel Pelirocco in Brighton. Its 18 individually-thumbed rooms include the sexy 50s-style Betty's Boudoir, featuring lashings of leopard print and a spa bath for two, Absolute Love with velvet chaise longues and heart-shaped headboard or 70s themed Lenny Beige's Love Palace, complete with a copy of The Joy of Sex.

 From £70 per night. Call 01273 327 055 for reservations.

16 The original no questions asked, rock'n'roll hostelry, London's Portobello Hotel has 24 over-the-top themed rooms, including the Japanese Garden Suite with a bed made from an opium den screen, Charlie's Room, with bamboo flooring and Indian furnishings, and the Roundbed Room, featuring what you'd expect, plus a free-standing bath by its side.

 From £185 for a standard room. Call 020-7727 2777 for reservations.

17 Take an independent walking holiday on Gozo where the beautiful nymph Calypso held Odysseus prisoner of love for seven years in Homer's epic. Stay in a stone bungalow at the secluded five-star Ta'Cenc hotel and spend your days exploring the island's spectacular rocky coastline, ancient hilltop villages and narrow inland valleys.

 Seven nights' half board with Headwater Holidays (01606 813333) costs £557pp including accommodation, route maps, flights and helicopter transfer to Gozo.

18 One of Europe's coolest city-break destinations, Prague has a lively gay scene, café culture and stunning architecture.

 Three nights in Prague with Man Around (020-8902 7177) costs from £260pp including three nights' B&B at the gay-friendly Ambassador Hotel on the historic Wenceslas Square and flights. Sovereign (08705 768373) ofers two nights' B&B at the Hotel Na Kampe 15 from just £329pp including flights and transfers.

19 Diamonds are not only forever, they're also a girl's best friend, and there's no better place to pick them up than Amsterdam, the rock capital of Europe.

 Two nights' B&B costs from £173 with Amsterdam Travel Service (0870 727 5916) including flights, free cycle hire, canal cruise and champagne tour of the Stoeltie diamond factory.

20 If music be the food of love, what better way to satisfy your inamorata than a weekend in Milan with tickets to see La Traviata at La Scala?

 Two nights' B&B at the four-star Hotel de la Ville near the Piazza del Duomo costs £889, including flights and best category opera tickets with JMB Travel (01905 425 628).

21 Discover the romantic cities of Europe on a luxury coach tour. Follow in the footsteps of heroes, storytellers, poets and saints, visiting Bruges, Amsterdam, Prague, Budapest, Vienna, Rome, Florence and Paris.

 The 19-day tour with Insight Vacations (08705 143 433) costs £1,485pp, including accommodation, most meals, private coach travel and all entrance and excursion fees.

22 Nights out will never be the same after a quick-fix break learning salsa, the hottest dance in the world, in Europe's capital of cool.

 Three days in Barcelona learning salsa with Dance Holidays (01206 577 000) costs £299pp including four hours of expert dance tuition, two nights' B&B accommodation, flights and escorted visits to the city's sexiest salsa clubs.

23 Hit the road on a motorbike made for two, riding a 500CB Honda through the winding country lanes of the Midi-Pyrenees. Visit the famous Cathar castles, bastides towns and fortified hilltop villages of the Ariege, the Albigeois and Corbieres on a pre-planned route.

 Three nights' half board with the French Holiday Service (020-7355 4747) costs £336pp, including hire of one motorbike for two people, but not flights.

24 Get away from it all in suite 66 at La Residencia in Majorca; situated at the top of the hotel, away from the eyes of peeping toms, it has an open log fire which is lit by the staff before arrival, private heated pool and magnificent views over the mountains and coastline.

 A two-night B&B break at La Residencia in Suite 66 with Seasons in Style (0151 3420505) costs from £570pp including return flights and transfers.

25 Take your prince or princess to the Castle Hotel Sarvar, a 19th-century fairytale castle in the small mountain village of Paradfasvar, 100km north-east of Budapest. Feast on venison goulash and plum brandy, then retreat to one of the hotel's antique and brocade filled rooms; try the Rakoczi Suite, which comes complete with Jacuzzi and sauna.

 Seven nights' B&B with Danube Travel (020-7724 7577) costs £790 including flights and transfers.

26 It may be cold outside, but you can cocoon yourselves away in the Waldhotel Fletschorn, one of the most romantic retreats in the Alps. Nestling on a forest plateau high above the Saaser valley, it's so cosy that you might even forget to ski.

 Seven nights' half board with Ski Solutions à la Carte (020-7471 7700) costs from £850 including flights and transfers.

27 The city of Romeo and Juliet, Verona is the number one destination for star-crossed lovers. And yes, Juliet's balcony really does exist, at the house once owned by the Cappello family, the model for the fictional Capulets.

 Lakes and Mountains Holidays (01329 844 405) offers three nights B&B in Verona for £329 including flights and tickets to a performance of Beethoven's Pastoral Symphony performed by Verona's renowned Orchestra dell Arena.

28 Scoring nul points for originality but dix for romance, Paris is without a doubt the number one destination for a romantic break. If you're going to do it, do it in style at the Hotel de Crillon; break the bank and go for the £800-a-night Grand Bernstein Suite, a favourite of Madonna and Jennifer Lopez, or opt for a slightly more modest standard room, from £350.

 Bookable through Leading Hotels of the World (0800 181 123).

29 Step back in time at the 17th-century Xara Palace Hotel, Malta. Set in the heart of Mdina, the antique-filled palazzo forms part of the medieval bastion walls of the ancient Norman capital. Ask for suite seven - its private terrace and Jacuzzi have 180-degree panoramic views over the island.

 Four nights' B&B with Cadogan Holidays (02380 828 300) costs from £482 including flights.

30 Whisk your loved one to Cyprus, birthplace of Venus. Indulge in life's sensual pleasures at the five-star Le Meridien Resort and Spa, set in a complex surrounded by waterfalls and grottoes, complete with an indoor/ outdoor thalassotherapy health centre and four sea-water pools.

 Seven nights' half board with Cyprair (020-8359 1234) costs £395 including flights.

31 Bring out the gypsy in you in Seville. Cruise the tapas and flamenco bars of the Triana, then return to Casa no 7, a six-room hotel set among the whitewashed houses and narrow alleys of the romantic Barrio Santa Cruz.

 Three nights' B&B with Abercrombie & Kent (0845 070 0612) costs from £460 including flights.

32 Long Arctic nights give you a great excuse to stay in bed and experience love in a cold climate. If you do decide to go out, optional extras on the four-day adventure trip to Iceland include skidoo safaris, cross country skiing, hiking and superjeeping across the snow-covered volcanic Lake Myvatn.

 From £ 495 for four nights' B&B with Arctic Experience (01737 214 214) including flights and transfers.

33 Get passionate on Grand Cayman's Seven Mile Beach, where Tom Cruise was seduced in the film The Firm. Explore the island's marine life in a two-man sub, sip cocktails on your balcony while watching for shooting stars, or just cuddle up in a hammock made for two. Absolute bliss.

v One week in a beachfront suite at the Hyatt Regency resort on Grand Cayman with Caribbean Escapes (020-7751 0660) costs from £1,888pp including flights and private transfers.

34 Hire a private junk and take to the South China Sea to explore some of Hong Kong's 260 outlying islands, visiting traditional Chinese fishing villages, temples and monasteries.

 Five nights in Hong Kong with Travelscene (020-8427 4445) costs from £689pp including flights and accommodation. For information on junk hire, call the Hong Kong Tourist Association on 020-7533 7100.

35 Have breakfast delivered to your private bungalow by canoe every morning and eat dinner under the stars on the Tahitian island of Bora Bora.

 Six nights' B&B in an overwater bungalow at the Bora Bora Pearl Beach resort with Holiday Options (01444 239999) costs from £2,250pp including flights, accommodation and one night in Santa Monica on the outward journey.

36 Experience the heady charms of jugglers, magicians and storytellers in Marrakech's central square, Jemaa el Fna, then escape to the ultra-luxurious Amanjena hotel; it's sumptuous pavilions are set in an oasis of palm and olive trees 7km away from the city.

 One week at Amanjena with Scott Dunn World (020-8672 1234) costs £2,192 including flights and transfers.

37 Take your beloved to romantic Rajasthan, spending three nights at Rajvilas in the pink city of Jaipur and two nights at Amarvilas in Agra, home of the Taj Mahal, built by Shah Jahan in memory of his favourite wife, Mumtaz Mahal.

 Greaves Travel offers seven nights (020-7487 9111) from £2,095 including flights, transfers, English-speaking guide, chauffeur driven car and accommodation in Delhi, Jaipur and Agra.

38 New England Vacations has done the work for you with their Romantic Hideaways package. Drive through Massachusetts, Rhode Island, Maine and Vermont, staying in country-style inns with crackling fires and antique-filled rooms aplenty.

 Eleven nights with New England Vacations (01582 469771) costs from £1,145 including flights, accommodation and car hire.

39 Spoil yourselves silly with a four-day his 'n' hers pampering package at the Spa of Peace and Plenty on Dunk Island, off the Greater Barrier Reef. Choose from a range of treatments, including body polishes, massages and facials, then spend the rest of your stay exploring Dunk's rainforests and national park.

 Bridge the World (020-7734 7447) feature seven nights' half board on Dunk Island including return flights and transfers from £1,856pp.

40 Sip rum punch in a hammock made for two at Malliouhana, a luxury resort on the Caribbean island of Anguilla. Bored of the island's 33 beaches? Take the hotel's private boat to Silly Cay, to lunch on barbecued lobster, caught and cooked by local chef, Gorgeous.

 A seven-night half-board Romantic Interlude package costs from £2,182 with Caribbean Connection (0870 751 9300), including flights and transfers.

41 Tear yourself away from some of southern India's finest beaches to explore the backwaters and spice plantations of Kerala, voted one of the 50 must-see destinations of a lifetime by National Geographic Traveller.

 Seven nights' B&B at The Sandy Beach resort in Kovalam costs around £400 with Goa Way (020- 7224 7070) including flights and transfers.

42 Couples who want to be alone can hire their own private island in the Seychelles. Guests staying in the restored French plantation house on Felicite are unlikely to be disturbed by unwanted visitors - closest neighbours are the islands of La Digue and Praslin, half an hour's boat ride away.

 Five nights on Felicite costs from £3,448 with Elite Vacations (020-8864 4431) including all meals, drinks and use of a yacht.

43 Perched on a mountainside overlooking the rice terrace of Ubud, Bali, Begawan Giri's 22 suites come complete with personal butler to run your bath and scatter frangipani petals over your king-size bed. Just like home, really.

 Seven nights' B&B costs from £2,210 with Classic Connection (0870 751 9310) including flights and transfers.

44 Take a bite of the apple and make yours an affair to remember in New York, one of the world's sexiest cities. Walk in Central Park, sip tea at The Plaza and recreate that scene on top of the Empire State Building.

 Three nights' B&B with Travelbag (020-7287 5559) costs from £403 including flights, city tour and theatre tickets.

45 Play Out of Africa on a tailor-made safari for two in Botswana; spend your nights in a selection of luxury tented camps and your days searching for game, walking with bushmen and riding quad bikes across the vast Makgadikgadi salt pans.

 An eight-day safari costs from £2,985 with J&C Voyageurs (01373 832111) including flights, full-board accommodation, drinks and all activities.

46 Wrap up warm for some Russian romance in St Petersburg, the Venice of the north, staying at the 19th- century Grand Hotel Europe, favourite haunt of Dostoyevsky, Tchaikovsky and Anna Pavlova.

 Four nights' B&B with Abercrombie & Kent (020-7559 8777) costs from £990, including flights and transfers.

47 Paul McCartney romanced his new flame Heather Mills at Parrot Cay, and it's not hard to see why. A 20-minute speedboat ride from Providenciales, accommodation on the tiny Turks and Caicos island is in cool, simple pavilions with canopied beds and private terrace, or balcony overlooking lush tropical gardens.

 Seven nights' B&B from £2,141 with Exclusive Destinations (01892 619 650) including flights and transfers.

48 Take to the saddle in Northern Patagonia, riding across Argentina's vast flat-topped hills and huge open plains, staying on estancias and camping out near the ancient money puzzle forests of the Lanin National Park.

 Seven nights for £1,008 with Ride World Wide (01837 82544) including riding, accommodation, all meals and drinks. Flights extra.

49 Lord Nelson married Fanny Nisbet under a giant silk cotton tree in the gardens of Montpelier Plantation Inn, St Nevis. Built on the ruins of a 280-year-old sugar plantation 750ft above sea level, accommodation is in the grand country manor-style Great House or 17 traditional West Indian cottages.

 Caribbean Connection (0870751 9500) offers seven nights' B&B from £1,777 including flights and transfers.

50 Pull out all the stops at the Burj al Arab, Dubai, a shimmering tower of gold leaf, shag-pile luxury on a man-made island in the Arabian sea. Fans of Vegas-style glitz will love the duplex rooms, complete with floor-to-ceiling windows.

 Seven nights in a deluxe suite costs from £3,095 with Elegant Resorts (0870 333 3383), including flights and transfers.

Breakfast is brought to you in the morning, while dinner is a short stroll through aromatic herb gardens to the 17th-century manor hotel's restaurant.  A cottage suite weekend break costs from £115pp per night, including breakfast, dinner and a bottle of champagne. Call 01492 584 466 for reservations. 2 Take a romantic cruise along the Norfolk Broads on the two-berth Bel Air. Nicknamed the Love Boat, she features a four-poster bed, Jacuzzi, central heating, fireplace, TV, video, microwave and even a saloon area with red heart-shaped sofa.  One week on the Love Boat with Hoseasons Boating Holidays (01502 501 010) costs from £410 per couple. Available immediately subject to weather conditions. 3 Follow the example of Madonna and Guy by escaping to Skibo Castle, Dornoch, for the ultimate highland fling. For complete privacy, stay at the Dairy in the hotel's grounds. The cottage features original turn-of-the century tiles, a mini library in the bathroom and living area with period furniture. Candlelit dinner and champagne can be delivered to your door.  From £480 per night, including meals, drinks and all activities. Call 01862 894 600 for reservations. 4 According to legend, the Giant's Causeway on the north coast of Northern Ireland was built by local giant Finn McCool as a pathway across the Irish Sea to his sweetheart on the island of Staffa.  Three nights' B&B at the 17th-century Bushmills Inn, ideally situated for exploring the causeway and north Antrim coast costs £248pp with Cresta Holidays (0870 33 33 303) including flights. Car hire can be arranged from £23 per day. 5 Stylish couples will love Combermere Abbey's 11 cottages near Whitchurch in Shropshire, decorated with furnishings by the likes of Ralph Lauren, Jane Churchill, Mulberry and Les Olivades. fields.headline: Ancestral vistas
fields.standfirst: Archaeologist Julian Richards explains the allure of  Stonehenge to Stephen Cook
fields.trailText: Archaeologist Julian Richards explains the allure of Stonehenge to Stephen Cook.
fields.body:
If you walk on a midwinter evening up the ancient grass avenue leading to Stonehenge, you sometimes see a blood-red sun sinking to the horizon between two of the tallest stones. "It's very spooky," says Julian Richards. "It looks like a beating heart slowly dropping out of sight.

He thinks the midwinter solstice probably saw the most important ceremonies. "It marks the turning of the year, the shortest day: from now on, the days will get longer and spring will follow. You talk to the gods, and light can return."

The walk up the Avenue is the finale of his favourite four-mile circuit of the area, best done in winter when low light and a touch of frost or snow emphasise the lumps and bumps that an archaeologist looks for.

Most visitors allow an hour and just see the stones, he says. But it's much more rewarding to give it four - then you can tour the rim of the natural amphitheatre, exploring the burial mounds and looking back at the sarsens, or large sandstones, and their place in the landscape.

"If you look around from the henge, on every skyline there is a group of barrows," says Richards. "You appreciate the stones more when you see them from a distance. It brings you closer to the lives of the people who built this place over 1,500 years."

His Stonehenge winter walk takes him from the car park to the dramatic cluster of barrows at the western end of the Cursus, a ditched enclosure 3km long and 100m wide. The pioneering 18th-century archaeologist William Stukelely wrongly believed it to be a Roman racecourse. You can speculate on its real use, which remains obscure, as you stroll eastwards along it, passing the sewage works gifted by modern planners. Richards thinks that 3,000 years ago the Cursus would have been stripped of grass, a glittering chalk expanse for processions and ceremonies.

The eastern end of it brings him to King Barrow ridge, his favourite part of the walk. "You start to see more burial mounds, and lovely vistas through the trees back towards Stonehenge - it's a great viewpoint, and sometimes the stones are sitting there surrounded by mist.

From here, via the New King barrows, Richards reaches the start of the Avenue for the processional approach to Stonehenge, which he thinks would have been reserved for priests and other dignitaries. If the sun is now sinking behind the stones, so much the better.

"You really need to get away from the car park and the souvenir shop and the 21st century to get a feel for the mystical landscape around Stonehenge," says Richards.

"If you go in the summer it's nice to take a picnic. But I once spent six months here living in a tent, and I can recall many picnics huddled in ditches trying to stop the coleslaw blowing off my plate."

The practicals

Salisbury rail station is 10 miles south of Stonehenge: national rail inquiries 0345 484950. Regular buses from Salisbury station to Stonehenge (01722 336855). An accommodation information and booking service is available on 0870 2405599, or call Amesbury Tourist Information Office on 01980 622833 (www.visitsalisbury.com or www.wiltshiretourism.co.uk). Salisbury and Wiltshire Cycling and Walking Hotline 01980 623255. A National Trust booklet, Exploring the Stonehenge Landscape, is available for £1 in Stonehenge car park or from NT Wessex Office, Eastleigh Court, Bishopstrow, Warminster, Wiltshire, BA12 9HW (01985 843600). Maps: OS Explorer (2 inches to 1 mile), no 130 (Salisbury and Stonehenge), £5.50 or Landranger (1 to 1 mile) no 184 (Salisbury and the Plain), £5.25.

fields.headline: Apartheid claim over Islam school
fields.standfirst:
Special report: religion in the UK
Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Plans to create Britain's first state-funded Islamic secondary school have come under fire because of the risk of creating "educational apartheid".
fields.body:
Plans to create Britain's first state-funded Islamic secondary school have come under fire because of the risk of creating "educational apartheid".

Birmingham city council's education and lifelong learning advisory team will be urged next week to support the proposals before they are submitted to the authority's school organisation committee next month.

Al Hijrah school, in Bordesley Green, Birmingham, is currently an independent school, but is seeking voluntary-aided status similar to Roman Catholic and Anglican church schools which would make it entitled to state funding.

Labour councillor Roy Pinney, a cabinet member for education and lifelong learning, defended the scheme as a reflection of the city's ethnic diversity. Mr Pinney said: "The creation of an Islamic secondary school would bring a new specialist dimension to education in Birmingham, reflecting the multi-cultural, multi-faith nature of the city."

But Tory councillor James Hutchings pledged to oppose the plan, and is pushing for a referendum to test local opinion. He said: "This is a major issue and has long-term implications. Do we want an integrated or disparate society? This Labour plan is clearly a question of apartheid in education. We should work for integration in this country.

"We have little serious racial trouble in Birmingham and one of the key factors is that we have integrated education. Teachers and staff deserve a lot of credit for that."

Mr Hutchings, who also sits on the education and lifelong learning team, said he favoured religious teaching in schools, but highlighted the "problems" created by separate faith schools in Northern Ireland.

Birmingham's chief education officer, Tim Brighouse, has recommended that if the school was over-subscribed, children from Islamic families would get preference. The minority faith schools are also allowed to retain their unique religious characteristics, with their faith remaining central to their work.

Since the 1997 general election, ministers have approved public funding for six minority faith schools which were independent and there are more in the pipeline. They include Britain's first state-funded Sikh school, Guru Nanak in Hillingdon, west London, which reopened under its new status in 1999. Also in Birmingham, the former independent Muslim primary school Al Furquan became a maintained minority faith school two years ago.

webTitle: France backs Blair on EU force

fields.headline: France backs Blair on EU force
fields.standfirst:
Summit sees Britain win concession over tighter controls on Eurostar to stem illegal immigration

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Summit sees Britain win concession over tighter controls on Eurostar to stem illegal immigration.
fields.body:
Tony Blair won the explicit support of France last night for his vision of a European defence force fully integrated with Nato, but at the cost of hearing President Jacques Chirac launch an impassioned attack on the US plan for a national missile defence shield.

Moments after the French president had pledged himself to a new drive to fill gaps in Europe's defences "in complete unity and harmony with Nato" he used the annual Franco-British summit to denounce President George Bush's anti-missile project as a costly and destabilising twist to the arms race.

When the two leaders and their senior colleagues met in Cahors for a one day session Mr Blair's host was highly diplomatic about the prospect for further integration of the EU. What he called a "strengthening, deepening and broadening of Europe" would come about only with the democratic consent of its peoples as "a federation of nation states".

Well aware of the sensitive election issues which Mr Blair faces at home, Mr Chirac and his prime minister, Lionel Jospin, also went halfway to meeting British concerns about the flow of illegal immigrants across French territory to Britain, mainly via Calais. But they rejected the home secretary Jack Straw's key demand that he be allowed to send those arriving from France with no papers straight back again.

On a sunny day in the regional capital of the Lot department in south-west France, with small crowds cheering the leaders, the discussions ranged from the drive to greater European economic efficiency - the subject of next month's Stockholm summit - maritime safety in the Channel, and the need for both ex-colonial powers to do more to help Africa help itself.

But the election-sensitive issues for Mr Blair were the promised European rapid reaction force which the Tory leader William Hague has claimed France will use to undermine Nato, and efforts to improve cooperation to stem illegal immigration.

On the RRF Mr Chirac was an on-message Blairite yesterday when he agreed to a new joint military committee to identify and improve weaknesses in defence capability.

It would be done "in complete unity and harmony with Nato. We are talking about two parallel, complimentary trends rather than being in competition with each other", he said.

But on Mr Bush's hopes of a missile defence shield over the US, which Mr Blair will discuss at Camp David on February 23, he was unyielding.

"We are concerned because I feel this is going to trigger enhanced [weapons] proliferation. It is an invitation to proliferation, one of the oldest problems around: namely the struggle between the sword and the shield since the beginning of time when the bow and arrow was invented 10,000 -12,000 years ago. Never in history has the shield won," Mr Chirac said. He predicted the US technology would be costly and uncertain, and would provoke even costlier counter measures.

Mr Blair offered no comment on the missile defence shield. But he did win an important concession on the long promised, but undelivered, French willingness to allow immigration officials of both countries to travel between Paris and London via Calais inspecting papers before and during journeys.

Under pressure from London, France will legislate to reclassify the Eurostar service between the capitals as an international one, thus enhancing immigration powers.

Officials will also be able to remove passengers who claim to be going only from Paris to Calais but lack the necessary documentation to travel on to Britain. As many as 400 a month gain entry this way, Mr Blair said. The necessary legislation has been promised by June.

A cross-Channel committee will also be set up to expedite contact between officialdom on both sides covering this and other sensitive issues such as travellers caught by French farmers' and truckers' blockades of the Channel ports, and oil spillages in its crowded waterways.

fields.headline: Sixty seconds in: Brand design
fields.standfirst: Harriet Marshall, a freelance account director, talks to Miles Brignall
fields.trailText: Harriet Marshall, a freelance account director, talks to Miles Brignall
fields.body:
When a consumer purchases a branded product they are not just buying a visual identity, but a set of values that effectively communicate a brand promise. While that might sound a bit ethereal, my team and I help companies design new and existing brands that confirm and add to that reputation.

The design of a new product must start with what we call a 'consumer insight'. Kit Kat is a good example of that - it's based on the insight that people like to sit down with a cup of tea and eat something sweet as a break from their daily routine. Once a company has found and understood an insight, it will test the market to see if a gap truly exists and, assuming one does, bring in someone like me to help them design it.

This starts with a meeting at which we define exactly what it is looking for. By this stage the client usually has an idea of what the product will look like, and possibly a name. From this meeting, I prepare a detailed brief and present it to the creative team who do the actual designing.

Although I do get involved in the design process, my role is mostly one of facilitator.

If we are designing a new soft drink, I'll go out and buy all the ones currently on the market and we'll evaluate them to make sure our ideas are sufficiently different. Once, as a team, we have the basis for our design we'll produce a sketch book containing between 10 and 20 roughed-out ideas and we'll present our initial ideas to the client.

I am a great believer they should see as much of the raw material as possible and we'll take along as many references as possible. For example, if we had been influenced by the colours in a Goya painting, I would include a copy of that. Equally, we might take along swatches of material or a style of photography - whatever.

It's only when we get the final go-ahead from the client that we begin work on the computers and actually design how the product will look. It's a hugely collaborative process and I'm there to manage the project and make sure it happens on time. Once we've finished, I'll present it back to the client and the concept will be researched with consumers. It will only go to market once the client is entirely satisfied that the design communicates the brand's values.

Although it sounds very long-winded the process can be as brief as three months. For me the buzz is about building relationships with clients. While that might sound a bit ethereal, my team and I help companies design new and existing brands that confirm and add to that reputation. The design of a new product must start with what we call a 'consumer insight'. Kit Kat is a good example of that - it's based on the insight that people like to sit down with a cup of tea and eat something sweet as a break from their daily routine. Once a company has found and understood an insight, it will test the market to see if a gap truly exists and, assuming one does, bring in someone like me to help them design it. This starts with a meeting at which we define exactly what it is looking for. By this stage the client usually has an idea of what the product will look like, and possibly a name. From this meeting, I prepare a detailed brief and present it to the creative team who do the actual designing. Although I do get involved in the design process, my role is mostly one of facilitator. If we are designing a new soft drink, I'll go out and buy all the ones currently on the market and we'll evaluate them to make sure our ideas are sufficiently different. Once, as a team, we have the basis for our design we'll produce a sketch book containing between 10 and 20 roughed-out ideas and we'll present our initial ideas to the client. webTitle: How to... deputise without becoming too big-headed

fields.headline: How to... deputise without becoming too big-headed
fields.standfirst: Is it a set-up or your chance to shine?
fields.trailText: Is it a set-up or your chance to shine?
fields.body:
You enjoy your job and know you're good at it. You like your team, have good relationships with colleagues and get on well with your boss. Then someone has to spoil it all by going on an extended holiday, taking maternity leave or finding another job. Without warning, you're asked to step into their - rather more senior - shoes.

If you're of the 'glass half-empty' persuasion, your first thoughts might well be: "It's not in my job description, I'm not being paid more and my title won't change. In fact, the company is just trying to exploit me".

Adopt this attitude, says the Edinburgh-based corporate psychologist Ben Williams and you're on the road to disaster. "Actually," he says, "it's a marvellous opportunity to show what you can do. Often promotions are earned by people who've been doing the job for a while first. Deputising is making an investment in your future."

Lawrence Wilson, director of careers and student development at Canterbury Christchurch University College, says that in many organisations deputising is standard practice when grooming someone for promotion: "Often, a company

will ask you to deputise to see how you perform under pressure. They want to see if you've got potential and how you cope with new hurdles. If you've mastered your own job or are starting to get frustrated, it can be an opportunity to excel and to learn new skills, or identify the areas where you need more training."

But a word of warning. "Occasionally,' says Lawrence, "an organisation might use deputising as a way of pushing you out. They'll give you a job they know you can't cope with, so that when you inevitably fail they'll have an excuse for letting you go. Or, if they're 'lucky', you'll become so unhappy that you'll leave of your own accord."

Whatever your company's motives, shoving your size 9s into a former colleague's size 7s can be a painful experience. It may mean learning new skills extra-quick, managing people who might resent you and living up (or down) to someone else's reputation. You may also have to juggle the demands of doing two jobs at the same time.

According to Ben Williams, the trick is to prioritise. "For most people, the problem is differentiating between what's urgent, but not important and what's important, but not urgent. Inexperienced people do the most urgent stuff first, then rush off to do the stuff that's urgent, but not important (still following?).

"These are the things that you can delegate, while you get on with other, more important tasks. You'll still have time to check over what they've done in time for the deadline. The unimportant and

non-urgent work is a luxury - you can leave it until you've got spare time, or give it to someone else."

Worried that your peers will be none too happy about your sudden rise in status and, therefore, feel unhappy about delegating? As long as you're fair and don't get too big-headed, there's nothing wrong in acting like the boss you've replaced - or enjoying a little of their reflected power.

Communication is the key. Try saying: 'I'm covering John's desk, so would you mind helping me?'

No-one expects you to be a clone of your forebear. "You'll never do the job in exactly the same way as the other person," says Ben Williams. "Simply do the best you can. But if you find they've done certain things in a superior way,

getting an insight into their methods and trying to work more like them gives you a great opportunity to add to your skills."

Of course, there's a fine line between deputising and letting your company walk all over you. Lawrence suggests that if your temporary position goes on

forever, without any promise of a new contract, promotion or pay rise, it's time to have a quiet word in your boss's shell-like.

As a last resort, you might have to contact personnel or, if you have one, your union rep.

If you don't remember anything else...

As politician Margaret Beckett discovered, being a deputy does not guarantee promotion. Appointed Labour leader after John Smith's sudden death, she was ousted by the more popular Tony Blair. Like Margaret, if your face doesn't fit you could find yourself returning to your former role and duties.

The company may not see you as senior enough for promotion, or the person you've deputised for might return to their job. Then again, someone new could be recruited. "If this is the case, says Ben Williams, "it could be time to get out."

webTitle: Body language - is it the sum of its parts?

fields.headline: Body language - is it the sum of its parts?
fields.standfirst: A rough guide to making yourself heard
fields.trailText: A rough guide to making yourself heard
fields.body:
The boss is listening to you ask for a pay rise when he starts pulling his earlobe. Do you get the message? Is there a message? Or has the boss just got a boil at the back of his ear?

Body language is supposed to be the other language - the one we don't speak, the language we are all supposed to understand at a deeply subconscious level.

Maybe we do. But more likely we don't, partly because of cultural differences and partly because it needs to be raised to the level of our conscious mind before we can analyse it.

And here's a scary thought: studies suggest 93% of our communication with others is non-verbal. What you actually say only makes up 7% of the picture. So, what you need is a rough guide to body language in the work situation.

Eye-balling

Liars are said to look away while they are telling their porkies - unless they are such accomplished liars they have trained themselves to look you in the eye whilst trotting out untruths. So, be wary of the one who stares at you longer than makes you comfortable.

People who rub their eyes are also being deceitful. Lying men look at the floor when they look away from you. Lying women look at the ceiling.

Bullies like to stare over their spec frames to intimidate. Invest in a pair of your own if you have to deal with one regularly.

When you want to look sincere during a business meeting gaze at the other person's face, focusing between the eyes. Don't let your gaze drop below their eye level unless you want things to get more social.

Arms and hands

These are very versatile. Arms folded across the body are in a defence position. Defence against what? If you're trying to make a point and the other person has folded their arms, don't bother; they are shutting your idea out, even if they are saying the opposite.

Clutching files and other things across the body is another defence or 'shutting out' posture.

Someone who folds their arms but with their thumbs on show, pointing up, feels superior. Try it now and again - you might get promotion.

Open palms are a positive gesture. Clenched fists need no explanation. Putting a hand over the mouth is another sign that someone is lying. Rubbing the nose is another one.

Neck scratchers have doubts about what you are saying. Chin strokers are thinking things over. So are people who put pens in their mouth so they don't have to speak and give you their opinion.

If someone stops stroking their chin and lets their head rest on their hand while you are talking to them, you are boring them. Don't waste your breath.

Legs

You can do a lot with legs as well. If you stand symmetrically and take up plenty of space, you will look and therefore feel more confident - especially important at interviews.

You will probably find that you 'lock' your ankles during an interview - undo them, otherwise it suggests you are holding back. Relax and make eye contact. And there is nothing wrong with smiling now and again.

Watch a one-on-one conversation where people are standing. They will start out with their legs crossed at the ankles and their arms folded. If they uncross their legs and start using their arms and hands with open palm gestures then they are also seeing 'eye-to-eye'.

Legs crossed above the knee when sitting is a standard European posture. It only becomes defensive if arms are crossed as well. Sales people never ask clients for a decision if they are sitting like this.

Men who sit with a leg crossed and the ankle resting on their knee are very competitve - women do it too (if they are wearing trousers). This is a good indicator of who is trying to climb the corporate ladder ahead of you.

Whole body postures

Types who sit with their hands behind their heads are power players. If they happen to be your boss, don't copy them - they won't like it. Women rarely assume this position.

Leaning forward in your chair indicates you are ready to do business. This is a good position to adopt during an interview - but not too early.

Men - and women - who stand with their hands on their waist or thumbs tucked into their belt are staking out their territory.

People whose whole body gestures take up a lot of space are power players.

Flattery

Mirroring another person's body language is a subtle way of flattering them, unless they are your boss and making power gestures. If you copy those you are offering to challenge them. Not a good idea.

Foreign bodies

Even though body language is common to everyone, there are still cultural differences and language sub-groups which, if you operate in the global marketplace, you might have to learn.

Finally, if your boss is pulling at his earlobe and he doesn't have a boil, then he's telling you that he doesn't want to hear what you have to say. You can kiss goodbye to that rise.

fields.headline: Rockin' role
fields.standfirst: Thanks to Cameron Crowe's rock drama Almost Famous, teen actor Patrick Fugit is now a bona fide star - and he didn't even have good taste in music
fields.trailText: Thanks to Cameron Crowe's rock drama Almost Famous, teen actor Patrick Fugit is now a bona fide star - and he didn't even have good taste in music
fields.body:
With his middle parting, Patrick Fugit doesn't look much like a movie star, which is probably why the 18-year-old was plucked from obscurity to play William Miller, the teenage journo who goes on the road with a fictional rock band in Almost Famous, Cameron Crowe's autobiographical paean to 70s rock.

You're from Salt Lake City, but you're not a Mormon?

No. About 60% of the people there are. It's a strange place to be if you're not a Mormon. It's very quiet, it's sort of a city with a town feeling. Not much happens there.

So how did you end up in Almost Famous?

I had an agent in Salt Lake City but acting was more like a hobby. It wasn't like, "I'm going to be an actor when I grow up." But Cameron Crowe sent out this nationwide casting call so we sent in a tape, and then six weeks later he called me up and said he wanted to fly me to LA for a screen test.

That must have been exciting?

It was. It was my first time in Los Angeles. It's a very enticing, very seductive place but once you get to know what LA's really like you don't want to live there. But I was at the Chateau Marmont and there was like Q from Star Trek, Rachel Leigh Cook was there, so it was all like a movie star-sighting adrenalin kind of thing. I was very wide-eyed and that's what Cameron said he liked about me.

You're basically playing the young Cameron Crowe. Did you see any similarities betwen the two of you?

Oh, yes. He said, "Don't play me as a 15-year-old," but after getting to know him, you can't help throwing in little bits and pieces of him. Cameron will do this little wave when he sees you, but William is this awkward, dorky kid and when you put that wave with his mannerisms it's really funny. Sometimes the way William talks, when he says, "OK, OK", that's very Cameron and the facial expressions are very much Cameron - he has a very expressive face.

Did you know much about 70s music before this?

I didn't. My dad has a huge vinyl collection downstairs but I was never too interested. The only CD I had was by Adam Sandler.

So you took a crash course in classic rock?

Yeah. Cameron went out and got me a ton of rock CDs, and he said, "Have this coming out of your ears, eyes, nose and mouth by the time we shoot." It really affected me. You don't get that from today's music. There's a lot of crap out there, which is why I never really listened to music until classic rock. Now it's all I listen to.

Does the rock'n'roll lifestyle appeal to you?

Kind of. It's a little out of control. I'm not a very fast-paced person. It was very much a rock'n'roll lifestyle shooting the movie.

Were you surrounded by groupies?

No, actually. There were some creepy extras around when we were shooting the big concert scenes. They'd come knocking at the door of your trailer.

Your only other film was 1998's Legion Of Fire: Killer Ants!?

You've done your homework. The story is that these ants are in Japan and they infest this shipment of lumber on its way to America. But the ship crashes in Alaska and the ants come out and live underground. It sounds like a really cool plot right? But it's a terrible movie. I'm eaten by ants in the first half-hour of the movie.

You've just graduated from high school, what will you do now?

I'm not going to go to college for a while, I'm going to carry on acting. I just got my first million dollar offer, which is exciting. It's outrageous. Who would pay me a million dollars to do what I do?

fields.headline: Grand Hotel, Tynemouth
fields.trailText: The hotel was popular with Laurel and Hardy, who always stayed here when appearing in Newcastle.
fields.body:
Address: Grand Parade, Tynemouth, Tyne & Wear NE30 4ER.

Tel: 0191-293 6666

Fax: 0191-293 6665

First impressions: Imposing Victorian hotel splendidly situated above the golden strand of Long Sands Beach. The hotel was popular with Laurel and Hardy, who always stayed here when appearing in Newcastle.

What are the rooms like? Our fourth-floor double was spacious and well decked out with tasteful heavy wooden furniture. The en-suite rooms also come with satellite TV, phone and tea- and coffee- making facilities. The views across Tynemouth Bay are excellent from the seafront rooms.

The bed test: Firm and comfortable double, although if you're over 6ft tall you may find it a tad short.

Bathroom luxury: Walk-in shower, wash basin, WC and Jacuzzi.

The restaurant: Recognised as one of the best in the area, and superbly decorated along a classic Victorian theme, including impressively huge chandeliers. There's a good selection including vegetarian dishes. Dover sole costs £18.75, baked aubergine £11.95.

The lounge: The perfect place to sit in large comfortable armchairs, drinking afternoon tea while watching the North Sea crashing on to the beach below.

What is there to see within walking distance? Take a walk along Long Sands Beach; walk into the rather twee Tynemouth village for a potter around the craft shops.

What is there to see nearby? Newcastle city centre is just a few minutes away on the Metro; the historic city of Durham is a short drive to the south; to the north is the magnificent Northumberland coastline; and inland there's Hadrian's Wall.

How much a night? Single rooms cost from £60 to £85, doubles from £65 to £90. The most expensive rooms have a Jacuzzi. Full English breakfast is included.

fields.headline: Make mine a...
fields.standfirst: Ratafia di Fragola
fields.trailText: Ratafia di Fragola
fields.body:
Darling. Sweetie. Angel. Bunnikins. Before you snuggle up under the duvet for a bit of Valentine's Day nookie, treat your inamorata to a sip of this deliciously decadent digestivo. Made by a small, family-run company in Montalcino, Tuscany, it contains 15% strawberry pulp - imagine liquefied strawberries with a kick - so the taste and colour are both wonderfully natural. It would be wicked well chilled with white chocolate or poured into a champagne glass and topped with fizz. Preferably Prosecco, though not an off-dry one, as it's sweet enough already.

So, who drinks it, apart from lovers and Tuscan ladies who lunch? Well, not many people at all, fortunately for Antonio Carluccio's wife, Priscilla, who painstakingly paints the labels by hand. (Apparently, it's not worth printing a coloured label for the 100-odd bottles a year they sell.) Add to her workload by buying it from Carluccio's shop in Covent Garden (020-7240 1487) and Carluccio's Caffés. It costs £24.25 for 50cl.
fields.bodyText: Darling. Sweetie. Angel. Bunnikins. Before you snuggle up under the duvet for a bit of Valentine's Day nookie, treat your inamorata to a sip of this deliciously decadent digestivo. Made by a small, family-run company in Montalcino, Tuscany, it contains 15% strawberry pulp - imagine liquefied strawberries with a kick - so the taste and colour are both wonderfully natural. It would be wicked well chilled with white chocolate or poured into a champagne glass and topped with fizz. Preferably Prosecco, though not an off-dry one, as it's sweet enough already. So, who drinks it, apart from lovers and Tuscan ladies who lunch? Well, not many people at all, fortunately for Antonio Carluccio's wife, Priscilla, who painstakingly paints the labels by hand. Add to her workload by buying it from Carluccio's shop in Covent Garden (020-7240 1487) and Carluccio's Caffés. It costs £24.25 for 50cl.

fields.headline: Sukiyaki, London
fields.standfirst: St Albans doesn't have anywhere decent to eat, moaned his friends. Oh yeah, said Matthew Fort. What about this fab Japanese place I read about the other day...
fields.trailText: St Albans doesn't have anywhere decent to eat, moaned his friends. Oh yeah, said Matthew Fort. What about this fab Japanese place I read about the other day...
fields.body:
She wouldn't believe me. Look, I said, sukiyaki is a dish. No, she said, Sukiyaki is a name - remember the pop song, she said, Sukiyaki it was called. Early 80s. Classic stuff. And they even sang some of it in Japanese.

Who did, I asked. I can't remember, she said, but I know they did. Aha, I said, but did they know what they were singing? Aha, she said. And then there it was on the menu of Sukiyaki for all to see: sukiyaki: "Scotch beef sirloin and fresh vegetables cooked and served at your table." She conceded with far more grace than I would have been able to muster had the situation been reversed. But it is hard to be ungracious after lunch somewhere as nice as Sukiyaki.

St Albans is not the first place you might think of looking for a decent Japanese restaurant. Mind you, if you listened to Costanza, the connoisseur of 80s pop, and The Gunner, her immensely civilised husband, you would have thought that there aren't any decent restaurants in St Albans at all - and they should know: they live there. This seems a little odd, seeing that St Albans has more than its fair share of millionaires and media hounds.

Anyway, I came across the name of Sukiyaki while browsing through the info Michelin sent along when the new guide came out recently. They had awarded it a red M, or whatever sign they use these days to signify good food at reasonable prices, and, after weeks of cutting-edge cooking and gastro-pubs, I fancied something by way of a change. Perhaps my friends can be forgiven being unaware of this little gem on their doorstep: Sukiyaki has been on Spencer Street for six years, it seems, without anyone getting terribly excited about it. But for a restaurant to survive that long anywhere is a sign that it is doing most things right.

The menu, which is helpfully laid out along western lines with starters and main courses, isn't exactly packed with ground- breaking stuff. Aside from the eponymous sukiyaki, there's a bit of teriyaki, a tonkatsu dish or two, and tempura, naturally, among the main courses; and yakitori, agedashi dofu and kushikatsu among the starters. Each dish is accompanied by a short, sensible explanation of what it is, so there is no need to worry about displaying embarrassing ignorance. Nor is there anything of the raw fish, braised jellyfish colon or deep- fried cocks-combs variety. This is Japanese food for beginners, and jolly good it is, too.

For it doesn't matter how sophisticated food is. What matters is how it is cooked and served. Both my companions were not only novices in matters of tempura and tonkatsu, but ardent vegetarians as well. No problem. The prawns were happily dropped from the roster of tempura moriawase, and replaced instead with a generous supply of further veg in an alpha-double-plus batter, light and friable. Before that, agedashi dofu - deep-fried bean curd - in a sauce bouncing with ginger, mirin, soya and seaweed stock, and a classic miso soup had provided a gentle entry, with rice and pickles to provide bulk and counterpoint.

The pickles were an item. There was a time - perhaps there still is - when a bride's way with pickles defined her negotiating strength in the marriage contract in certain countries in the Far East. On the basis of the pickles we had, the pickler in the kitchen at Sukiyaki could command her or his own price. They were delicate, poised, lightly acid little coils of vivid green cucumber and deep purple radish.

In relation to my own set of dishes - gyoza dumplings and buta shoga (thin slices of pork in a ginger sauce) - perfect foils to burnish the tastebuds between each mouthful. The pastry on the dumpling was refined, the stuffing perky with aromatics. The slices of pork of the buta shoga were like folds of linen, bathed in a mirin-sweetened sauce to which ginger added a cheerful warmth. The miso soup had an unusual degree of bloom and depth.

The point that I kept coming back to was how clean and fresh it all tasted. Do you want more? Occasionally, yes, but this will do me very nicely on a regular basis, thank you. And, at £8.50 for my set lunch, I should be able to afford it.

In fact, the huge total for the three of us was £49.35, and that included £5.40 on beer, £3 on sake and £2.30 on wine. All in all, though it pains me to say so, Michelin have got it absolutely right as far as Sukiyaki is concerned.

webTitle: Animal welfare concerns on Hollywood films

fields.headline: Hollywood shoot horses, don't they?
fields.trailText: Actors are often told never to perform with children or animals, but perhaps animals should be warned about performing with humans.
fields.body:
Actors are often told never to perform with children or animals, but perhaps animals should be warned about performing with humans.

For more than a decade cinema-goers have been reassured by a statement at the end of films that "no animals were harmed in the making of this film", but now a newspaper has criticised the organisation responsible for monitoring animal welfare on set.

The film and TV unit of the American Humane Association (AHA), which is based in Los Angeles, observes some 850 productions a year and reckons to cover 80 to 90% of all US films that use animals.

On the unit's website, ahafilm.com, around 90% of the productions are listed as "acceptable." But the unit has only nine full-time field staff and operates with a budget of around $1.5m (£1m).

The Los Angeles Times claims this has led to the unit being slow to criticise animal mistreatment but swift to defend the big studios.

AHA lawyers tried in vain to prevent the publication of the Times investigation on the grounds that it used information from a confidential report into claims that an AHA investigator had dated two trainers whose work she was assigned to oversee. She was criticised in the report for a "gross lack of professional judgment".

A horse used in the 1999 Disney film The 13th Warrior had to be destroyed after a wire sliced through its tendons and an artery. The AHA called the death an "industrial accident".

Although the film did not receive the on-screen credit, on the website it is listed as "believed acceptable", but now the official who monitored the scene has told the Times the accident had been avoidable.

The film Running Free receives a "believed acceptable" rating from the AHA despite the fact that shock collars and pellet guns had been used to train horses, four of which died during filming. The AHA says it will update its files to make references to the deaths.

The organisation has defended its role, saying that its standards are high and that producers had responded by improving animal welfare.

webTitle: All change for big names of the catwalk

fields.headline: All change for big names of the catwalk
fields.standfirst:
Yves St Laurent clash with Tom Ford signals rise of young designers as winter collections go on show

Special report: London Fashion Week 2001
fields.trailText: Yves St Laurent clash with Tom Ford signals rise of young designers as winter collections go on show.
fields.byline: Jess Cartner-Morley, fashion editor and Hadley Freeman
fields.body:
Will green still be the new black? Are miniskirts really making a comeback?

Such burning issues will be addressed in the next five weeks on the catwalks of New York, London, Milan and Paris, as designers show the autumn/winter collections that will go on sale in September.

As usual, there will be as much going on off the catwalk as on. The fashion world is in the midst of upheaval. A cultural shift is taking place, as the couturiers of old survey the rise of a modernising spirit among a new generation of designers. This dynamic is symbolised in the relationship between Yves Saint Laurent, 65, and Tom Ford, 38.

YSL, the ready to wear division of Yves Saint Laurent and by far the largest portion of the clothing and accessories business, is now under the control of Gucci Group, with Tom Ford designing for both labels.

Yves Saint Laurent himself, who retains creative control of the haute couture collection, appears not to accept this shift entirely gracefully. Last year he ruffled Gucci feathers by opening a Paris boutique of one-off Yves Saint Laurent pieces, in violation of the agreement restricting him to haute couture.

Nonetheless, this is as nothing next to the big-business dramas of the industry. Bernard Arnault's luxury giant LVMH - which owns Louis Vuitton, Christian Dior, Givenchy, Christian Lacroix, Fendi, and Loewe, and now US heavyweight Donna Karan - has an arch rival.

Gucci, which owns designer shoe label Sergio Rossi along with Yves Saint Laurent, has recently acquired control of Alexander McQueen and, earlier this week, the white-hot Milanese label Bottega Veneta. There are persistent rumours that Gucci's next announcement will concern Nicholas Ghesquiere, the young designer at the helm of Balenciaga.

While Gucci Group is snapping up cutting-edge designers and labels, and LVMH is hitting more established brand names, the rivalry is fierce.

Gucci's deal with Alexander McQueen, giving the designer backing to develop his label, was given piquancy by him also designing for LVMH's Givenchy.

After quarrels over creative control, the deal with Gucci was the final nail in the coffin. McQueen's contract for Givenchy will not be renewed, although he is expected to present a ready to wear collection for the house in Paris next month.

His replacement at Givenchy is likely to be announced soon. Bernard Arnault is reported to be talking with the young avant-garde Belgian designer Oliver Theyskens.

The tantrums are not restricted to Europe.

In New York Calvin Klein has been in a battle with Linda Wachner, chairman of Warnaco, the company to which Klein licenses his underwear and jeans ranges. He accused Warnaco of damaging his name by selling CK goods in downmarket stores, and a court case was only headed off by an 11th hour deal.

For this weekend, at least, Calvin Klein will be spared the limelight, as all eyes turn to Sean John.

The label might not be well known in this country, but the man behind it is - rap mogul Sean "Puffy" Combs, on trial in New York on gun and bribery charges. Sean John's clothes last year accounted for an estimated $100m of the $160m income of Combs's empire, and his latest collection will be on show in New York's Manhattan tonight.

The event will be broadcast live - a first for a US fashion show.

Who's who of winners and losers

New York

Katayone Adeli

Gwyneth Paltrow extolling the perfection of Adeli's trousers gave her prominence. But it is her lace detailing and beautiful tailoring that make this a label worth watching.

Alice Roi

Wide necked jumpers paired with leggings, dresses slashed so high even Liz Hurley would blink - yet Alice Roi, 24, managed to make them cool and desirable last season.

London

Lizzy Disney

After having enormous success in New York, she has returned to London this year for her first show in her native city.

Shelley Fox

The first winner of the Jerwood Fashion Prize in 1999, Shelley Fox has proved that deconstruction need not be synonymous with difficult.

Milan

Patty Shelabarger

Even in glitzy Milan, shows from the cartoonish Patty Shelabarger stand out. Her lacy jeans and girly slip dresses have become almost as recognizeable on the fashion circuit as the pink-haired designer herself.

Paris

Alexandre Herchcovitch

Never mind supermodel Gisele - Alexandre Herchcovitch is the real energy behind Brazil's fashionable resurgence. The success of this avant garde designer has raised the South American fashion industry beyond supermodels.

Lanvin

Another sufferer from the feuding rife through the fashion world. The venerable label is about to lose its menswear designer, Dominique Morlotti, and the house itself is rumoured up for sale. An uncomfortable reflection of the clash of the old world of fashion against the commerciality in the modern world.

Friday

7.15-7.30 Up/shower.

8.00-8.30 travel to work.

8.30-16.00 at work (no lunchbreak).

16.00-17.00 travel home.

17.15-17.30 put washing in machine.

17.15-17.30 no cooking today/ takeaway meal.

17.30-19.00 do reports on children at nursery.

19.00-19.30 wash up dishes.

19.30-20.00 read newspaper.

20.00-20.30 Snack.

20.30-23.00 Visit friends, then home.

23.15-1.45 Watch TV.

Saturday

9.30-10.00 Up/shower.

10.30-11.00 cook breakfast.

11.30-11.45 wash up.

12.00-15.30 go into town/shopping.

16.00 visitor arrives.

18.00-19.00 cook and eat meal.

19.15-20.30 watch TV and chat to my partner.

20.30-20.45 Shower.

21.30-2.30 out with my partner.

Comments

It's difficult to imagine doing so much in one day. I noticed how we hardly have time to talk. I'd like Patrick to do more, but he's not here. And I'd like to work fewer hours at my job - I often have to take work home to get it all done.

Patrick Laird, electronic engineer. Went to university after working in a factory and now studies for his MSc two nights a week

7.15-8.00 Up/shower.

8.00-8.30 Go to work.

8.30-9.00 Coffee/sandwich/meeting.

17.30-19.00 Go to university/group assignment for degree.

19.00-20.00 In library.

20.00-22.00 Pub.

22.00-22.30 Home and dinner.

22.30-23.45 Listen to music/talk to partner.

23.45 Bed.

Saturday

8.15 Wake up.

9.00 Shower.

10.00-12.00 Library.

12.00-14.00 Shopping.

14.15 Arrive at partner's house.

15.00-15.15 Vacuum living room.

15.45-16.45 Studying.

16.45-18.00 Shop with partner for Sunday meal.

18.00-19.00 Prepare Sunday meal.

19.00-20.00 Watch TV.

20.00-20.30 Shower/shave.

21.00-23.00 Out with partner.

23.00 To a party.

Comments

I know Darlene does a lot. She doesn't stand still. A shorter working week would be good, but I'm learning such a lot. I really like it.

webTitle: Kingston upon Hull warned not to squander windfall

fields.headline: Keeping watch on Kingston's 'pot of gold'
fields.standfirst: Auditor warns town hall in Prescott's backyard not to squander cash from windfall on grandiose projects in £650m spending spree
fields.trailText: Auditor warns town hall in Kingston upon Hull, home of John Prescott, not to squander cash from windfall on grandiose projects in £650m spending spree.
fields.body:
Two years ago it was labelled the richest authority in Britain after receiving £255m from the part sale of a shareholding in the local phone company.

But the city of Kingston upon Hull - home of a stricken football club and the deputy prime minister, John Prescott - has been chastised by a local government watchdog.

The district auditor has warned the Labour-run council that a spending spree triggered by the windfall was "neither realistic nor achievable" and could in time leave it in serious financial difficulties.

After finding a "lack of urgency" on previous warnings, he has found a £270m shortfall in a £650m capital spending plan that includes double-glazing and central heating for all council homes that need them, a massive school repair programme, a purge on dirty streets - and £40m to build a super stadium for rugby league and Hull City football club. This week the club called in administrators after the players had not been paid for five weeks.

The auditor's report could prove an embarrassment to Mr Prescott, MP for Hull East, whose Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions oversees local government. He has used Hull as a model example of selling municipal assets to fund improved council services.

Although Hull's remaining shareholding in Kingston Communications, the phone service set up by the council in 1902, is worth another £430m, the auditor, Paul Lundy, questioned the public perception that the 1998 windfall had made the council wealthy. "The reality is somewhat different," he warned.

This was because a substantial proportion of the sale proceeds had been committed to "one-off" big projects, and the amount left to spend on frontline services was a fraction of what had been suggested.

His report told the council: "It is essential that no firm commitment is made to proceed with any capital scheme until there is certainty of funding and the longterm revenue consequences have been identified."

Woundingly, he also said that although the authority aspired to be a "top 10" British city, "this is unlikely to be achieved unless there is a significant cultural change in the way it conducts its business and changes its long held attitudes and working practices".

To make matters worse, Mr Lundy said the council had used another £32m to cover a funding gap in its day-to-day spending, amounting to £289m in the current financial year.
