webTitle: Northern cities try hard sell in south

fields.headline: Northern cities try hard sell in south
fields.standfirst: Merseysiders are being professionally briefed on northern statistics so they can subtly sell the region to southerners at dinner parties
fields.trailText: Merseysiders are being professionally briefed on northern statistics so they can subtly sell the region to southerners at dinner parties.
fields.body:
First a group of Yorkshiremen stood outside King's Cross station in rush hour, handing Londoners Yorkie bars wrapped in a list of reasons why they should move to Bradford. Then a Manchester roadshow came to London with northern food and drink.

Now Merseysiders are being professionally briefed on northern statistics so they can subtly sell the region to southerners at dinner parties.

These marketing campaigns, most government-funded, are part of Labour's latest attempt to move people and businesses north and turn regional cities into alternative European high-flyers similar to Barcelona, Lyon or Milan.

This month a series of adverts will appear on London's underground, buses and black cabs aimed at upping the status of northern regions and selling them to London. The government has paid hundreds of thousands of pounds for cities to be branded by regional development agencies and public-private partnerships. The EU has put money into research on how to advertise English cities to the English.

According to EU-funded research, Londoners need adverts for other cities because the English are painfully ignorant about geography. Southerners think Yorkshire is all mining and thatched cottages, Manchester is rain and Merseyside is the Beatles - when in fact it is the nation's capital for call centres. People are not investing because they don't know how good these regions are.

To counter this, the Mersey Partnership this week launches a London ad campaign informing commuters: "Merseyside is the golfing capital of England", "Merseyside is one of the safest city regions in the UK", and "Liverpool has more museums, theatres and galleries than any other UK city outside London".

Yorkshire Forward follows up in March with posters on the tube telling commuters: "Yorkshire's full of bankers" and "e-by gum!", drawing on the fact that 70% of Yorkshire people work in financial or business services and 33% of all UK internet traffic goes through the region.

Barrie Kelly, head of marketing at the Mersey Partnership, said: "Research has found people in the south-east are completely ignorant about Merseyside and the north. They think it's all football and the Beatles. They haven't got a clue about the cultural diversity, which is why our posters in London use "wow facts" aimed at educating them. The image of the north has improved by 40% in the last five years. We are working to further that."

At the centre of the regional campaigns are the "quality of life" wars between northern cities competing for stressed London exiles. Merseyside is reminding Londoners that 36% of the region is greenbelt. Manchester and Yorkshire cities are squabbling over how long it takes to get into countryside from the centre of town. "In Manchester it's strictly fields you can get to in 20 minutes, whereas from Leeds, Sheffield or York you're in open countryside which is much better," said Theresa Lindsay of the Yorkshire Forward campaign.

The Marketing Manchester group is focusing less on London poster campaigns and more on cornering the weekend break tourist market, especially from Ireland and Europe. Fact books and vouchers are being distributed in tie-ins with travel groups and credit cards. And Manchester's Mission Metropolis roadshow returns to London this year so business conference organisers can sample Manchester products "without travelling north of Hemel Hempstead".

Will the marketing work? The Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions said promotion was a small but essential part of economic development in the regions. Yorkshire Forward reported that when their team handed out Yorkie bars in London stations few factsheets were trampled underfoot, which suggested Londoners were clinging to any hope of a better life up north.

If all else fails there are still the "Mersey Champions", local people who are to be briefed via the Mersey Partnership's website so they can "talk it up" at football matches and other social occasions. Everyday people, the agency says, are "an excellent mobile sales force".

webTitle: Vaccine safety to be reviewed after BSE criticism

fields.headline: Vaccine safety to be reviewed after BSE criticism
fields.trailText: Government advisers will next month begin to review the safety of vaccines dating back to the early 1970s.
fields.body:
Government advisers will next month begin to review the safety of vaccines dating back to the early 1970s, following criticisms that they had not sufficiently examined all the possible ways that BSE may have spread from cattle to humans.

Evidence has recently emerged that oral polio vaccines using material from British cows was in use until last October despite long-standing controls that were meant to prevent just such an occurrence.

The new checks are part of the government's response to the verdict on the BSE scandal by Lord Phillips, the master of the rolls, who called for major changes in the way ministers, civil servants and advisers responded to such crises in future.

Lord Phillips's report demanded less secrecy, more willingness to consider unwelcome scientific opinion and better contingency planning for "worst case" scenarios. It was also fiercely critical of the way government departments failed to monitor basic safety measures when the possibilities that people could catch new variant CJD, the fatal human form of BSE, from infected cow meat were first raised in the late 1980s.

The possibility that vaccines offered another route to infection has long been recognised and successive guidelines were introduced during the 1990s. The guidelines were meant to ensure only sources from countries without BSE were used.

Foetal calf serum has long been used to help "grow" strains of viruses to use in vaccines against diseases such as polio. The committee on the safety of medicines only last year looked at vaccine production dating back to 1980, and last October a vaccine using British-sourced material was withdrawn.

The government insists the risk of catching variant CJD is "incalculably small" but has ordered more checks because Lord Phillips concluded that BSE had probably been prevalent but unnoticed through much of the 1970s.

Ministers have also agreed to consider opening up the system for approving medicines; make sure any bovine-based products including cosmetics are tracked; and re-examine whether present methods for disposing of the meat industry's waste are safe.

The government's 102-page interim response to Lord Phillips's report accepted or agreed with most of its 167 findings. But it argued much progress had already been made on ending departmental turf wars, widening the range of scientific advice, being more open with the public, and planning for the worst - notably the possibility that BSE might have transferred to sheep.

However the response questioned Lord Phillips's judgment that BSE most likely first started as a mutation in cattle and said the origin remains uncertain. A review of the current state of knowledge is already under way. It also stated that: "The government does not believe there are any serious gaps in its powers to take proportionate emergency action against hazards to human or animal health."

A handful of civil servants who are still in their posts and more than two dozen ministers, officials and advisers criticised by Lord Phillips will not be disciplined.

Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, said yesterday: "There isn't one person who is to blame for this. It was an institutional failure and a political failure right across government." However the Conservatives "were thrown out of office, at least in part, because of the way they managed the BSE crisis."

MPs will debate the government's response next week and the public have been invited to comment before ministers determine whether further action is necessary.

webTitle: Trust sells skin to Porton Down

fields.headline: Trust sells skin to Porton Down
fields.standfirst: NHS patients not told of chemical weapons tests
fields.trailText: NHS patients not told of chemical weapons tests
fields.body:
Chemical weapons were tested on human skin removed from NHS plastic surgery patients without their knowledge, a hospital admitted yesterday.

The skin, which was removed during breast and abdominal surgery at Salisbury district hospital, was used by scientists at the nearby Porton Down chemical warfare facility to test how human tissue was damaged by corrosive chemicals.

It was also used to investigate how drugs could be injected through the skin, and to develop barrier creams to protect against chemical attack.

Consent forms signed by patients said the skin would be used for "medical research" without explaining that it was being used by the defence evaluation and research agency (Dera) which runs the facilities on Salisbury Plain, Wiltshire.

Skin removed during the normal course of surgery was sold to military researchers for an annual fee of £17,000.

The practice began in 1995 and was stopped two weeks ago in the wake of the Alder Hey report.

The hospital said it recognised some patients might object to their skin being used for defence experiments, and offered apologies.

But Salisbury community health council, which represents patients' interests, said it was surprised to learn of the sale of body parts.

Chief officer Mark Woodcock said: "Patients will understandably be extremely distressed to hear of this news.

"The CHC believes that the trust needs to provide answers to the following questions:

"First, who in the trust in May 1995 authorised the trust to sell body parts to Porton Down?

"Second, why did the trust continue to sell after public awareness of problems at Alder Hey first occurred in November 1999?"

A Ministry of Defence spokeswoman, speaking on behalf of Dera, confirmed the skin was used in chemical warfare tests. "Some of the tests were to find out how the skin absorbs chemicals that might be used to attack our armed forces. But they were solely for defence purposes - we stopped developing chemicals for attack at Porton Down in the 1950s.

"Most of the chemical tests done were for the benefit of civilians. They were with corrosive chemicals that are used in the home and work place, to see how the skin would be affected by a spillage."

A hospital spokesman said it was calling a halt to the process until it obtained further guidance from the Department of Health. The money it received from the Dera went back into patient care. No complaints had been received from patients yesterday.

Left-over skin was also used by the hospital to investigate wound healing and the preparation of artificial skin, as well as the treatment of burn wounds.

The hospital trust said in a statement: "The trust had thought it appropriate for patients' consent to be sought for the use of surplus skin in all forms of medical research through a consent form.

"The trust now recognises that this did not inform patients of the specific use of the skin and that some individuals may not have wished for the skin to be used by Dera and offers its sincere apologies for this."

The shadow health secretary, Liam Fox said: "This simply reinforces the need to have rigorous regulations in place to ensure proper informed consent for all patients.

"One of the points I made in the aftermath of Alder Hey was that patients should be clearly informed of the purposes for which organs and tissues would be used."

webTitle: Return of malaria feared as UK climate warms

fields.headline: Return of malaria feared as climate warms
fields.standfirst:
UK becoming vulnerable to tropical disease warns health department

Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Malaria could return to southern counties in the next 20 years as the climate warms, and during the summer months half of England would be at risk of an outbreak, the Department of Health said yesterday.
fields.body:
Malaria could return to southern counties in the next 20 years as the climate warms, and during the summer months half of England would be at risk of an outbreak, the Department of Health said yesterday.

In the department's first review of the effects of climate change on the nation's health, it said that warmer summers would provide a foothold for tropical diseases, and much greater spread of tick borne ailments like Lyme's disease, which attacks the joints.

Higher temperatures would cause 10,000 more cases of food poisoning, add 2,000 to the 800 deaths each year from heatstroke and, combined with the hole in the ozone layer, cause an extra 5,000 skin cancers and 2,000 cataracts a year.

Not all the news was bad. Cold kills more than 80,000 people a year through heart attacks and other circulation problems. Scientists expected this to drop by 15,000 by 2020, and another 5,000 by 2050. The milder winters would also cut the annual steep rise in hospital admissions that so disrupts the NHS each year.

Less certain were the health effects of the heavy rain, flooding and storms that were expected to become a feature of the British climate.

In Scotland, this was expected to lead to increased damp in houses causing winter ailments, and milder winters and more standing water offering breeding grounds for clouds of midges. This would make life unpleasant and damage the tourist industry.

It was the expected early arrival of malaria that most exercised Liam Donaldson, the government's chief medical officer, yesterday.

He said it likely to involve the milder form of the disease, plasmodium vivax, which did not often kill but frequently recurred.

More than 2,000 cases of traveller's malaria were reported each year, and more than two-thirds of these were life threatening.

The vast majority of victims had been on holiday abroad, but there had been about 60 cases recorded of people living near airports who had been bitten by a stray mosquito arriving on board an aircraft.

Mosquitoes able to carry malaria have always existed in Britain, and the disease was endemic between the 16th and 19th centuries. David Rogers, a professor at Oxford University, said malaria was the disease referred to as ague by Shakespeare. It had died out in the 19th century because of better housing (partly because man stopped living close to farm animals), and draining of marshes.

The last outbreak in England was in Kent when troops returning from the first world war with malaria were bitten by local mosquitoes that spread the disease to people who had never left England.

A similar return from abroad of humans with malaria was how the disease was expected to be reintroduced, and it could occur at any time during the warm summer months.

Salt water marshes were most likely to breed malaria mosquitoes. The Norfolk fens, the Thames estuary, parts of south-east Kent, and the Somerset levels, where the disease thrived in the last century, were the most susceptible.

Prof Rogers said there was a danger of the second more deadly form of malaria reaching Britain.

Plasmodium falciparum killed 1m children a year in Africa. It was spreading to western Turkey and Mexico and could well be brought to Britain by holidaymakers.

Other "tropical" diseases like West Nile fever, which has recently killed people in New York, must also be candidates for reaching Britain. It was carried by wild birds and had already infected horses in southern France - showing it could spread to the UK, Prof Donaldson said.

The new checks are part of the government's response to the verdict on the BSE scandal by Lord Phillips, the master of the rolls, who called for major changes in the way ministers, civil servants and advisers responded to such crises in future. Lord Phillips's report demanded less secrecy, more willingness to consider unwelcome scientific opinion and better contingency planning for "worst case" scenarios. It was also fiercely critical of the way government departments failed to monitor basic safety measures when the possibilities that people could catch new variant CJD, the fatal human form of BSE, from infected cow meat were first raised in the late 1980s. The possibility that vaccines offered another route to infection has long been recognised and successive guidelines were introduced during the 1990s. The guidelines were meant to ensure only sources from countries without BSE were used. Foetal calf serum has long been used to help "grow" strains of viruses to use in vaccines against diseases such as polio. The committee on the safety of medicines only last year looked at vaccine production dating back to 1980, and last October a vaccine using British-sourced material was withdrawn. Ministers have also agreed to consider opening up the system for approving medicines; make sure any bovine-based products including cosmetics are tracked; and re-examine whether present methods for disposing of the meat industry's waste are safe. webTitle: Posh floored as Ali G tackles Becks

fields.headline: Posh floored as Ali G tackles Becks
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: For David and Victoria Beckham, ridicule is an occupational hazard. But rarely can Britain's first couple have been subjected to as uncomfortable a 40 minutes as that spent being grilled by Ali G for Comic Relief.
fields.body:
For David and Victoria Beckham, ridicule is an occupational hazard. But rarely can Britain's first couple have been subjected to as uncomfortable a 40 minutes as that spent being grilled by Ali G for Comic Relief.

Previously the pair have agreed only to the meekest of interrogations, but this exchange was a world away from Michael Parkinson. Over the course of a 40-minute interview, which will be edited for broadcast on March 16, the couple were subjected to the full blast of the comic's singular style.

Dressed in a leather burgundy jumpsuit with the legend "Save Africa" emblazoned on the back above a map of Italy, Ali G introduced the couple to the live audience with the words: "Every boy wants to be in his boots and every man wants to be in his missus. Big up for none other than Victoria and David Beckham!"

His opening comment to Beckham was a pointer to what was to come. "Now, just because its Comic Relief doesn't mean you can speak in a silly voice."

Over the next 40 minutes the comedian subjected the pair to a series of uncomfortable questions about their private life and the state of their marriage. Referring to the Beckhams' taste in decor and clothes Ali G asked: "So, they is some people who suddenly get loads of money who become very tasteless. How has you two managed to avoid that?"

"I don't know. I'm sure we're wearing things that some people look at and think they are tasteless," replied Victoria.

Referring to Victoria's health he said: "Now there is rumours that you used to suffer from an eating disorder, Tell me, was you actually dyslexic?"

"I've never actually been dyslexic and I've never actually been anorexic either, so that's just rumours," said Victoria.

Later Ali G asked whether she had recovered from "miningitis", before she pointed out that she had contracted viral meningitis.

For much of the interview Beckham remained silent, speechless at inquiries about the etiquette of taking a shower after matches and whether he would prefer to be married to Victoria's fellow Spice Girl, Emma Bunton. Asked about his dress sense he did manage a response.

"So now, Beckham, let's talk about fashion. We has all seen pictures of you wearing clothes that was well embarrassing and frankly make you a proper laughing stock! What's the name of that dress that you wore?" "Sarong," replied Beckham.

"Yeah I know it was so wrong," responded the comedian, played by Sacha Baron-Cohen.

Even Victoria was struck dumb by a series of questions relating to the couple's son Brooklyn.

Ali G: "So tell me, does Brooklyn like your music, or is he getting a bit old for it now?"

Victoria: "Well yeah, he does like music, he jigs about and dances. He's also into football as well, so it's nice."

Ali G: "Respect, respect. So how old is Brooklyn now?"

Victoria: "He's nearly two."

Ali G: "So tell me, is your little boy starting to put whole sentences together?"

Victoria: "He's learning the bits and pieces, so yeah."

Ali G: "And what about Brooklyn?"

webTitle: Entertainment Rights wins licensing rights for Mr Bean

fields.headline: Mr Bean bagged
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Entertainment Rights, the intellectual property firm backed by leisure magnate Trevor Hemmings, has won the British licensing and merchandising rights for a 52-part animated series of Mr Bean, the television character made famous by actor Rowan Atkinson.
fields.body:
Entertainment Rights, the intellectual property firm backed by leisure magnate Trevor Hemmings, has won the British licensing and merchandising rights for a 52-part animated series of Mr Bean, the television character made famous by actor Rowan Atkinson.

"Entertainment Rights intends to capitalise on the success of the brand with plans for licensed products across all areas," it said in a statement.

A film version, Bean - The Ultimate Disaster Movie, grossed over $240m at the box office worldwide.

Entertainment Rights, run by chief executive Mike Heap, has built up a portfolio of kids characters over the past two years including Basil Brush and Budgie the Helicopter, the story created by the Duchess of York.

"Mr Bean is a household name and at Entertainment Rights our strategic vision is to build strong and instantly recognisable brands," Mr Heap said.

Shares closed up 5% at 29.5p.

fields.headline: Serendipity or shrewdness, it's a Hollick hit
fields.standfirst:
Changing fortunes at ITV

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Notebook: Changing fortunes at ITV.
fields.body:
Take a quick glimpse at the share price charts of Granada, Carlton Communications and United Business Media, and it is easy to determine which you would rather have put your money into at this time last year.

Granada, which peaked at more than 300p a share, was yesterday worth 190p, a fall of 37%. Carlton, 930p at its height, was worth 482p, a drop of 48%.

United, which reached the £10 mark last summer, at present stands at 770p, a more modest 23% drop, but that gap was in effect bridged as the company gave details of its typically complex plan to return £1.25bn to shareholders - the equivalent of 245p per share.

During the heat of the battle last summer to decide which company would emerge as the dominant force in ITV, United appeared decidedly to be the loser. After failing to merge with Carlton, United had little option but to sell out to Granada.

During the whole process Lord Hollick, United's chief executive, kept grinning maniacally. He had, he assured us, been the winner out of this. He had wrung fantastic value from the sale of the ITV assets, regardless of that fact that his strategy for the business had been blown out of the water.

Now, as the television advertising market softens - and Granada told us by how much it has done so earlier this week - so Lord Hollick seems to have been proved correct.

The sale of the ITV assets has been the catalyst for United to do what investors had been demanding for some time - shed the mini-conglomerate tag. United has cleared out the blight of Express Newspapers and is moving toward the sale of its other consumer businesses, leaving a much more focused business to business rump. Commanding £1.75bn for the ITV franchises, he now appears to have sold at the peak. Whether that was pure serendipity or shrewd financial management is another matter.

Obits.com

Choose your own obituary page. There's the Dot Com Graveyard at Upside.com, or the forthright fuckedcompany.com where recently laid-off workers can vent their spleen. And then there is itulip.com. Launched ahead of its time, in 1998, the site has long since given up warning about the internet bubble. They're previewing the Greenspan economic wasteland now. Bears will be bears, of course, and they have plenty to celebrate at present.

The seams of the new economy seem to be splitting everywhere, from advertising-driven websites offering advice on personal finance to the Silicon Valley giants producing the internet's communication backbone.

Motley Fool, an early trendsetter in offering amateur investors a fresh approach to financial news, laid off 30% of it staff this week, despite the fact that it has just bagged £20m of fresh venture capital. The redundancies are simply a recognition that it has to drive towards profitability, rather than continually racing into new markets.

Meanwhile, fresh on the heels of disappointing earnings news from Cisco, Lucent - its arch rival in the business of producing all the web's routers and other networking equipment - has landed itself with a regulators' inquiry into its accounting practices.

But in London last night, early indications on the biggest test of market sentiment - namely the flotation of Orange - suggested the £5bn issue has been a success. The so-called book has been covered at least twice.

Investors who applied for stock should hope that market jitters elsewhere will encourage France Télécom's investment banks to price the issue at the lower end of expectations. Dealings begin on Tuesday.

Inner city spirit

Michael Porter, the Harvard Business School guru, is usually associated with weighty tomes on national competitiveness. But Professor Porter is also a champion of attempts to regenerate America's blighted inner cities through new enterprises. He has developed an index of inner city firms ranking them according to how fast they are growing.

Inner cities usually get a bad press as a place to start up a business. But Prof Porter has uncovered a wealth of unquoted firms doing surprisingly well in challenging areas.

Yesterday the chancellor, Gordon Brown, launched Britain's version of the InnerCity 100 - which will be run by the New Economics Foundation, a think tank that works on neighbourhood renewal issues. NEF hopes that the index will help attract other companies into the inner cities.

Financial exclusion is not just a problem for individuals - companies are affected as well.

If the index highlights the success of inner city ventures, it should make it easier for them to gain access to capital.

The future will not necessarily be built in a Thames Valley business park.

webTitle: Reward for shareholders after ITV sell-off

fields.headline: Hollick gives back £1.25bn
fields.standfirst:
Reward for shareholders after ITV sell-off

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Reward for shareholders after ITV sell-off.
fields.body:
Lord Hollick's United Business Media yesterday gave details of a complex plan to return £1.25bn to the company's shareholders.

The cash is a large part of the proceeds from the sale of the group's three ITV franchises at the end of last year after a failed attempt to merge with Carlton Communications. United raised £1.75bn in total from the disposal of the Anglia, HTV and Meridian businesses to Granada Media.

Investors will receive the equivalent of 245p for each share through a complex series of arrangements designed to minimise tax liability.

Lord Hollick said: "We have crystallised tremendous value for shareholders through the sale of our television and other assets. Disposals over the past 12 months have realised a total of over £3.2bn, leaving the company financially strong and well placed to execute its strategy."

The cash will be distributed in the form of "B" shares. Investors then have the choice of selling them for cash, receiving a single dividend for the same amount or take continuing dividends from them. The company will then consolidate its ordinary shares. It is buying back around one third of its capital.

Shares in the company yesterday fell by 25p to 770p on the announcement that was signalled by United at the time of the ITV sale.

United has reshaped itself around business-to-business media, market research and news distribution. It sold Express Newspapers at the end of last year and is expected to sell its remaining consumer assets, including a stake in Channel 5.

"We have moved decisively to restructure the company and build market leading positions," Lord Hollick said. "Each will be grown both organically and by acquisition."

United had originally been expecting to take Granada shares from the sale. It took cash after the Granada share price collapsed.

 Richard Desmond's Northern & Shell yesterday continued the paring back of Express Newspapers which the publishing company bought for £125m last November.

Norther & Shell has agreed the sale of Express Newspapers Financial Services to Seymour Pierce for £500,000. The asset management business has 9,000 customers and investments worth £300m.

webTitle: Anne Robinson to present US Weakest Link

fields.headline: Anne Robinson's £1m link with US
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: If her irritating put-downs were not enough for a British audience, Anne Robinson is about to be unleashed on the United States where she will present a version of the The Weakest Link, in a deal which will net her at least £1m.
fields.body:
If her irritating put-downs were not enough for a British audience, Anne Robinson is about to be unleashed on the United States where she will present a version of the The Weakest Link, in a deal which will net her at least £1m.

The US network NBC has taken out an option on the game show for six years, which could make the contract worth up to £15m, but even if the show which will be broadcast from April is a success, it is unlikely to last that long.

Ms Robinson, 56, was elated. "I'm absolutely delighted. Mrs Thatcher conquered America and now I'm going to have a go," she said. The increase in her workload means she will leave the BBC's consumer programme, Watchdog.

The deal was signed after Ms Robinson, who was voted the rudest woman on TV by magazine readers, made a pilot show for the network. John Penrose, her husband and agent, said: "I can't reveal the exact details, but she's not going to be out of pocket. It's a multi-million pound deal. They have the option to use her for six years."

It is common for TV formats to be sold around the world, but the presenter does not usually travel with them. Mr Penrose said: "It's a remarkable achievement for any British presenter to be invited to appear on prime time TV in the states. There's only one Anne Robinson - that's exactly why NBC decided to go for her."

The US version of the game show will follow the same format as the British model. The show, which was launched last summer on BBC2, features Ms Robinson's catchprhase: "You are the weakest link. Goodbye." After becoming BBC2's most-watched programme, with a daily slot at 5.15pm, it landed a weekly peak-time airing on BBC1 as well.

The BBC estimates that sales of The Weakest Link around the world will be worth £30m over the next five to 10 years. The UK production team is currently working with broadcasters in France, Italy, Germany and Israel among other countries to produce local versions of the show.

webTitle: Media reaction to Blair's euro annoucement

fields.headline: Blair sparks frenzied debate with euro 'sensation'
fields.standfirst: Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: In the end the message was delivered not by a spin doctor, not in a briefing, a speech or a radio interview, but at the dispatch box in the House of Commons.
fields.body:
In the end the message was delivered not by a spin doctor, not in a briefing, a speech or a radio interview, but at the dispatch box in the House of Commons.

Backbenchers, constitutionalists and commentators often bemoan the irrelevance these days of parliament, and remark the prime minister's distaste for being there. But when it comes to defining terms precisely, New Labour came home. "Early in the next parliament", Tony Blair revealed, meant "within two years".

On the face of it, it is hard to square the frenzied reaction to this "sensational" news with the text. Parliaments can last five years, often last four and a bit. So to suggest "early" equates to the first half seems neither profound nor sensational.

But the Sun said Blair "sensationally vowed to kill the pound and adopt the euro within two years". Which he did not. The Mirror said the prime minister's answer "crushed" the "hapless" William Hague "with one killer blow". According to the Daily Telegraph, Hague said Blair "had sounded the death knell for the pound" and the Conservatives would "fight him every inch of the way".

Peter Riddell, in the Times, floated the possibility that the prime minister's "within two years" might have been a "slip". But the Daily Mail was in no doubt that "the battle for the pound" had been "thrust dramatically into the heart of the election campaign". As if the Mail would have allowed it to reside anywhere else. But however great the hyperbole there was no doubt that by defining "early" Blair had launched the debate the government has seemed so anxious to avoid.

Perhaps earlier comments from the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, and the trade secretary, Stephen Byers - "part of a carefully coordinated operation between the two ministers", according to the Independent - pushed the prime minister. Cook "abandoned the government's cautious stance on the euro by claiming Britain would vote for the single currency in the next parliament if five economic tests were met", the paper reported.

Two days later, the day before Blair's intervention, Byers said the benefits of British membership of the single currency were obvious. The Financial Times said this was "a sign he will take on the role of the government's euro cheerleader following the departure of Peter Mandelson".

The prime minister was saying no more than that the five economic tests would be assessed within two years, but it was immediately pointed out that the decision to join the euro required more than passing the economic tests.

As the Times leader put it: "So monumental and irreversible a decision has implications so profound for British democracy and nationhood that the decision on joining or staying out should never be taken on economic criteria alone. Monetary policy lies at the core of what it is to be self-governing. Mr Blair does not see the importance of the constitutional dimension. He will not be trusted until he does."

The Sun said the prime minister had handed the Tories a gift. "They can fight the election on the euro "which is opposed by about 80% of voters in Britain. Blair clearly thinks he can turn the country round. If he does so, he will have pulled off a political miracle the like of which we have never seen".

The Financial Times called on Blair to show that he intended the answer to the euro question to be yes. The government "must now emphasise that its position is far from neutral. Mr Blair must set about the huge task of winning over the voters". He has the chance to explain why "the nation is strengthened not weakened by pooling of sovereignty with its neighbours".

The size of the task was underlined by the latest Eurobarometer poll on attitudes to the EU. As the Guardian reported: "Britain has come out bottom in five of seven key categories of support for the EU, with backing for the single currency down to a record low".

Only 21% supported joining the euro.

 Peter Cole is professor of journalism at Sheffield University

Backbenchers, constitutionalists and commentators often bemoan the irrelevance these days of parliament, and remark the prime minister's distaste for being there. But when it comes to defining terms precisely, New Labour came home. "Early in the next parliament", Tony Blair revealed, meant "within two years". On the face of it, it is hard to square the frenzied reaction to this "sensational" news with the text. Parliaments can last five years, often last four and a bit. So to suggest "early" equates to the first half seems neither profound nor sensational. But the Sun said Blair "sensationally vowed to kill the pound and adopt the euro within two years". Which he did not. The Mirror said the prime minister's answer "crushed" the "hapless" William Hague "with one killer blow". According to the Daily Telegraph, Hague said Blair "had sounded the death knell for the pound" and the Conservatives would "fight him every inch of the way". Peter Riddell, in the Times, floated the possibility that the prime minister's "within two years" might have been a "slip". But the Daily Mail was in no doubt that "the battle for the pound" had been "thrust dramatically into the heart of the election campaign". As if the Mail would have allowed it to reside anywhere else. webTitle: Who works harder, men or women?

fields.headline: Give us this day
fields.standfirst: It's an age-old question: who works harder, men or women? The female homemaker/male provider stereotype is long gone; both now spend hours at the workplace. But is the gender divide in domestic matters really a thing of the past? Five couples kept time diaries to find out
fields.trailText: It's an age-old question: who works harder, men or women? The female homemaker/male provider stereotype is long gone; both now spend hours at the workplace. But is the gender divide in domestic matters really a thing of the past? Five couples kept time diaries to find out
fields.body:
British men spend more time away from their children than fathers anywhere else in Europe. But there is no mass movement among UK fathers to win back time out of the labour market; there are no proposals from the government to cut men's working week; and men who want more time off - or women who want men to take time off to play more of a part in parenting and homemaking - have no champions in the government.

A promise to "uphold family life" as the "core of society" was part of New Labour's manifesto at the last election. Since then, home secretary Jack Straw has led a new movement in the cabinet - the married men's movement - enthusiastically supported by his deputy at the home office, Paul Boateng, and by the prime minister himself. They shied away from a proposal for state dowries to entice couples to marry (heterosexual, of course), but the prime minister did set up a ministerial committee on the family, chaired by Straw.

Straw made his views clear when he told a Christian group that although "it is not for the state to put pressure on people to marry", he believed the government should promote marriage as the best barricade between childhood and a career in crime. Marriage is most likely to provide children with "two participating parents". So how much do these cabinet ministers participate in parenting?

According to Downing Street, the prime minister "eats and sleeps the job". When Paul Boateng was at the department of health, his spokesperson said he "works all the hours that God gives". When we asked the home office, a trawl through Straw's diary revealed a six-day-week of several 18-hour days. His shortest working day was 13.5 hours. When Straw delivered his big speech on "family matters", he devoted only two paragraphs out of 65 to time. Perhaps the long-hours culture should be challenged, he ventured - but not, it seems, among politicians.

We asked a range of people to complete detailed diaries of their daily lives; we wanted to find out how much parenting, and how much paid and unpaid work, men and women do. We also asked them what they thought of these politicians' pronouncements. Darlene Aiken, a nursery supervisor with an 18-year-old son, was dismissive: none of them had anything relevant to say, she said. Helen Hughes, a full-time homemaker with two children, feels that, "in the politicians' eyes, you are a nonentity - because you are not draining the state of anything, you are not a problem".

Jack Lowe, a photographer and father of a two-year-old son, was unimpressed by the example set by Tony Blair when he finally decided to take paternity leave after his wife's labour. "He seemed so shocked. How had it passed him by before? It could have helped a lot of dads if he'd decided beforehand to take paternity leave. My job is just as important to me as his is to him." Lowe took three weeks' holiday when the baby was born.

Jaspal Dhaliwal, a computer consultant, argued, "The biggest thing that would help parents, single parents and two-parent families is adequate childcare. We both work full-time and we took a financial hit on childcare - we paid out more than we pay on our mortgage. Equality costs money." All of these parents are worried by the amount of time fathers spend away from their families. The past three decades has seen tumult between the genders and generations; women and children have come to expect care and companionship from men. Yet during these decades, men's working time has actually grown.

Helen Hughes's husband, Jim, a design engineer, knows that it is his job and travel time that keeps him from his wife and children: "I get up before the children and when I get home they're on their last legs." Before his children started school, he worked a 12-hour day. Sometimes, he worked six months without a day off. Now, he works an average week. Doing the diary made him think "how little time I spend with my kids. When I get met at the door, it's very nice, it's 'Daddy, Daddy!' But I'd like to get my briefcase down first." His wife lives by a different timetable: "I have the guilt thing," she says. "When he comes home, that's it, the end of his day. But I don't stop till I drop."

The married men's movement in the cabinet tends to focus on the purported flight of the mothers into the labour market, or on a divorce culture that allegedly leaves boys in a world without men. Implicitly they invoke a "golden era" of fathered family life, in the 50s, say, when people left their doors unlocked and the sun always shone and mothers were always at home.

This is the Rupert Bear template with Father giving Rupert his full attention and providing a proper model of masculinity. But there was no golden age: the 50s father spent an average of only 11 minutes a day caring for his little ones. These days he spends 44 minutes a day caring for his pre-school child, according to Professor Jonathon Gershuny, Britain's premier expert on domestic time.

In those olden days, fatherhood was about being a provider rather than a parent, it was about absence and authority over women and children. Is it the loss of that distant power that the men's movement really laments? Contemporary children who live with their dads probably enjoy more congenial fathering than at any time in modern history.

Gershuny's research on the use of time in everyday life reveals that mothers in full-time work actually spend more dedicated time caring for their pre-school children than the full-time homemakers of the 50s: an average 107 minutes a day, compared with 20 minutes four decades ago. This is no surprise to baby-boomers who lived their childhood in the golden era. Mothers may have been a permanent presence in the home, but "being there" did not always mean "being with" their children. "Go out and play," they told their kids. The street was their space. It is not parents so much as cars that have rendered that theatre of childhood a dangerous place. In any case, today's school-age children of professional parents are increasingly away from their homes and streets: they're often at school and children's clubs from 8.30am until 6.30pm.

Research commissioned by the Childcare Commission was not designed to ask men how much childcare and housework they do. But these themes dominate the disagreements between men and women. According to counselling service Relate, "The most common cause of housework arguments is the amount men do." According to Gershuny, when women go out into the labour market, men scarcely increase their share of the domestic work. And so, because men have not taken over responsibility for domestic work, women's overall working time (paid and unpaid) gets longer and longer.

Contrary to the expectation that domestic work will decline, it is increasing: not only do parents expect to spend more time with their children, but some domestic activities, far from fading away, are being recalibrated from "labour" to "leisure". There is, for example, a revolution in British cuisine. "For the great majority of us, employed or not, cooking for our own households often seems the only genuinely productive thing we get to do," comments Gershuny. Women, he notes, however anxious to shed domestic work, will still cook. "House cleaning," comments Gershuny, "is mere maintenance," which perhaps explains why women still perform three-quarters of it even when they, like the men they live with, have full-time jobs outside the home.

Contrary to conventional wisdom, younger men do less than the average, and their contribution to core domestic work, according to Gershuny, "hardly changes with the presence of children". In fact, his use of time-use diaries confounds several myths. True, his research suggests that men spend an average of 28 minutes a day on domestic work compared with women's 177 minutes, but both genders spend more time than they used to alone with their children of all ages. For women, the figure is about 10 hours a week, twice as much as men, according to Legal & General, whose interest in mothers' work - both paid and unpaid - concerns its worth. If a mother dies and has to be replaced, what would she cost? Legal & General reckons the average mother's unwaged work would cost more than £200 a week to replace.

The government, however, retains the view that work is only work if it is paid for in the labour market. That's why it landed itself in trouble, and not only with women's groups, when it insisted that single mothers should "work" - as if they weren't already working.

Despite its confidence about state intervention in morals and marriage, our government recoils from tackling the big issue - the redistribution of time and money between the genders. It was 70s feminism that began the debate. Alarmed by the exhausting effects of entering the labour market on the same terms as male breadwinners who had wives at home to take care of them and their children, some proposed an alternative politics of time: the part-time woman worker should be regarded as the norm. She has no one to service her; she simultaneously takes care of herself and others. This model proposes a reduced working week for everyone tailored to synchronise with children's time, and a dramatic rise in child benefit to erase the residual excuses for unequal pay between men and women.

Not surprisingly, this strategy was an affront to the traditions of the labour market. For a century, both employers and trade unions had bargained for a male breadwinner: a man paid a family wage and serviced by an unpaid woman.

Defenders of the patriarchal family and the family wage, notably the Thatcherite Institute of Economic Affairs (IEA) and the social democratic Institute of Community Studies (ICS), promote men's privileged place in the economy - and thus their estrangement from everyday responsibilities in the home - on the grounds that women are better at it, and that if men are expected to be women's equals, they'll skive, or worse, they'll skiddaddle. When it comes to domestic democracy, these political enemies unite.

Geoff Dench, at the ICS, takes the pessimistic position shared by the IEA: men won't pay the price of parenting unless they are given a privileged place in the economy and in the home. If they are expected to be equal and they are liberated by free love, they'll do even less.

A third approach has been proposed by Amitai Etzioni, the American sociologist and leader of communitarianism. Etzioni was promoted in Britain by Demos director Geoff Mulgan who advises Straw's ministerial group on the family; Etzioni is a proponent of the theory of the "parenting deficit", which argues that the family is falling apart because of the divorce culture and because women are doing what men do, fleeing the nest, going out to work and abandoning children to the drinks cupboard and the television.

Evidence shows, however, that divorce merely means that women are leaving men, not their children. Nevertheless, Etzioni is popular among those seeking evidence for their apocalyptic angst about families falling apart, about community and crime.

A glance at Britain's time-use and employment statistics shows that men and women live in different time zones. Even when they're at home, they're doing different things, and mothers' entry into employment is still contingent on taking care of everyone. Britain's labour market is polarised between full-time men and part-time mothers.

Gershuny reckons that the government's family agenda is not only "grossly old-fashioned" but also "unacceptable", because it does not deal with the deficit between men and women. Despite the dramatic rise in women's paid work, men's domestic work - stable at around 30 minutes a day - hardly changes. Gershuny detects a long-term gender convergence between men and women. Demos imagines that we are almost there. It argues that corporate culture and men are being feminised and that women are being masculinised.

But are the genders converging? Among our diarists, no one recognised this. Cleaner and community activist Sue Rickus said, "To be honest, the woman still goes out to work, sees to the children, while the men go out to work, come home and that's that. No, men and women aren't getting more alike. If only!"

Kath Webb, who lives with Jack Lowe and toddler Callum, agreed. "We have quite a modern relationship, but Jack is a breadwinner and I am a full-time housewife. His job is his job. My job is looking after Callum." Even when they are at home together, they do different things - she always cooks, he always clears up.

The premier researcher on time and gender in the US, Arlie Hochschild, argues that something else is happening. Although the genders are changing and the pressure towards equality is coming from women, the genders may still be living different lives. Hochschild is an academic in California, where the divorce rate is 60%. "Divorce has utterly different consequences for men and women. It reasserts the gender divide." After divorce, women do even more everyday childcare (as well as everything else). They often do all of it - in Britain, 40% of divorced men lose all contact with their children. According to Hochschild, divorce has become a "central fact of marital life that is leading to gender differences". Men and women may become simultaneously more alike and more estranged. Western women may find themselves preferring motherhood supported by the sisterhood of friends and relatives than a precarious alliance with a father.

She does not see a parenting deficit among fathers and mothers so much as a "care deficit" caused by the withdrawal of the welfare state, particularly in the US and the UK - and the ones who are losing out are children, the elderly, patients recovering from surgery, or schizophrenics abandoned to unwelcoming communities. "The state has become a deadbeat dad," says Hochschild.

Nowhere in the world offers an optimistic prognosis. Even in Sweden, the west's model of social solidarity and equality, the provision in the 90s of paid parental leave available for both mothers and fathers to share during children's early years has yielded little change - fathers took up only 11.5% of the paid leave.

In Britain, those fathers who strive for a better balance between home and work have no champions other than the women they live with, and certainly none in political society. Yet many men "have a more advanced and less traditional gender ideology than their lives would suggest".

fields.bodyText: British men spend more time away from their children than fathers anywhere else in Europe. But there is no mass movement among UK fathers to win back time out of the labour market; there are no proposals from the government to cut men's working week; and men who want more time off - or women who want men to take time off to play more of a part in parenting and homemaking - have no champions in the government. A promise to "uphold family life" as the "core of society" was part of New Labour's manifesto at the last election. Since then, home secretary Jack Straw has led a new movement in the cabinet - the married men's movement - enthusiastically supported by his deputy at the home office, Paul Boateng, and by the prime minister himself. They shied away from a proposal for state dowries to entice couples to marry (heterosexual, of course), but the prime minister did set up a ministerial committee on the family, chaired by Straw. Straw made his views clear when he told a Christian group that although "it is not for the state to put pressure on people to marry", he believed the government should promote marriage as the best barricade between childhood and a career in crime. Marriage is most likely to provide children with "two participating parents". So how much do these cabinet ministers participate in parenting? According to Downing Street, the prime minister "eats and sleeps the job". When Paul Boateng was at the department of health, his spokesperson said he "works all the hours that God gives". When we asked the home office, a trawl through Straw's diary revealed a six-day-week of several 18-hour days. His shortest working day was 13.5 hours. When Straw delivered his big speech on "family matters", he devoted only two paragraphs out of 65 to time. Perhaps the long-hours culture should be challenged, he ventured - but not, it seems, among politicians. We asked a range of people to complete detailed diaries of their daily lives; we wanted to find out how much parenting, and how much paid and unpaid work, men and women do. We also asked them what they thought of these politicians' pronouncements. Darlene Aiken, a nursery supervisor with an 18-year-old son, was dismissive: none of them had anything relevant to say, she said. Helen Hughes, a full-time homemaker with two children, feels that, "in the politicians' eyes, you are a nonentity - because you are not draining the state of anything, you are not a problem". Jack Lowe, a photographer and father of a two-year-old son, was unimpressed by the example set by Tony Blair when he finally decided to take paternity leave after his wife's labour. "He seemed so shocked. How had it passed him by before? It could have helped a lot of dads if he'd decided beforehand to take paternity leave. My job is just as important to me as his is to him." Lowe took three weeks' holiday when the baby was born. Jaspal Dhaliwal, a computer consultant, argued, "The biggest thing that would help parents, single parents and two-parent families is adequate childcare. We both work full-time and we took a financial hit on childcare - we paid out more than we pay on our mortgage. Equality costs money." All of these parents are worried by the amount of time fathers spend away from their families. The past three decades has seen tumult between the genders and generations; women and children have come to expect care and companionship from men. Yet during these decades, men's working time has actually grown. Helen Hughes's husband, Jim, a design engineer, knows that it is his job and travel time that keeps him from his wife and children: "I get up before the children and when I get home they're on their last legs." Before his children started school, he worked a 12-hour day. Sometimes, he worked six months without a day off. Now, he works an average week. Doing the diary made him think "how little time I spend with my kids. When I get met at the door, it's very nice, it's 'Daddy, Daddy!' But I'd like to get my briefcase down first." His wife lives by a different timetable: "I have the guilt thing," she says. "When he comes home, that's it, the end of his day. But I don't stop till I drop." The married men's movement in the cabinet tends to focus on the purported flight of the mothers into the labour market, or on a divorce culture that allegedly leaves boys in a world without men. Implicitly they invoke a "golden era" of fathered family life, in the 50s, say, when people left their doors unlocked and the sun always shone and mothers were always at home. This is the Rupert Bear template with Father giving Rupert his full attention and providing a proper model of masculinity. But there was no golden age: the 50s father spent an average of only 11 minutes a day caring for his little ones. These days he spends 44 minutes a day caring for his pre-school child, according to Professor Jonathon Gershuny, Britain's premier expert on domestic time. In those olden days, fatherhood was about being a provider rather than a parent, it was about absence and authority over women and children. Is it the loss of that distant power that the men's movement really laments? Contemporary children who live with their dads probably enjoy more congenial fathering than at any time in modern history. Gershuny's research on the use of time in everyday life reveals that mothers in full-time work actually spend more dedicated time caring for their pre-school children than the full-time homemakers of the 50s: an average 107 minutes a day, compared with 20 minutes four decades ago. This is no surprise to baby-boomers who lived their childhood in the golden era. Mothers may have been a permanent presence in the home, but "being there" did not always mean "being with" their children. "Go out and play," they told their kids. The street was their space. It is not parents so much as cars that have rendered that theatre of childhood a dangerous place. In any case, today's school-age children of professional parents are increasingly away from their homes and streets: they're often at school and children's clubs from 8.30am until 6.30pm. Research commissioned by the Childcare Commission was not designed to ask men how much childcare and housework they do. But these themes dominate the disagreements between men and women. According to counselling service Relate, "The most common cause of housework arguments is the amount men do." According to Gershuny, when women go out into the labour market, men scarcely increase their share of the domestic work. And so, because men have not taken over responsibility for domestic work, women's overall working time (paid and unpaid) gets longer and longer. Contrary to the expectation that domestic work will decline, it is increasing: not only do parents expect to spend more time with their children, but some domestic activities, far from fading away, are being recalibrated from "labour" to "leisure". There is, for example, a revolution in British cuisine. "For the great majority of us, employed or not, cooking for our own households often seems the only genuinely productive thing we get to do," comments Gershuny. Women, he notes, however anxious to shed domestic work, will still cook. "House cleaning," comments Gershuny, "is mere maintenance," which perhaps explains why women still perform three-quarters of it even when they, like the men they live with, have full-time jobs outside the home. Contrary to conventional wisdom, younger men do less than the average, and their contribution to core domestic work, according to Gershuny, "hardly changes with the presence of children". In fact, his use of time-use diaries confounds several myths. True, his research suggests that men spend an average of 28 minutes a day on domestic work compared with women's 177 minutes, but both genders spend more time than they used to alone with their children of all ages. For women, the figure is about 10 hours a week, twice as much as men, according to Legal & General, whose interest in mothers' work - both paid and unpaid - concerns its worth. If a mother dies and has to be replaced, what would she cost? Legal & General reckons the average mother's unwaged work would cost more than £200 a week to replace. The government, however, retains the view that work is only work if it is paid for in the labour market. That's why it landed itself in trouble, and not only with women's groups, when it insisted that single mothers should "work" - as if they weren't already working. Despite its confidence about state intervention in morals and marriage, our government recoils from tackling the big issue - the redistribution of time and money between the genders. It was 70s feminism that began the debate. Alarmed by the exhausting effects of entering the labour market on the same terms as male breadwinners who had wives at home to take care of them and their children, some proposed an alternative politics of time: the part-time woman worker should be regarded as the norm. She has no one to service her; she simultaneously takes care of herself and others. This model proposes a reduced working week for everyone tailored to synchronise with children's time, and a dramatic rise in child benefit to erase the residual excuses for unequal pay between men and women. Not surprisingly, this strategy was an affront to the traditions of the labour market. For a century, both employers and trade unions had bargained for a male breadwinner: a man paid a family wage and serviced by an unpaid woman. Defenders of the patriarchal family and the family wage, notably the Thatcherite Institute of Economic Affairs (IEA) and the social democratic Institute of Community Studies (ICS), promote men's privileged place in the economy - and thus their estrangement from everyday responsibilities in the home - on the grounds that women are better at it, and that if men are expected to be women's equals, they'll skive, or worse, they'll skiddaddle. When it comes to domestic democracy, these political enemies unite. Geoff Dench, at the ICS, takes the pessimistic position shared by the IEA: men won't pay the price of parenting unless they are given a privileged place in the economy and in the home. If they are expected to be equal and they are liberated by free love, they'll do even less. A third approach has been proposed by Amitai Etzioni, the American sociologist and leader of communitarianism. Etzioni was promoted in Britain by Demos director Geoff Mulgan who advises Straw's ministerial group on the family; Etzioni is a proponent of the theory of the "parenting deficit", which argues that the family is falling apart because of the divorce culture and because women are doing what men do, fleeing the nest, going out to work and abandoning children to the drinks cupboard and the television. Evidence shows, however, that divorce merely means that women are leaving men, not their children. Nevertheless, Etzioni is popular among those seeking evidence for their apocalyptic angst about families falling apart, about community and crime. A glance at Britain's time-use and employment statistics shows that men and women live in different time zones. Even when they're at home, they're doing different things, and mothers' entry into employment is still contingent on taking care of everyone. Britain's labour market is polarised between full-time men and part-time mothers. Gershuny reckons that the government's family agenda is not only "grossly old-fashioned" but also "unacceptable", because it does not deal with the deficit between men and women. Despite the dramatic rise in women's paid work, men's domestic work - stable at around 30 minutes a day - hardly changes. Gershuny detects a long-term gender convergence between men and women. Demos imagines that we are almost there. It argues that corporate culture and men are being feminised and that women are being masculinised. But are the genders converging? Among our diarists, no one recognised this. Cleaner and community activist Sue Rickus said, "To be honest, the woman still goes out to work, sees to the children, while the men go out to work, come home and that's that. No, men and women aren't getting more alike. If only!" Kath Webb, who lives with Jack Lowe and toddler Callum, agreed. "We have quite a modern relationship, but Jack is a breadwinner and I am a full-time housewife. His job is his job. My job is looking after Callum." Even when they are at home together, they do different things - she always cooks, he always clears up. The premier researcher on time and gender in the US, Arlie Hochschild, argues that something else is happening. Although the genders are changing and the pressure towards equality is coming from women, the genders may still be living different lives. Hochschild is an academic in California, where the divorce rate is 60%. "Divorce has utterly different consequences for men and women. It reasserts the gender divide." After divorce, women do even more everyday childcare (as well as everything else). They often do all of it - in Britain, 40% of divorced men lose all contact with their children. According to Hochschild, divorce has become a "central fact of marital life that is leading to gender differences". Men and women may become simultaneously more alike and more estranged. Western women may find themselves preferring motherhood supported by the sisterhood of friends and relatives than a precarious alliance with a father. She does not see a parenting deficit among fathers and mothers so much as a "care deficit" caused by the withdrawal of the welfare state, particularly in the US and the UK - and the ones who are losing out are children, the elderly, patients recovering from surgery, or schizophrenics abandoned to unwelcoming communities. "The state has become a deadbeat dad," says Hochschild. Nowhere in the world offers an optimistic prognosis. Even in Sweden, the west's model of social solidarity and equality, the provision in the 90s of paid parental leave available for both mothers and fathers to share during children's early years has yielded little change - fathers took up only 11.5% of the paid leave. In Britain, those fathers who strive for a better balance between home and work have no champions other than the women they live with, and certainly none in political society. Yet many men "have a more advanced and less traditional gender ideology than their lives would suggest". fields.headline: Richard Nixon, Andy Warhol (Vote McGovern), 1972
fields.trailText: · View the work online
fields.body:
· View the work online

Artist: Andy Warhol (1928-87), the son of Andrej and Julia Warhola, immigrants to the US from Ruthenia, now part of Slovakia, near the Ukrainian border. Warhol's father worked in construction and mining, and his mother encouraged the sickly, shy child to draw. After training at Pittsburgh's Carnegie Institute of Technology, he went to New York and established himself as a commercial artist. After some tentative attempts at painting pop imagery, he had an exhibition in Los Angeles in 1962 that consisted of 32 paintings of cans of Campbell's soup. The rest is history.

Subject: Richard Milhous Nixon (1913-94), the Californian Republican who had the most broken-backed career in American politics. Chosen by Eisenhower as his running mate in 1952, he was considered a successful vice president, yet his subsequent campaign for president in 1960 ended in narrow defeat by John F Kennedy. Hence perhaps Nixon's desperation to cling to office after he was finally elected in 1968.

His achievements - ending US involvement in Vietnam, for instance - are overshadowed by the events of the 1972 presidential election campaign, in which he sought re-election against the Democrat George McGovern. Nixon won by one of the widest margins in American history, but sinister circumstances surrounded a break-in at the offices of the Democratic National Committee. An investigation by the Washington Post linked the burglary to the Committee to Re-elect the President. Nixon himself denied involvement. But he kept tapes of his meetings, and when these were demanded by the investigation, they revealed his part in concealing the break-in. He resigned in August 1974 to avoid impeachment. In the strangest twist of all, in his final years he was partially rehabilitated as an elder statesman.

Distinguishing features: As a relic of a moment in American history associated with chicanery and paranoia, this is a bold assertion that truth lies on the surface. When Warhol made a screenprint to be sold in aid of the Democrats' presidential bid, he chose to do a portrait not of McGovern but of his opponent. Warhol's poster image of Nixon is not even a caricature; it is a portrait, derived from a photograph, not distorting Nixon's features except through colour. Nixon's face is acidic green, colliding shockingly with an orange background, almost like classical Indian art in its chromatic intensity. It captures the way Nixon in the flesh looked like a cartoon, his head too big for his body. But that's all in the way of satire.

This is the opposite of the classic political cartoon in which the artist riffs on someone's features until they become ludicrous exaggerations. Warhol does not feel the need to distort his subject - he merely has to show him. This says: "The facts are looking you in the face. What more do you need? This is Nixon. Vote McGovern."

Given the secret undercurrent of American public life revealed in the Watergate tapes, Warhol's portrayal is uncanny. This image, which ought to be seen alongside Warhol's portraits of Jackie Kennedy as a Mater Dolorosa, reflects the diminution of American democracy after the murders of the Kennedys and Martin Luther King. Warhol was a Catholic and this image is not political but religious. By making Nixon's face a lurid green, he implies the president is diabolic. Warhol wants to show us evil abroad in the land: Nixon is a devil.

Voters evidently failed to see what was before their eyes, even though Warhol's print added to the Democrats' campaign funds, reputedly by more than $40,000.

Inspirations and influences: Another pop artist who intervened in politics was Richard Hamilton, whose painting of Hugh Gaitskell as a Famous Monster of Filmland expresses his support for the Bevanite wing of the Labour party against the right-wing Gaitskell.

Where is it? Century City, Tate Modern, London SE1 (020-7887 8008), until April 29.

webTitle: Julie Burchill: Give me some truth

fields.headline: Give me some truth
fields.trailText: What Popstars demonstrates is that success in showbusiness has very little to with with having 'It', and much to do with wanting it.
fields.body:
Like the other 10 million smartest people in the country, I've been glued to the TV for the past month of Saturday evenings witnessing the joy that is Popstars. But unlike most of the other 10 million - and certainly unlike most of those over the age of 40 featured in the latest Who's Who, I'll wager - I am a hardcore case.

Not only do I watch it, but I tape it, watch it over again, make everyone who comes to the door watch it - and then I log on to the Popstars website for a couple of hours of rigorous debate on subjects such as "MYLEENE AND THE MIXED RACE SHOWBIZ SCHISM" and "HAYLEY EVETTS - THE GOD THAT FAILED".

I love Popstars for many reasons - Nigel's Tiller Boy coarseness, Kym's cleavage, the fact that Jim Davidson is on the other side - but one of the main reasons I like it is that, by watching it, I feel that I am striking an active blow against noncy middle-class ideas about "quality" television; and, indeed, on a grander international scale, about ideas of creativity and enlightenment.

After years of being your run-of-the-mill media ponce who believes that art and culture are necessarily good things and that being able to write a good book is automatically more desirable than knowing how to unblock drains, say, I now find myself growing increasingly impatient with the whole fetid, self-adoring circle jerk that is the creative process. We are supposed to dislike docusoaps on the grounds that they are brain candy, but the words pot and kettle do come very quickly to mind here. Do we really believe that we learn more about the human condition from the latest adaptation of a snooty old Nancy Mitford novel than we do from Big Brother?

It is the big lie of the creative industries that "fiction is a lie which tells us the truth about life". But it doesn't; it simply tells us how a sex-obsessed old bigot felt in the 50s (Take A Girl Like You) or how a sour old spinster felt in the 18th century (Pride And Prejudice). And then there's the fact that televising a book remains as silly and illogical as miming a sculpture or dancing a painting. (People do, of course, sing plays - we call it opera, posssibly the dumbest thing human beings can do with their clothes on.)

Good docusoaps, from The Family to Popstars, take us way beyond their immediate concerns into the realms of the truly profound. Popstars artistically (Myleene playing Coldplay's Trouble over film of the judges going to deliver their final verdicts) and emotionally (Kym's parents!) batters the hell out of fictions about the Muse Biz, be they parochial TV productions such as A Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star or big-budget Hollywood films such as Almost Famous (in which singing along to an, ahem, Elton John song on the tour bus is presented as some sort of epiphany; only if you're Gary Barlow, I'd have thought).

It also speaks volumes in a handful of images that leave even the great novelists in the dust. One can grasp more about the dynamics of mother/son devotion from watching Noel and his mother embracing than one can from the whole twisted, tortuous text of Sons And Lovers; ditto about the triumphs and tribulations of multi-culturalism from seeing Danny in the kitchen, this huge young black man surrounded by his tiny, adoring white female household, than you could ever get from White Teeth, gorgeous as it is. And devoted to Diary Of A Nobody as I am, there has simply been no comic creation in any work of fiction, ever, who can make us feel the horror, amazement and pure molten glee that Darius Danesh evoked last month.

The clever, sensitive side of me likes docusoaps for those reasons. And the stubborn, immature side of me likes them because they annoy actors so much! Docusoaps, which make people "famous" for being themselves, blur beautifully the boundaries between "civilians" (to use Scab Hurley's lovely term) and nobodies, between "deserved" fame and undeserved. Because, of course, so many people today, from Peter Mandelson to Carol Vordermann, are famous for being famous, rather than for possessing any real skill. Why are they worth "more", say, than Craig from Big Brother in any other way than a £1,000-a-night call girl working Park Lane is worth more than a King's Cross tart selling £5 hand-jobs?

Just after Big Brother, when Nichola and Caroline were going to lots of parties and getting wildly drunk, they fell on top of Vanessa Feltz at some launch party, bringing her down to the floor in an admittedly unappetising melee. It struck me as being peculiarly poignant when some soap actor I'd never heard of huffed, "It's disgusting that they should try to associate themselves with us in this way; they're not real stars."

But if I've heard of Nichola and Caroline and not him, and as Big Brother pulled in so many more viewers than any of Feltz's pathetic TV efforts, surely Nichola and Caroline were the real stars - on that occasion at least? If we claim otherwise, we move into surreal territory, proposing the existence of "secret" stars and pariah "personalities". The point about "creative" types is, of course, that they are so sorely aware of their own unexceptional talents that pulling up the drawbridge becomes a hysterical reflex. Hence the always amusing sight of the Spices, Steps, S Clubs and Atomic Kittens accusing each other of being "manufactured".

What Popstars demonstrates is that success in showbusiness has very little to do with having "It" and very much to do with wanting it - see Madonna. It also blows the conspiracy of creativity, and the colossal con that in some way actors, writers and directors are doing us this massive honour by illuminating our dull little lives with the blade-true searchlight of their soul mining.

Whereas, in fact, the whole lot of them - from Peter Brook to Kelly Brook - are overgrown children who just cannot get beyond the Let's Pretend stage of life and who couldn't do a useful job to save their lives. A bit like me - but at least I'm hip to the fact!

Who'd want to watch In A Land Of Plenty when they could watch Popstars, or read a novel by Tony Parsons when they could read the lives of Lorna Sage or Dave Pelzer? A moron, that's who. Some sad sack who can't deal with real life and seeks solace with a legion of imaginary friends. Myself, I would rather sit down beside the next old lady I see sitting on a bench and listen to her life story for a couple of hours than read any of the "great" novels of the past 100 years. For truth is not only stranger than fiction, it's a lot more fun.

webTitle: Artist at breaking point with show of destruction

fields.headline: Artist at breaking point with show of destruction
fields.trailText: An artist will today begin destroying all his possessions in the name of art. In a fortnight's time all that Michael Landy, 37, will have left will be a cat named Rats and his girlfriend, the Turner Prize-winning artist Gillian Wearing.
fields.body:
An artist will today begin destroying all his possessions in the name of art.

In a fortnight's time all that Michael Landy, 37, will have left will be a cat named Rats and his girlfriend, the Turner Prize-winning artist Gillian Wearing.

Landy has made a computer inventory of everything he owns, 7,006 objects from odd socks and David Bowie singles to his Saab 900 car.

Each item, including his collection of works by artists such as Tracey Emin and Damien Hirst, will be publicly placed on a conveyer belt in C&A's former store in Oxford Street, central London, and be shredded or granulated so that nothing but particles remain.

Landy said the process would form an exhibition, Break Down, that examined society's romance with consumerism. "It's about the amount of raw material that goes into making objects, and about the lifespan of things. But the title also reflects an emotional break down.

"I see this as the ultimate consumer choice. Once Break Down has finished, a more personal break down will commence - life without my self-defining belongings."
