fields.headline: Rumour hammers Invensys
fields.trailText: There was an edgy feel to trading in the market yesterday. Confused dealers did not know who or what to believe as prices swung around violently in reaction to news both real and imagined.
fields.body:
There was an edgy feel to trading in the market yesterday. Confused dealers did not know who or what to believe as prices swung around violently in reaction to news both real and imagined.

The nervousness was typified by the performances of Invensys, the industrial controls and automation group, and online directory services group, Scoot.com .

Bobbing in and out of positive territory for much the morning session, Invensys's stock price went into a sudden reverse around lunchtime as word spread that investment bank CSFB had cut its profits forecast by 15% and reduced its target price to 140p after a meeting with the company.

This was news to CSFB. "There is no rating change, it [Invensys] is still a buy with a 250p target price," said a CSFB spokeswoman, who confirmed that a meeting with Invensys' corporate communications department had taken place.

Invensys's share price, however, remained 10% below its opening level.

Sources close to Invensys blamed the fall on a knee-jerk reaction to a profits warning from North American outfit Power-One, which competes in the same market as Invensys's soon to be floated power systems division.

There was a further twist. Traders said Merrill Lynch, one of Invensys's brokers, restarted coverage of the company yesterday with a distinctly lukewarm "neutral" rating.

In a note to clients a Merrill analyst was understood to have said thatn, given the amount of strategic and operational change at the company, it was becoming increasingly hard to value its shares. Not a problem nervous investors were having, however. Preferring to sell first and ask questions later, Invensys closed down 16.25p at 163.75p.

Scoot, the punters dream stock, was proving as volatile as ever. Reports that a consortium headed by Richard Li, the billionaire chairman of Hong Kong's PCCW, was ready to offer Vivendi 125p a share for its 22.4% stake as a prelude to a full bid, sent the shares up to 79p early on.

But then came a stock exchange announcement which said that Scoot had not been in contact with Mr Li and knew of no basis for the reports. So, the price came all the way back down to 69.5p.

Yet the punters were not finished. Hearing that Vivendi might use the £1bn it raised through a convertible bond is sue on Thursday to make an offer, Scoot eventually closed 0.5p higher at 71.5p.

In the wider market, the FTSE 100 index closed 41.8 points lower at 6,164.3, undermined by weakness in telecom heavyweights BT and Vodafone. Over the week the blue-chip index shed 92 points.

BT lost 25p to 595p as investors took fright at reports that it has discussed the possibility of an emergency rights issue with shareholers. Meanwhile, Vodafone slipped 9.75p to 216.25p - its lowest close since April 1999 - as institutions sold the stock to make way for Orange, which comes to market next week.

Things would have been a lot worse for the FTSE 100 had BP and Shell not advanced, 8p to 607p and 17p to 601p respectively. Both were benefiting from a firm crude price and in Shell's case positive reaction to Thursday's strong fourth-quarter figures.

Indirectly Shell was also behind the rise in BG, up 7p to 257p. A peak at yesterday's results revealed that Shell is sitting on a cash pile of around £8bn. The gossips say the cash is burning a hole in Shell's pocket and it is going to use it to bid for BG.

Shell has already indicated it plans to use much of the money for a massive share buyback. Indeed, Shell bought back 1m shares on Thursday.

Centrica rose 12p to 247 after a favourable regulatory ruling and a USB Warburg upgrade.

Over in the technology sector, a feeble showing from the Nasdaq at yesterday's opening hit the FTSE Techmark 100 index, which ended 53.38 points weaker at 2,587.95.

webTitle: Faisal Bodi on Islam in British politics

fields.headline: Politics and religions
fields.standfirst:
Special report: religion in the UK
Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Faisal Bodi: One of the conspiracy theories surrounding Diana's death had at least one positive effect. Among British Muslims it triggered a lively debate on the place of religion in our constitution.
fields.body:
When Diana, Princess of Wales, died, one of the more fantastic conspiracy theories doing the rounds in Muslim capitals was that she had been bumped off by British intelligence agents defending the Crown from non-Christian designs.

Since her consort, Dodi al-Fayed, was a Muslim, went the theory, Diana might convert to Islam to marry him and in doing so predispose her two sons, William and Harry, to the faith. That - shock, horror - would have presented the prospect of a Muslim heir to the throne.

Aside from entertainment value, the theory did have one positive effect. Among British Muslims it triggered a lively debate on the place of religion in our constitution. When Muslims talk about constitutional reform we usually mean one thing: disestablishment. But advocates are thin on the ground. Paradoxical as it may sound, most Muslims have so far been content to live under the patronage of an established Church and would be sorry to see it dis-established.

Theologically, we have found justification for second-class coexistence in an eighth-century precedent, when a group of persecuted believers from the nascent community fled Arabia to seek refuge in Abyssinia under a benevolent Christian king. That has released us from the religious requirement to uphold the shariah (the divine law) in its entirety, to a position where we ought to uphold as much of it as is legally possible.

In practical terms, Muslims have viewed the Church's statutory presence in parliament, and the dual responsibility of the monarch as head of the Church of England and head of state, as a valuable anchor tying Britain to its monotheistic past. For smaller faith groups, the Church's weakness has been a source of strength: a church with little more than symbolic political influence has left them free to get on with their own business.

Yet this status quo discourages reform. It locks the Muslim community into a position of disadvantage and second-class status. Look, for example, at the number of Anglican bishops entitled to sit in the Lords. Last year's Wakeham report recognised this privilege, but recommended that it be more evenly spread between the Christian denominations.

Eight minority faiths would benefit by sharing five seats on a rotating basis. This would leave the Muslim community barely better off. Although they form the second largest religious community (estimated conservatively at 1-1.5m), they end up with the same allocation as Jews (300,000) and Buddhists (30-130,000).

The long hand of the Church extends to other areas of parliament. When they assume office, non-Christian peers and MPs must declare their allegiance to its head. Before each sitting, the sole Muslim MP, Mohammad Sarwar, must listen to the inaugural prayer read out by the sergeant at arms. Upon entering and leaving the House, he must also bow towards the Speaker to honour the altar that stood behind his throne in the days when parliament sat in St Stephen's Chapel.

Anglican privilege is also manifested in other areas of life. Two years ago, the government appointed a Muslim adviser to the prison service, the first civil service post dedicated to servicing the needs of the Muslim community. But because the Prison Act does not allow for anyone other than an Anglican chaplain to administer to the spiritual needs of inmates, Maqsood Ahmed has had to be employed by the Chaplaincy Service. So we have the absurd situation whereby the activities of a Muslim chaplain are, in theory, subject to the whims of a Christian chaplaincy.

This grace and favour approach sits uneasily alongside the idea of a modern multi-faith democracy. It sidesteps what is actually needed: a root and branch reordering of the relations between faith groups and the state. fields.bodyText: When Diana, Princess of Wales, died, one of the more fantastic conspiracy theories doing the rounds in Muslim capitals was that she had been bumped off by British intelligence agents defending the Crown from non-Christian designs. Since her consort, Dodi al-Fayed, was a Muslim, went the theory, Diana might convert to Islam to marry him and in doing so predispose her two sons, William and Harry, to the faith. That - shock, horror - would have presented the prospect of a Muslim heir to the throne. Aside from entertainment value, the theory did have one positive effect. Among British Muslims it triggered a lively debate on the place of religion in our constitution. When Muslims talk about constitutional reform we usually mean one thing: disestablishment. But advocates are thin on the ground. Paradoxical as it may sound, most Muslims have so far been content to live under the patronage of an established Church and would be sorry to see it dis-established. Theologically, we have found justification for second-class coexistence in an eighth-century precedent, when a group of persecuted believers from the nascent community fled Arabia to seek refuge in Abyssinia under a benevolent Christian king. That has released us from the religious requirement to uphold the shariah (the divine law) in its entirety, to a position where we ought to uphold as much of it as is legally possible. In practical terms, Muslims have viewed the Church's statutory presence in parliament, and the dual responsibility of the monarch as head of the Church of England and head of state, as a valuable anchor tying Britain to its monotheistic past. For smaller faith groups, the Church's weakness has been a source of strength: a church with little more than symbolic political influence has left them free to get on with their own business. Yet this status quo discourages reform. It locks the Muslim community into a position of disadvantage and second-class status. Look, for example, at the number of Anglican bishops entitled to sit in the Lords. Last year's Wakeham report recognised this privilege, but recommended that it be more evenly spread between the Christian denominations. Eight minority faiths would benefit by sharing five seats on a rotating basis. This would leave the Muslim community barely better off. Although they form the second largest religious community (estimated conservatively at 1-1.5m), they end up with the same allocation as Jews (300,000) and Buddhists (30-130,000). The long hand of the Church extends to other areas of parliament. When they assume office, non-Christian peers and MPs must declare their allegiance to its head. Before each sitting, the sole Muslim MP, Mohammad Sarwar, must listen to the inaugural prayer read out by the sergeant at arms. Upon entering and leaving the House, he must also bow towards the Speaker to honour the altar that stood behind his throne in the days when parliament sat in St Stephen's Chapel. Anglican privilege is also manifested in other areas of life. Two years ago, the government appointed a Muslim adviser to the prison service, the first civil service post dedicated to servicing the needs of the Muslim community. But because the Prison Act does not allow for anyone other than an Anglican chaplain to administer to the spiritual needs of inmates, Maqsood Ahmed has had to be employed by the Chaplaincy Service. webTitle: Barney buy-out boosts Bob's US prospects

fields.headline: Barney buy-out boosts Bob's US prospects
fields.trailText: The firm behind Bob the Builder yesterday claimed that the pre-school favourite's chances of making it as big in the US market as he is in Britain have been given a boost by its £190m acquisition of the Texas based company that owns Barney the purple dinosaur.
fields.body:
The firm behind Bob the Builder yesterday claimed that the pre-school favourite's chances of making it as big in the US market as he is in Britain have been given a boost by its £190m acquisition of the Texas based company that owns Barney the purple dinosaur.

Peter Orton, chief executive of HIT Entertainment, said that the takeover of Lyrick Studios was "a double whammy" that gave the British firm an established US infrastructure through which to sell programming and merchandising, as well as ownership of one of the most popular children's characters on the other side of the Atlantic.

"If you want to be a major player in the US you need to deal direct with the major retailers and Lyrick has strong relationships with all the big players like WalMart and KMart," Mr Orton said.

"Barney is part of every pre-school home in the US and this puts us into play in the biggest market in the world. It sets us on the way to becoming the pre-school Disney that we want to be."

In the past nine years consumers have bought 55m Barney videos, 68m books and 25m soft toys. Barney is broadcast every weekday and at weekends on the US national public service network PBS, which has the highest share of the pre-school television audience in the US.

Analysts welcomed the takeover which will be financed through a mixture of cash and shares. "It's broadly a good deal because it reduces their dependence on the success of Bob and gives them better distribution in the US," said Celia Leaberry, analyst at Deutsche Bank.

UBS Warburg, the investment bank that advised HIT on the takeover, raised £76m in cash by placing shares at 440p each and issued a further £114m worth of shares to the owners of Lyrick, the Leach family.

Dick Leach, Lyrick's 73-year-old founder, will join the board of HIT, although the British company will take over the day-to-day running of its US counterpart. In the 1980s his daughter-in-law, Sheryl Stamps Leach, came up with the idea for Barney as a way of keeping her hyperactive two-year-old son entertained.

The takeover has surprised many industry observers who say that Lyrick has turned down several takeover offers in the past. HIT is now likely to use the deal as a springboard to drive further consolidation in the children's TV market.

HIT shares, which have been suspended since news of a takeover first leaked out, are expected to start trading again on Monday.

webTitle: Crank or campaigner? After ten nail bombs police still cannot decide

fields.headline: Crank or campaigner? After ten nail bombs police still cannot decide
fields.standfirst: Targets range from chip shops to estate agents
fields.trailText: Targets range from chip shops to estate agents
fields.body:
It began when a brown Jiffy bag, packed with nails and ball bearings, was sent to an agricultural suppliers in North Yorkshire. Four similar devices were subsequently defused by army bomb disposal experts and another five exploded leaving three people injured - including a 43-year-old woman, recovering from a heart condition, who was badly hurt.

What was initially dismissed seven weeks ago as a seemingly random act by animal rights activists appears to have escalated into a small-scale bombing campaign, from the midlands to the north, with police from nine forces, M15 and Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist squad rapidly re-assessing earlier theories with the realisation that a more sinister force could be at work. Was this an organised group or a crank in the mould of David Copeland who killed three people and injured 139 in a nail bomb attack on a gay pub in Soho, central London, as well as planting bombs in markets in Brixton and Brick Lane '?

A pest control firm, a pet shop and a farm might fit with previous patterns well-known to Scotland Yard which routinely tracks the activities of disparate groups that make up the animal rights movement. But why a chip shop in North Wales, charity shops in Cumbria and Lancashire, or an estate agency in East Yorkshire?

Significantly, both mainsteam and militant animal rights groups insist that the random and indiscriminate nature of the attacks is self-defeating in their cause. "Why target innocent people?" asked one campaigner. "Why do this when more of the public are raising serious questions about animal welfare. There is just no sense in it."

In North Yorkshire, where police are coordinating the investigation, Assistant Chief Constable Peter Walker, is careful not to jump to instant theories. "The problem here is the randomness and the lack of reasoning," he said. "We can't follow a discreet track. With this kind of thing, it could be one zealot operating on his or her own, or a group."

Nevertheless, some detectives acknowledge that the random nature is a marked departure from the tactics usually employed by extreme animal rights groups; even those people on the extreme fringes tend to target either high-profile laboratories or the property of staff employed by them. Favoured tactics include planting incendiary devices under vehicles - 11 have been placed under the cars of medical researchers in the past eight months - sending threatening letters, blockading roads and premises and protesting outside the homes of people involved in medical research. In a recent incident at Huntingdon, a medical researcher had chemicals sprayed in his eyes by two men in balaclavas.

This is where the bombings break with previous patterns. No group has claimed responsibility. The packages contain no notes. They have been sent through the postal system, across a significant geographical area, making it difficult for police to focus their investigations.

Fearing "copycat" extremists could use the information, the police refuse to supply details of the devices and people targeted have been urged to keep quiet while the investigation continues. But Mr Walker concedes that the internet is an easy source of information.

But while police have an open mind, it is clear that the animal rights lobby is crucial to the investigation - if not as suspects, then as an organisation with a knowledge of disaffected, fringe elements, perhaps former members bearing a grudge who might resort to desperate freelance tactics.

For the nail bomb attacks have coincided with an upsurge in protest by the wider animal rights community, in particular a campaign against the struggling medical research laboratory, Huntingdon Life Sciences (HLS).

The actions of an organisation calling itself Shac, Stop Huntingdon Animal Cruelty, are more typical of the new tactics employed by militants. For the past two years, a coalition of groups and individuals have put a concerted effort into a single, carefully selected target, HLS. The group is led by husband and wife team, Greg Avery and Heather James, both veterans of the movement, who run the campaign from websites and newsletters. They claim to have a 10,000-strong database of willing volunteers, two of whom have been jailed for threatening HLS employees.

Avery accepts that Shac have stepped up their campaign, dedicated to closing HLS within three years. He acknowledges that some activists may use methods, such as incendiary devices under cars, as a method of protest. But he is adamant that the nail bombs are not the work of animal rights activists.

"This has nothing whatsoever to do with the animal rights movement," he insists. "Look at the targets. They're a bit strange. You'd think if someone was going to risk a jail sentence that they would go for a more hard target, like labs."

He dismissed suggestions that the cause would be damaged if another bomb went off. "The public are more savvy than you think. They won't think animal rights people are doing this."

Others in the animal rights commu nity disagree. Andrew Butler of the People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, (Peta), the largest animal rights group in the world, conceded that the 10 latest targets were a mystery but said that there were legitimate reasons for police to suspect extreme animal rights activists: "These nail bombs have certainly raised awareness in general. As far as these and other violent actions go, it is a consequence of being ignored by the government, industry and scientists."

While rejecting violence, Mr Butler says the home secretary, Jack Straw, has not helped matters. "He stands up in parliament and legitimises businesses like HLS and says he will pass laws to crack down on animal rights protesters. Some people are bound to become jaded when this happens. They are going to turn to other extreme methods."

So the one bond uniting the disparate elements of the movement is opposition to the government's increasingly hard line in which they see science taking precedence over the rights of animals. They are angered that ministers have taken on board the scientific community's case for legislation to crack down on demonstrations, such as those directed at HLS, with more powers to stem the protests taking place outside researchers' homes.

The scientific case is pushed by the Research Defence Society (RDS). It has the support of a number of MPs, including the former prime minister, John Major, who is MP for Huntington. Last week in the Commons he backed the second reading of the criminal justice and police bill, which embraces the stronger powers.

He said:"The animal rights movement is not composed wholly of peaceful protesters - far from it." He added that there was "what I can only call ... an anarchist minority using the tactics of urban terrorism. One day is they continue to act as they have been doing, someone will be killed".

In the context of the latest bombings, this is no idle claim. Mark Matfield, a director of the RDS, says they suspect the attacks are the work of animal rights extremists, whatever the protestations to the contrary. He views the bombing as a sinister turn in tactics. "This campaign is the most worrying to date," he says. "They are somewhat maverick and the targeting is ad hoc. These people seem totally unconcerned if employees, or even children get injured. It would seem to suggest that we are dealing with a lone crank."

This view is shared by Keith Ashcroft, a forensic psychologist who has worked with police on criminal profiling, the art of matching a crime to a particular individual who might be on Scotland Yard's data base. "Judging from the indiscriminate nature of these bombings, this looks like the work of a disorganised criminal or possibly someone who is mentally ill, suffering from delusions," he says. "These types of people are the hardest to pin down."

Whoever is responsible, police are in no doubt of the link between the 10 bombings. "If you are a charity worker you don't expect to receive a nail bomb in the post," says Mr Walker. "These people could have been more seriously injured. All the devices have been potentially lethal."

Janet Blythe, aged 43, who works at an estate agents in Patrington, East Yorkshire, can testify to that. She suffers from a heart condition and sustained serious injuries to her face and eyes when she opened a Jiffy bag in the morning mail on January 5. Thankfully, others so far have had luckier escapes.

fields.headline: Persimmon plight
fields.trailText: Persimmon shareholders might be asking themselves just what they have bought.
fields.body:
Persimmon shareholders might be asking themselves just what they have bought.

Yesterday, Beazer, which Persimmon agreed to acquire for £559m last month, reported an 18% drop in profits in the six months to December 31, blaming weak sales in the summer period.

The figures surprised analysts who expected a better performance from Beazer given the good market conditions rival housebuilders have been reporting.

Stephen Rawlinson, analyst at Peel Hunt, doubts whether Beazer will now be able to meet profits forecasts for the full year.

"While the company claims that it will be able to meet its objectives to June 2001, we think that they are probably deluding themselves."

He expects Persimmon shares to remain below the 300p mark because of the Beazer figures.

Last night they stood at 282p, after falling 18.5p yesterday.

Persimmon shareholders have a chance to vote on the takeover on February 21.

fields.headline: When the joke's on you
fields.trailText: I was at the Channel 4 parliamentary awards the other day (it's shown at 8.05pm tonight) and mused once again on why famous politicians laugh so heartily at rude gags against them.
fields.body:
I was at the Channel 4 parliamentary awards the other day (it's shown at 8.05pm tonight) and mused once again on why famous politicians laugh so heartily at rude gags against them. For years I've assumed it's because they are desperate to be thought jolly good sports, able to take a joke at their own expense, marvellously well-rounded human beings underneath that rather pompous carapace. So I watched as the likes of Ann Widdecombe and Gordon Brown threw back their heads in delight when people made jokes about her figure, or his tight-fistedness.

Then the nominations for political humorist of the year came up (I have now been shortlisted unsuccessfully in four awards over the past 12 months, which may be a record. In 15 years or so they'll give me a special Lifetime's Failure gong.) Linda Smith, one of the most popular regulars on the News Quiz, had been filmed talking about me. "He is the best possible chairman of the News Quiz we could have ... " she said, and my little heart glowed. " ... in his price range," she added, to hilarity from the guests.

Then something disturbing happened. Instead of thinking that she had spoiled a nice compliment, I felt a sense of quiet pride. Someone somewhere thought I was worth being rude about. On television! Me! A camera crew had to be assembled, lighting engineers were put on the case, a sound man fiddled with a little throat mike, a director murmered "are we rolling, Darren?" all so that I could be mildly and humorously insulted in front of one or two million people tonight.

In that alarming moment, I think I understood something about politicians which I should have twigged in the 24 years during which I have been writing about them.

Later in the day I was standing outside the Press Complaints Commission party, along with a small wet crowd of sightseers who hoped for a glimpse of Prince William, plus a few people who had invitations but were being held back because "royalty's leaving". The reason I was there was that a colleague had given me his invitation, but it turned out he hadn't replied, and to get in you needed an admission card. So being in a weak position anyway, and unwilling to face further public humiliation, I decided to push off home. As I walked across Waterloo Bridge, I thought what a very F-list thing I had been about to try to do.

A-list celebrities are the likes of royalty, David Beckham, Madonna, the prime minister. The B-list includes lesser footballers, TV presenters, actors who are on TV quite a lot and second rank politicians. I am at F, which is I believe, the lowest possible level. As and Bs go on Clive Anderson and Michael Parkinson, Cs and Ds appear on popular daytime TV shows, and us F's are invited to turn up on Grampian's popular Hunt My Slipper, with Lulu and that bloke who's sometimes on Rab C. Nesbitt (I've made that up).

A to Ds get fat cheques for addressing black-tie dinners. On the F list you get an invite from provincial chartered surveyors' associations. ("While we cannot offer a fee, we can promise you a very jolly evening, plus reasonable travel expenses.")

When you're on the F-list, small boys ask for your autograph, then peer at it and ask each other, "who izzee?" As and Bs are lent gorgeous clothing and cars in the hopes that they'll be seen in them; Fs are sent pocket diaries with, mysteriously, the phone numbers of London clubs listed inside. As to Ds go to the kind of bash where they have velvet ropes and heavy security to protect the other As inside. On the F-list you go to the launch of books which you would never dream of reading.

I 've been fascinated by the arguments in the Guardian letters page about Eminem, and the lyrics of his hit, Stan. The weird thing seems to me that we're supposed to believe that Stan, a deranged fan, sits down and writes a letter to his hero, Eminem, who then sits down with a pen and a piece of paper and actually writes back to him - though too late to stop him locking his girlfriend in the boot and driving off the bridge. Since when did anyone under the age of 30 write a letter, except to a kindly relative after Christmas? I'm sure there's a text message for: "im gng t kll grlfrnd & cmmtt scde".

The other interesting element in the track is the "sampling" of the song Thank You, by Dido, a singer who is herself English posh totty. Her CD is top of the charts here and has already sold more than 2m copies in America. So the American part is about some weirdo who cannot face life and needs to destroy others to resolve his anguish. The British section is quite the opposite. Thank You is about a young woman waking up with a hangover on a cold, wet day. Then she sees a picture of her boyfriend, and decides things aren't quite so bad. In the next verse she's late for work, but he phones her and she decides again that "it's not so bad, not so bad."

Thus the American message is that life should be perfect, or else it's intolerable. The British message is "mustn't grumble". No wonder that the song has such resonance on both sides of the Atlantic.

I felt very old the other night. We went to a concert to celebrate some anniversary or other of Eel Pie island, which is in the river Thames nearish to where we live. There used to be a hotel there, and groups such as The Who and the Rolling Stones played there in their early days, which is partly why so many of them settled in the neighbourhood.

The hotel burned down in mysterious circumstances ages ago, so the concert was in a council property on the Middlesex bank instead. I enjoyed the Downliners Sect, whom you may very vaguely remember, and the Yardbirds looked promising - though there was such appalling feedback during their set that you could scarcely pick out the tunes. Everyone looked remarkably old, as did most of the audience. Most eerie of all was, that although the bar had done terrific trade, almost nobody was dancing.

Then something disturbing happened. Instead of thinking that she had spoiled a nice compliment, I felt a sense of quiet pride. Someone somewhere thought I was worth being rude about. On television! Me! A camera crew had to be assembled, lighting engineers were put on the case, a sound man fiddled with a little throat mike, a director murmered "are we rolling, Darren?" all so that I could be mildly and humorously insulted in front of one or two million people tonight. In that alarming moment, I think I understood something about politicians which I should have twigged in the 24 years during which I have been writing about them. Later in the day I was standing outside the Press Complaints Commission party, along with a small wet crowd of sightseers who hoped for a glimpse of Prince William, plus a few people who had invitations but were being held back because "royalty's leaving". The reason I was there was that a colleague had given me his invitation, but it turned out he hadn't replied, and to get in you needed an admission card. So being in a weak position anyway, and unwilling to face further public humiliation, I decided to push off home. As I walked across Waterloo Bridge, I thought what a very F-list thing I had been about to try to do. A-list celebrities are the likes of royalty, David Beckham, Madonna, the prime minister. The B-list includes lesser footballers, TV presenters, actors who are on TV quite a lot and second rank politicians. I am at F, which is I believe, the lowest possible level. As and Bs go on Clive Anderson and Michael Parkinson, Cs and Ds appear on popular daytime TV shows, and us F's are invited to turn up on Grampian's popular Hunt My Slipper, with Lulu and that bloke who's sometimes on Rab C. Nesbitt (I've made that up). A to Ds get fat cheques for addressing black-tie dinners. On the F list you get an invite from provincial chartered surveyors' associations. ("While we cannot offer a fee, we can promise you a very jolly evening, plus reasonable travel expenses.") When you're on the F-list, small boys ask for your autograph, then peer at it and ask each other, "who izzee?" As and Bs are lent gorgeous clothing and cars in the hopes that they'll be seen in them; Fs are sent pocket diaries with, mysteriously, the phone numbers of London clubs listed inside. As to Ds go to the kind of bash where they have velvet ropes and heavy security to protect the other As inside. On the F-list you go to the launch of books which you would never dream of reading. I 've been fascinated by the arguments in the Guardian letters page about Eminem, and the lyrics of his hit, Stan. The weird thing seems to me that we're supposed to believe that Stan, a deranged fan, sits down and writes a letter to his hero, Eminem, who then sits down with a pen and a piece of paper and actually writes back to him - though too late to stop him locking his girlfriend in the boot and driving off the bridge. Since when did anyone under the age of 30 write a letter, except to a kindly relative after Christmas? I'm sure there's a text message for: "im gng t kll grlfrnd & cmmtt scde". The other interesting element in the track is the "sampling" of the song Thank You, by Dido, a singer who is herself English posh totty. Her CD is top of the charts here and has already sold more than 2m copies in America. So the American part is about some weirdo who cannot face life and needs to destroy others to resolve his anguish. The British section is quite the opposite. Thank You is about a young woman waking up with a hangover on a cold, wet day. Then she sees a picture of her boyfriend, and decides things aren't quite so bad. In the next verse she's late for work, but he phones her and she decides again that "it's not so bad, not so bad." Thus the American message is that life should be perfect, or else it's intolerable. The British message is "mustn't grumble". No wonder that the song has such resonance on both sides of the Atlantic. I felt very old the other night. We went to a concert to celebrate some anniversary or other of Eel Pie island, which is in the river Thames nearish to where we live. There used to be a hotel there, and groups such as The Who and the Rolling Stones played there in their early days, which is partly why so many of them settled in the neighbourhood. The hotel burned down in mysterious circumstances ages ago, so the concert was in a council property on the Middlesex bank instead. I enjoyed the Downliners Sect, whom you may very vaguely remember, and the Yardbirds looked promising - though there was such appalling feedback during their set that you could scarcely pick out the tunes. Everyone looked remarkably old, as did most of the audience. Most eerie of all was, that although the bar had done terrific trade, almost nobody was dancing.

fields.headline: At this price?  Dawson
fields.trailText: Are shares in clothing group Dawson International as plush as its cashmere cardigans?
fields.body:
Are shares in clothing group Dawson International as plush as its cashmere cardigans?

This was the question for analysts yesterday as the Scottish company announced takeover talks had ended but that it is expecting profits, before tax and exceptionals, to double to £8.2m when announced in March.

The shares fell 4p to 58.5p after Dawson said discussions with investor Guiness Peat Group, which began last October, have not led to a firm proposal.

GPG, which holds 21.3% of Dawson, had indicated it would be interested in making a cash offer of 85p per share, but more than four months later, nothing had materialised.

"To avoid the continuing uncertainties caused by the GPG approach, the boards of Dawson and GPG have agreed to terminate discussions," Dawson said.

The City never really believed GPG would bid, with some analysts saying the investor's aim was to flush out an offer from a third party.

"We are now getting back to building the business and developing the Ballantyne brand," said Dawson chief executive Paul Munn.

However, developing Ballantyne - a range of cashmere clothes particularly popular with Italian men - and taking the company forward might not be straightforward.

Dawson hopes to turn the traditional brand into something more fashionable, but the jury is out on whether it will succeed. The company looks like it has had a good year, according to what it said yesterday, and the loss-making parts of the business - such as Pringle knitwear - have been sold.

"These results reflect a strong performance from all of Dawson's cashmere activities," the company said. But, there are no details of exceptionals so results in March could yet yield some surprises. Hold until it is more apparent how Dawson has been doing over the past year.

webTitle: Colombian death squads target British volunteers

fields.headline: Colombian death squads target British volunteers
fields.standfirst: Gunmen threaten workers from international aid groups as president tries to halt slide towards civil war
fields.trailText: Gunmen threaten workers from international aid groups as president tries to halt slide towards civil war.
fields.body:
Rightwing death squads have threatened to kill members of an international human rights group which includes British volunteers working in some of the most dangerous regions of Colombia.

Paramilitary gunmen have warned members of Peace Brigades International (PBI) that they are now considered a "military objective" because of their work with community groups in the northern town of Barrancabermeja.

PBI teams - which include British, Canadian and Australian volunteers - provide unarmed escorts for community activists, trade unionists and human rights workers who are often targets of the rightwing militias.

Two gunmen burst into the offices of the Popular Women's Organisation (OFP), a local women's group, during a peace demonstration on Wednesday.

Identifying themselves as members of Colombia's largest paramilitary group, the United Self-defence Force of Colombia (AUC), they confiscated mobile phones and a passport belonging to a Swedish PBI volunteer. "From this moment onwards, you are targets," they warned.

OFP runs soup kitchens for war refugees in Barrancabermeja, an industrial town of 200,000 people which has become a battleground for the warring factions.

Once a stronghold of leftwing rebels, the town is now dominated by the paramilitary squads. Guerrillas and paramilitaries rarely confront each other directly, and most of their victims are unarmed civilians accused of collaborating with the other side.

Last year the bloody conflict claimed more than 500 lives in Barrancabermeja. Human rights monitors say most killings are the work of the paramilitaries. "We know that when they make a threat they're not playing around," said Yolanda Becerra, an OFP organiser.

OFP organisers say that they have been targeted for denouncing paramilitary abuses. "They are recruiting boys as young as 12 ... they seduce them with £150, a cellphone and a gun. As women and mothers, we cannot allow this," said Ms Becerra.

"The paramilitaries don't understand that a women's group can have an independent political position. They say that we're a front organisation for the insurgents," she said.

Since the early 1980s PBI has accompanied endangered activists like Ms Becerra in countries around the world. Volunteers have been harassed, mortar-bombed and stabbed, but they are believed to have saved scores of lives.

"We're unarmed, so in terms of protection we depend on the support of the community behind us," said a PBI spokeswoman, Emma Eastwood.

In Barrancabermeja, nine volunteers provide 24-hour accompaniment for the OFP and other local groups.

"The organisations we accompany have been threatened very seriously over the years and are now threatened on a daily basis," said Denise Cauchi, 33, a former journalist and one of four British PBI volunteers in Colombia.

"I wouldn't say you ever get used to [the danger], but there's no time to get carried away by your emotions. There's only time to focus on what you have to do."

Wednesday's death threat came as President Andres Pastrana met the leader of Colombia's largest rebel group in what many saw as a last-ditch attempt to save the country from all-out war.

He travelled to the heart of guerrilla-controlled territory for a two-day meeting with Manuel "Sureshot" Marulanda, commander of the 17,000-strong Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (Farc).

The militias have grown rapidly in recent years, now fielding some 8,000 fighters, and despite government denials, human rights groups say that the militias still receive support from some police and army officers.

Farc has refused to make any concessions or declare a ceasefire. Rebels continue to kidnap civilians and attack villages, even though the government has withdrawn police and troops from an area twice the size of Wales, a condition for negotiations.

Colombians have steadily lost faith in the talks, which have failed to bear fruit and many are calling for a tougher stance against the guerrillas.

"There is an incredibly polarised conflict in Colombia. They're in a situation which could almost be described as a civil war, and in that kind of situation, the civilian population and organisations which defend it tend to get caught up in the crossfire," said Ms Eastwood.

webTitle: Looking into the state of UK plc

fields.headline: Sins of the suits lurk among the exceptionals
fields.standfirst: Ignore the corporate blarney. Results from six of Britain's most powerful companies expose declining profitability
fields.trailText: Ignore the corporate blarney. Results from six of Britain's most powerful companies expose declining profitability.
fields.body:
Thursday was a day to treasure for market anoraks. Six of the most powerful pieces on the corporate chessboard released their financial results, providing a timely insight into the state of the global economy and of UK plc.

The six were AstraZeneca, Barclays, BT, ICI, Shell and Unilever. Together they span the new and old economies, from ice-cream to oil and from overdrafts to ulcer drugs. Each happens to be wholly or partly domiciled in the UK, but this is a function of history and convenience, for each has an international spread of interests.

The results announcements from this big six bore the stamp of investor relations advisers. No surprise there. The job of the analyst is to take a sheet of coarse sandpaper to the coats of varnish and reveal the truth within.

I have no specific interest in the six companies that revealed their varnished truths, aside from a small personal shareholding in Barclays - a hangover from last year's takeover of the Woolwich. So, sandpaper at the ready, I was able to take a gander at their statements unburdened by any prior prejudice.

What struck me first was the vast disparity between the actual profits reported by the six and the profit progression they sought to claim for themselves. In market parlance, I was focusing on actual earnings attributable to shareholders, while the companies were drawing the eye towards their own calculations of "underlying" earnings.

The difference between the two measures is typically made up of two factors - the profits of businesses that have been sold during the accounting period, and exceptional profits or losses. A variety of sins can lurk within the exceptionals line in the accounts, from redundancy and other restructuring costs to losses incurred on asset disposals.

On Thursday exceptionals were the order of the day. The average earnings per share of the six companies fell almost 10% relative to the prior accounting period. The greatest culprit was ICI, which swung from profits in 1999 to losses in 2000. It was not alone: Unilever's EPS slumped 59% and BT's 31%.

BT's day was a disaster. Its shares dropped 9% as the City boggled at the company's limited options for reducing a projected debt burden of a staggering £30bn.

One hopes for their sakes that BT's beleaguered management saw the opprobrium coming. However, the boards of ICI and Unilever might feel miffed at their post results share falls. Both sought to draw attention away from the costs and charges incurred in reshuffling their portfolios. Indeed ICI flagged "headline" earnings growth of 19% and Unilever of 14%.

Management attempts to exclude exceptionals from analysis of their performance is understandable. It might even be forgivable if such charges did not occur so regularly. Each individual exceptional item may strictly be unique, but collectively their recurrence suggests they have become the norm for most mega-corporations.

One indicator of management success on behalf of shareholders is the growth in shareholders funds - that is the value of share subscriptions and of past profits retained within the business. In aggregate, the six companies only grew their shareholders funds by 4% last year - not much to crow about.

Accounting conventions diminish the value of this indicator, for much of the cost of acquisitions - the "goodwill" inherent in a corporate brand - gets written off against shareholders funds. The onus on management is to ensure that the returns generated from these acquisitions justify the initial outlay and goodwill write-offs.

Shell aside, the fortunes of each of the companies will be determined in large part by the success or failure of corporate transactions. Barclays has bought Woolwich, BT has gorged on third-generation mobile licences, Unilever has splashed £18bn on a range of food brands, ICI continues to strip down its portfolio, AstraZeneca is itself the product of a major drugs merger.

Waxing lyrical

The six executive teams waxed with varying degrees of lyricalness about the prospective consequences of corporate action. My award for corporate blarney, however, goes to Matt Barrett, chief executive of Barclays, who skated across "the adoption of value-based goals" to this sign-off: "We have much more to do if we are to achieve our aspiration of being in the top quartile amongst the best in class in the global financial services industry."

None spoke optimistically about the underlying operating environment, although Shell probably felt it politically sensitive to point out that crude oil prices can go down as well as up.

The most telling statement on the industrial economy came from ICI, which told the market that "sales in January 2001 recovered from December levels and were broadly in line with January 2000". What global growth?

The overwhelming impression the big six gave was of work still to do - again, Shell aside. "Focus" remains the in vogue management mantra. Each company is trying to keep many plates spinning, but has decided that it is easier to perform this feat if the plates on their sticks can be clustered close together in similar product lines.

With the world economy slowing and inflation still negligible, profits growth will be hard to come by this year. Throw in the corporate bets that they have made and it would be astonishing if all six of the management teams survive the year intact.

 Edmond Warner is chief executive of Old Mutual Securities

fields.headline: Anne Lindbergh
fields.standfirst: Shy intellectual whose marriage to a famous aviator turned her life upside down
fields.trailText: Shy intellectual whose marriage to a famous aviator turned her life upside down.
fields.body:
Fame came to Anne Morrow Lindbergh, who has died aged 94, through marriage to the pioneer pilot Charles Lindbergh. He became the world's most celebrated man for making the first solo flight across the Atlantic in 1927. But fame brought her misery, then tragedy, then infamy, only transcended by her own, highly-praised, writing career.

She said early on that she wanted to marry "a hero" and got her chance on holiday in Mexico City, where her father was US ambassador. It was only seven months after "Lucky Lindy" had landed in Paris and Lindbergh was present as a family guest. Anne was immediately struck. Their first date was in an aeroplane, which Charles flew over Long Island. On the second date, he proposed. Anne, who was studying at university and looking forward to a quiet, intellectual life, hesitated for weeks before accepting.

She later wrote: "The man I was to marry believed in me and what I could do, and consequently I found I could do more than I realised, even in that mysterious outer world that fascinated me but seemed unattainable. He opened the door to 'real life,' and though it frightened me, it also beckoned. I had to go."

Her husband taught her to fly and they made air trips around the world together. She also wrote 13 books, several of them bestsellers, and one, Gift From the Sea in 1955, discussed the plight of women and anticipated much of what Betty Friedan wrote in The Feminine Mystique eight years later. But Anne was also at the tragic centre of the infamous Lindbergh kidnapping in 1932, when the couple's first-born, Charles Jr, was snatched and held to ransom, though already murdered. A carpenter, Bruno Hauptmann, was executed for the crime in 1936, but his guilt is still controversial.

Anne then became embroiled in the charges of anti-semitism and pro-Nazi sentiments that engulfed her husband in the late 1930s and 40s, as both joined the American isolationist movement. Despite a muddled book she wrote in support of their views - it was described by a biographer of her husband as "one of the most despised books of its day" - recent evidence suggests that she was less enthused than Charles, and thought he might be making a grave mistake.

Finally, after a gap of 15 years, she began writing again, and was largely forgiven for her pre-war views, which she recanted anyway during a period in which she published well-received volumes of diaries and letters. Her husband died in 1974 and she stopped writing in 1980. In 1991 she suffered the first of a series of debilitating strokes and kept to her house in Vermont.

Although her husband was a Minnesota farm boy, Anne was born into an upper-class family in New Jersey. Her father, Dwight Whitney Morrow was a senator and partner in JP Morgan. Her mother, Elizabeth, was a poet and educator, and on the board of Smith University. Anne followed her there in 1924 to study English.

After meeting Lindbergh, Anne, a diminutive, shy young woman, was hurled into the maelstrom of fame and publicity that surrounded "Lindy". The press besieged them constantly, and the barrage was one reason they took to the air so often. On Easter morning 1930, they broke the speed record from Los Angeles to New York, taking 15 hours. Anne was seven months pregnant, but wrote: "I couldn't complain. It would prove I'm a weak woman."

After the birth of their doomed son, the publicity became unbearable, and she later blamed it for the kidnapping. When their second son, Jon, was born in 1935, reporters sideswiped the Lindbergh car and wrenched open a door to photograph the boy. The Lindberghs immediately fled to England, where another child was born in London.

Her first book, North to the Orient, was published in 1937 and became a bestseller. It related their flight to China via Canada and Alaska, a heroic deed in those days. Another aviation book, Listen! The Wind, came out in 1938 and was praised as a "small work of art".

But Charles was now getting involved in dubious politics. During their time in London and Paris, they had visited Germany, where Charles was impressed by the aircraft industry. Anne was not present in 1938 at a "stag" dinner at the US Embassy in Berlin, when Hermann Goering, Hitler's air minister, presented Lindbergh with a medal. After the dinner, Charles showed the box to his wife. She opened it, glanced inside and looked away. Then she said without emotion, 'the Albatross'."It was a prophetic remark.

Denounced in America over the medal, the Lindberghs even thought of moving to Berlin. Then in 1941, Lindbergh made a speech in Iowa saying that the "Jewish race" in America was clamouring for war. He was denounced by a Roosevelt cabinet member as "the number one Nazi fellow-traveller."

In her isolationist book, The Wave of the Future, Anne Lindbergh condemned Nazi tyranny but argued that it was unstoppable, the future, and - in a howler that must rank among the world's worst - described Hitler as "not greedy for power". Later she reflected that Charles's 1941 speech might have been an "unconscious bid" for leadership in anti-Jewish politics, but she never wrote an autobiography or analysed that period in detail.

She is survived by a daughter and three sons.

 Anne Spencer Morrow Lindbergh, writer and aviator, born June 22 1906; died February 7 2001.

She also wrote 13 books, several of them bestsellers, and one, Gift From the Sea in 1955, discussed the plight of women and anticipated much of what Betty Friedan wrote in The Feminine Mystique eight years later. But Anne was also at the tragic centre of the infamous Lindbergh kidnapping in 1932, when the couple's first-born, Charles Jr, was snatched and held to ransom, though already murdered. A carpenter, Bruno Hauptmann, was executed for the crime in 1936, but his guilt is still controversial. Anne then became embroiled in the charges of anti-semitism and pro-Nazi sentiments that engulfed her husband in the late 1930s and 40s, as both joined the American isolationist movement. Despite a muddled book she wrote in support of their views - it was described by a biographer of her husband as "one of the most despised books of its day" - recent evidence suggests that she was less enthused than Charles, and thought he might be making a grave mistake. Finally, after a gap of 15 years, she began writing again, and was largely forgiven for her pre-war views, which she recanted anyway during a period in which she published well-received volumes of diaries and letters. Her husband died in 1974 and she stopped writing in 1980. In 1991 she suffered the first of a series of debilitating strokes and kept to her house in Vermont. Although her husband was a Minnesota farm boy, Anne was born into an upper-class family in New Jersey. Her father, Dwight Whitney Morrow was a senator and partner in JP Morgan. Her mother, Elizabeth, was a poet and educator, and on the board of Smith University. Anne followed her there in 1924 to study English. After meeting Lindbergh, Anne, a diminutive, shy young woman, was hurled into the maelstrom of fame and publicity that surrounded "Lindy". The press besieged them constantly, and the barrage was one reason they took to the air so often. On Easter morning 1930, they broke the speed record from Los Angeles to New York, taking 15 hours. Anne was seven months pregnant, but wrote: "I couldn't complain. It would prove I'm a weak woman." After the birth of their doomed son, the publicity became unbearable, and she later blamed it for the kidnapping. When their second son, Jon, was born in 1935, reporters sideswiped the Lindbergh car and wrenched open a door to photograph the boy. The Lindberghs immediately fled to England, where another child was born in London. Her first book, North to the Orient, was published in 1937 and became a bestseller. It related their flight to China via Canada and Alaska, a heroic deed in those days. Another aviation book, Listen! The Wind, came out in 1938 and was praised as a "small work of art". But Charles was now getting involved in dubious politics. During their time in London and Paris, they had visited Germany, where Charles was impressed by the aircraft industry. Anne was not present in 1938 at a "stag" dinner at the US Embassy in Berlin, when Hermann Goering, Hitler's air minister, presented Lindbergh with a medal. After the dinner, Charles showed the box to his wife. She opened it, glanced inside and looked away. Then she said without emotion, 'the Albatross'."It was a prophetic remark. Denounced in America over the medal, the Lindberghs even thought of moving to Berlin. Then in 1941, Lindbergh made a speech in Iowa saying that the "Jewish race" in America was clamouring for war. He was denounced by a Roosevelt cabinet member as "the number one Nazi fellow-traveller." In her isolationist book, The Wave of the Future, Anne Lindbergh condemned Nazi tyranny but argued that it was unstoppable, the future, and - in a howler that must rank among the world's worst - described Hitler as "not greedy for power". Later she reflected that Charles's 1941 speech might have been an "unconscious bid" for leadership in anti-Jewish politics, but she never wrote an autobiography or analysed that period in detail. She is survived by a daughter and three sons.  Anne Spencer Morrow Lindbergh, writer and aviator, born June 22 1906; died February 7 2001.

fields.headline: Canada to investigate embassy 'sex slaves'
fields.trailText: Canada's foreign minister, John Manley, is to investigate allegations that diplomats have smuggled children into Canada to work in their embassies as sex slaves and domestic helpers.
fields.body:
Canada's foreign minister, John Manley, is to investigate allegations that diplomats have smuggled children into Canada to work in their embassies as sex slaves and domestic helpers.

The allegations were raised in the House of Commons on Thursday by the opposition MP Monte Solberg, who said they were based on a newspaper column that quoted an unnamed government source describing how Canadian officials had turned a blind eye to the problem.

The source did not provide details, or say which embassies were involved.

"Officials are accused of covering up several cases of foreign diplomats smuggling children into Canada, abusing them as underpaid embassy domestics, and sexually assaulting them," Mr Solberg told the Commons.

Mr Manley has been under considerable pressure to crack down on the foreign diplomats posted to Canada's capital after an apparently drunk Russian envoy, Andrei Knyazev, drove his car on to a sidewalk, killing one woman and seriously injuring another.

The Russian diplomat refused to face criminal charges, claiming diplomatic immunity, and has since left the country.

Mr Knyazev, it turns out, had been stopped by police for drunk driving in 1999, but was never prosecuted. In fact, the Canadian government sent him a letter of apology because police had handcuffed him.

Mr Manley has already launched an investigation into the incident, and said he will broaden it to include inquiries into child sex slaves.

fields.headline: Leslie Edwards
fields.standfirst: A great 20th-century British dancer who helped lay the foundations of the Royal Ballet
fields.trailText: A great 20th-century British dancer who helped lay the foundations of the Royal Ballet.
fields.body:
In a programme note for his last appearance on stage at Covent Garden in November 1993, Dame Ninette de Valois wrote: "If ever a member were ever to be called 'legendary' in the Royal Ballet it should certainly be Leslie Edwards."

Edwards, who has died of cancer at the age of 84, was a pioneer dancer of the Royal Ballet who served the company as an outstanding dancer actor for more than 60 years.

He appeared in more than 70 different roles; was ballet master to the Royal Opera for 20 years; and for 26 years was, most significantly, the guiding spirit behind the Royal Ballet's Choreographic Group. He epitomised the loyalty, integrity, professionalism and sense of duty which characterised those pioneer dancers of the 1930s and enabled them to build the foundation on which Britain's national ballet was to rest.

Born in Teddington, at the age of 16 Edwards was sent by his then teacher, Marie Rambert, to Ninette de Valois at Sadler's Wells because she "needed an extra boy" - in those days they always needed an extra boy. He joined the Vic-Wells (now Royal) Ballet in 1933 and, except for a brief return to Rambert, remained ever after. He undertook an enormous range of roles and was in nearly all the early ballets of de Valois and Ashton, and Ashton continued to create for him right up to Enigma Variations (1968) in which, as Basil Nevinson, he sat quietly playing his cello - not only with the Royal Ballet but also, later, as a guest with Birmingham Royal Ballet.

He also, of course, appeared in the great classics: Hilarion in Giselle, a sympathetic Benno, the Prince's friend, in Le Lac des Cygnes and, most famously, Catalabutte in Sleeping Beauty. As this courtly master of ceremonies, he was the first British dancer to acknowledge the enormous ovation which came after the curtain rose, on Oliver Messel's setting and the assembled court at the old Metropolitan Opera House, when the Sadler's Wells Ballet conquered New York.

Edwards was one of the loyal team who saw the company through the privations of the war (his war service was cut short when he was invalided out in 1943), years of constant touring, food rationing, air raids and blackouts, thus enabling it to remain intact and ready to meet the challenge of reopening the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, in 1946.

It was during the second world war that he began to establish his special gift - his unerring sense of theatre - in mime roles. He had learned from Tamara Karsavina and Olga Preobrajenska, but he put his stamp on his creations. As the diabolic magician Archimago in Ashton's The Quest (1943) and as the beggar in Robert Helpmann's Miracle in the Gorbals (1944), rootling among the dustbins with his violin, he proved himself an actor of uncanny power.

From these roles he moved easily to the comedy of an ebullient foxtrotter in Facade, to the obsequious Arthur in the Ashton/Berners/Gertrude Stein A Wedding Bouquet and later, the rosy-cheeked, blustering Farmer Thomas which he created in Ashton's La Fille mal gardée.

Edwards worked with choreographers as distinct as de Valois, Ashton, Helpmann, Andrée Howard, Léonide Massine, Bronislava Nijinska, John Cranko, and Kenneth MacMillan. He was the first Escalus in MacMillan's Romeo and Juliet, making a compelling entrance down a long flight of stairs and displaying, as he delighted to be told, a most elegant pair of legs.

This wide experience of choreography stood him in good stead when he came to help and encourage the young hopefuls of the Choreographic Group. He recognised early the gifts of such artists as Geoffrey Cauley, Ronald Hynd, Wayne Eagling, David Bintley, Michael Corder, Jonathan Burrows, Matthew Hawkins and many, many others.

Edwards had known the hard times of the company's history - the immensely successful (and profitable) coast-to-coast tours of America in the 1950s were gruelling - as well as the good, and he never forgot the economies which had to be made in the early 1930s. I have an affectionate memory of travelling back from Birmingham on a Sunday morning with Leslie and a designer friend. "Let's update to a Weekend First," we suggested. Leslie was adamant. "No," he said firmly. "Miss Baylis would not have liked it."

Edwards received the OBE for services to dance in 1975; the Queen Elizabeth II Coronation award of the Royal Academy of Dancing in 1984; and the Lorenzo il Magnifico prize for dance in 1991. A studio was named for him in the rebuilt Sadler's Wells theatre.

 Leslie Edwards, dancer, born August 6 1916; died February 8 2001.

fields.headline: Indian dynasty aghast at £1bn 'Rasputin' will
fields.trailText: The heir to one of India's oldest and richest royal families was preparing last night to take legal action after being disinherited from a £1bn fortune, not to mention the world's two largest chandeliers, by his vengeful and politically disapproving mother.
fields.body:
The heir to one of India's oldest and richest royal families was preparing last night to take legal action after being disinherited from a £1bn fortune, not to mention the world's two largest chandeliers, by his vengeful and politically disapproving mother.

The Maharajah of Gwalior discovered yesterday that his mother, Rajmata, who died two weeks ago, aged 82, had left all of the family's priceless treasures - including jewels, dazzling crystals, and numerous properties - to her "Rasputin-like" 81-year-old personal secretary and a number of trusts.

Some 500 of the maharajah's angry retainers immediately besieged the family's Italian palazzo-style palace in the historic town of Gwalior, demanding that the will be amended in his favour.

The maharajah's friends have accused the secretary, Sardar SC Angre, of conspiring to influence the rajmata in her declining years to deprive her son of the estate.

"He was more than just a secretary. I would not go as far as to suggest any physical involvement, but there is no doubt he was extremely influential on her," one family source said last night. "He was a Rasputin-like presence."

The maharajah, Madhavrao Scindia, fell out with his mother in the 1970s when he joined the Congress party. He is now its deputy leader.

The rajmata, meanwhile, became a stalwart of the rightwing Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata party, persecuted by Indira Gandhi but currently in power.

The feud between mother and son was well known, but few had expected it to carry on in death.

In her will, written in 1985, the rajmata said her son had "rendered himself unfit to cremate his mother's dead body".

"Any mother can imagine how painful and agonising it is to disown her only son - but the way my son disowned all that the Scindias stood for in their long struggle in defence of the country left me with no option," she wrote.

In the end the maharajah burned his mother before her will was made public.

The Scindias are one of India's most illustrious princely families: a 19th-century predecessor was one of only five maharajahs awarded a 21-gun salute by the British, in recognition of his status. In the 1857 Indian uprising, the maharajah stayed loyal to the British cause, even though his troops carried out a mutiny.

Last night, attention was focused on the fate of the late rajmata's priceless jewellery collection, hidden in a series of steel cupboards in the family's Italianate Jai Vilas palace.

Its 35 rooms also contain two giant chandeliers, each weighing 3.5 tonnes, as well as a silver bath tub, several moth-eaten stuffed tigers, and a model railway used to carry brandy and cigars around the table after dinner. The chandeliers were only hung after 10 elephants tested the roof.

Mr Angre, who was one of the rajmata's executors, said her assets including land, property, and companies had a value of some £4.5bn. He had personally been gifted two stud farms.

"I have not once but several times walked into the jewellery vault. I have personally helped rajmata prepare the inventory of all the family's movable and immovable assets, which runs into 500 pages. The fortune left behind by the rajmata is fantastic," he declared.

The rajmata also deprived her three daughters of most of their inheritance, leaving them only a few family heirlooms. Most of her jewellery should be exhibited in India's national museum, her will made clear.

webTitle: Anti-immigrant party is a wild card in Australian polls

fields.headline: Anti-immigrant party is a wild card in Australian polls
fields.trailText: She lost her seat at the 1998 federal election, was abandoned in mid-term by all 11 of her Queensland state MPs, and her party, One Nation, was banned in several states for membership and registration irregularities. But Pauline Hanson has defied political obituaries to come back as the wild card in Australia's forthcoming state elections.
fields.body:
She lost her seat at the 1998 federal election, was abandoned in mid-term by all 11 of her Queensland state MPs, and her party, One Nation, was banned in several states for membership and registration irregularities. But Pauline Hanson has defied political obituaries to come back as the wild card in Australia's forthcoming state elections.

One Nation, the scourge of illegal immigrants, welfare programmes for aborigines and global free markets, has been re-registered in time for elections in Western Australia today and Queensland next Saturday. Opinion polls put its support at up to 46% in parts of Western Australia, and 15% in some Queensland seats.

After hitting the headlines with a maiden speech in parliament that attacked Asian immigration and aboriginal welfare programmes in 1996, Ms Hanson, a former fish-and-chip shop owner, formed One Nation in 1997. One million predominantly rural voters backed the party in the 1998 election, attracted by her promise to speak out for the ordinary Australian "battler", neglected by the country's two-party political establishment.

Two-and-a-half years on, Ms Hanson told the Guardian that voters were more disaffected than ever. "Since the last election the GST [goods and services tax] has been imposed, the dairy industry has been deregulated, fuel prices have escalated and illegal boat people are coming in waves to our shores," she said.

Although the party has not held a press conference or issued definite policy statements in the two state campaigns, she was was getting a "fantastic" response from the public on walkabouts One Nation would campaign for "punishment before rehabilitation", and a "fair go" for the "average" Australian in the face of "big business cartels" taking over the country.

The party's vote peaked at 22.7% in the June 1998 election in Queensland, Ms Hanson's home state, but fell below 9% in the federal election four months later. One Nation almost imploded as internal struggles and missing funds triggered mass defections and the creation in Queensland of a rival party, the City Country Alliance.

While certain seats in Western Australia and Queensland are polling strong support for One Nation, collated polls put the party on 5% in WA and 4% in Queensland. One Nation officials concede that they would be happy with a couple of seats in each state.

The Labor party is expected to retain power in Queensland, and the long-serving Liberal premier, Richard Court, is likely to maintain his hold on government in Western Australia. But both governments could lose their overall majorities, leaving One Nation holding the balance of power.

The party also has the opportunity to make its mark in state elections in South Australia, the Northern Territory and Tasmania before the federal election, likely to be called by the prime minister, John Howard, in November.

But Paul Reynolds of Queensland University believes that One Nation's support will fragment, with many voters returning to their traditional party allegiances.

"It's not a disciplined block of voters," he said. "It was a protest vote and they'll spray everywhere. When Ms Hanson met some real opposition and couldn't formulate a policy, the show fell apart in six months."

David Denemark of the University of Western Australia said: "If there's nothing to show at the end of this year's elections, One Nation may disappear. But the issue frustrations will remain. Independents may take up the cause and talk about the forgotten battlers and the bastards in Canberra."

Ms Hanson will stand for a senate seat in the federal election. Observers say that with proportional voting she stands a fair chance of getting a seat.

"Where's the way of life in Australia any more?" she said. "Where's the standard of living? Where are the opportunities? We've got everything here: we have the resources, we have the land, but politicians have just sold us out."

webTitle: Ian Mayes on the look of newspapers

fields.headline: Picture this
fields.standfirst: The readers' editor on... how the look of the newspaper evolves
fields.trailText: The readers' editor on... how the look of the newspaper evolves.
fields.body:
These Open Door columns fall into roughly three categories: one dealing with ethical issues raised by the Guardian's journalism; another addressing your frequently justified protests at our abuse of the English language; and the third describing how various parts of the Guardian work, or answering your questions about technical matters such as Why does the ink come off on your hands? (copies of that column are still dispatched to readers on request).

Columns in the last category - into which this one also falls - often coincide with or anticipate important changes within the Guardian. An example was the column I wrote discussing points you had raised about the paper's coverage in the north of England. I was able to treat the subject with reasonable enthusiasm because in the course of researching it the editor revealed his plans for a special edition, Guardian North, which is now well established. The complaints now are that the edition does not extend over a large enough geographical area.

This week I set out to talk to colleagues about questions you have raised broadly covering aspects of the appearance of the paper, in particular whether the sometimes slack crediting of illustrations implied an undervaluing of the contribution they make to the Guardian. One thing that prompted a sharp response from a reader was the publication of an uncredited image from the distinctive hand of Norman Rockwell, the artist who, perhaps more than any other, delineated the softer side of the American dream. The illustration arrived unidentified from an agency and no one recognised the image, which we credited as a "photograph" where "illustration" would at least have been more accurate.

These things happen. But on the bigger point, of undervaluing illustration, nothing could be farther from the truth. Various forms of illustration, including cartoons, have played an important part in the Guardian since the period following the first world war when David Low joined the paper. There has been a leading political cartoonist on the Guardian since then, among them, Papas, Gibbard, and now, of course, Steve Bell.

A colleague, recently retired, who fought for a real place in the paper for cartoonists and illustrators, from the 1960s onwards, points to the advances in the past decade or a little longer. Bigger papers, the publication of a magazine, and the need to have a change of pace between different types of article, made the use of illustrations, he believes, inevitable.

"The introduction of a bona fide design department staffed by trained designers, rather than just journalists with design flair, brought about major changes whereby illustration became regarded as a vitally important ingredient of a successful Guardian. By the early 90s we were, I think, ahead of any other daily paper in our use of illustration."

To put it in perspective, the Guardian in all its parts uses a total of about 1,600 photographs during an average week, and about 40 cartoons and illustrations. That figure does not include graphics - the charts, diagrams and explanatory drawings that also play an increasingly important part in the paper.

Professional designers were not introduced into the Guardian without resistance. Now there are almost a dozen in the department, seven of them (not all full-time) working on the broadsheet main paper and its tabloid second and third sections.

At the beginning I said these columns looking at the inner workings of the Guardian sometimes coincided with important changes. In this case it is the appointment of the paper's art director, the head of the design department, to a new post as creative director of the paper in which he will be responsible for the entire visual appearance of the Guardian: its typography, use of photography, and all other visual elements, cartoons, illustrations and graphics.

This kind of overview is common on magazines but unusual, to say the least, on broadsheet newspapers, in Britain anyway. It does not mean that the Guardian is about to become a magazine, but it does, in my view, mark a significant development in the cultural changes I have been describing.

In particular the technological changes and the vast expansion of the Guardian accompanying them have altered the role of the picture editor, making it not only possible but necessary that pictures are viewed and selected from an increasing number of screens around the building.

The present picture editor, who has done so much to enhance the paper's reputation for photography and to broaden the range of images presented to the paper's readers, will be concentrating on his own photography. He believes the development is a logical one in which the role of the paper's staff photographers should be enhanced.

As the changes take effect you will let us know what you think.
