webTitle: Adding insult to injury for accident victims

fields.headline: Adding insult to injury for accident victims
fields.standfirst: A £20m advertising campaign by the controversial no-win, no-fee firm Claims Direct is being partly funded by the very people it is aimed at. Phillip Inman discovers who is enduring the pain
fields.trailText: More than a quarter of the costs charged by Claims Direct, the no-win no-fee personal injury firm, result from a TV and radio advertising campaign that has cost up to £20m, it emerged this week.
fields.body:
More than a quarter of the costs charged by Claims Direct, the no-win no-fee personal injury firm, result from a TV and radio advertising campaign that has cost up to £20m, it emerged this week.

The revelation will be seen as another blow to the company which has faced a barrage of criticism for charging excessive costs that in many cases were deducted from successful damages claims - sometimes leaving clients with a fraction of the compensation they were awarded.

Costs amount to more than £1,200 in each case handled by Claims Direct over the past year, during which time it recruited about 60,000 customers. About £340 of that figure can be accounted for by advertising costs, according to figures supplied by advertising analyst AC Neilson. The figures show annual spending on advertising by companies according to the price guide published by media organisations.

Last year the BBC's Watchdog programme highlighted several individual cases of Claims Direct customers who were told that successful damages had been reduced dramatically after costs were deducted. In one case an accident victim received a cheque for £79 despite winning a settlement of £1,500.

This week Claims Direct admitted it was in discussions with the Office of Fair Trading following a further complaint by a customer. It said the company was talking to OFT officials about rewording its marketing literature in the light of the complaint. The Lord Chancellor's department, which oversees the industry, says it is also investigating a complaint against the company, though a spokesman for Claims Direct was unaware of any further complaints.

Claims Direct is not the only personal injury business to launch high-profile advertising campaigns. Another specialist firm, the Accident Group, is understood to be preparing to launch an advertising campaign of a similar size in an effort to drum up business.

The spur for the advertising campaigns are the statistics supplied by one company to the government last year. It said there were 11.2m accidents in the UK each year and more than 2m of the people injured blamed someone else for the accident. At present, only about 350,000 make claims for personal injury. The companies - known as claims management firms - believe the outcome is a potential market of 1.7m additional claims for personal injury each year.

But solicitors' groups, which have suffered while claims management companies have prospered, and insurers believe that attempts to cash in on the growing personal injury market has caused confusion and led costs in the industry to spiral out of con trol. The Law Society, which represents all solicitors in England and Wales, says ministers should sort out the mess.

Law Society chief executive, Janet Paraskeva, says: "The government should consider regulation of claims management companies. They tend to charge very high premiums from which they fund their massive marketing campaigns - the public would be better served going directly to a solicitor, rather than through a middle man."

While there is a feeling that lawyers "would say that wouldn't they", charges for using claims management com panies remains an issue.

Insurers like Norwich Union, the UK's largest, are prepared to fight both solicitors and claims managers when it believes they want to recover exorbitant costs. If their customer is found to have caused an accident then it can either concede that damages should be paid or be forced to pay through the courts.

Peter Graham, the insurer's director of technical claims, says: "I think the principle is fine, that extra costs are incurred where there is extra risk because the case is complicated and might fail and extra time and effort has been put in. But in uncontested cases where we admit liability there is no reason to pay extra costs. And if the industry did just pay it will only increase everyone's insurance premiums unnecessarily."

Mr Graham says Norwich Union is currently contesting a case in which a firm of solicitors asked for damages to be paid, costs, and a success fee of 40%. The case is due to be heard in the Court of Appeal later this year.

"At the moment [the industry] looks like a free for all," he says. "I think sense will prevail in the end. But Claims Direct in particular, which charges the most of all the firms, is going to have some difficulty sustaining its policy at the current price it charges."

Claims Direct is by far the largest company in the field of personal injury in the UK. It was set up in 1995 by Tony Sullman, a former taxi driver. The company floated on the stock market last year at 180p per share giving it a value of over £300m. Adverse publicity appeared in November and by the company's own admission its sales have slumped. Shares are now worth 33.5p. In the first half of last year profits were £10.3m on a turnover of £42.7m.

It started life offering a service for a percentage fee, but switched to a system based on customers being given a loan to take out a so-called after-the-event insurance policy costing £1,312.50.

Accident victims are contacted by a claims assessor who rates thier chances . If it is given a score over 50%, they offer to take the case and ask the claimant to take out the insurance policy. Then the information is passed to solicitors who take over the handling of the case.

If the claim fails and the customer loses, the policy pays for the legal costs incurred by both sides and the premium on the policy. If the claimant wins, the other side pays the premium and the costs.

The trouble is that firms like Norwich Union have refused to play ball and pay the costs and the premium. Claims Direct says it has succeeded in recovering its insurance premium in 100 cases since April 1 last year. Insurers have refused to pay the premium in 500 cases.

April 1 2000 is a significant date because the Access to Justice bill came into effect and legal aid for personal injury claims was abolished. The bill, written by the previous government and enacted by Labour, said the costs of successful claimants should be paid which encouraged solicitors to take on no-win no-fee cases. It failed to outline how much those costs should be or any guidelines that could be used by the courts.

According to a series of statements over the last year by Claims Direct's chief executive Colin Poole, the lack of clarity in the act is the source of his company's problems and made matters worse rather than better.

He has another 40,000 cases in the pipeline dating back to last April and thousands more still unresolved from previous years. The company has set aside £5m to compensate people who are affected by the new law but submitted their claim before it came into effect, and has guaranteed the first £1000 of a claim. The 40,000 taken on since April will not be given compensation, he says.

Instead he intends to mount a series of court actions if agreement cannot be reached with insurers. A spokesman confirmed that between 20 to 30 cases would be launched on behalf of claimants to pursue the costs Claims Direct believes can be fully justified. In answer to the criticism that its costs were inflated by huge marketing costs, the company says they were not out of line "for the kind of company we are or the industry we are in".

The Association of British Insurers is attempting to bring solicitors' groups, representatives of the claims management industry and insurers into discussions to hammer out a deal that might provide a structure all can agree on. Until then, they intend to see each other in court.

fields.headline: Sell while the dust settles
fields.standfirst: Stockbrokers say Abbey's share price will fall as it wrestles with Lloyds TSB. Phillip Inman reports
fields.trailText: Abbey National shareholders should consider selling up before the bank finds itself embroiled in a lengthy takeover battle with Lloyds TSB, stockbrokers advised this week.
fields.body:
Abbey National shareholders should consider selling up before the bank finds itself embroiled in a lengthy takeover battle with Lloyds TSB, stockbrokers advised this week.

The decision by Lloyds TSB to pursue a marriage with Abbey despite two clear rejections by Abbey's board of directors is likely to bring several months of public wrangling. The proposal is also likely to be referred to the Competition Commission, the government watchdog, to decide if the merger breaches competition rules. A rival bid by the Bank of Scotland has already been given the all-clear by the government and the Abbey board wants to accept.

Justin Urqhuart Stewart, of Barclays Stockbrokers, says the Abbey's share price could drift downwards as the banks fight it out. "Over the next few months we are likely to see Lloyds launch a hostile bid which will almost certainly be referred to the competition authorities. Then the shares will go into purdah and probably a gentle decline. I would be happy to take the cash in the current situation."

Jeremy Batstone of NatWest Stockbrokers agrees but says the spur to sell is based on his view that all bank shares are likely to drift down from current highs.

"We are suggesting that investors lock in the gains of the last six months. Institutions are preparing to sell when bond yields pick up, which is predicted to happen in the spring. People shouldn't wait until there is a sell-off, when share prices will inevitably turn down."

Abbey National's share price has doubled since August, though it has yet to reach its 1999 peak. Part of the rise can be attributed to the bid interest which kicked off with the Bank of Scotland in November and then Lloyds TSB in December. Since floation in 1989 the shares have increased by nearly 10 times. Now more than 2m individual shareholders, who hold nearly 40% of the stock, are faced with the dilemma over whether to sell or stick and see if either merger pays off.

The Bank of Scotland deal is a "merger of equals" that fails to include a premium for Abbey shareholders. Instead they are asked to believe that the two banks will grow faster than a combined Abbey/Lloyds bank. Lloyds, by contrast, wants to pay Abbey shareholders just over £13 for each share based on the current value of 1.5 Lloyds shares and 260p cash.

Banking unions want shareholders to reject the Lloyds deal as it relies heavily on job cuts and branch closures. Lloyds believes 9,000 jobs will go along with 300 Abbey branches near existing Lloyds outlets.

fields.headline: Only when I laugh
fields.trailText: Despite all the reports that voters are losing their confidence in it, I scent hope for the poor old beleaguered/embattled NHS.
fields.body:
Despite all the reports that voters are losing their confidence in it, I scent hope for the poor old beleaguered/embattled NHS. Its understaffed wards will very soon ring to the tramp of eager feet as more and more newspapers send star writers to do menial work undercover in hospitals. The Times had an undercover cleaner last week; the Evening Standard shortly before contributed a hospital porter. Michael Portillo, it may be remembered, signalled his conversion to care and compassion by doing a turn as a porter in one of the London hospitals.

It is notable that those who take on these assignments tend to emerge with a far greater respect than before for the overworked, underpaid staff with whom they share their duties. But what is really so heartening is that given the copycat nature of journalism, I expect to see further recruits reporting for work all over the country. AN Wilson, Jeremy Clarkson, Sir Peregrine Worsthorne, Paul Johnson, Lord Rees-Mogg, Nigella and Dominic Lawson... there's a very good chance that one of them will be pushing your trolley next time you go in for an op.

Throughout the Clinton years I usually judged that the good exceeded the bad, though sometimes I felt the bad exceeded the good. His manner of leaving office, and especially the spate of pardons, in some cases where behaviour had seemed unpardonable, inclined me to the darker verdict. But what I had never quite appreciated, until a letter from Washington reached me this week, was the shamefulness of the office trashing which left incoming Republicans wrestling with chewing gum stuck to their desks and deprived many keyboards of the letter W. Now my eyes are opened. "The Hite House, Ashington" the letter began, "Ednesday. Dear Smalleed - As a nespaper riter yourself you ould surely appreciate the oeful effects of this retched day's ork. It explains hy for several eeks I have not found the ords to make any kind of orthhile presidential utterance on such matters as orld affairs, elfare policy, or issues involving omen. Communication with the capital of Russia is difficult; communication with the capital of Poland near impossible hen one cannot employ a. My one hope is that your editor may in these circumstances allo you to quote verbatim my ell-founded vie that Illiam Jefferson Clinton and his ruffianly cre are a crod of icked ankers.

Yours sincerely... etc, etc."

Hich, of course, I feel bound to endorse.

I am sorry to say that some readers have taken offence at my recent assertion, in the context of Captain Dreyfus, that the seaside town of Hartlepool in some way resembles the Ile du Diable in French Guyana (not Guinea, as I unaccountably said) to which Dreyfus was exiled.

I'm afraid I made the mistake of attempting irony, an art form which for some reasons always does badly in newspapers. I shall now make amends, by naming happy, historic, currently humdinging Hartlepool as number 2, to follow enchanting Uttoxeter, in the acclaimed Smallweed collection of Places to Visit This Summer.

Here are just a few of the place's allurements:

 Hartlepool used to be known as The Hartlepools. In those days there was Hartlepool and separate West Hartlepool, making a total of two; now they are merged. The parliamentary seat known as The Hartlepools went Tory in 1959. Could do so again, some say, if local people turn against Peter Mandelson.

 The old sea wall, it appears, is a pretty sight. At one time the town was surrounded by walls, built to keep out the Scottish enemy (Lab, Dunfermline East). The re-creation of a port of Napoleon's day on the old town quay won the accolade of New Tourist attraction of the Year in 1996. The young women of Hartlepool are said to be hardy. "The sight of hordes of Hartlepool lasses making their way to prestigious night spots such as Oscar's and Bogart's wine bars wearing one outfit between six of them is not uncommon", according to Michael Russell's Alternative Hartlepool website. The council's site prefers to hold out the chance of discerning individual buildings in Sunderland (18 miles distant) on a fine day.

 * A guide can probably take you to Peter Mandelson's constituency home. Once, asked by a local paper which treasure he'd rescue from his house if it caught fire, Pete replied: my Hartlepool FC supporters' club scarf.

 West Hartlepool has a rugby union team which used to play in National League first division but is now in the second division, where it isn't doing too well. Its record this season: played 17, lost 17, points for, 169, points against 794. That makes an average loss per game of 10-46. This on Smallweed's (usually fallible) calculations is even worse than that of the post-Macpherson-demoralisation Metropolitan Police team in London division 2 - played 15, lost 15, points for 118, points against 521, average loss 8-35. I fear relegation looms, to North division 1 where the lads will find themselves playing against Driffield and Hull Ionians.

A lawyer writes: I hope Smallweed is not launching a snide attack on Driffield. Watch it, OK? Thank you, that will be 50 guineas. Or in your case, 50 guyanas.

Smallweed responds with saintly patience: Very well. I'll do Driffield next.

And finally, here are some rugby results: Old Keynesians 8, Old Malthusians 8. Old Mandelsonians 5, Old Vegetarians 6. Old Reprobates 20, Old Curmudgeons 5. Old Sectarians 28, Old Theologians 0. Old Sabbatarians 13, Old Thessalonians 14. Old Predestinarians v Old Valetudinarians: following failure of Old Valetudinarians to muster a team, Old Predestinarians win on a walkover.

Later: match declared void. The Old Predestinarians, aware that the Old Valetudinarians were predestined not to muster a team, did not show up either, and were therefore disqualified.

An Old Theologian writes : How come the Predestinarians failed to spot that they would be disqualified if they went absent?

Smallweed roughly retorts : Enough of the metaphysics, lad. No wonder your side got thumped.

But what I had never quite appreciated, until a letter from Washington reached me this week, was the shamefulness of the office trashing which left incoming Republicans wrestling with chewing gum stuck to their desks and deprived many keyboards of the letter W. Now my eyes are opened. "The Hite House, Ashington" the letter began, "Ednesday. Dear Smalleed - As a nespaper riter yourself you ould surely appreciate the oeful effects of this retched day's ork. It explains hy for several eeks I have not found the ords to make any kind of orthhile presidential utterance on such matters as orld affairs, elfare policy, or issues involving omen. Communication with the capital of Russia is difficult; communication with the capital of Poland near impossible hen one cannot employ a. My one hope is that your editor may in these circumstances allo you to quote verbatim my ell-founded vie that Illiam Jefferson Clinton and his ruffianly cre are a crod of icked ankers. Yours sincerely... etc, etc." Hich, of course, I feel bound to endorse. I am sorry to say that some readers have taken offence at my recent assertion, in the context of Captain Dreyfus, that the seaside town of Hartlepool in some way resembles the Ile du Diable in French Guyana (not Guinea, as I unaccountably said) to which Dreyfus was exiled. I'm afraid I made the mistake of attempting irony, an art form which for some reasons always does badly in newspapers. The Old Predestinarians, aware that the Old Valetudinarians were predestined not to muster a team, did not show up either, and were therefore disqualified. An Old Theologian writes : How come the Predestinarians failed to spot that they would be disqualified if they went absent? Smallweed roughly retorts : Enough of the metaphysics, lad. fields.headline: Mortgages head for bargain bins
fields.standfirst: Costs of home loans are nearing their lowest level in a generation, reports Patrick Collinson
fields.trailText: Don't accept a mortgage offer unless the rate is 5.25% or below. That was the message this week from mortgage brokers after the first cut in Bank of England base rate for two years.
fields.body:
Don't accept a mortgage offer unless the rate is 5.25% or below. That was the message this week from mortgage brokers after the first cut in Bank of England base rate for two years.

The Halifax instantly cut its standard variable rate from 7.74% to 7.5%, although many other lenders have cheaper standard rates, as the table below shows. But new borrowers and people remortgaging can enjoy even lower rates by opting for discount and fixed rate deals, which can bring the "pay rate" down to as little as 4.77%. Check out the panel op posite for the best deals currently available.

The cost of a mortgage is now heading to the lowest levels in a generation, as City economists predicted that this week's cut is just the first of several to come this year. City money markets are already projecting another two 0.25% cuts in bank base rate by this summer, taking the Bank of England rate to 5.25%.

A £100,000 mortgage that cost more than £1,200 a month in payments in 1990 now costs as little as £600 per month and is likely to fall to just £550 a month by midsummer. But to obtain such rock-bottom rates, borrowers need to switch between lenders regularly and remortgage into the best deals.

Beyond summer, interest rates are projected to rise again, with the money markets pencilling in a rise back towards 5.75% in Bank of England base rate by the end of 2002.

New borrowers therefore face a dilemma. Should they take a discount, with the aim of riding rates down over the coming months, or should they opt for a longer-term fix to avoid the forecast upswing in rates next year?

Currently discount mortgages are the overwhelmingly popular choice, with around 65% of home buyers opting for them. Typically, they have offered 1.5%-2% off a lender's standard variable rate and with this week's rate cut, their benefits firmly kicked in.

For example, Abbey National has a two-year discount loan which cuts 2.25% off the bank's (relatively high) variable rate. With this week's rate cut, the pay rate fell from 5.49% to 5.24%. A further two 0.25% rate cuts may see the pay rate fall to just 4.75%.

But there is a caveat. The discounted rate only moves down if the lender's standard variable rate shifts downward. In the last cycle of interest rate movements, the big lenders initially matched the Bank of England cuts with similar ones of their own. But later cuts were met with resistance by Halifax and Abbey National, which began lopping off just 0.1% for each 0.25% fall in base rate, saying they had to protect savings rates instead.

The alternative to discounts is a fixed rate mortgage. Ray Boulger, at mortgage broker John Charcol, says that although they have been spurned by borrowers recently, they are an attractive option again and leave home buyers with the comfort of knowing exactly how much they have to pay every month. Five-year fixes topped out at around 7.2% in 1999 but are now down to around 5.8% and falling fast.

He says: "You could see five-year fixed rates down at around 5% later this year. That's when you should snap them up immediately." Meanwhile, two-year fixes have fallen below 5% in many cases.

Borrowers should insist on a mortgage which has no overhanging penalties which stop you from switching to another lender when the discount or fixed period runs out. There is nothing to stop home buyers becoming "serial remortgagers", saving thousands by playing a cat and mouse game with lenders and keeping their pay rate permanently below the standard variable rate.

The Guardian Guide to Remortgaging your Home is available free on 0800 694 6444

webTitle: Thriving Berlin pestered by boom town rats

fields.headline: Thriving Berlin pestered by boom town rats
fields.trailText: John Hooper in Berlin: Last weekend? Funny you should ask. The high point of mine was jousting with a sewer rat. In our flat, there is a room we use to store all sorts of bits and pieces.
fields.body:
Last weekend? Funny you should ask. The high point of mine was jousting with a sewer rat. In our flat, there is a room we use to store all sorts of bits and pieces. On the Friday, I stumbled in to look for something and found a rat scurrying over my feet to cower by the door which gives on to the back stairs.

It was not till the following morning that I felt ready to confront the brute. If it had cowered by the door, I reasoned, then maybe it was as keen as I that it should leave. As I entered the room the rat, disappeared under a shelf. I opened the door to the stairs, then withdrew to let it ponder its options.

Half an hour later, I went back. The rat appeared to have gone, but as I bent down over a duster box, out it sprang, this time clearly up for a fight. I poked it with a broom handle, but it just came back for more. Then, I lanced it straight in the belly, sent it tumbling down stairs and pulled shut the door.

What a way to spend Saturday morning.

All big cities have rats, but in Berlin they are peculiarly visible. I have come across them in the passageway that runs beneath the Charlottenburg S-bahn and, again, at the Hackescher Markt, staring back insolently and refusing to budge.

It turns out that these are very contemporary creatures - reunification rodents.

Karolina Bauer-Dubau is the pest queen of Berlin. She works from an office at the Institute for Tropical Medicine decorated with a large, colourful poster of one of the most disgusting insects I have ever seen. Sitting at a desk littered with tiny bottles filled with dead flies, she explained why the rats of Berlin so often come into contact with the humans.

First, there were the sudden falls in temperature that are characteristic of the weather here. The night the rat got into our flat it was minus 12C.

But the other factor was the fall of the Wall. It made available vast areas of the city for development and turned Berlin into what is often called the world's biggest building site. As the construction workers tear out sewer pipes they dislodge the rats and send them in search of new homes.

All of which is good news only for the Kammerjäger - the "closet hunters". This is the delightful German name for what we prosaically call pest controllers.

Ours has just arrived - a thin young man dressed from head to foot in black. As I write, he is tracing the stinking line of urine and other body fluid left by the rat back to that cosy duster box. It might wish to bring its friends and family.

Dr Bauer-Dubau reckoned there would be a colony nearby.

"Of about how many?" I asked, as casually as possible.

"Oh, up to 60," she said. And smiled prettily.

webTitle: Russia wary as Bush orders defence review

fields.headline: Russia wary as Bush orders defence review
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Russia
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Russia and the United States traded hostile rhetoric yesterday as security and intelligence chiefs in both countries abandoned the past decade's talk of partnership.
fields.byline: Ian Traynor in Moscow  and Julian Borger  in Washington
fields.body:
Russia and the United States traded hostile rhetoric yesterday as security and intelligence chiefs in both countries abandoned the past decade's talk of partnership.

The White House ordered the most comprehensive defence review since the cold war and a senior Moscow analyst warned of "an acute and all-embracing crisis" in relations between the US and Russia.

The Russian foreign ministry issued a statement attacking the head of the CIA, George Tenet, who told the US congress this week that Russia under President Vladimir Putin had embarked on a whole series of moves inimical to US interests.

Mr Tenet's remarks followed an angry performance by Sergei Ivanov, Mr Putin's closest aide, in Munich last weekend, in which Mr Ivanov warned the west against profiteering in demanding debt repayments from Russia.

Mr Ivanov, secretary of Russia's security council, accused Nato of triggering a Chernobyl-type disaster in its 1999 war against Yugoslavia, and threatened an arms race if the Bush administration pushed ahead with its controversial plans for a national anti-missile defence shield.

But Washington signalled its resolve to push ahead with the National Missile Defence project. Mr Bush said he had asked the defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, to conduct a "top-to-bottom" review of the military, "reviewing missions, reviewing opportunities for change". Although he made no mention of nuclear weapons, he is expected to order big unilateral cuts in the US nuclear arsenal, in a clear sign that the administration has put its faith in NMD as the mainstay of security.

According to the New York Times, the review could reduce the US nuclear arsenal from the current 7,519 warheads to below the 2,000-2,500 goal agreed by the US and Russia in strategic arms reduction talks in 1997.

The proposed cuts, laid out last year by the Bush presidential campaign, are intended as a "sweetener" to persuade Russia, China and Washington's Nato allies to accept US plans to build the the missile shield.

While Moscow is keen to slash nuclear arsenals, it is wary of moves which could herald an easier passage internationally for the "son of star wars" programme. In Munich, Mr Ivanov's speech contained little new substance, reiterating the Kremlin's opposition to NMD and Nato expansion. But its aggrieved tone was much more anti-western than is usually heard from senior Russians at a western conference.

The Bush and Putin administrations are still sizing one another up, but relations between them have got off to a bad start, with the Russians feeling they have been gratuitously snubbed by the US.

Mr Rumsfeld attended the same Munich conference on international security as Mr Ivanov but refused to meet him. "Rumsfeld did not meet Ivanov so as to avoid a serious discussion on strategic issues," said Sergei Rogov, director of Moscow's USA-Canada Institute. "He sees Russia as less important and so he met Nato ministers and ignored Ivanov."

While Mr Bush's proposed missile shield is the central point of division, Washington and Moscow are at odds on a number of issues. Mr Tenet told Congress that Russia was cultivating China, India and Iran through arms sales to diminish US influence, and was pressuring its former Soviet neighbours for similar reasons. The US state department said Russia was deploying economic and political weapons to beat the independent media into submission.

"There can be little doubt that Putin wants to restore some aspects of the Soviet past... sometimes at the expense of neighbouring states or the civil rights of Russians," Mr Tenet said.

The accelerated timing of the US defence shake-up could intensify pressure on Britain and other Nato allies to clarify their position on NMD sooner rather than later. There is concern in Europe that the plan will torpedo the 1972 anti-ballistic missile (ABM) treaty and upset the strategic balance in Europe and Asia.

The New York Times yesterday quoted a senior US official as saying Mr Bush would not declare his intention to withdraw from the ABM treaty, but Mr Rumsfeld has already said the accord is "ancient history".

Russian newspapers yesterday interpreted Mr Tenet's speech as a return to the cold war, and the foreign ministry noted that the CIA chief saw Moscow as a threat rather than a partner.

"He preferred to put the Russian theme in the context of 'threats' to US security rather than of cooperation... in mutually supporting international security," it said.

webTitle: Belgian PM wants Euro-tax which would bypass governments

fields.headline: Belgian PM wants Euro-tax which would bypass governments
fields.standfirst:
Presidency could be used to promote integration

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Presidency could be used to promote integration.
fields.body:
European Union citizens should pay a "Euro-tax" directly to the union, which must become more democratic as it plans its future, the prime minister of Belgium, Guy Verhofstadt, has urged.

As Mr Verhofstadt will chair the EU's rotating presidency from July, his outspokenly federalist comments are bound to be studied closely by Europe's leaders.

In an interview published in a Brussels-based weekly yesterday, he made clear that he would use the Belgian presidency in the second half of this year to promote a radical view of the future of the union; this will set alarm bells ringing among British Eurosceptics.

The liberal prime minister, cultivated as an ally by Tony Blair on economic issues, made no secret of his strongly integrationist approach, which is certain to influence preparations for the next EU treaty review in 2004.

Crucially, Mr Verhofstadt will set the agenda for the so-called inter-governmental conference (IGC) at the Laeken summit in December - although, as president, he will also have to consider the views of other member states.

British officials have said that it would a "disaster" if Belgium has too much influence over what is discussed, especially if there is wide support for making the controversial Charter of Fundamental Rights legally binding.

Alain Gerlache, a spokesman for the Belgian leader, said Mr Verhofstadt's comments were part of the broad debate about the EU, which began last May when the German foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, suggested that the union be given a constitution.

France and Britain have both since made clear they want the EU to remain a club of nation states in which the council of ministers, where the 15 governments cooperate, wields more clout than the supranational European commission.

Mr Verhofstadt was not specific about his most radical proposal, the EU-wide tax, but he said it was the "best solution" to replace the complex contribution system currently in place. "Like everyone pays their local and national taxes, you should have a direct-financing system for the EU," he said yesterday.

Belgium, one of the six founding members of the European Economic Community in 1957, has long been a champion of deeper integration, partly because it is itself so federal that its national identity sometimes seems in doubt.

Mr Verhofstadt's views, however, are bound to upset countries such as Britain, Denmark and Sweden, highly sceptical of more integration at the expense of national sovereignty.

Belgium has also been trying to enhance the role of the 12-member group of finance ministers of the euro-zone, to the irritation of the three euro "outs", which are worried that the forum of all 15 ministers, Ecofin, is being weakened.

"Until now we have seen Europe as an evolutionary process. But when we have geographically re-unified the European continent, I think it is absolutely necessary to have a final debate about what the EU is for - what competences it has and what type of institutions it needs," Mr Verhofstadt told the magazine European Voice.

Britain is playing for time in the great debate about the EU's future, having agreed at last December's Nice summit to hold a new IGC, largely because of German pressure to clarify the "final status" of the EU, and especially the key division of powers between Brussels and member states.

webTitle: Bush disowns Clinton peace proposals for Middle East

fields.headline: Bush disowns Clinton peace proposals for Middle East
fields.standfirst:
Special report: George Bush's America
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israeli tanks pound Palestinian gunmen in the most ferocious clashes for weeks.
fields.body:
Israeli tanks pounded Palestinian gunmen in the most ferocious clashes for weeks yesterday as the Bush administration disowned months of dogged effort by President Bill Clinton to deliver a peace deal in the Middle East.

Yesterday afternoon's gun battle in the West Bank city of Ramallah was a clear message from the field commanders of the Palestinian uprising that the hardline policies of Israel's prime minister-elect, Ariel Sharon, will only reap more violence.

In the Gaza Strip, meanwhile, a teenage shepherd was killed by Israeli tank fire near the Jewish settlement of Kfar Darom. He was the first Palestinian to be killed in the violence that has erupted since Mr Sharon's landslide victory on Tuesday.

Yesterday morning Mr Sharon met the outgoing prime minister, Ehud Barak, to discuss forming a national unity government. Mr Sharon offered Mr Barak the post of defence minister.

However, yesterday's violence overshadowed Mr Sharon's attempts at coalition building and the tentative diplomatic moves by the US and the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, to gauge the true intentions of Israel's most celebrated hardliner.

The Palestinian leader telephoned Mr Sharon yesterday seeking to resume negotiations. "The condition for that is a complete halt to violence," Mr Sharon responded.

All signs point to an escalation in violence, with Mr Sharon confronting a car bomb in an ultra-orthodox Jewish neighbourhood of Jerusalem, sustained firing overnight on the Jewish settlement of Psagot, and gun battles in Ramallah - all within 72 hours of his election.

The other plank of Mr Sharon's peace policy is his refusal to honour Mr Barak's promises on territory and Jerusalem that brought Israel "closer than ever before" to a peace deal with the Palestinians at the Red Sea resort of Taba last month.

The talks were broadly based on proposals put forward by Mr Clinton in his last days of office. But the Bush administration has made it clear that it has scrapped any existing Clinton proposals and has stepped back from the active mediation practised by Mr Clinton .

"The ideas and parameters that were discussed in the last few months are - were - President Clinton's parameters and, therefore, when he left office, they were no longer a US proposal or presidential proposal," the state department spokesman, Richard Boucher, told reporters on Thursday.

However, the US secretary of State, Colin Powell, is to visit Israel and the Palestinian-ruled areas later this month, and Mr Bush telephoned Mr Sharon and Mr Arafat to urge them to calm the region.

Mr Powell's trip - to Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Israel, Gaza and the West Bank, Jordan and Kuwait - will be his first foreign trip alone since he took office on January 20.

Mr Bush told reporters: "I certainly hope that people recognise a change does not necessarily mean that the peace process won't go forward. And I think we ought to take Mr Sharon for his word and that is, he wants to promote peace in the Middle East."

But in Ramallah yesterday demonstrators scattered for cover as Palestinian gunmen holed up in empty tower blocks shot over their heads at Israeli troops on an adjacent hill. Nearly 30 people were injured by live fire and rubber-coated steel bullets. A French photographer, Laurent Van Der Stockt, was shot in the leg.

"There is no chance to negotiate with Sharon, we must stop wasting our time thinking about that," said Marwan Barghouti, a Fatah leader in the West Bank.

webTitle: Donor sleaze scandal deepens for Clintons

fields.headline: Donor sleaze scandal deepens for Clintons
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Suspicions surrounding the last hours of the Clinton administration deepened yesterday after it was revealed that the former wife of the billionaire Marc Rich - pardoned by the outgoing president - had promised to help fund Bill Clinton's presidential library.
fields.body:
Suspicions surrounding the last hours of the Clinton administration deepened yesterday after it was revealed that the former wife of the billionaire Marc Rich - pardoned by the outgoing president - had promised to help fund Bill Clinton's presidential library.

Denise Rich refused to testify to a congressional committee investigating Mr Clinton's last-minute pardon of her former husband, who fled tax evasion and other charges 17 years ago. Ms Rich cited her fifth amendment rights protecting her from self-incrimination but the committee chairman, Dan Burton, has said he might offer her immunity and compel her to testify.

Her lawyers admitted in a response to written questions that Ms Rich had pledged "an enormous amount of money" for the planned Clinton presidential library in Arkansas.

The library donation, coming soon after revelations about Ms Rich's $1.4m contribution to the Democratic party election campaign and her purchase of furniture for the Clintons, has added to the sense of sleaze which accompanied the former first family's departure from office.

Democrats have lined up with Republicans in denouncing the pardon for Mr Rich, who was charged with tax evasion and trading with an enemy nation, Iran, while hostages were being held in Tehran. He now lives in Switzerland.

Eric Holder, the former deputy attorney general, admitted to the House committee on government reform that he had erred when he told the Clinton White House that he was "neutral, leaning toward favourable" about the Rich pardon.

He said he had not known all the facts of the case against Mr Rich, and he denied he had recommended a pardon in the hope of enlisting the help of Mr Rich's lawyer, Jack Quinn, in securing the top job in the justice department if Al Gore won last year's election.

The committee also studied subpoenaed emails exchanged by the Rich legal team in which they discussed tactics to win the pardon. One reported that Mr Clinton told a leading Democratic fundraiser that he "wants to do it and is doing all possible to turn around the WH [White House] counsels".

fields.headline: Predator
fields.trailText: If in Britain nine million cats kill 275 million creatures a year, US cats should, by extrapolation, kill 2,000 million. That would be incredible.
fields.body:
The animal rights people conveniently overlook the cruelty of animals to animals. The number of foxes killed by human hunters with hounds may reach 25,000 a year (10,000 of them by hunters on foot), but this is peanuts compared with the number of animals killed by cats.

The Mammal Society calculates that cats kill approximately 275 million creatures in Britain each year. Admittedly, the cats' victims include creatures that are not generally much mourned, such as worms and moths. But the estimate also includes 200 million mammals and 55 million birds (not to mention 10 million reptiles and amphibians) - this is mass murder on a scale that human beings have not yet dared aspire to. Per head, it is equivalent to wiping out the entire human population of the US each year. Yet most people are sentimental about cats, and do not blame them for this grotesque behaviour.

In fact, cats are generally more popular than dogs as pets, although dogs are far less murderous. In Russia, according to a survey published this month, 10% more people keep cats than dogs. The Russians' preference may have something to do with the fact that many of them are forced to live on low incomes and in miserably cramped conditions. Unlike dogs, cats do not need much spent on their food (or, at least, they shouldn't, given their terrifying efficiency at finding it for themselves). They also do not need taking for walks, which the Russians must find an advantage.

But even in the US, where most people are comparatively rich and spend a lot of their time not merely walking but jogging, cats are also more popular than dogs as pets. Americans own around 64,250,000 cats, as opposed to 62,400,000 dogs. This is a sobering thought when one considers the massacres these American cats must perpetrate. If in Britain nine million cats kill 275 million creatures a year, American cats should, by extrapolation, be killing something like 2,000 million. That would be incredible. Can there really be so many voles and dormice and other little mammals running around the US, or are the Americans merely more generous with the Whiskas?

Dogs, of course, are natural killers, too, which was why mankind decided to cultivate them as friends some 30,000 or more years ago. It was a mutually advantageous relationship. Man was incompetent at hunting, relying on primitive traps and weapons to capture his prey; dogs could chase animals, catch them, and kill them with their jaws. As a reward for bringing home his dinner, man protected the dog, petted him, and lit campfires to keep him warm. The dog has been absurdly grateful ever since.

The point of the cat was far less obvious, since it killed only creatures inedible to man and refused to obey orders. Yet the ancient Egyptians revered cats and mummified them in their tens of thousands. The cat has never shown any sign of gratitude for this, but man has lived on under the delusion that the cat, like the dog, is his friend.

"My cat and dog when I come home/Run out to welcome me;/She, mewing with her tail on end,/While wagging his comes he./Oh, yes, they come - they never fail/To listen for my sighs;/ My poor heart brightens when it meets/The sunshine of their eyes" - so wrote the Victorian poet Ebenezer Elliott, oblivious to their cruel and heartless side.

Man, although he now gets his food from Tescos and McDonald's, still has the hunting instinct in his genes. He still likes to hunt foxes, shoot birds and catch fish. In Britain, he may not be as dedicated a murderer as the cat, but, beside foxes, he annually kills something around 20 million pheasants and other game birds, 312 tonnes of fish, and many thousands of rabbits and hares. The animal rights activists take the view that, as moral beings, humans should repress this unattractive aspect of their nature and not even be allowed to conduct a few animal experiments in laboratories to save their own lives.

It seems strange of them to get so hysterical about this when you consider the far greater slaughter that animals inflict on each other - it may well be dangerous to prevent humans from doing what comes naturally. It could drive many of them to crime, or make them even more cruel than usual to their spouses. We now learn that rabbits are to be excluded from the list of animals that would be protected by the proposed ban on hunting with dogs. This is because the government has suddenly woken up to the folly of criminalising dog-owners whose pets chase rabbits. The owner may be egging the dog on, or he may be urging it to stop; so whom do the animal rights people blame for a rabbit's death? This may be a tricky one, but there is no doubt who is responsible for slaughter carried out by cats. It is cats, and cats alone.

webTitle: Hague changes his mind over pensioners' payment choice

fields.headline: Hague changes his mind over pensioners' payment choice
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: William Hague yesterday performed a spectacular u-turn when he abandoned a flagship Conservative policy that would roll the basic state pension and other "gimmicks", such as free television licences, into one payment.
fields.body:
William Hague yesterday performed a spectacular u-turn when he abandoned a flagship Conservative policy that would roll the basic state pension and other "gimmicks", such as free television licences, into one payment.

Amid fears that Labour will run a general election scare campaign against the Tory plans, central office announced that pensioners would be free to choose how they received their payments.

Pensioners would still be allowed to collect their weekly basic state pensions and receive separate payments for other benefits, such as the winter fuel allowance. Or they could have a consolidated payment, in which everything was rolled into one cheque.

The u-turn came as the Tories made a renewed bid for the "grey" vote yesterday by announcing an extra £100m for pensioners. David Willetts, shadow social security secretary, said an extra 750,000 pensioners would receive free television licenses and winter fuel payments. These included pensioners in nursing homes, those who did not have a television and would receive a cash equivalent television and those who lived abroad.

Central office said the extra cash would not have any impact on Mr Hague's tax and spending plans, because the £100m would come from savings to the working families tax credit announced on Thursday, when Mr Willetts said he would save £100m by denying the credit, which tops up the pay off the less well off and middle income earners, to higher rate tax payers.

He denied that the Tories were rewarding privileged groups. "We will pay a consolidated pension to 220,000 pensioners on income support in residential and nursing homes who are among the very poorest in the country. It also benefits 100,000 pensioners who cannot benefit from the free TV licence because they do not own a TV."

Tory sources denied that their plan to drop a universal payment for the pension and benefits was a u-turn. "We have revised the policy after listening to pensioners," a source said. "This is more like an s-bend."

He added: "Labour ran a very potent scare tactic during the last campaign - which was a lie - that we would scrap the basic pension. We have decided to pre-empt them.They will no doubt have to pulp a lot of leaflets at Millbank."

Labour last night claimed the Tories' changes to the working families tax credit would add an average £150 a year to the tax bill of 116,000 families.

Andrew Smith, chief secretary to the Treasury, said: "Far from being confined to 'more affluent families', this tax rise will affect thousands of hard working families."

webTitle: CJD may rule out young organ donors

fields.headline: CJD may rule out young organ donors
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: Organ donations by young people may have to be restricted to cut the unquantified risk of transmitting variant CJD between patients, according to experts in BSE and its deadly human form.
fields.body:
Organ donations by young people may have to be restricted to cut the unquantified risk of transmitting variant CJD between patients, according to experts in BSE and its deadly human form.

In a scientific paper sure to raise new concerns about the supply of organs for transplants American and British scientists have proposed that some procedures might use tissues only from people over 30. Most known victims of vCJD have been relatively young.

The authors singled out corneal eye transplants as an area where changes might be made, but said that had to be balanced against scaring potential donors and wrecking the whole transplant programme.

The scientists, in an article for the US Centers for Disease Control, outlined the need for Britain to consider new policy moves, such as organ restrictions, as a precaution against transferring vCJD. Controls on blood donation, imports of plasma products, far wider use of disposable surgical instruments and new decontamination procedures have already been introduced or are planned because doctors are worried that a rising number of people have vCJD but have not displayed signs. Eighty-six Britons have died and another eight cases been diagnosed.

Campaigners wishing to encourage organ donations fear the recent body parts controversy at Alder Hey hospital, in Liverpool, has already lengthened the 6,000-strong waiting list for transplants.

The report coincided with a government promise yesterday to review again the safety of vaccines that used material from cattle over the past 30 years, to consider opening up the secret licensing process for medicines and to prepare contingency plans for the consequences of new BSE-like diseases.

But its interim response to the 16 volume report of the Phillips inquiry into BSE, published last October, says many improvements already exist or are underway, including the establishment of an independent food standards agency.

The authors of the new paper include Paul Brown, of the National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, Maryland, a consultant to the European CJD surveillance programme, Robert Will, head of the CJD surveillance unit, Edinburgh, and Ray Bradley, who sits on Seac, the government's main advisory committee on BSE and CJD.

In their report on the background, evolution and concerns about BSE and vCJD, they recognise that "in the absence of a screening test, a zero-risk policy is untenable because it would require termination of the national organ donor programme. A compromise might be the temporary deferral of organ donors - or perhaps only corneal donors - younger than 30 or 40 years of age. However, this measure might so diminish (and panic) the donor population as to be inadvisable."

They added that sound medical practice could not be suspended on the basis of a theoretical risk. Dr Brown, the principal author, told the Guardian, however: "It would be a good idea to talk about it and find out whether or not this would be an acceptable compromise." Restrictions on the use of corneas might be a useful test case since the eyes linked to the brain and were a potentially infective part of the body.

"You would not necessarily accept organs, say, from people who died under a certain age, until we found out more about how risky these are. At the moment we can assume they are either not risky or very low risk. There is a world of difference between the two."

Experts are particularly worried about eye and teeth surgery because of their links to the central nervous system where vCJD strikes. Opticians and dentists have already been warned to change procedures.

The thinking behind restricting corneal donation to older people appears to be the supposition that most victims of vCJD so far have been relatively young. They were most at risk in the mid-80s to early-90s when food safety controls were introduced. Also, unlike other organs such as hearts, lungs or kidneys which deteriorate with age, eyes from far older donors can still be offered. However, many scientists believe they do not know enough about the incubation or infectivity to justify age differentials.

The Department of Health said: "We are not proposing to change our policy on CJD risk grounds at the moment."

fields.headline: A spin too far, says Labour
fields.standfirst:
Ex-minister hits streets as former colleagues denounce Brussels dream

Special report: Peter Mandelson
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson was yesterday cast into the political wilderness by the Labour leadership after the ex-Northern Ireland secretary infuriated former cabinet colleagues by suggesting he should be made a European commissioner.
fields.byline: Nicholas Watt, Michael White, Martin Wainwright  and Ian Black
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson was yesterday cast into the political wilderness by the Labour leadership after the ex-Northern Ireland secretary infuriated former cabinet colleagues by suggesting he should be made a European commissioner.

John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, led the charge when he suggested that the former Northern Ireland secretary was no longer a friend of the Labour party.

In an interview with the BBC Today programme, an impatient Mr Prescott dismissed a series of pro-Mandelson articles in rightwing newspapers yesterday, which were inspired by "friends" of the former minister. "They are hardly friends of the Labour party," Mr Prescott said, in a devastating put-down to Mr Mandelson who prides himself on his impeccable Labour heritage.

"It is all the froth of politics, it doesn't mean a damn," Mr Prescott added. "It is the next steps of this government that people are concerned with, not the next steps of Peter Mandelson."

At the annual Franco-British summit in Cahors an evidently furious Tony Blair ducked all questions about the Mandelson affair - to the evident puzzlement of his host President Jacques Chirac. webTitle: China dreams of new heights in Tibet

fields.headline: China dreams of new heights in Tibet
fields.standfirst: After 50 years of planning and false starts, Beijing announces epic rail project to the roof of the world
fields.trailText: After 50 years of planning and false starts, Beijing announces epic rail project to the roof of the world
fields.byline: John Gittings  in Shanghai and  Steven Morris
fields.body:
The Great Wall of China is regarded as one of the most impressive engineering feats in history. A railway line linking Tibet with the rest of China across some of the most difficult terrain in the world has the potential to match it.

Yesterday it emerged that the Chinese government has given final approval for a line which - if completed - would become one of the most spectacular railways in the world.

To succeed, engineers will have to build huge bridges and viaducts across rivers and glaciers and bore vast tunnels through rock. The final section, which has to climb on to the Tibetan plateau, has been called "next to impossible" by some experts.

There are the daunting problems of building the line on permafrost and on ground which is solid for most of the year but liable to melt in the summer.

Many in the west have greeted the project with cynicism and scepticism. One railway man who has experience of working in Asia said: "It is going to be the most difficult railway engineering project of all time. What do they hope to get from it? They cannot really expect to make a profit out of it. Clearly it is being done for political reasons."

The project is part of what China calls its campaign to "develop the west", including Tibet. Beijing has indicated that it is prepared to make the huge investment needed to improve the living standards of a region officially considered the most "backward" in China.

The railway has been talked about for five decades. Work did eventually start in the 1980s but ground to a halt after 520 miles at Golmud in the neighbouring province of Qinghai. This section has since been upgraded and is the main route for supplies to Tibet which are trucked the rest of the way to Lhasa.

So far the route into Tibet has not been revealed. But after entering the Tibet Autonomous Region, the existing road which the railway is likely to follow passes through the isolated towns of Amdo and Nagqu.

Travellers have described the road as "the roughest and most stunning of journeys" into Tibet. In 1998 it was swept by blizzards which began in September, killing hundreds of thousands of livestock.

Most of the route is extremely sparsely populated. It provides employment for small numbers of semi-nomadic herdsmen and for a few hardened salt and mineral miners. Part of the region was recently hit by a severe earthquake and landslides are frequent.

The logistics of the operation are daunting. Four-fifths of the 700-mile railway will be built at an altitude over 4,000 metres, and more than half will be constructed on permafrost.

Chinese research institutes are said to have been studying the problems of building on permafrost since the 1950s. China claims that "the key technological problems in railway engineering on the frozen earth of the Qinghai-Tibet plateau have by and large been solved".

But experts note that building on permafrost is not always the most difficult aspect of such a project. The Trans-siberian railway has encountered problems recently because parts of the hardened frost on which the lines are laid has begun to melt, possibly because of global warming, causing the track to buckle.

Probably the hardest task will be the sharp climb up to the Tanggulashan range (5,200 metres) - source of the Yangtze and Mekong rivers. A large goods train will struggle to ascend a gradient of more than 3% safely, making the construction of tunnels a necessity.

China has become one of the world's leading railway builders, laying 1,000 miles of track a year. Over the past 20 years its technology has improved vastly. In general it has preferred to develop its own machines rather than import them and has had some success exporting rolling stock.

There are several railway construction bureaux across the country. For such a project two bureaux might team up to do the work. Normally the Chinese prefer to use more manpower and fewer machines - though it is not possible to know how many workers will be needed to complete the line. However many, the work will be very dangerous and lives will probably be lost.

Chris Jackson, deputy editor of Railway Gazette International, said: "It will require very skilful engineering but it not impossible. Ten or 15 years ago the Chinese were using picks and shovels to build their railways. Now they have excellent machinery and resources."

Railway experts across the globe will be watching with interest. Brian Green, technical director of Reading-based GIBB Rail, said: "Getting through the mountain terrain is going to be the biggest challenge, finding the right gradient." But he questioned the economics. "To justify a railway economically you need to get freight traffic through it, perhaps 10m tonnes a year. I can't see that happening."

There are fears that the export to Tibet of China's modern and commercial way of life will dilute the territory's ethnic and religious character. Critics say the line is part of a cynical strategy to reduce the demand for religious and political freedom.

Environmental problems could also be created. The railway will pass through one of the last habitats of the Tibetan Antelope, or chiru. Once seen by 19th century explorers in vast herds, it is the only large mammal, excluding man, endemic to the Tibetan plateau.

Beijing's decision was announced with the full weight of authority of its most senior leaders.

An announcement published yesterday claimed that the line would be "the longest and most elevated railway built on highlands in the world". Feasibility studies and route planning were under way, but the report did not give a starting date for construction. President Jiang Zemin was quoted as saying that the railway was "highly necessary".

According to Premier Zhu Rongji, the railway would "accelerate economic and social development in Tibet... and reinforce unity among various ethnic groups".

Great railway feats

Trans-Siberian railway

The railway linking Moscow and Vladivostok opened in 1904, one of the greatest ever feats of engineering. A parallel line is now in operation. Recently, the gradual melting of the permafrost has caused parts of the track to twist and sink. The 5,773-mile journey takes more than 150 hours.

Canadian Pacific railway

The last spike of the Canadian Pacific railway, linking the Atlantic to the Pacific through tthe Rockies, was hammered home in November 1885. The line was upgraded in the 1980s and 1990s. There are plans to build a fixed rail link between the USA and Alaska.

Andes

British engineers were behind many of the schemes at the turn of the century to build rail links across the Andes. Among the spectacular routes is the Transandine line linking Buenos Aires to Valparaiso. It is not so much the height which is staggering but the steepness of the climb.

Africa

Rhodes's vision of a rail link from the Cape to Cairo has never been achieved. However, there have been remarkable feats of railway engineering in Africa, including the 2,900-mile line from Dar es Salaam in Tanzania to Kapiri Mposshi in Zambia.

Australia

The longest straight stretch of track - 297 miles - is on the Nullabour plain in south Australia. Though the flatness of the countryside made laying track relatively easy, the isolation of the area caused huge logistical difficulties.

webTitle: Fears for missing hostess as body found

fields.headline: Fears for missing hostess as body found
fields.trailText: The seven-month search for missing British hostess Lucie Blackman appeared to have reached a tragic conclusion yesterday with the discovery of a dismembered and decapitated body in a seashore cave.
fields.byline: Jonathan Watts  in Miura and Jamie Wilson
fields.body:
The seven-month search for missing British hostess Lucie Blackman appeared to have reached a tragic conclusion yesterday with the discovery of a dismembered and decapitated body in a seashore cave.

It may take several days to confirm the identity of the victim, however, because the head is encased in concrete and the body badly decomposed.

"We are still unable to confirm the sex or race, but it looks like a woman," said a spokesman for the Tokyo metropolitan police department. "Obviously we want to check dental records, but currently this isn't possible."

Ms Blackman's father, Tim, who spent several months in Japan searching for his daughter, said he was "shattered" by the discovery and was finding it difficult to face up to the possibility that it could be Lucie.

He said he was holding on to the belief that if the body did turn out to be that of his daughter, she probably did not suffer. "Whatever may have happened after she failed to regain consciousness is not something that would have been bad for her, although it has been bad for us," he said.

"At this time we do not have confirmation that it is Lucie - just a lot of arrows pointing in that direction. We will probably have to wait until after the weekend or early next week for more details."

About 100 detectives have been searching for the former British Airways stewardess, 22, from Sevenoaks, Kent, since she went missing on July 1 last year after telling a friend that she was going to the seaside with a client from the bar where she worked.

Since October, the hunt has focused on the coast at Miura, about 40 miles south of Tokyo, where Joji Obara, the prime suspect in Ms Blackman's disappearance, owns a beachside property.

It was in a small secluded cove, almost blocked off on three sides by a steep cliff and thick vegetation, that police found human limbs and later a torso and head yesterday morning. More than a dozen detectives wearing blue tunics and face masks excavated the site behind large blue tarpaulins.

The cove is about two minutes walk along a rocky beach from a flat owned by Mr Obara, 48, who is on trial in one of the most brutal multiple rape cases that Japan has ever seen.

After the wealthy businessman was arrested in October, police found more than 50 videos at his home in Tokyo showing him assaulting drugged women, many of whom were foreign. Victims have testified at the Tokyo district court that they fell unconscious after being offered a spiked drink by Mr Obara at his beachside apartment.

Two weeks ago, prosecutors pressed a new charge of sexual violence resulting in death relating to an Australian woman who died in 1992 after claiming he had drugged her.

The businessman told police he met Lucie at the Casablanca bar where she was working as a hostess to fund a trip round Asia after giving up her job with British Airways. But he denies any involvement in her disappearance.

Japanese police, known for their cautious approach, have questioned Mr Obara about Ms Blackman but have been reluctant to press charges without a body or confession.

Yesterday, many in Japan questioned why it had taken so long for police to find a body. The cove near the Miura marina was supposed to have been thoroughly searched after Mr Obara was seen on the beach with a shovel late at night around the time of Ms Blackman's disappearance.

A caretaker at the apartment told detectives he saw Mr Obara splattered with concrete during the same period.

Local fishermen said the city police mistimed their initial search of the coastland.

"There are nooks and crannies in those caves that are invisible except at low tide," said Chioko Deguchi, a wakame seaweed harvester. "They could easily have missed a hiding place if they searched at any other time of day."

Mr Blackman, 47, a property developer who lives on the Isle of Wight, visited Japan several times to appeal for information about his daughter. Thousands of leaflets bearing a photograph of Lucie were distributed around Tokyo and a £100,000 reward was offered for information leading to her whereabouts.

Mr Blackman said yesterday: "I held a hope in my heart for many weeks that perhaps I would be asked to go to Tokyo and at best bring Lucie home alive, at worst to identify her body. As events are unfolding it would seem the remains uncovered, if it does turn out to be Lucie, are skeletal and the need for identification does not exist."

webTitle: John O'Farrell  on the BSE report

fields.headline: Talking bullocks
fields.standfirst:
No good looking for scapegoats. The Tories had turned them all into cattle pellets

Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: No good looking for scapegoats. The Tories had turned them all into cattle pellets.
fields.body:
Yesterday the government gave its response to the long-awaited inquiry into the BSE crisis. There was incredulity in Whitehall that although Lord Phillips's report stretches to 17 volumes, at no point did he manage to squeeze in the "Mrs Thatcher; mad cow" gag.

As someone who worked on various comedy shows through the late 80s and early 90s, I saw at first hand the grim consequences of BSE. Every day at the Spitting Image offices, two sackloads of unsolicited sketches would arrive from aspiring writers who thought there might be a connection to be made between the phrase "mad cow" and the personality of the then prime minister. Hadn't they noticed that we did that joke seven times in the first show of the series?

Lord Phillips is mildly critical of the last government, saying they were guilty of prevarication and disingenuousness regarding bovine spongiform encephalopathy. "That's easy for you to say," replied the Tories. But in reality his report has been far too timid. The BSE crisis encapsulated everything that was wrong with the last Conservative administration: profit put before public safety, ministerial dithering followed by a clumsy cover-up, all rounded off with a mean-spirited failure to compensate victims.

Successive Tory agriculture ministers tried to pretend there was nothing strange about feeding sheep to cattle because, as everyone knows, cows are naturally carnivorous; it was only the political correctness of loony Labour councils that had forced cows to become vegetarian. Douglas Hogg is currently on safari in Africa, hoping to spot a pack of wildebeest hunting down some poor defenceless lion. The reason that mad cow disease began in the UK is because Mrs Thatcher abolished the health and safety laws that prevented the feeding of raw infected sheep carcasses to dairy cows. She said if it was good enough for her ...

As the cases of BSE steadily increased, the Tories caused instant panic by reassuring consumers that there was absolutely nothing to worry about. John Gummer famously demonstrated the safety of British beef for the cameras by feeding his daughter a beefburger. She only ate it because she was so hungry after a morning spent swimming at the Sellafield health spa. Even the visiting Jacques Chirac was served up a dish of British beef, which he accepted without comment, although he was spotted slipping off to the toilets several times with a bulging serviette.

It was all part of a Conservative strategy to reassure our European partners about the safety of the roast beef of old England. To be fair, they had an uphill task. Every week thousands of tourists would arrive in London, slightly anxious about the effects of mad cow disease. First stop would be the Tower of London where an old man with a big smile and a funny costume would come up to them and say "Hello, I'm a Beefeater!"

"Oh really?" they'd say, backing away slowly, trying not to make eye contact. Then they'd notice he was wearing a skirt and orange stockings and was coming towards them with a big axe. It was soon after this that British beef was banned on the continent. Not just beef, but all related products and every night millions of Britons tuned in to the evening news to see if Moira Stewart could say "bull's semen and bullocks" without cracking a smile.

The European ban on British beef then became another reason to knock the European Union, even though the US had banned the importing of British beef several years before. The Conservatives had reacted swiftly to this, saying, "That's fine, Mr President. Whatever you think's best."

Lord Phillips's report also notes that in the early days there was very little information forthcoming about the risks of BSE. Perhaps this was because the government had already spent its leaflet budget warning everyone about Aids. So all we knew was that if a cow had BSE and was also a heroin addict, it was probably best not to share needles.

Where were the public information films featuring celebrity cows like Ermintrude off the Magic Roundabout? "Hey calves, if a farmer offers you a pellet of recycled sheep, Just Say No!" Where were the health warnings at the bottom of Steakhouse menus? "HM Government Warning. Eating a T-bone steak may cause you to get up from your chair and stagger sideways into the salad cart."

The present government has set up the food standards agency and, unlike its predecessor, has agreed to pay compensation to the victims. For once there is a political issue that is as black and white as a Friesian cow. Labour should be given due credit and the report should have had the courage to say that the Conservatives behaved appallingly.

Instead Lord Phillips opened by saying he would not be looking for scapegoats. But then I suppose he probably wouldn't have found any; the goats all disappeared years ago. The Tories had them converted into cattle feed along with all the sheep.

webTitle: Supreme court justice defies Mugabe threat

fields.headline: Supreme court justice defies Mugabe threat
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: One of Zimbabwe's supreme court justices, Nick McNally, refused to cave in to threats from President Robert Mugabe's government yesterday and announced that he would stay on the bench until his retirement in December.
fields.body:
One of Zimbabwe's supreme court justices, Nick McNally, refused to cave in to threats from President Robert Mugabe's government yesterday and announced that he would stay on the bench until his retirement in December.

Mr Justice McNally, 69, said he would not be bullied into resigning just one week after the Mugabe government forced out Anthony Gubbay, the chief justice of the five-member supreme court.

Mr McNally confirmed that the justice minister, Patrick Chinamasa, urged him to take early retirement yesterday and issued a not-so-veiled threat if he decided to stay.

"I was told very politely and very nicely that I should go - take my leave and go, otherwise anything could happen. It was said very frankly that they didn't want me to come to any harm," he said. "I've been trying to think of a gesture that would be appreciated and not futile... I've decided not to go."

Mr Chinamasa also paid a visit to the supreme court justice, Ahmed Ibrahim. It is not known if he decided to resign.

The Mugabe government is attacking the supreme court because it has reversed some of its policies. In December the court ruled that Mr Mugabe's "fast-track" land seizures were illegal and ordered the police to uphold the rule of law and remove squatters from privately owned farms.

In January, it said that Mr Mugabe could not amend the law to prevent the results of parliamentary elections being challenged on the grounds of violence, intimidation and fraud.

Mr Mugabe, cabinet ministers and the leader of the "war veterans", Chenjerai Hunzvi, have bitterly denounced the supreme court justices, calling them "relics of Rhodesia". It is understood that Mr Mugabe is to appoint a new, more compliant, supreme court.

"[Forcing Chief Justice Gubbay to retire] is a signal to the rest of the world that Zimbabwe's government fears the law and is determined to subvert it," the Zimbabwe Independent newspaper said yesterday.

Harare's efforts to neutralise the courts coincide with its moves to muzzle the country's independent press. Two weeks ago it called for the critical Daily News to be closed down; an explosion then destroyed its printing presses.

Harare's legal community, however, is taking heart at Justice McNally's stand. "It was distressing when Chief Justice Gubbay succumbed to the government's threats. If the chief justice cannot stand up for principle then who can?" one Harare lawyer, who did not want to be named, said.

"That is why the legal community, lawyers both black and white, are so pleased that Justice McNally has decided to stand up for what is right."

webTitle: Virgin's cheap rail tickets leave passengers fuming

fields.headline: Virgin's cheap rail tickets leave passengers fuming
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: What Virgin describes as "the world's biggest rail offer" has caused some of Britain's biggest headaches for travellers seeking half-price tickets on the company's trains.
fields.body:
What Virgin describes as "the world's biggest rail offer" has caused some of Britain's biggest headaches for travellers seeking half-price tickets on the company's trains.

Phone lines have jammed, websites have seized up and queues have wound round station concourses as frustrated customers have tried to take advantage of an offer which means a return journey from Manchester to London could cost as little as £9.

Virgin launched the scheme to woo travellers back to the trains after disruption following the Hatfield crash.

The company concedes there were problems when the offer was launched but says difficulties have been eased as extra staff have been brought in and sales hours extended.

Jock Scott, seeking a London ticket, said he gave up on the Virgin phoneline and failed to get through on the website. "In the end, I went to Piccadilly station in Manchester five minutes before the travel centre closed and managed to pick up my ticket then."

Greg Challis, deputy secretary of the rail users' committee in the north-west, said callers complained both of the difficulty of buying tickets and of problems with weekend travel. "There has been a huge demand and the processes were not put in place to cope with it," he said.

The Virgin spokesman said extra staff had been deployed as soon as the huge demand became clear. "The average wait on the telephone is now four minutes," he said. "We have doubled the number of staff in the call centre and extended the hours from 6.30am to 10.30pm."
