webTitle: Harry and the hankies of blood

fields.headline: Harry and the hankies of blood
fields.trailText: Last night's TV
fields.body:
Once you get past the titles for Timewatch (BBC2), which strangely look like an advert for Waterstone's ("Good reading begins with a W", that sort of thing), you can get quite carried away with the drama of it all.

Through its portrait of John Dillinger, last night's impressively watchable documentary painted a great picture of America in the 1930s. This was a landscape of foreclosing banks, speakeasies on every block, disdain for the authorities, gangsters, molls and mayhem. By following the ascent of Dillinger from his humble beginnings in Indiana to the position of Public Enemy Number One, Timewatch told how, during the Depression, Hollywood's gangsters and their real-life counterparts fulfilled the people's need for folk heroes who were darker and more complex than their morally upright predecessors.

It showed the suave, virile and ruthless archetype made famous by Jimmy Cagney in the movies, indicating that the media follow where society leads, not vice- versa. It also provided proof that reconstructions need not be cringeworthy refuges for duff actors nor superfluous decoration to the thrust of the programme.

As well as presenting this wider, national picture, Timewatch mapped out Dillinger's life - on its own quite fascinating - in scrupulous detail. A number of enthusiastic talking heads added to the programme's strengths, although a couple of professors seemed (like the public and press at the time) inappropriately enamoured of the gangster's escapades.

One talked emotionally of Dillinger crying over an arrested girlfriend and seemed disapproving when mentioning how he was surrounded by parasites (while apparently overlooking his penchant for robbing banks and killing people). All agreed he was handsome, perhaps even more so than "Handsome" Harry Pierrepoint, who taught him everything he knew. He had a magnetism about him, they agreed, which made him irresistible to the public. A real-life movie star gangster. As they delighted in telling of daring escapes, another truth emerged: the good-looking are forgiven a lot. Just ask Jörg Haider.

When he was eventually shot and killed by G-Men, bystanders dipped their handkerchiefs in his blood as souvenirs for their children. We'd like to think we've grown up since then but, really, we're no different. We still take train robbbers and those who attempted to rob De Beers at the Dome to our hearts. Whatever, we still love a baddie.

Office Gossip (BBC1) continues and there's no let-up in the slothful, unfunny turgidity. Neil Stuke continues to reprise his Game On persona, toning it down slightly, Pauline Quirke looks constipated as Jo, and Maxine (Pippa Haywood) ploughs the well-worn furrow of office monster. We know this because she is blonde and wears animal prints. Cheryl, the receptionist, is plain annoying. We know this because she is played by Sarah from EastEnders, though without the caterpillars-for-eyebrows she used to sport.

Slow, obvious, badly written and directed, Office Gossip might be funny were it perkier, bitchier and faster. As it is, it's not really worth telling your friends about. In fact, it's about as fun to share as impetigo.

fields.headline: The king of prints
fields.standfirst: A dyslexic East Ender, he worked as a window cleaner before taking up photography. His iconic images shaped our vision of the 60s and his glamorous personal life has attracted headlines.  Nicholas Wroe  on the ultimate celebrity photographer, who believes fame is meaningless
fields.trailText: A dyslexic East Ender, he worked as a window cleaner before taking up photography. His iconic images shaped our vision of the 60s and his glamorous personal life has attracted headlines. Nicholas Wroe on the ultimate celebrity photographer, who believes fame is meaningless
fields.body:
The leading character in Michelangelo Antonioni's 1966 film Blow-Up, a womanising, Bentley-driving, ineffably cool photographer, was played by David Hemmings. But even before the film was released everyone "knew" it was based on David Bailey. It never really mattered that the photographs used in the film - an intriguing if highly flawed siting of Italian Marxist cinematic theory in swinging London - were in fact taken by Don McCullin.

Or that the Hemmings character was also drawn from the two other members of the East-End photographic triumvirate; Brian Duffy and Terence Donovan. Although it was Hemmings's body that sat astride the model and pushed the camera lens into her face, as far as history is concerned it was David Bailey who launched into what has become the clichéd patter of the fashion studio: "That's great, that's great," he coaxed the supine girl. "Again with the hair. Do that again. C'mon, c'mon. More, much more."

That this image has proved so durable - Mike Myers recently acknowledged its part in the creation of Austin Powers - must be particularly irksome to Bailey, who claims that by the time the film was released the 60s were over; "after 66 it was just media hype". But equally, by that time, he had already taken some of the defining photos of the decade - the unlined face of the young Mick Jagger, the Kray twins playing with their pet snakes, the first supermodel, Jean Shrimpton, emerging from the crowd on a Manhattan street - and had become a household name. All the while his life was being lived as much before the lens as behind it. The tall, skinny, beautiful and posh women he photographed and slept with, among them Shrimpton, provided the template for contemporary cool. By the time he married the French actress Catherine Deneuve in 1967, with Mick Jagger as his best man, he was front-page news. For better or worse it was this incarnation that Antonioni sealed forever on celluloid.

The artist Brian Clarke has known Bailey for 25 years. "The fact that his personal history has become confused with the body of work is not helpful to the understanding of that work. But, I have no hesitation in saying he is one of the great defining photographers of our time." Clarke says what sets him apart, astonishingly for someone who has made a career in the fashion industry, is authenticity. "He has no bullshit and for someone in that world it is almost unique. Of all the famous people I have known, Bailey carries fame with the least sense of burden. He knows it is meaningless and he deals with it on that level. He is neither impressed by fame nor hindered by it."

David Puttnam was Bailey's agent in the mid-60s. Puttnam says: "To his immense credit he hasn't changed at all. He still has all the same strengths and all the same weaknesses he ever had. He genuinely loves photography. He still gets excited by the equipment and the process and the technology as well as the images." Photo historian Martin Harrison worked with Bailey on his huge 1999 retrospective book Archive One and has curated several major exhibitions of his work. "He hates his association with the 60s because he is still working now. Most artists don't want to talk about their old stuff because they are producing new stuff all the time. He is associated with this glamorous 60s thing. But it's not like he took a dive in 69."

Indeed Bailey has been working solidly ever since and has amassed a vast body of work. "But I don't really look at my old stuff and don't really think about it that much," he says. "I made a movie in 1999 [The Intruder] and I've never really seen the finished version on a screen." Instead he throws himself into a dizzying schedule of new projects. Recently a day trip to Helsinki was immediately followed by four days in South Africa. In the previous nine months he had been to New York eight times, LA twice, Japan, India, the Philippines, as well as "many" trips to Spain and France. He also does portrait photography for a prince in Saudi Arabia - "but I always charge more or less the same no matter who they are; once you try and get too clever you get your knickers in a twist" - and says the travel is not too bad because a lot of it is on private planes. But most of his work is done in London anyway, although 85% is for overseas consumption.

This has been the routine for 40 years, and the result is not only some of the finest fashion and portrait photography of the period, but also nearly 500 commercials - the current one for Orange mobile phones showing hands imprinted with orange squares is his - books, documentaries, exhibitions and films. As far back as 1966 he directed a film, GG Passion, about a rock star being hounded to death by his fans - it was partly funded by Roman Polanski, who also introduced him to Catherine Deneuve - and as recently as 1999 he directed a low budget, noirish thriller, The Intruder, staring Nastassja Kinski and Charlotte Gainsbourg

Brian Clarke says there is no mystery as to why, now aged 63, Bailey keeps going so hard: "He's an artist. Artists always keep going." Indeed, despite working throughout his career in a profoundly commercial arena, he has been respected as an artist almost from the beginning. There was a full-scale exhibition of his work in the National Portrait Gallery as far back as 1971, and the V&A has also held a major show. The NPG first bought his work in 1972 - a portrait of Julie Christie - and in 1988 commissioned him to photograph Princess Diana. Bailey acknowledges the irony in this: as a child, "photography was something you did once a year on Margate Beach".

He was born in Leytonstone 1938 in the next street to where one of his heroes, Alfred Hitchcock, was born. He's always said that his main influence was the cinema and not other photographers. "The only cultural thing I had in the East End was the cinema. We went there because it was cheaper than putting a shilling in the gas. We'd go seven nights a week sometimes. I was already taking pictures before I even saw work by Irvine Penn or Bill Brandt."

The family moved to East Ham when he was three, after their house was damaged by a Luft waffe bomb. He has one younger sister, Thelma, and says he was brought up by his mother and his aunt Dolly, "everyone had an Aunt Dolly in the East End." He hardly ever saw his father, a tailor's cutter, describing him as a bit of a Jack the Lad. "My mother and father sort of split up and my father wasn't interested in what I did. I never liked him but I was probably conditioned by my mother not to like him. I was hers and my sister was more his. I don't think he liked me but I never really saw him that much."

"My father thought I was fucking queer, but queer didn't mean homosexual. In those days it just meant a bit of an oddball." He was also different in that he was an undiagnosed dyslexic. "I knew I was smarter than the teachers," he recalls, "but they thought I was an idiot and I used to get the cane for not being able to spell and all that kind of thing." He now says that while the idea of him being a visual rather than a literary person cannot all be ascribed to his dyslexia, he acknowledges that it definitely pushed him in that direction. The only subject he was any good at was drawing. He still paints and produces about six pieces a year, mostly for his own pleasure although he has sold "a few" including two works to New York artist Julian Schnabel.

When he was 14 or 15 he started to go to dance halls and learned about the local gang culture. "The Krays, the Barking Boys and the Canning Town Boys were the three gangs at the time. They weren't gangsters, they were just hooligans. They just went around beating people up if you looked at them wrong in a dance hall. I got beat up by the Barking Boys because I danced with one of their girlfriends. They left me in the doorway of Times Furnishing."

It added to his cachet as a product of that world and provided them with some of the recognition they craved. When he left school on his 15th birthday without any qualifications he took a series of odd jobs, including debt collector for a boxing referee, carpet salesman, copy boy for the Yorkshire Post Fleet Street office and window dresser. But I was still A1." He chose the air force because he thought it would be easier than the army and was posted to Singapore and Malaya where he trained in parachuting and jungle rescue.

"I read a lot in the air force," he says. "Although I don't really read, I just sort of skim the pages. I see the words more than read them. I was making up for lost time and I got through four or five books a week. I knew somewhere in the back of my mind that reading was the key to power in some way." He speaks now with the wide-ranging enthusiasms of the auto-didact. He drops in something he saw in the Koran, mentions what "Mr Einstein" said about such and such and praises the novelist Peter Ackroyd's treatment of London.

Bailey asked what he was publishing and he said, 'we're doing the annotated letters of Marcel Proust. Have you heard of him?' Bailey said, 'yes. We visual people read more than you literary people look."

When Picasso came along it was almost like getting religion. I realised there were no rules. A bicycle wheel could be square because Picasso said so." Some years later he was asked to photograph Picasso but said no, not wanting to risk spoiling the myth - "although I do regret that now".

So how did he get on in the forces with Picasso's study of Dora Maar above his bed? "Everyone else had pin-ups of girls over their beds, so I did used to get into fights. But because I was from the East End I could look after myself. I also had the best-looking WAAF as my girlfriend so they knew I wasn't gay."

He bought his first serious camera in Singapore where they were cheap and took it to Chinese pawn shops every other week to pay for film and to get it developed; he still has the tickets. After leaving the air force in 1958 he applied to all the top London studios for a job. The photographer John French made him third assistant and gave him an introduction to John Parsons, the Vogue art director. Bailey says: "They were both gay, and looking back I realised that I was an outsider like they were. They were beyond the class and the accent thing."

Within a few months he was working as a freelance, taking fashion pictures for the Daily Express, and soon after was offered a contract at Vogue. He turned it down at first because as a freelance he was getting paid more for one picture than they were offering per week. "But I didn't really know what Vogue was," he says. "I thought it was just another magazine that used pictures. I wasn't that interested in fashion and preferred reportage and portraits, but fashion gradually took over because of Vogue."

In 1961, a year after he began work for British Vogue, he was given a contract by American Vogue. When he and Shrimpton arrived at their first meeting with editor Diana Vreeland in New York, her response anticipated the reaction the Beatles would get a few years later. "Stop!" she exclaimed to all her staff, "the British have arrived!" Robin Derrick, the present art director at British Vogue, carries on the comparison. "Bailey invented the persona of a British fashion photographer. And the body of work is colossal." Derrick also cites the importance of Bailey's ability to charm people. "When he speaks to you he grips your forearm. Even if he then talks to someone else he doesn't let go of you. It's not technique. It's the way he is. He took my picture once. It's not the best picture he's ever done, and it's not even the best picture of me ever done, but I did feel what it was like to have the charm gun pointed right at you for a moment. He is a very engaging man."

The photography writer Terry Hope edited Bailey's column in Amateur Photographer magazine. He says for the general photographic public Bailey was also enormously influential: "He had no problem that it was a magazine with the 'amateur' in the title and was aimed largely at enthusiasts. He sees himself as a working photographer and people respect that. There have been a lot of good photographers since, but there's not really been anyone who captured people's imagination in the way he did."

When speaking about the 60s, Bailey runs through his patter with practised ease: The Beatles were a bit of a joke and it was the Stones who were really interesting; him and Terry Stamp and Donovan and Jean Shrimpton and Mick and Vidal Sassoon were all mates so fame wasn't that weird; all they were aware of was, in perhaps what will be his best-remembered phrase that, "the 50s were grey and the 60s were black and white".

Martin Harrison, who has curated a major touring exhibition of Bailey's work, Birth of the Cool, which opens in Edinburgh next week, says that while the word iconic is overused, nothing else fits Bailey's work of the period. "His pictures of the Krays and Mick Jagger and all that are what people now call iconic images of the modern age. it might be a bit of a drag for him, but you can't stop his pictures being that." The exhibition includes all the key images from the 60s as well as more recent work. "Seeing a picture of Jean Shrimpton next to Kate Moss, there is a sort of stylistic continuity. His work is usually very graphic, very close up, quite contrasty and even stark."

Although Bailey says that as a photographer he was always more an observer than a participant, his life and relationships were headline news. He says he has had four marriages and six wives. The first was Rosemary Bramble, a Clapham typist he married in 1960, who has been slightly airbrushed out of the legend. The following year he embarked on a four-year relationship with Jean Shrimpton. He met Deneuve when shooting her for Playboy in Paris. Their wedding precipitated a tabloid scandal when she wore a black dress and smoked throughout the ceremony and he wore jeans.

Although still technically married to Deneuve, in 1968 he began to live with American model Penelope Tree. She was 17 and he was 30 when their relationship began. He still counts her among his four or five closest friends. "I fell in love with him," she says. "It was pretty instant. I'd never met anyone quite so honest or sexually direct." Tree, from a wealthy Anglo-American family, said that being photographed by him was, "like being circled by a bird of prey. You are the only thing in his mind and vision, and that can be quite exciting."

When they started to live together she began to work for the drug charity Release. Despite his apparently raffish lifestyle, in domestic matters Bailey was conservative, particularly in what he expected from his partners. He complained that her new friends would come to his house, drink his scotch, smoke his dope and then accuse him of being a capitalist. "He was very suspicious of the people I brought home and that I had another life," says Tree. "But he is also very perceptive. There were some wankers around, but also he was closed to anyone who wasn't on his track. Much more than most people he is on his own track and he's not really interested in anything outside of that. He is still totally single-minded. he has a really clear idea of what he wants in life. He is incredibly ambitious in that he really believes he can leave a mark on the world."

He married the model Marie Helvin in 1975. They divorced 10 years later and he married his current wife, the second Catherine Bai ley, who as Catherine Dyer was a model. The couple have three school-age children, Fenton, Paloma and Sascha. Bailey says fatherhood has made him more tolerant of people: "My assistants have benefited." Catherine and the children are based in Devon but Bailey rarely goes there, instead spending most of his time in London in his ultra-modern glass flat in King's Cross or at his nearby studio.

As with all his partners, Bailey has extensively photographed Catherine. There are fashion shots and family shots and arty shots and pornographic, or erotic, shots. It is an area of his work that has caused consistent controversy. In response to his 1984 book, Nudes, Germaine Greer wrote, "the surface of the plate excites him more than skin could ever do. The sensibility that emerges from [the book] is neither gross, nor sensualist nor perverse, but jaded, aloof, calculating and inhuman."

Catherine herself has said how proud she is of his work and has spoken of how pictures of her in lesbian clinches and other explicit scenes in fact celebrate female sexuality. But, and it feels very suburban even to ask the question, how does Bailey feel about his children seeing their mother portrayed in this way? "They grew up with it so it is nothing new. Maybe if they suddenly saw it for the first time it would be different, and maybe their friends snigger a bit." He says that the 1995 book of pictures of Catherine, The Lady Is A Tramp, "is probably the best book I have ever done. It is the most personal."

And have his photographs of women changed since his wife became a mother? "Like the old Mafia joke? He'd only allow his mistress to give him a blow job because his wife kisses his children? No, it hasn't changed anything for me." What troubles him more is that, "photography is always about the dead. You look at a Picasso and you don't think that the people in it are dead. But if you look at an old photograph of a couple you think about the fact that they are both dead. A painting removes death, but in photography you retain death."

He says he has always thought about death. "I think I was so surrounded by it being bought up during the war. All I remember is being whacked round the head and told to stand still while another hearse went by. It is not really death, it is the idea that I am going to miss something and not be around to see what is going on. I'm sort of living my life backwards, having children so late, [he was 47 when his first child was born] and it is sad in a way because you think about dying and not seeing them grow up. It is the curiosity of living that is exciting. It is not as simple as just the reaper. If it was I would have my lawyers talk to the reaper now and sort something out." His 1992 book of his 80s work, If We Shadows, is re-issued later this month. The opening image is of a tombstone he saw in Australia bearing the legend "In loving memory of David Bailey. Died February 10th 1926 aged 39".

In fact Bailey's health is pretty good. "A lot of photographers have burned up and combusted in hazes of drugs and booze," says Robin Derrick, "but he hasn't." Bailey has the occasional cigar but says he hasn't drunk for 25 years. "Drink was never a real problem, and just before I stopped I never really got drunk. There is a misconception that it was all drugs in the 60s but it was mostly drink. A bottle of wine was always open. My mother died at 86 and my gran at 96, but the men didn't do too well, but then they were drinkers and smokers." He consoles himself by noting that, "most photographers seem to live until they are 90". But that was not true in the case of his friend Terence Donovan who committed suicide in 1996. Bailey said soon afterwards that his death was "the worst thing that ever happened to me".

He started making commercials in the mid 60s and has now directed nearly 500. He directed the first Flake advert - the first ad to be banned by British television - and in a recent television poll of the top 100 ads he had the unique distinction of featuring both in front of the camera - "who do you think you are? David Bailey?" - and behind, with, some would say ironically, the "feminist" Volkswagen ad in which the woman discards her fur coat and jewellery. He also directed the Lynx anti-fur ad - "It takes a dozen dumb animals to make a fur coat and just one to wear it".

"It is difficult to put as much artistically into commercials," he admits, "but I try. The ones where I have done what I wanted, like the Volkswagen one, do work pretty well." As a documentary film-maker he has made films on Warhol, and his 1998 film, Models Close Up, was the highest-rated Channel 4 documentary that year. "Someone said it was a deep look into shallow waters," he laughs, "which I liked." It is a fine piece of work in which he not only showcased his natural empathy with the models but did his duty to the viewer by raising the exploitative and predatory aspects of the industry. He also questioned Naomi Campbell about tantrums and Kate Moss about drugs.

Throughout his career he also found time for photo-documentary projects. There was a moody study of London's East End in the late 60s, a catalogue of the area around his former Primrose Hill home, a trip to Papua New Guinea in the mid-70s and a decade later he went to Sudan during the famine for Band Aid. The Nobel prize-winning novelist William Golding wrote the preface for the resulting book, Imagine. Some of these pictures, "will keep you awake tonight," warned Golding, "and perhaps make you feel you will stay awake for ever".

But it is his classic portraits for which he is still best known. One of 25 Beatles pictures recently went for £10,000 and one of the remaining 10 Kray brother pictures sold for £15,000. He says he thinks he has become a photographer's photographer. "I do things that unless you are a photographer you wouldn't even notice. For the last 20 years I have refused to put hands in my portraits. But you would only really notice that if you knew about photography. So sometimes the pictures become a message to another photographer. Only [someone like] Bruce Weber is going to understand what you are talking about. I know that is ultra-indulgent, but sometimes I do my pictures for them."

Bailey says because of this he is more popular with older photographers than with younger ones. Rankin, from Dazed and Confused magazine, is one of the most acclaimed young British photographers. He agrees that Bailey is sometimes dismissed. "But it's too easy to say he's past it. Bailey and Richard Avedon were the two who influenced me most in portrait photography. I thought the sensitivity and the emotion he could capture from his subjects were inspiring. And his style still stands up. He does shots of Johnny Depp like he would have done 40 years ago, and they are great."

David Puttnam says the presence of young talent acts as a spur to Bailey. "He is a genuine workaholic and wouldn't know what to do with himself if he stopped. But he's also very ambitious and genuinely believes he's got a lot left in him. Even with him and Donovan and Duffy, as close as they were, they were incredibly competitive with each other."

Bailey continues with his schedule and lets whatever public image he has look after itself. Well, almost. Antonioni's film version may be 35 years old, but it's never too late to get the details right. "The whole thing about the East End fashion photographer is that it is perfect for cheap journalism," he explains. "They always have me talking like a cockney but I don't think I speak particularly cockney. And in fact I've never been out with girls who wear white boots. And I've never called a woman a bird."

Life at a glance: David Royston Bailey

Born: London, January 2 1938.

Educated: Plashet Grove School, East Ham, London.

Married: Rosemary Bramble 1960, divorced; Catherine Deneuve1967, divorced;Marie Helvin 1975, divorced; Catherine Dyer 1985 (two sons Fenton16 and Sascha 6, one daughter Paloma 15).

Major exhibitions: National Portrait Gallery 1971; V & A 1983; international centre of photography, New York 1984; Barbican 1999.

Books: Box Of Pinups 1964, Goodbye Baby And Amen 1969; Beady Minces 1974; Papua New Guinea 1975; Trouble And Strife 1980; Lon don NW1 1982; Black And White Memories 1983; Nudes 1984; Imagine 1985; If We Shadows 1992; Lady Is A Tramp 1995; Rock & Roll Heroes 1997; Archive One 1999.

Films: Warhol 1974; Who Dealt? 1993; Lady is a Tramp 1995; Models Close-Up 1998; The Intruder 1999.

 Birth of the Cool opens February 17 at the Scottish National Gallery of Modern Art, Edinburgh. If We Shadows is published by Thames & Hudson at £24.95.

But even before the film was released everyone "knew" it was based on David Bailey. Although it was Hemmings's body that sat astride the model and pushed the camera lens into her face, as far as history is concerned it was David Bailey who launched into what has become the clichéd patter of the fashion studio: "That's great, that's great," he coaxed the supine girl. "Again with the hair. Do that again. C'mon, c'mon. More, much more." But equally, by that time, he had already taken some of the defining photos of the decade - the unlined face of the young Mick Jagger, the Kray twins playing with their pet snakes, the first supermodel, Jean Shrimpton, emerging from the crowd on a Manhattan street - and had become a household name. All the while his life was being lived as much before the lens as behind it. The tall, skinny, beautiful and posh women he photographed and slept with, among them Shrimpton, provided the template for contemporary cool. By the time he married the French actress Catherine Deneuve in 1967, with Mick Jagger as his best man, he was front-page news. For better or worse it was this incarnation that Antonioni sealed forever on celluloid. The artist Brian Clarke has known Bailey for 25 years. "The fact that his personal history has become confused with the body of work is not helpful to the understanding of that work. But, I have no hesitation in saying he is one of the great defining photographers of our time." Clarke says what sets him apart, astonishingly for someone who has made a career in the fashion industry, is authenticity. "He has no bullshit and for someone in that world it is almost unique. Although Bailey says that as a photographer he was always more an observer than a participant, his life and relationships were headline news. He says he has had four marriages and six wives. The first was Rosemary Bramble, a Clapham typist he married in 1960, who has been slightly airbrushed out of the legend. The following year he embarked on a four-year relationship with Jean Shrimpton. He met Deneuve when shooting her for Playboy in Paris. Their wedding precipitated a tabloid scandal when she wore a black dress and smoked throughout the ceremony and he wore jeans. Although still technically married to Deneuve, in 1968 he began to live with American model Penelope Tree. She was 17 and he was 30 when their relationship began. He still counts her among his four or five closest friends. "I fell in love with him," she says. "It was pretty instant. I'd never met anyone quite so honest or sexually direct." Tree, from a wealthy Anglo-American family, said that being photographed by him was, "like being circled by a bird of prey. You are the only thing in his mind and vision, and that can be quite exciting." When they started to live together she began to work for the drug charity Release. Despite his apparently raffish lifestyle, in domestic matters Bailey was conservative, particularly in what he expected from his partners. He complained that her new friends would come to his house, drink his scotch, smoke his dope and then accuse him of being a capitalist. "He was very suspicious of the people I brought home and that I had another life," says Tree. "But he is also very perceptive. There were some wankers around, but also he was closed to anyone who wasn't on his track. Much more than most people he is on his own track and he's not really interested in anything outside of that. He is still totally single-minded. he has a really clear idea of what he wants in life. He is incredibly ambitious in that he really believes he can leave a mark on the world." He married the model Marie Helvin in 1975. They divorced 10 years later and he married his current wife, the second Catherine Bai ley, who as Catherine Dyer was a model. The couple have three school-age children, Fenton, Paloma and Sascha. Bailey says fatherhood has made him more tolerant of people: "My assistants have benefited." Catherine and the children are based in Devon but Bailey rarely goes there, instead spending most of his time in London in his ultra-modern glass flat in King's Cross or at his nearby studio. As with all his partners, Bailey has extensively photographed Catherine. There are fashion shots and family shots and arty shots and pornographic, or erotic, shots. It is an area of his work that has caused consistent controversy. In response to his 1984 book, Nudes, Germaine Greer wrote, "the surface of the plate excites him more than skin could ever do. The sensibility that emerges from [the book] is neither gross, nor sensualist nor perverse, but jaded, aloof, calculating and inhuman." Catherine herself has said how proud she is of his work and has spoken of how pictures of her in lesbian clinches and other explicit scenes in fact celebrate female sexuality. But, and it feels very suburban even to ask the question, how does Bailey feel about his children seeing their mother portrayed in this way? "They grew up with it so it is nothing new. Maybe if they suddenly saw it for the first time it would be different, and maybe their friends snigger a bit." He says that the 1995 book of pictures of Catherine, The Lady Is A Tramp, "is probably the best book I have ever done. It is the most personal." And have his photographs of women changed since his wife became a mother? "Like the old Mafia joke? He'd only allow his mistress to give him a blow job because his wife kisses his children? No, it hasn't changed anything for me." What troubles him more is that, "photography is always about the dead. You look at a Picasso and you don't think that the people in it are dead. But if you look at an old photograph of a couple you think about the fact that they are both dead. A painting removes death, but in photography you retain death." He says he has always thought about death. "I think I was so surrounded by it being bought up during the war. All I remember is being whacked round the head and told to stand still while another hearse went by. It is not really death, it is the idea that I am going to miss something and not be around to see what is going on. I'm sort of living my life backwards, having children so late, [he was 47 when his first child was born] and it is sad in a way because you think about dying and not seeing them grow up. It is the curiosity of living that is exciting. It is not as simple as just the reaper. If it was I would have my lawyers talk to the reaper now and sort something out." His 1992 book of his 80s work, If We Shadows, is re-issued later this month. The opening image is of a tombstone he saw in Australia bearing the legend "In loving memory of David Bailey. Died February 10th 1926 aged 39". In fact Bailey's health is pretty good. "A lot of photographers have burned up and combusted in hazes of drugs and booze," says Robin Derrick, "but he hasn't." Bailey has the occasional cigar but says he hasn't drunk for 25 years. "Drink was never a real problem, and just before I stopped I never really got drunk. There is a misconception that it was all drugs in the 60s but it was mostly drink. A bottle of wine was always open. My mother died at 86 and my gran at 96, but the men didn't do too well, but then they were drinkers and smokers." He consoles himself by noting that, "most photographers seem to live until they are 90". But that was not true in the case of his friend Terence Donovan who committed suicide in 1996. Bailey said soon afterwards that his death was "the worst thing that ever happened to me". He started making commercials in the mid 60s and has now directed nearly 500. He directed the first Flake advert - the first ad to be banned by British television - and in a recent television poll of the top 100 ads he had the unique distinction of featuring both in front of the camera - "who do you think you are? David Bailey?" - and behind, with, some would say ironically, the "feminist" Volkswagen ad in which the woman discards her fur coat and jewellery. He also directed the Lynx anti-fur ad - "It takes a dozen dumb animals to make a fur coat and just one to wear it". "It is difficult to put as much artistically into commercials," he admits, "but I try. The ones where I have done what I wanted, like the Volkswagen one, do work pretty well." As a documentary film-maker he has made films on Warhol, and his 1998 film, Models Close Up, was the highest-rated Channel 4 documentary that year. "Someone said it was a deep look into shallow waters," he laughs, "which I liked." It is a fine piece of work in which he not only showcased his natural empathy with the models but did his duty to the viewer by raising the exploitative and predatory aspects of the industry. He also questioned Naomi Campbell about tantrums and Kate Moss about drugs. Throughout his career he also found time for photo-documentary projects. There was a moody study of London's East End in the late 60s, a catalogue of the area around his former Primrose Hill home, a trip to Papua New Guinea in the mid-70s and a decade later he went to Sudan during the famine for Band Aid. The Nobel prize-winning novelist William Golding wrote the preface for the resulting book, Imagine. Some of these pictures, "will keep you awake tonight," warned Golding, "and perhaps make you feel you will stay awake for ever". But it is his classic portraits for which he is still best known. One of 25 Beatles pictures recently went for £10,000 and one of the remaining 10 Kray brother pictures sold for £15,000. He says he thinks he has become a photographer's photographer. "I do things that unless you are a photographer you wouldn't even notice. For the last 20 years I have refused to put hands in my portraits. But you would only really notice that if you knew about photography. So sometimes the pictures become a message to another photographer. Only [someone like] Bruce Weber is going to understand what you are talking about. I know that is ultra-indulgent, but sometimes I do my pictures for them." Bailey says because of this he is more popular with older photographers than with younger ones. Rankin, from Dazed and Confused magazine, is one of the most acclaimed young British photographers. He agrees that Bailey is sometimes dismissed. "But it's too easy to say he's past it. Bailey and Richard Avedon were the two who influenced me most in portrait photography. I thought the sensitivity and the emotion he could capture from his subjects were inspiring. And his style still stands up. He does shots of Johnny Depp like he would have done 40 years ago, and they are great." David Puttnam says the presence of young talent acts as a spur to Bailey. "He is a genuine workaholic and wouldn't know what to do with himself if he stopped. But he's also very ambitious and genuinely believes he's got a lot left in him. Even with him and Donovan and Duffy, as close as they were, they were incredibly competitive with each other." Bailey continues with his schedule and lets whatever public image he has look after itself. Well, almost. Antonioni's film version may be 35 years old, but it's never too late to get the details right. "The whole thing about the East End fashion photographer is that it is perfect for cheap journalism," he explains. "They always have me talking like a cockney but I don't think I speak particularly cockney. And in fact I've never been out with girls who wear white boots. And I've never called a woman a bird." Life at a glance: David Royston Bailey Born: London, January 2 1938. Educated: Plashet Grove School, East Ham, London. Married: Rosemary Bramble 1960, divorced; Catherine Deneuve1967, divorced;Marie Helvin 1975, divorced; Catherine Dyer 1985 (two sons Fenton16 and Sascha 6, one daughter Paloma 15). Major exhibitions: National Portrait Gallery 1971; V & A 1983; international centre of photography, New York 1984; Barbican 1999. Books: Box Of Pinups 1964, Goodbye Baby And Amen 1969; Beady Minces 1974; Papua New Guinea 1975; Trouble And Strife 1980; Lon don NW1 1982; Black And White Memories 1983; Nudes 1984; Imagine 1985; If We Shadows 1992; Lady Is A Tramp 1995; Rock & Roll Heroes 1997; Archive One 1999. Films: Warhol 1974; Who Dealt? 1993; Lady is a Tramp 1995; Models Close-Up 1998; The Intruder 1999.  Birth of the Cool opens February 17 at the Scottish National Gallery of Modern Art, Edinburgh. If We Shadows is published by Thames & Hudson at £24.95.

fields.headline: Murder and Metropolis
fields.standfirst: Germany is at last acknowledging Fritz Lang as one of its great movie makers. But, says  Kate Connolly, dark questions have been raised about his role in his wife's death
fields.trailText: Germany is at last acknowledging Fritz Lang as one of its great movie makers. But, says Kate Connolly, dark questions have been raised about his role in his wife's death
fields.body:
It had a cast of 36,000, cost a whopping 5m Reichsmarks and set the standard for science fiction films for decades to come. Fritz Lang's silent classic Metropolis - which had already bankrupted the huge Ufa studio before its premiere in Berlin on January 10 1927 - was a dystopian vision of the 21st century: an enslaved underclass, forced to maintain the scientific luxury of the ruling elite, revolt and bring the city to its knees, until a pauper girl and an aristocratic boy's love for each other saves the day.

Fittingly, 21st-century Berlin will tomorrow host the world premiere of the digital reconstruction of Lang's masterpiece - part of the Berlin film festival's 55-film retrospective of the great director's work. The two-week long tribute is the most comprehensive ever, but it's the digital reconstruction of Metropolis that is getting film fans really excited.

With its shapely silver robots (which served as precursors for Terminators, Robocops and the like) and architecturally over-bearing cityscapes resembling the internal workings of Industrial Revolution factories, the reworked Metropolis, according to those who have had a glimpse, still has the ability to hold audiences in thrall.

Only 15,000 Berliners saw the original cut of Metropolis before it was withdrawn to have 90 minutes trimmed for the American market. Although some of the cuts have been found, 1,000m of film is missing, probably for ever. Film historian Martin Koerber spliced together this new version from negatives used in the US release and other portions found gathering dust in the film archives.

The original 1927 picture quality has been restored, missing sequences have been filled in with written summaries, and the original music, composed by Lang's second wife, Thea von Harbou, has been replaced with music by Berliner Bernd Schultheis, the silent film and electronic music composer. "This is the closest anyone will come to seeing the original film," Koerber says. Festival organisers claim their retrospective will "re-evaluate an extraordinary man" and "emphasise a superb achievement in film history".

This is the first real attempt to rehabilitate one of Germany's greatest film directors. Lang, who was born in Vienna in 1890 and trained as an architect, was responsible for three of the largest film productions of 1920s Germany. Dr Mabuse: the Gambler in 1922 was followed by the first film adaptation of Wagner's Die Niebelungen in 1923. Four years later Metropolis appeared, then, in 1931, came the deeply pessimistic M, Lang's first sound film - about the hunt for a paedophile.

M and Metropolis proved to be Lang's ticket to Hollywood, for which he embarked in 1933, declining Goebbels's invitation to serve the Nazi cause. He achieved international recognition with Rancho Notorious, The Big Heat and While the City Sleeps, and returned to Germany in 1957, a rich and successful man.

There he was shocked to find the film world still teeming with former SS officers and Nazi lawyers. In disgust, he headed straight back to the US. Like Marlene Dietrich, he turned his back on Germany, and it was years before his countrymen would begin to forgive him. In fact, due to his collaboration with Jean-Luc Godard, for years he was far more popular in France than in Germany. He died in Los Angeles in 1976.

To coincide with the retrospective, Berlin's Filmmuseum has prepared an exhibition about the life of Lang, a secretive man who relished embellishing his legend. While the exhibition was being pieced together, new documents emerged that shed disturbing light on Lang's private life. The director tried to hide the fact that he was first married to a Lisa Rosenthal, who died in suspicious circumstances in 1920. There is no record that he ever mentioned her in accounts of his life. A Browning revolver was the cause of her death, and witnesses at the time say that Lang pulled the trigger during an argument in 1920. Two years afterwards, he married Thea Von Harbou, his co-scriptwriter with whom he worked closely on Metropolis; they later became estranged when she found solace in the Nazi party.

Lang's biographers say it is no wonder he spent a lifetime making films full of guilt, false accusations, unsolved crimes, atonement, suicide, murder and manslaughter. Nor is it a surprise that in his will the "incarnation of perfectionism" (as his director friend Robert Siodmak called him) asked that all his personal documents be destroyed. His films are all we have to go on.

fields.headline: One hell of a combination
fields.standfirst: Botticelli's drawings for Dante's Divine Comedy are sexy, hypnotic and obsessive - even when depicting all the torments of the underworld. Now they're being shown in full for the first time.  Jonathan Jones  is entranced
fields.trailText: Botticelli's drawings for Dante's Divine Comedy are sexy, hypnotic and obsessive - even when depicting all the torments of the underworld. Now they're being shown in full for the first time. Jonathan Jones is entranced
fields.body:
The job of the critic, said the 19th-century aesthetician Walter Pater, is to elucidate "the peculiar quality of pleasure" that an artist gives us. He was thinking about Sandro Botticelli, the 15th-century Florentine painter of The Birth of Venus and The Primavera, whose crisply sensual art was practically forgotten in 1870, when Pater published his essay. Pater, bringing to Botticelli the hedonistic eye of a man who taught Oscar Wilde a thing or two, resurrected him as an artist and launched him as what he is now - one of the sexiest names of the Renaissance.

Botticelli's Mars and Venus lie languidly in the National Gallery, in a painting on poplar wood probably stripped from a bedroom chest. Mars is a young man asleep, almost naked, his limbs painted with incredible precision - the skin under his knee is delicately creased - while Venus, more powerful in her white robe, rules the picture. Love triumphs over war and, just to emphasise the point, naughty, plump little cupids play with Mars's discarded armour. It is exquisite.

Botticelli gives us a special kind of pleasure, just as Pater claimed. But Pater didn't know the half of it. He had never seen the drawings by Botticelli that come to the Royal Academy in London next month. He had an idea they existed - he saw bad copies of some of them - and knew they must be important. But it is only now, after centuries of obscurity, that Botticelli's illustrations to Dante's Divine Comedy have been brought together from disparate collections in Rome and Berlin. They are Botticelli's greatest work, as well as the most ravishing of the many illustrations to The Divine Comedy done over the past 700 years. Seeing these drawings, probably done for Botticelli's patron Lorenzo de Pierfrancesco de' Medici, is like finding that a house you have known all your life has a secret, beautiful room.

The Victorians rediscovered Dante Alighieri (1265-1321) about the same time as Botticelli. They adored the story of his unrequited love for Beatrice Portinari, which he wrote about in La Vita Nuova. Victorian painters, including Dante Gabriel Rossetti, loved to imagine the world of desire of Dante's Florence; in Rossetti's Dante's Dream (1871), with a view of the Palazzo Vecchio in the background, Dante sees Beatrice - posed by Rossetti's lover Jane Morris - in her tomb. It is a morbidly sensual vision of sex and death.

The Divine Comedy tells of Dante's journey through the afterlife to discover the meaning of Christian faith. His quest is described in three books - Inferno, Purgatorio and Paradiso. As he is led through Inferno (Hell) by the Roman poet Virgil, Dante meets friends who fought with him in the communal strife that tore medieval Florence apart: the struggle of two factions, the Guelphs - to which Dante belonged - and the Ghibellines. Dante's faction was hounded out of the city, and he wrote The Divine Comedy from exile in Ravenna. The poem is full of the ghosts of a broken community.

Nineteenth-century artists took a dangerous pleasure in Dante's tale. They took their cue from William Blake, whose Romantic illustrations take the side of the sinners against a tyrant god; his drawing of the condemned blasphemer Capaneus makes him a muscular, proud rebel against God. It is this pleasure in hell that gives Victorian illustrations of Inferno their peculiar power. Gustave Doré's engraved illustrations, published in 1868, were a central influence on French symbolism and Max Ernst's surrealist collages; Doré's vision of hell is macabre, full of black pits and bodies sensually torn apart. Doré models his statuesque sinners - nude like Botticelli's - on Renaissance art, in particular on Michelangelo. His Dante is a pastiche of Renaissance art as an art of sadistic pleasure.

This fascination culminated in The Gates of Hell, a vast bronze relief of sinners plummeting downwards, bodies writhing, tangled, in arabesques, on which Auguste Rodin worked from 1880 to his death in 1917. The Gates of Hell are taken from Dante; as Virgil leads Dante through them he reads the inscription, Abandon Hope All Ye Who Enter Here. Rodin's gates are not theological: they explode into hellish delight in the possibilities of form.

Yet all these later versions of Dante, even Robert Rauschenberg's illustrated Inferno with its transposition of the fires of Hell to 1960s America, pale beside Botticelli's interpretation.

Dante is unambiguous about how easy it is to end up in hell and how much praying you have to do to get from purgatory to paradise. But there's also pleasure, a voluptuous enjoyment of all the things of this world. In the way it revels in landscape, literature and the individual, with every character realised in the most vivid way, The Divine Comedy belongs to the Renaissance - to Botticelli and his peers.

Consider Dante's relish for the natural world. Landscape was in medieval culture a barren wilderness, full of sinful birds and bees. Dante loves it. His entire epic poem is, in a sense, about landscape. He lavishes attention on the physical topography of the other world: the descending circles of hell, the mountain of purgatory, the spheres of heaven. It is one of the few poems you need maps to make sense of. This discovery of the physical world is what we associate with the Florentine Renaissance - for example, Leonardo da Vinci's "aerial perspective", invented to paint the sky accurately.

Botticelli's overwhelming concern is to make the space of Dante's other world real. His first drawing is a map of Dante's hell, visualising it as a hollow cone with tiers - the circles of hell - getting narrower as they descend. Botticelli doesn't just hypothesise this map; he sticks to it. As we follow from drawing to drawing in hell, we feel we are descending; when we get to Mount Purgatory, we ascend.

And then there is the body. Learning to take pleasure in the human figure was the most radical way in which the Renaissance subverted the medieval world view. Botticelli's bodies - "always attractive", as Pater drooled - are the definition of Renaissance physical beauty. He takes an immense delight in rendering the physical forms of Dante's sinners, demons and devils, all kinds of bodies; Botticelli could never resist a centaur. In his drawing of the snake-headed Gorgons that sneer at Dante and Virgil from the towers of the city of Dis, their faces are cruelly alive, and so are the tiny faces of every snake on their heads. Everyone in Inferno, except for Dante and Virgil, is naked: Botticelli draws genitals, belly buttons, eyes all with the same clinical detail. The sufferings of the various kinds of sinner - the corrupt clergy upside-down in wells, the flaming sarcophagi containing heretics - are hyperlucid. It becomes hypnotic, as your eyes ravenously follow Botticelli's.

The 16th-century artist and biographer Vasari, in his life of Botticelli, claims that as well as illustrating the Divine Comedy, Botticelli wrote a commentary on it. Botticelli's interest in Dante was an unhealthy obsession "on which he wasted much of his time, bringing infinite disorder into his life by neglecting his work". Botticelli's growing religious passion led him to desert painting, says Vasari, and become a follower of the apocalyptic preacher Savonarola, who predicted the destruction of Florence; the artist's late paintings - particularly his Mystic Nativity in the National Gallery - anticipate the coming apocalypse. It's the intensity of Botticelli's engagement with Dante that makes his drawings unique: he believed this stuff, that our actions will have consequences in eternity. His drawings don't so much illustrate The Divine Comedy as manifest it. There has never been such a partnership of visionaries.

 Botticelli's Dante: the Drawings for The Divine Comedy is at the Royal Academy, London W1 (020-7300 8000) from March 17 to June 10. Blake's Dante can be seen in the William Blake exhibition at Tate Britain, London SW1 (020-7887 8008), until February 11.

His first drawing is a map of Dante's hell, visualising it as a hollow cone with tiers - the circles of hell - getting narrower as they descend. Botticelli doesn't just hypothesise this map; he sticks to it. As we follow from drawing to drawing in hell, we feel we are descending; when we get to Mount Purgatory, we ascend. And then there is the body. Learning to take pleasure in the human figure was the most radical way in which the Renaissance subverted the medieval world view. Botticelli's bodies - "always attractive", as Pater drooled - are the definition of Renaissance physical beauty. He takes an immense delight in rendering the physical forms of Dante's sinners, demons and devils, all kinds of bodies; Botticelli could never resist a centaur. In his drawing of the snake-headed Gorgons that sneer at Dante and Virgil from the towers of the city of Dis, their faces are cruelly alive, and so are the tiny faces of every snake on their heads. Everyone in Inferno, except for Dante and Virgil, is naked: Botticelli draws genitals, belly buttons, eyes all with the same clinical detail. The sufferings of the various kinds of sinner - the corrupt clergy upside-down in wells, the flaming sarcophagi containing heretics - are hyperlucid. It becomes hypnotic, as your eyes ravenously follow Botticelli's. The 16th-century artist and biographer Vasari, in his life of Botticelli, claims that as well as illustrating the Divine Comedy, Botticelli wrote a commentary on it. Botticelli's interest in Dante was an unhealthy obsession "on which he wasted much of his time, bringing infinite disorder into his life by neglecting his work". Botticelli's growing religious passion led him to desert painting, says Vasari, and become a follower of the apocalyptic preacher Savonarola, who predicted the destruction of Florence; the artist's late paintings - particularly his Mystic Nativity in the National Gallery - anticipate the coming apocalypse. It's the intensity of Botticelli's engagement with Dante that makes his drawings unique: he believed this stuff, that our actions will have consequences in eternity. His drawings don't so much illustrate The Divine Comedy as manifest it. There has never been such a partnership of visionaries.  Botticelli's Dante: the Drawings for The Divine Comedy is at the Royal Academy, London W1 (020-7300 8000) from March 17 to June 10. fields.headline: Shaking the family tree
fields.standfirst: Both his grandfathers were jailed by the British, but for what? In his quest to learn the truth about his roots, the writer and barrister Joseph O'Neill uncovered intriguing stories of espionage, murder and rebellion
fields.trailText: Both his grandfathers were jailed by the British, but for what? In his quest to learn the truth about his roots, the writer and barrister Joseph O'Neill uncovered intriguing stories of espionage, murder and rebellion
fields.body:
At some point in my childhood I became aware that during the second world war, my Turkish grandfather - a Christian hotelier named Joseph Dakad, who lived in Mersin, a port in south-east Turkey - had been imprisoned by the British in Palestine, a place exotically absent from any atlas. A shiver of an explanation accompanied this information: the detention had something to do with spying for the Germans.

At around this time, I also learned that my Irish grandfather, James O'Neill, had been jailed by the authorities in Ireland in the course of the same war. Nobody explained precisely why, or where, or for how long, and I foggily attributed his incarceration to the circumstances of a bygone Ireland, a place of cold, adventurous nights and clean-cut valour. This notion was fostered by the two things I knew about Jim O'Neill: that he'd been an expert poacher of salmon on the Bandon river, in west Cork, and that he'd served in the First Battalion, First Cork Brigade, IRA. These were glamorous facts from a gritty world of revolution that was thrillingly distant from the bourgeois, entirely agreeable environment of The Hague, the city where I spent most of my childhood.

My grandfathers were barely spoken of in my family, and it was not until I was 30 that the curious parallelism in their lives struck me with any force and that I was driven to explore it. In August 1995, I went to Mersin, which is as humid a spot as you'll find in the Mediter ranean summer, and visited a man named Salvator Avigdor. Sipping a limonata and mopping his brow, he told me that he and his wife were the last two Jews left in Mersin.

The synagogue had disappeared, as had the 70 families who lived in the town when he joined the Toros hotel as an 18-year-old in September 1935. This was a time, he said, when Mersin was a marvel, a cosmopolis where you'd hear three words of French, four words of Turkish and three words of Arabic, and when Joseph Dakad, a punctilious but fair boss, would carouse until three or four in the morning, only emerging from his rooms in the hotel loft at noon. In 1940, Avigdor recalled with a sigh, the Toros hotel was the place to be.

It had 20 rooms and a first-class restaurant with a chef who had cooked for Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, the first president of the Turkish republic. On Sunday nights, there was dancing on the terrace overlooking the sea. The hotel buzzed with Mersin society, travellers and foreign so-called businessmen. Avigdor revealed that the Turkish authorities forced Monsieur Dakad to engage a man - Moharem, by name - who was an agent of the Turkish secret police and whose job it was to spy on the goings-on; that an Austrian resident of Mersin, a friend of my grandfather, was a German agent and quite possibly a double agent of the Turks; and that, in 1940, Avigdor quit his job because the secret police wanted him to intercept letters and inform on the guests staying at the hotel. The most eminent of these was the German ambassador, Franz von Papen.

I asked Avigdor whether my grandfather ever expressed opinions about the war. "Never. It was out of the question. At the hotel, there would be a German here, an Englishman there, and Italian in between. You couldn't open your mouth. You never knew who was working for who." "Do you think my grandfather worked for anyone?" I asked. "Well, he was Germanophile, that's for sure. His German was fluent, and he'd speak to the German visitors at the hotel. I personally think that he probably did work for the Germans. You see, once you've given a little information, that's it, you've crossed the line."

He didn't elaborate on his speculation. "You must understand, Mersin was an important place. It was full of intrigue, like Lisbon. Mersin," he said, pointing upwards, "was like Casablanca." When he said this, I thought, of course, of a man in a white tuxedo who tries to steer a neutral and profitable course through a sea of vultures, gamblers, desperadoes, lovers and idealists. Humphrey Bogart, as the owner of Rick's Café Américain, had been almost exactly my grandfather's age, and Casablanca was set in December 1941, which was when Joseph Dakad was running the Toros hotel, just months before his detention by the British authorities in Syria in March 1942.

My grandfather was arrested on the train from Jerusalem, where he'd been on a business trip, on suspicion of being an Axis agent. He was initially held in a military prison in Beirut. After repeated suicide attempts, he was transferred to a onastery in Emmaus, Palestine. He remained there until September 1945. His captivity had lasted three and a half years. Jim O'Neill, meanwhile, had been arrested in January 1940. After a spell at Mountjoy prison, he was interned at the Curragh camp, Co Kildare, with other prominent republicans. It was not until November 1944 that he returned to Cork, to his family and the Bandon river. In summer, around Inishannon in west Cork, the Bandon could be a jungle river. Rank, swollen trees - beech, oak, willow, ash, sycamore, horse chestnut, evergreens - gather heavily over the banks, the trunks enveloped by vines and dangling plants. It is here, near Enniskean, that Jim O'Neill was born on the family farm, Ardkitt.

By the standards of the Bandon valley, Ardkitt is neither large nor remarkable. There is a front yard; a stone pigpen, now in ruins; an old stone cattleshed; and a whitewashed Victorian farmhouse with a slate roof and yellow-painted trims to the windows and chimney-top and front door. In the secretive way of west Cork, the pastures of Ardkitt, which comprise slightly over 50 acres, are visible only after you have tramped up to the crest of the land rising gently at the rear of the farmhouse. One drizzly November afternoon in 1995, I walked towards the fields of Ardkitt for the first time. Hundreds of small puddles pocked the mud.

These wet, empty fields were the site of golden memories for my father. He and the older O'Neill boys, aged about 10, took working holidays on the farm and loved it from the moment they awoke to the moment, at the end of the day, they washed their feet in the cold water of the well. It was idyllic, my father had told me, but all I sensed, standing on the brow of the hill in the rain, was that this was a hard place, a place that exacted hard physical effort. A short while afterwards, I got into the car to leave. My father's brother, Uncle Brendan, who had accompanied me to Ardkitt, was still talking to his cousin Pat O'Neill, who now lived on the farm.

Then Pat went into the house and returned with a white towel. He handed it to Brendan. They laughed, and Brendan came over to the car, got into his seat and slammed shut the door. He dropped the towel on my lap. I felt a weight among the folds. I unfolded the towel. A rusted revolver sat between my knees. I looked at my uncle. Colt .45, he said, starting the engine, that's the gun that shot Admiral Somerville. Shortly after nine o'clock on Tuesday March 24 1936, the occupants of The Point, Castletownshend, County Cork - vice- admiral Henry Boyle Townshend Somerville and his wife - heard footsteps on the gravel path outside their dining-room window. "Perhaps that's one of the boys coming to see you", said Mrs Somerville, the boys being the young men of the locality who dropped by to ask the admiral's help in joining the British navy. "I'll go and see," her husband said. The cook and the housemaid were out for the evening. There was a knock at the door. Admiral Somerville picked up an oil lamp, crossed the hall, and stepped into the porch at the entrance to the house. Mrs Somerville, who remained in the dining room, heard an indistinct voice outside the glass-panelled front door: "Are you Mr Somerville?" "I am Admiral Somerville."

His wife heard gunshots and the sound of glass shattering. She grabbed a lamp and rushed into the hall. As she entered, a strong gust of wind blew in through the open door of the porch, extinguishing the flame she carried, leaving her in complete darkness. She called her husband's name - "Boyle! Boyle!" - but received no response. All that was audible was the sound of footsteps - the steps of two people was her impression - retreating down the gravel avenue towards the gate of the house. Mrs Somerville advanced in the darkness towards the porch.

She saw her husband lying motionless by the doorway among the broken remains of his lamp. Alongside the body was a piece of cardboard on which this message, in letters cut from newspapers, had been glued, "This British agent has sent 52 boys to the British Army in the last few months." At the inquest, four days later, the state solicitor, a Mr T Healy, described Admiral Somerville as "the descendant of a proud family", who had fought "to keep in this country a parliament which had legislated for the entire country, the descendant of one who had disdained rank and wealth in order to fight for that parliament, which legislated for 32 counties and not for a dismembered and partitioned country".

This was a reference to a great-grandfather of the deceased, Charles Kendal Bushe (1767-1843), Lord Chief Justice of Ireland from 1822 to 1842, who spoke in the Dublin parliament in January 1800 against its forthcoming union with the English parliament. People also noted that the admiral's father had been a friend of a local republican hero, Jeremiah O'Donovan Rossa, who died in New York in 1915. On the repatriation of his remains, at Glasnevin cemetery, the republican Patrick Pearse famously proclaimed: "Life springs from death; and from the graves of patriot men and women spring living nations... The fools, the fools, the fools! They have left us our Fenian dead, and while Ireland holds these graves, Ireland unfree shall never be at peace." The suggestion that the admiral was a recruiting agent for the British armed forces was, Healy stated, false. "He used no influence to get any man or boy into the English navy... No notice or warning was given to the deceased, but instead he was hurled to his death. No stain will lie on the memory of the deceased where he was known, and throughout the country the action which has taken place is abhorrent."

The killers had fled in a car seen by two schoolgirls driving away from the house at great speed. An investigation began the following day. Castings were taken of the tyre-marks left by the car, photographs and measurements were taken of the scene, fingerprints and footprints were thoroughly examined. A week after the homicide, rumours began to circulate that inquiries had extended into Kerry and that an arrest was imminent. But nobody was ever arrested for the murder of Admiral Somerville. Decades after Somerville's death, the hero of the Anglo-Irish war, Tom Barry, went on record that a Cork IRA squad had been instructed to "get" the admiral, but that "the leader of the IRA squad, not the most stable of men, apparently was carried away, and interpreted his orders quite literally, and shot the admiral dead."

As for Uncle Brendan, he did not elaborate on his pronouncement about the Colt .45. I didn't press him. Streams of confidential information run underneath all families, but the very integrity of republican families depends on secrecy: mutual, unintrusive loyalty is an essential familial glue - you have to stick together for better or worse, my grandfather would say to his sons. The reservoir of O'Neill republican confidences was Brendan. He was the son my grandfather trusted, to whom he vouchsafed knowledge of certain matters so that Brendan might bear witness to them and, it could be inferred, keep them in memory until they might safely emerge at the lit surface of history. My grandmother could not tell me whether the story about the gun was true We were never told anything, Grandma said. She did, however, remember the hullabaloo that the Somerville shooting caused; and she also knew - from what source, I didn't know - that the car used by the assassins had been finally abandoned at Rathduff, a small village north of Cork city, close by the house of a relative. Not long after the Ardkitt trip, something else surfaced.

Breaking a silence he'd kept for a quarter of a century, an uncle by marriage told me that, upon his engagement to my aunt, a fellow remarked to him, "Do you know you're marrying the daughter of the man who shot Admiral Somerville?" I claim the privilege, as a grandson, to dwell on my grandfathers in a way of my choosing. I could think of their lives as tragedies. I could linger on the continuing violence and hatred in Turkey and Ireland, and link my grandfathers' shortcomings to the lethal infirmities in those countries' political cultures. But I would rather release my grandfathers. I would rather think of them at ease, and at liberty from mortal emotions.

fields.headline: North Pembrokeshire
fields.trailText: A Country Diary
fields.body:
Home from holiday, straight to the garden - January, and the frogs are floundering on spawn jelly bags, singing the songs of spring in the sunshine. Next day the woods had to be visited. Unfortunately the weather had changed. The roads were flooding again. The paths were mud. It was mild so the badgers had been rooting for food and re-locating their latrines. Birds were lively, great tits sawing out their spring songs. There is a good sprinkling of shiny dark green holly seedlings. The lighter, green leaves of celandine and pennywort gleamed in the rain from their fat beds of rotting leaves. A raven flew silently through the oak trees. Following its path backwards we saw a large nest near the top of a tall oak. Long-dead trees lying in a gully covered in moss were gleaming with an almost fluorescent intensity. My holiday felt like Bede's sparrow in his Ecclesiastical History, "from winter going into winter" - what could it understand of the king's feasting hall?

I'd been to Lanzarote, a volcanic island whose last eruption was in 1824. There, rain is only a dampness. Some parts are a wilderness of desolate, black viciously sharp rocks. The Timanfaya National Park covers an area which was a fertile plain until the eruptions of 1730-36, now it is a desolation of volcanic cones and craters, but like all deserts it has a strange attractiveness. The visitors' centre has a cooking spit using geothermal heat. An attendant spoons you some lava debris to hold. You can't, it's too hot. Dry scrub smoulders and flares, but the most bravura trick is to pour a bucket of water into a pipe stuck in the ground. Two seconds later it re-appears as steam with the explosion of a rocket going into space. Vineyards use volcanic rock as a circular protection for each vine against the wind and as a means of catching the dew. Their lava mulch looks like cinders. Already mosses and lichens which can withstand the heat are colonising the rocks. Did Pembrokeshire look like this millions of years ago?
