fields.headline: The state they're in
fields.standfirst: Surfer, gangster, palm tree and pool... they're all part of the American dream but, as the West Coast is hit by an energy crisis, California is reassessing its image.  Duncan Campbell  reports
fields.trailText: Surfer, gangster, palm tree and pool... they're all part of the American dream but, as the West Coast is hit by an energy crisis, California is reassessing its image. Duncan Campbell reports
fields.body:
The lights have been going out all over California as a result of an energy crisis caused by the badly-handled deregulation of electricity, and the spectacle of this rich and powerful state suffering blackouts and breakdowns has caused much merriment in the rest of the United States. With impeccable timing, the Los Angeles County Museum of Art (LACMA) is holding its largest exhibition, Made in California: Art, Image and Identity 1900-2000, while this week in Anaheim, Disney opened its newest theme park called California Adventure, which focuses on everything from the Golden Gate to Hollywood and the state's famous redwood forests.

California's literature has also come under scrutiny, with the publication of a new survey of the writing of the region. Each project aims to define the condition of a state that seems at once both America squared and yet very specifically a country of its own.

When the New Yorker ran a special edition on California three years ago, Alex Ross described the relationship that other Americans have with the state as "one that takes on the inflections of a resentful sibling or a jilted lover. They're suspicious of the beautiful façade; they like to look behind it and see nothing there. (A good therapist would recognise this as a violent defence mechanism set off by fear of rejection: am I cool enough? Am I cute enough?)"

Recently in LA Weekly, the city's main radical paper, Harold Myerson wrote in an essay on Bush and Clinton: "To Democrats, Republicans are a bunch of Texans who pollute the earth. Correspondingly, to Republicans, Democrats are a bunch of Californians who pollute the culture." This view is shared by many Americans. Californians are from another country, with a population of 34m, and it would be the seventh, eighth or 10th strongest economy in the world, depending on which economist is being interviewed on the radio this morning.

One of the most striking pieces in the LACMA exhibition is Ed Keinholz's Back Seat Dodge '38, a mixed media construction of back-seat sex. When it was first exhibited at the museum in 1966 it led to an official threat of closure if the work was not removed. Eventually a compromise was agreed, which allowed the gallery's attendants to open the car door and show the illicit sex, provided there were no minors present. Now, of course, minors and majors alike can wander past and wonder what all the fuss was about. Those boundaries have been erased and California can largely take the credit - or blame - for that.

The exhibition's title makes it clear that this is not just about art but about the image and identity that have created such ambivalent feelings towards California and what it represents in the collective cultural psyche. The images that flash past in the chronological journey through the exhibition are the images that have flashed past the world: the surfer and the gangster, the palm tree and the pool - here represented by David Hockney's The Splash (1966) - Mickey Mouse and the fruit-pickers, Grateful Dead posters and topless bathing suits, Black Panthers and Mexican borders, Muscle Beach and missions.

"California has invented so much of the postmodern world that most places are packing away their idiosyncracies in order to more closely resemble California," writes Richard Rodriguez in the fat book that accompanies the exhibition. "California has for so long played America's America. The end of the road. Or a second shot at the future."

A century ago it was this lyrical vision of the state, a world where the sun always shone - literally and metaphorically - that was presented to the world. This was "the new Eden of the Saxon home-seeker," said the founder of the Southwest Museum, Charles Fletcher Lummis. Americans who suffered from tuberculosis or asthma came in their thousands to Pasadena and Ojai and Palm Springs. Then with the entry of the US into the first world war in 1917 came the boost to the economy through food and clothes production. For those seeking spiritual refreshment, California provided some of the most charismatic religious hucksters imaginable; one of them, Aimee Semple McPherson, the evangelist who died of a drug overdose in 1944, is commemorated in the exhibition by Barse Miller's satirical Apparition Over Los Angeles.

The state in the early years of the last century had an almost mystical view of itself as a Rome or an Athens, a place that would define the future and be the birthplace of the new. Although it might have been the "Saxon home-seeker" who was encouraged, in the early silent films there were stars like Anna May Wong and Dolores Del Rio - both celebrated in the exhibition - who demonstrated that California's special magic was that it stood at the crossroads between east and west, between Latin America and the English-speaking north.

So amongst the dreamy landscapes and the beach culture, there is Diego Rivera's Allegory of California from 1931 and Frederic Penney's Madonna of Chavez Ravine. As well as the work of Judy Chicago and John Cage, there is the 1905 poster for Carmel by the Sea and the Rose Brand Oranges ads. As Alex Ross noted in the New Yorker: "In no other place could there have been tennis games between Arnold Schoenberg and George Gershwin, or a poem by Bertolt Brecht on the subject of Charles Laughton's garden."

To many people, of course, California is defined by film. The current exhibition recognises that, with its gelatin-silver prints of Norma Shearer and Joan Crawford by George Hurrell, and the costume created for Greta Garbo in Inspiration. But it is the other Edenic vision, celebrated by Edward Ruscha's Standard Station and Robert A Bechtle's '67 Chrysler, which captures the famous light that hits the state between the desert and the Pacific and brought David Hockney here in the first place.

Another English exile, Christopher Isherwood, reflected in his diaries the feelings of the outsider for the state. When he arrived by bus in May 1939 he recorded: "When we reached Needles, a patriotic lady passenger began to sing 'California, Here I Come!' It seemed little enough to arrive at after such a journey - the furnace-hot, quivering, untidy desert... I think one's disappointment on first coming to the West is really due to its size. The European mind cannot grasp such distances, such prodigality, such barrenness, such riches. It grows weary and bored. The eye refuses to look and the ear to listen."

California remains a butt of cultural mockery, a place where the eye does not look too hard or the ear listen too closely. To the east-coast literary establishment, a book party in LA is an oxymoron. Californians use books merely as drinks coasters, goes the joke. In a NY Times review of the new collection of Raymond Carver's prose, Call if You Need Me, Claire Dederer writes of the earlier Carver work, Short Cuts, and how it was turned into a film by Robert Altman: "Altman captured Carver's mood of crummy, slipshod marginality and cleverly relocated it to Los Angeles, the world capital of crumminess." What other city in the world gets lumbered with such a sneering, lazy, cliched nickname as Tinseltown?

Last month also saw the publication of The Literature of California Volume One, 870 pages of writing edited by Maxine Hong Kingston, Jack Hicks, James D Houston and Al Young. This volume deals with pre-colonial Native American writing through to 1945 and features Jack London, Mary Austin, and John Rollin Ridge (Yellow Bird) to Upton Sinclair, James M Cain, John Steinbeck, F Scott Fitzgerald, Dashiell Hammet, Chester Himes and Nathanael West.

Reviewing the book in the LA Times, Thomas Sanchez suggests: "California reflected in the mirror of its writers is as diverse and complex as Europe, yet it coheres, held by the glue of the new. Here people are defined not by their past but by their future." The volume contains the earliest known use of California, in a fictional romance circa 1510, when Garci Rodriguez Ordonez De Montalvo writes that "on the right hand of the Indies there is an island called California, very close to the side of the Terrestial Paradise".

Among the writers included in the volume are those who were drawn to this terrestial paradise for a variety of reasons. Robert Louis Stevenson, who lived for a happy while in northern California, John Muir, Raymond Chan dler, people who are not Californians by any stretch of the imagination but whose work was affected in one way or another by their time in the state.

Richard Rodriquez notes that "paradigmatic Californians weren't so by birth... Cesar Chavez was born in Yuma. Willie Mays, Louis B Mayer, Jack Kerouac, Richard Neutra, Lucy and Desi, Edward Teller - all of them from far away. All of them living forever in California on the same street." But California offered each something that was not available elsewhere in north America. No wonder the state's motto was Eureka!

The Museum of Contemporary Art in LA is currently running a billboard ad campaign created by the giant advertising firm TWBA/Chiat/Day. One reads "Car Washes and a Couple of Taquerias, 2000. Courtesy of the Museum of Contemporary Art" and it is posi tioned beside a couple of fairly ordinary carwashes and taquerias. It has been criticised locally for its "unfathomable condescension"; certainly the army of central Americans who polish the gleaming off-road tanks driven by the high-rollers in LA are hardly likely to rush off to MOCA once they realise that they are part of a notion of conceptual art.

But in their way the billboards do make a point. The real "art" in California is as much in the open air, whether a building designed by Frank Gehry on the Venice shorefront or a neon sign in the shape of a cactus advertising a Mexican restaurant, as inside a gallery. Essentially, the message of the exhibition and the volume of literature is that, in California, all is possible.

This is the state, after all, of Richard Nixon and Ronald Reagan but also the Black Panthers and the Berkeley anti-war move ment, the Hollywood Ten and the grapepickers' boycott as well as Disneyland and Charles Manson, Silicon Valley and Death Valley, the Beach Boys and the Zoot Suit riots, the rappers and beats. It is the place where both Michael Jackson and William Randolph Hearst - as well as Disney - chose to build their pleasuredomes.

Orson Welles famously said: "The terrible thing about LA is that you sit down, you're 25 and you get up you're 62." California's name may be more than 500 years old but its art and image have been created by people who did manage to get up before they were 62, whether it was to make Citizen Kane or any of the multitude of images and identities now being celebrated. And if the lights do go out, well, there is always the sunshine - and those oranges.

 Made in California runs until March 18.

webTitle: Saudi security scare raises bomb doubts

fields.headline: Saudi security scare raises bomb doubts
fields.trailText: Prince Nayef, the Saudi minister who is heading investigations into bomb attacks against Britons, has doubled the number of his personal bodyguards to 300 men, opposition sources said yesterday.
fields.body:
Prince Nayef, the Saudi minister who is heading investigations into bomb attacks against Britons, has doubled the number of his personal bodyguards to 300 men, opposition sources said yesterday.

Although a Briton, a Belgian and a Canadian have confessed on Saudi television to two of the bombings, and nine other foreigners are under arrest, the prince's move casts doubt on whether they are the real culprits, Saad Fagih of the Movement for Islamic Reform in Arabia said yesterday.

All 12 suspects, as well as the victims of two car bombs in Riyadh on November 17 and 22 last year, have been linked to illicit drinking activities in the Saudi capital. But the authorities have offered no explanation for three subsequent bombs.

On December 5, a Scotsman, David Brown, lost an eye when a juice carton placed near his car's windscreen exploded in the eastern town of al-Khobar.

On January 10, a small explosion occurred in a telephone kiosk outside the Euromarche shopping mall in Riyadh. Four days later, police defused a bomb found under an Irishman's car in Riyadh.

Almost all the western suspects were under arrest when the two most recent incidents occurred.

Prince Nayef, the interior minister, has always taken his safety seriously, but the doubling of his bodyguard followed the discovery of a note at the scene of the Euromarche bombing, Dr Fagih said.

He added that two different sources had told him that the bombers' note had warned that there would be another, much larger, explosion if Prince Nayef did not release their "brothers".

Besides the 12 foreigners, the authorities are holding about 70 "mojahedin youths" in connection with the bombings.

Meanwhile Gary Dixon, the Briton who ran the Empire drinking club in Riyadh, was yesterday trying to launch a last-minute appeal against his deportation from Dubai to Saudi Arabia on alcohol-related charges.

A friend said: "He's afraid they may try to make him out as 'Mr Big' in the bombings."

fields.headline: Akers firm runs into trouble
fields.standfirst:
Financial difficulties hurt EuroTelecom

More net news
fields.trailText: Chris Akers, the entrepreneur behind a string of sports, media and internet-related company flotations, is struggling to pull one of his latest stock market vehicles out of severe financial difficulties.
fields.body:
Chris Akers, the entrepreneur behind a string of sports, media and internet-related company flotations, is struggling to pull one of his latest stock market vehicles out of severe financial difficulties.

EuroTelecom, a firm that specialises in installing hi-tech internet facilities in commercial buildings, said yesterday that it had "working capital difficulties" nine months after Mr Akers, as non-executive chairman, helped it raise £17m through an AIM flotation.

The announcement wiped 33% off EuroTelecom's share price and they closed the day valued at 6p each. It left several investors who had bought into the flotation at more than 150p per share seething. The firm is understood to have around £1m left but has reduced cash burn from around £1.5m per month to £250,000.

"I want to know what the hell has happened," said one angry investor. "We were told that this firm had no burn rate and yet now there's cash difficulties. You don't get into a flotation and expect this to happen."

Phil Derry, chief executive of the company, said it was "in discussions with parties which may or may not lead to an injection of funds".

Asked if he thought the company would go bust he said: "We need a fair wind but I don't think so. I'm confident we can sort something out. We've invested heavily in infrastructure and have a substantial order book. I think we've got an interesting company."

The board is thought to be deeply split over the way the company has been run. Mr Akers and Mr Derry are thought to be at loggerheads and at the end of last year the former asked accountants BDO Stoy Hayward to conduct a financial audit of the accounts.

Two directors Amanda Staveley and David Walton announced on Thursday that they were quitting the board. A fortnight ago finance director David Linell, who clashed with non-executives, announced his resignation due to "pressures of his other business interests".

In October the company reported sales of £6.5m but operating losses of £3.7m were higher than original forecasts. At that stage it had around £5m in the bank and had won contracts including an order to wire Microsoft's campus in Cambridge and the Printworks development in Manchester.

EuroTelecom's difficulties and the anger expressed by some of its shareholders will be a blow for Mr Akers, who experienced the most successful period of his business career last year.

He bounced back from a bitter power struggle at Leeds United football club that saw him quit as chairman. He sold his Sports Internet vehicle to BSkyB for £301m and helped to build InTechnology, a data storage firm that was one of the best performing shares of last year.

Those performances built him a loyal following among investors.

Since then Mr Akers has floated Newsplayer.com, I Feel Good and Sports Resource. Shares in Newsplayer are currently changing hands at half the level they first fetched. IFeelGood, run by former Loaded magazine editor James Brown, has seen its shares recover after a disappointing start.

Sports Resource has seen its shares perform strongly.

webTitle: David Rowland founds another internet incubator

fields.headline: 'Spotty' Rowland founds another risky incubator
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: David "Spotty" Rowland, the reclusive multimillionaire entrepreneur behind the high-profile internet incubator Jellyworks, has floated another vehicle to invest in high-risk ventures.
fields.body:
David "Spotty" Rowland, the reclusive multimillionaire entrepreneur behind the high-profile internet incubator Jellyworks, has floated another vehicle to invest in high-risk ventures.

Mr Rowland, along with his 24-year-old son and Jellyworks chief executive Jonathan Rowland, are understood to be backing Cerberex, a cash shell which has just raised around £12m on the Guernsey stock exchange.

It is thought that the equally reclusive Barclay family, owners of the Ritz hotel and Sunday Business newspaper, may also be investors.

The Barclay and Rowland families are old friends; they invested together in Jellyworks and are both based in the tax-efficient environment of the Channel Islands.

Jellyworks was one of the wonder stocks of the dot.com boom and saw its shares rise tenfold in value on their first day of trading in December 1999. Only seven months later it was sold to the investment bank, Shore Capital, for less than a quarter of the level of its peak valuation.

Cerberex, named after Jonathan Rowland's TVR Cerbera sports car, is looking to invest in opportunities in the life sciences and biotech areas. It is chaired by Graham Robeson, the former chairman of Jellyworks and one of Mr Rowland Snr's most loyal lieutenants. Neither Mr Robeson or Mr Rowland were returning telephone calls yesterday.

The biggest shareholder in Cerberex prior to the placement was a Bermuda-based firm, where Monaco-domiciled financier Ian Ilsley is a director. Aim-listed internet investment firm netvest.com is also a shareholder.

Other directors of Cerberex include Keith Smith, a director of stockbroker Nabarro Wells & Co, and Samuel Taylor, a director of Aim-listed technology firm JAB Holdings.

Prospective shareholders in Cerberex were asked to stump up a minimum of £100,000.

"Spotty" Rowland remains an active player on the London stock market, with stakes in a number of companies. He leaves the limelight to Jonathan, who is a non-executive director of television equipment firm VFG, in which the family has a major stake.

He oversees the families' main investment vehicle, Rowland Capital, from offices located in London.

Mr Rowland, along with his 24-year-old son and Jellyworks chief executive Jonathan Rowland, are understood to be backing Cerberex, a cash shell which has just raised around £12m on the Guernsey stock exchange. It is thought that the equally reclusive Barclay family, owners of the Ritz hotel and Sunday Business newspaper, may also be investors. The Barclay and Rowland families are old friends; they invested together in Jellyworks and are both based in the tax-efficient environment of the Channel Islands. Jellyworks was one of the wonder stocks of the dot.com boom and saw its shares rise tenfold in value on their first day of trading in December 1999. Only seven months later it was sold to the investment bank, Shore Capital, for less than a quarter of the level of its peak valuation. Cerberex, named after Jonathan Rowland's TVR Cerbera sports car, is looking to invest in opportunities in the life sciences and biotech areas. It is chaired by Graham Robeson, the former chairman of Jellyworks and one of Mr Rowland Snr's most loyal lieutenants. Neither Mr Robeson or Mr Rowland were returning telephone calls yesterday. The biggest shareholder in Cerberex prior to the placement was a Bermuda-based firm, where Monaco-domiciled financier Ian Ilsley is a director. Aim-listed internet investment firm netvest.com is also a shareholder. Other directors of Cerberex include Keith Smith, a director of stockbroker Nabarro Wells & Co, and Samuel Taylor, a director of Aim-listed technology firm JAB Holdings. He oversees the families' main investment vehicle, Rowland Capital, from offices located in London.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Kabila killer 'did not die'
fields.body:
Kabila killer 'did not die'

The killer of the former Congolese president, Laurent Kabila, escaped from the scene of the shooting and was not killed, as stated by Congolese authorities, a French newspaper reported yesterday.

Le Monde did not name the killer but said he was a member of the presidential guard and one of 35 former "kadogos", or child soldiers, trying to overthrow the government. Reuters, Paris

OJ surrenders to face charges

OJ Simpson surrendered to police in Florida's Miami-Dade county yesterday on charges stemming from a December traffic altercation in which a motorist accused him of reaching into his car and pulling off his glasses.

Simpson, charged with burglary and assault, moved to the Miami area early last year. Police have since responded three times to reported disturbances between Simpson and his new girlfriend. AP, Miami

India to produce new missile

India has approved the production of a nuclear-capable, intermediate-range ballistic missile, a senior defence ministry source said yesterday.

No date was given to start producing the Agni-II missile, which would have a range of 1,200 miles, but it is likely to be brought into service this year, officials say. AP, Delhi

Burglars shown on internet

The net was closing in on two burglars yesterday after images of them rifling through a Sydney home were published on the internet by the computer programmers they had robbed.

Two brothers, who fitted a webcam to their home computer following a previous break-in, posted the images it captured of the new robbers on a website. Patrick Barkham, Sydney

webTitle: Rolls staff strike over jobs move to Montreal

fields.headline: Rolls staff strike over jobs move to Montreal
fields.trailText: Workers at a Rolls-Royce factory in Coventry yesterday started a series of one-day strikes in an attempt to prevent the aerospace company from exporting their jobs to Canada.
fields.body:
Workers at a Rolls-Royce factory in Coventry yesterday started a series of one-day strikes in an attempt to prevent the aerospace company from exporting their jobs to Canada.

The strike, involving designers and engineers, is the first at the plant for at least 20 years. Union officials said that the strikes were designed to get the company to withdraw redundancy notices issued to about 450 people ahead of negotiations.

A spokesman for the Manufacturing Science and Finance union said that it was not prepared to have talks with the company until the redundancy notices were withdrawn.

However the MSF, which has about 600 members among the plant's largely non-unionised 2,400 employees, has submitted alternative proposals which it claims would substantially reduce the scale of job losses. The plant carries out research and developmenton gas turbines and marine engines as well as aeroengine overhauls.

Rolls-Royce plans to shed up to 1,300 jobs by moving the energy business to Montreal and the marine business to Bristol.

A company spokesman said that jobs would be offered to staff prepared to move to Montreal or Bristol. In addition there were other vacancies for skilled engineers and designers elsewhere in the group.

He said the company wanted to discuss revisions to its original plan, taking into account some of the proposals put forward by the unions, but it was not prepared to lift the redundancy notices. Union officials said any scaling down of the plant would make it vulnerable to closure in any later reorganisation.

"We are trying to impress on the company that this is the thin edge of the wedge," an MSF spokesman said, adding that the Canadian government had provided Rolls-Royce with financial incentives to move the energy R&D work to Montreal.

webTitle: Money launder theory in murder inquiry

fields.headline: Money launder theory in murder inquiry
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Police are investigating claims that the murder of an Argentine-based executive of Antfactory - a London internet investment firm - and his wife is connected to money laundering activities, according to press reports.
fields.body:
Police are investigating claims that the murder of an Argentine-based executive of Antfactory - a London internet investment firm - and his wife is connected to money laundering activities, according to press reports.

Mariano Losanovscky Perel - an executive in the financial services team at venture capital company Antfactory Latin America - and his wife Rosa Berta, were found dead last week at Carilo, an exclusive Argentine beach resort.

Reports in La Nacion newspaper said police described the killings as a "clean and professional job." Each was killed with a single bullet.

Antfactory Latin America is half-owned by Citicorp Venture Capital Latin America, a subsidiary of New York based Citigroup, and 50% owned by Antfactory, which specialises in supporting the online strategies of old economy firms.

In a statement, Antfactory Latin America said: "Antfactory's deepest condolences are with the relatives and friends of the Perel family over the tragic death of Mr Perel and his wife. Antfactory Latin America has been working to collaborate as closely as possible with the Argentine authorities in helping to clarify the case."

Mr Perel had been with the financial services group in Latin America for only five months.

fields.headline: Glotel suffers as US slowdown prompts profits warning
fields.trailText: Telecoms consultancy group Glotel yesterday issued an unexpected profits warning, blaming the slowdown in the US economy and the need to make bad debt provisions after one of its main customers went into bankruptcy.
fields.body:
Telecoms consultancy group Glotel yesterday issued an unexpected profits warning, blaming the slowdown in the US economy and the need to make bad debt provisions after one of its main customers went into bankruptcy.

The news saw the company's shares almost halve in value, wiping about £64m off its market value. They reached a peak of 810p last year at the height of the technology boom - but yesterday fell a further 175p to close at 187.5p.

The company, which provides temporary technical staff to telecoms organisations, said that profits for 2000 would be well below analysts' expectations.

"The global uncertainty in the telecoms industry has caused headcount freezes and lay-offs which has impacted on Glotel's fourth-quarter sales and profitability," the company said in a statement.

Demand for temporary technical help has fallen off at telecoms companies, it reported, and this has knocked back Glotel's profit margins by 28% since December.

The City had predicted profits of £8m after the last interim results, published in December.

Those estimates are being adjusted sharply downwards after Glotel said that it will need to make room in its balance sheet for unpaid contracts totalling £1m.

In mid-January one of its largest clients, Northpoint Communications, went bankrupt, accounting for the bulk of the bad debt.

This has had a significant effect on the sales and margins in the group's operations on the west coast of America, it said.

The company said trading in Britain was in line with expectations, but this was not enough to make up for the problems being experienced in the US.

The company was founded in 1989 in a Tottenham Court Road serviced office and now boasts in the region of 160,000 freelance contractors working out of 24 offices in Europe, the Americas, Africa and Asia-Pacific.

Plans to build eight new offices this year may be put on hold as Glotel management reviews its prospects in the light of the current poor market for telecoms.

It is expected to freeze recruitment across the group and shift existing staff to new roles.

fields.headline: Land Rover cuts jobs
fields.standfirst:
Freelander production suffers as BMW fails to meet demand for diesel engines

Britain's car industry
fields.trailText: Freelander production suffers as BMW fails to meet demand for diesel engines
fields.body:
Two of the world's leading car companies are at odds over the supply of engines for Land Rover's best selling Freelander model, a dispute which has already cost 250 jobs.

BMW, which sold Land Rover to Ford for £1.8bn last year, has told the company that it cannot sell extra diesel engines to meet increased demand for the Freelander.

When it sold the Solihull-based company, BMW agreed to supply 32,000 diesel engines a year for the Freelander.

Land Rover said yesterday that the contract had been based on BMW's forecasts for sales of diesel-powered Freelanders. But Freelander sales have soared under Ford's ownership, to the point where it is now the best selling 4x4 vehicle in Europe.

BMW turned down Land Rover's request for "a substantial increase" in diesel engines for the Freelander, claiming that the Steyr plant in Austria, which makes them, was operating at full capacity. Paradoxically the Steyr plant has just started making diesel engines for BMW's first 4x4.

A BMW spokesman said that capacity at the Steyr plant had been stretched.

The plant was originally built to produce 300,000 petrol and diesel engines a year in the 1980s, and last year made 600,000 engines.

He said the group's plan was to move some of Steyr's petrol engine production to the group's newly opened Hams Hall engine plant near Birmingham, and step up diesel production at Steyr. But this would take time.

The switch will not be in time to provide Land Rover with extra TD4 engines for the Freelander. As a result, Land Rover has been forced to cut annual Freelander production from 84,000 to 74,000, resulting in the loss of up to 250 jobs.

A spokeswomen said that production of Freelanders with diesel engines would be capped at 32,000 a year "for the foreseeable future".

In January alone, Land Rover saw demand for diesel-powered Freelanders rise 92%. It is unable to get the TD4 diesel engine from any other manufacturer.

The spokeswoman said BMW's inability to supply further TD4s was "a bitter blow", but added that it would not prevent the company from returning to profit next year as forecast.

"Clearly this is not a desirable state of affairs," she said. "We are continuing discussions with our suppliers.

"Unfortunately it is not possible to re-engineer the vehicle to take another manufacturer's engine."

Ford is investing more than £300m to turn its Dagenham plant into a global centre for diesel engine production. But it cannot supply engines for the Freelander at the moment.

Land Rover is hoping to achieve the necessary job cuts through voluntary redundancies. The spokeswomen said that a special redundancy package had been discussed with the unions.

BMW claimed that it, too, was being hit by the capacity problems at Steyr. The plant also makes petrol and diesel engines for the group's 3 Series and 5 Series models.

"We would like to sell more diesel cars to the public in this country," the group's UK spokesman said. "We are in a similar position [to Land Rover] in not being able to meet demand."

webTitle: GM rubber trees may grow blood protein

fields.headline: Rubber trees may yield blood protein
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: Rubber trees in Malaysia may soon flow with albumin, the protein in human blood given in transfusions, with rubber for making aircraft tyres as a useful byproduct.
fields.body:
Rubber trees in Malaysia may soon flow with albumin, the protein in human blood given in transfusions, with rubber for making aircraft tyres as a useful byproduct.

Hoong-Yeet Yeang, of the Rubber Research Institute in Kuala Lumpur, told the Biovision 2001 conference in Lyon in France, that trees "milked" for nearly a pint of latex sap every other day could be genetically engineered to provide commercial enzymes for shampoos, for chemotherapy drugs, as well as safe human blood products for hospitals.

Working with young trees and low funds, he had done experiments with dozens of plants supplying albumin.

Bananas have been developed to "grow" human vaccines. Strawberry plants have been modified to make anti-decay toothpaste. But albumin is a vital protein needed in huge quantities to drip into the bloodstreams of accident and surgery victims.

Supplies in Britain have been interrupted because of fears of contamination by donors with variant CJD. Other teams have genetically engineered sheep to provide albumin and other blood products.

Rubber was part of the Malaysian landscape, said Dr Yeang. "But in recent years the price of rubber has not been very good. So there is a great incentive to find new uses for the rubber tree and this is an obvious one. You can get continual production just by tapping rubber trees."

In making high quality rubber the important ingredient in the sap was latex, but a high proportion of the sap was protein that had to be removed as waste. Therefore plants could be the ideal factories for blood and other valuable proteins, he said. "Grown in the field, plants require little more than sunlight, water and basic horticultural input to survive. As protein manufacturing factories, plants are solar-powered and ecologically friendly."

Dr Yeang and his colleagues introduced the albumin gene into the tree's DNA sequence, and persuaded it to release the protein to make 70% of the sticky liquid tapped from the tree.

webTitle: Kingston upon Hull warned not to squander windfall

fields.headline: Dreams dashed for city with a 'pot of gold'
fields.standfirst: Auditor warns town hall in Prescott's backyard not to squander cash from windfall on grandiose projects in £650m spending spree
fields.trailText: Auditor warns town hall in Kingston upon Hull, home of John Prescott, not to squander cash from windfall on grandiose projects in £650m spending spree.
fields.body:
Two years ago it was labelled the richest authority in Britain after receiving £255m from the part sale of a shareholding in the local phone company.

But the city of Kingston upon Hull - home of a stricken football club and the deputy prime minister, John Prescott - has been chastised by a local government watchdog.

The district auditor has warned the Labour-run council that a spending spree triggered by the windfall was "neither realistic nor achievable" and could in time leave it in serious financial difficulties.

After finding a "lack of urgency" on previous warnings, he has found a £270m shortfall in a £650m capital spending plan that includes double-glazing and central heating for all council homes that need them, a massive school repair programme, a purge on dirty streets - and £40m to build a super stadium for rugby league and Hull City football club. This week the club called in administrators after the players had not been paid for five weeks.

The auditor's report could prove an embarrassment to Mr Prescott, MP for Hull East, whose Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions oversees local government. He has used Hull as a model example of selling municipal assets to fund improved council services.

Although Hull's remaining shareholding in Kingston Communications, the phone service set up by the council in 1902, is worth another £430m, the auditor, Paul Lundy, questioned the public perception that the 1998 windfall had made the council wealthy. "The reality is somewhat different," he warned.

This was because a substantial proportion of the sale proceeds had been committed to "one-off" big projects, and the amount left to spend on frontline services was a fraction of what had been suggested.

His report told the council: "It is essential that no firm commitment is made to proceed with any capital scheme until there is certainty of funding and the longterm revenue consequences have been identified."

Woundingly, he also said that although the authority aspired to be a "top 10" British city, "this is unlikely to be achieved unless there is a significant cultural change in the way it conducts its business and changes its long held attitudes and working practices".

To make matters worse, Mr Lundy said the council had used another £32m to cover a funding gap in its day-to-day spending, amounting to £289m in the current financial year. He had already warned members this could not be allowed to continue, because of the uncertainty of future cash flows from the old phone company. Consequently, the authority had either to cut spending, increase council tax significantly, or consider selling assets such as land and buildings.

Opposition councillors were scathing about the council's financial management. Simone Butterworth, leader of the Liberal Democrat group, warned that unless the authority mended its ways the government might have to take over some council services. "It has lost its way," she said. "We have not had experience of spending large sums of money, and some councillors went around thinking we had a pot of gold and it would always be filling up."

Chris Jarvis, an independent councillor who left the Labour group five years ago, added: "They have been behaving like children in a sweet shop, and made massive spending commitments that were not achievable."

Patrick Doyle, the veteran council leader, said in a statement that the authority had agreed that a three-year programme of spending cuts was necessary, and that consultants were working on a business plan for the super stadium, which has risen substantially in cost.

webTitle: Clinton haters still find rich pickings

fields.headline: Clinton haters still find rich pickings
fields.standfirst:
Ex-first couple lose magic as triumph turns to disaster

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Ex-first couple lose magic as triumph turns to disaster
fields.body:
Bill Clinton's exit from the White House had been planned and orchestrated as a glittering valediction - full of extended and reflective interviews, a deluge of dynamic presidential executive orders and appointments, and a sentimental tour of farewell speeches delivered in iconic sites from the Clinton years such as Little Rock, Arkansas, and Dover, New Hampshire.

Right up to the last moment on January 20, there was even the tantalising hope that it might yet be crowned by something grander still, that Mr Clinton might even be able to work the personal magic one last time and somehow conjure a Middle East deal from the embers of the collapsing Oslo peace process, thus providing the elusive cornerstone of what he hoped would be his "legacy".

Yet an increasingly incredulous, and now increasingly angry, Democratic party has watched as the intended triumph has morphed into an unintended disaster, and the couple who have been seen for so long as the masters of modern political choreography have presided over a public relations debacle.

In the first days after George W Bush's accession, it seemed hard to believe that things could get much worse for the Clintons. The 42nd president left the White House still haunted by his affair with Monica Lewinsky, in the shadow of the eleventh-hour plea-bargain brilliantly executed by the independent counsel Robert Ray as the removal vans were being loaded outside.

Then there were the pardons, the ink scarcely dry on the list as the Bushes drove up to the White House for pre-inaugural coffee. After that there came the revelations about the gifts. Most devastatingly of all, the Clintons stood accused of accepting two coffee tables and chairs from Denise Rich, the New York Democratic fundraiser and former wife of the disgraced financier Marc Rich, whose pardon was widely seen as inexplicable in any terms other than as payback. And then the vandalism rumours started to circulate.

Exactly what happened in the White House and the neighbouring Old Executive Office Building in which most of the presidential and vice-presidential staff have their offices in those final hours of the Clinton-Gore administration still remains unclear. That some isolated vandalism took place - silly pranks like the case of the missing Ws, for instance - is beyond doubt. That it never matched up to the wilder claims about pornography and glued filing cabinets seems almost equally likely.

What is certain is that the rumours triggered an eruption of venom from the professional Clinton-haters. "I had promised myself not to write again about Bill Clinton - not to give the Big Creep the satisfaction of publicity," wrote the conservative Fox TV anchorman Tony Snow "but the Man From Hope couldn't resist the temptation to give us one last White Trash Weekend." And that was among the more polite comments.

For a few days, the US media gorged itself on the Clintons one last time, reporting fiction as certainty and sloppily elevating gossip into established truth. The plundering of Air Force One turned out to have been grossly exaggerated. The value of the gifts removed by the Clintons was little different from those removed by earlier presidents and was dwarfed by the $2m (£1.4m) home with which admirers presented Ronald Reagan when he left the presidency in 1989. Clinton's list of pardons was not greatly different from those of his predecessors.

Yet two wrongs did not make a right. A lot of the stories were fact not fiction. And the way that the Clintons have subsequently handled the spiralling scandals has revealed a ham-fisted touch that is the more incredible because it comes from a couple whose supposed mastery of media relations spawned a host of international imitators, not least in Tony Blair's Labour party.

On Wednesday, the Clintons announced that they were returning $28,000 (£19,000) worth of furnishings. The reason? A succession of donors had discovered that the gifts they had intended for the White House had ended up in Clintons' home in Chappaqua in the New York suburbs. Some said they were offended. "I would never give a gift to the Clintons," claimed businessman Brad Noe, after learning that his $3,000 (£2,000) sofa was on the list.

This Thursday one of the Republican party's arch Clinton-haters, Congressman Dan Burton of Indiana, took his chance to turn the knife in the wound. His government reform committee conducted an all-day grilling of Eric Holder, the Clinton administration justice department official, and Mr Rich's lawyer Jack Quinn in an attempt to squeeze the last drop from the shady Rich pardon deal.

Two weeks ago, the New York Times described the pardon for a man who is accused of defrauding the US Treasury of $48m (£33m) as "a shocking abuse of presidential power and a reminder of why George W Bush's vow to restore integrity to the Oval Office resonates with millions of Americans who otherwise disagree with the new president's politics".

"Knowing everything that I know now, I would not have recommended to the president that he grant the pardon," Mr Holder, formerly deputy attorney general to the departed Janet Reno, told the Burton committee. As he did so, one Republican staffer looked to be rubbing his hands in glee.

The nation's most senior Republican, Mr Bush avoids such ostentatious behaviour. He has no need for it. By standing above the swirling allegations against his predecessor, Mr Bush is collecting a richer political dividend than seemed possible three weeks ago at his subdued inauguration. Mr Bush's first opinion poll approval ratings this week came in at 57%, not a bad score, especially after his controversial election. He has the Clintons to thank for it.

On the other side of the political divide the disbelief is palpable. "We find ourselves with a Democratic party that is being defined by the actions of Bill Clinton as he left office," California congresswoman Maxine Waters said this week. "I don't know how long this goes on."

If that question nags at Mrs Waters, then it is also providing a deafening background to Mrs Clinton's early weeks in the US senate. Once again, it is open season on Hillary, as Republican and Democratic enemies alike try to kick her while she is down. Everything from her hair to her ethics is grist to the mill. "They should just lay off. Come pick on some of the rest of us," Democratic Senator Kent Conrad pleaded this week. Not surprisingly, his request has gone unanswered.

For Bill and Hillary Clinton the three weeks since January 20 have been a time that you would not wish upon your greatest political enemies. Except that those words exactly describe how the Republican party establishment have seen the Clintons for the past eight years - so the rulers of the new US domestic order are loving every minute of the ongoing humiliation of the former first couple.

Gifts, pardons and White House trash

January 19 On Bill Clinton's last full day as president he strikes a deal with independent counsel Robert Ray. Charges are dropped in return for Clinton's admission of false testimony over Monica Lewinsky, five years' loss of his Arkansas legal licence and a $25,000 fine

January 20 Two hours before leaving the White House, Clinton announces 176 pardons and commutations, including former CIA director John Deutch, heiress/ terrorist Patty Hearst, Whitewater chum Susan McDougal, brother Roger Clinton and fugitive financier Marc Rich.

At noon, George Bush is sworn in.

Bill and Hillary Clinton leave the White House with $190,000 worth of gifts acquired during their eight-year residence. The Clintons fly to New York aboard Air Force One for the last time

January 23 First rumour that Clinton staff systematically removed W-keys from White House keyboards

January 24 Claims that Air Force One was "stripped bare" of memorabilia during final Clinton flight to New York

January 25 Allegations about "trashing" of White House grow with claims of graffiti, pornography, glued filing cabinets - and possible charges against Clinton and Gore staff for $60,000 worth of damage

January 26 Bush White House says no formal investigation of trashing claims

January 30 Clinton reported to be asking for $624,000 from public funds to pay for office space in midtown Manhattan

February 2 Clintons announce that they will pay for $86,000 worth of the gifts they took with them from the White House.

Clinton announces that his foundation will pay $339,000 towards the rent of his new offices; the rest will come from public funds

February 3 Clinton fundraiser Terry McAuliffe becomes new chairman of the Democratic party.

February 5 Clinton lectures financial services convention for $100,000 fee

February 7 Newspapers report Clinton argument with Al Gore in December about blame for loss of the White House. Clintons announce they are returning $28,000 worth of earlier gifts after donors said they intended them for the White House

February 8 House of Representatives government reform committee holds full day of public hearings into Clinton's pardon of Marc Rich

webTitle: Durex board to meet over rift

fields.headline: Durex board to meet over rift
fields.trailText: Durex condoms maker SSL International is likely to hold an emergency board meeting next week to thrash out disagreements among directors over the position of chief executive Iain Cater and chairman Stuart Wallis.
fields.body:
Durex condoms maker SSL International is likely to hold an emergency board meeting next week to thrash out disagreements among directors over the position of chief executive Iain Cater and chairman Stuart Wallis.

The rift, disclosed in the Guardian yesterday, has split the board with the executive team largely backing Mr Cater and many of the non-executives behind Mr Wallis.

Mr Wallis is due to return from a skiing holiday this weekend. Four other directors are overseas, including one in Australia and one in the US.

One insider said: "We're talking about mature businessmen here, running an international organisation. The matter will be considered in a civilised way."

One document to which the Guardian has gained access is entitled "The case against the chairman". It criticises the "level of commitment to the company's affairs" of Mr Wallis, who is London-based.

It also accuses him of a "general inability to bring the board together".

Another document demands the departure of Mr Cater. The letter, from a fellow director, says: "Ian, as I see it you have two options: resign or the board will terminate your service contract."

Mr Wallis could not be contacted. SSL's shares dipped 1.5p to 490p.

SSL sounded a profits warning in November due to stocking problems. This sent the shares tumbling 40%, wiping £600m off the Cheshire-based firm's value.

Some directors believe it was overambitious to merge twice in two years - first joining healthcare firm Seton with foot care company Scholl, then adding the condoms maker, London International.

fields.headline: Japan trims interest rates
fields.standfirst: Fresh package of initiatives aims to boost ailing economy
fields.trailText: Fresh package of initiatives aims to boost ailing economy
fields.body:
Japan's policymakers yesterday announced a series of initiatives aimed at raising confidence in the country's ailing economy and boosting its struggling stock market.

The Bank of Japan cut its discount rate for the first time in six years while the ruling Liberal Democrats laid out plans for a reform package, including proposals to allow companies to buy back their own shares and the introduction of US-style, equity-based pension schemes. The review also includes a promise to review the taxation of dividends.

The need for support for both the economy and the stock market has been sharply underlined this week. On Thursday the main stock market index, the Nikkei 225, fell to its lowest level for more than two years, the same day as the release of figures showing the economy had shrunk by 0.6% in the third quarter of last year.

Analysts suggested that the cut in the discount rate - from 0.5% to 0.35% - was largely symbolic and noted that the Japanese central bank had resisted pressure to cut the overnight call rate.

The decision to reduce the discount rate - the amount the central bank charges for loans to commercial banks - could help to avoid a credit crunch by heading off a rise in money market rates as banks scramble for liquidity next month when the financial year draws to a close.

"The discount rate is, in a way, a symbol so we don't expect a lot of banks to come running to use this new facility but, if something goes wrong, they know they can come here for shelter," said BoJ governor Masaru Hayami. The ruling Liberal Democrats have been putting pressure on the Bank of Japan to cut rates ahead of elections to the Upper House of the country's parliament this summer.

Mr Hayami denied the cut had been introduced because of political pressure for lower rates, however.

He said that reversing last year's decision to raise money market rates to 0.5% would not be appropriate because the economy was gradually recovering.

The news brought a modest rally in the Nikkei which gained 284.6 points to 13,422.83 but there remain deep concerns about the state of the Japanese economy.

"The [interest rate] cut is extremely cosmetic. The governor is giving something back for the mistake of the [money market] rate increase last year," according to Graham Turner at GFC Economics.

Japan was in a debt trap where falling asset prices were triggering bankruptcies which in turn were forcing further assets sales, adding to the downward pressure on prices. "Even the 1930s were not as bad as this in some respects."

The only way to break the cycle would be to nationalise the banks and call a halt to the bankruptcies according to Mr Turner, but, he said: "There is no consensus building for that."

fields.headline: Self-obsession
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 33
fields.trailText: A friend of Tanya's in publishing had told her that an old hack called Sue Townsend had been trying for years to publish the secret diaries of Adrian Mole, claiming that they were fiction
fields.body:
Friday, February 2, Ashby de la Zouch, Leicestershire

I was sitting in the kitchen with a chicken noodle Cuppa-Soup this evening, waiting for the Archers to begin, when to my astonishment I heard my name mentioned on Radio 4. I turned up the volume and listened in growing horror to a "trail" of a television programme featuring a man called Adrian Mole, a former offal chef who's family home is in Ashby de la Zouch.

This TV Mole has a mother called Pauline and a father called George. This cannot be mere coincidence - somebody has published my life and is exploiting it for commercial reasons. I immediately rang my agent's solicitor, Peter Elf, and left a message. The BBC must be prevented from broadcasting this series. Surely I have intellectual copyright on my own life?

I was unable to concentrate on the Archers, and thus missed a strand of an important storyline: will Kate go back to South Africa with her black lover and take her first-born child?

Saturday, February 3

Several people, including Pandora, have rung up to enquire about the Mole TV series. Pandora was outraged, though I could tell that she is rather flattered that she is being played by Helen Baxendale.

Monday, February 5

I rang Greg Dyke's office at 7am this morning, but the slug-a-bed was not at his bed. Do we licence-payers award a full-time salary to a man who apparently works part-time? It would appear so.

Mr Elf warned me against taking out an injunction against the BBC. He said, "It would be a David and Goliath situation." I pointed out to him that little David was in fact the victor against the giant Goliath. Elf replied, "In my opinion, David struck lucky with that stone. Goliath obviously had a very thin skull."

Tanya Braithwaite brought last week's Radio Times around this morning. Inside, was a "film-set diary" purported to have been written by a bloke calling himself Adrian Mole. This Mole bloke was also upset that his life was being exploited.

A friend of Tanya's in publishing had told her that an old hack called Sue Townsend had been trying for years to publish the secret diaries of Adrian Mole, claiming that they were fiction. She showed me a piece of the manuscript. I read in increasing astonishment as details of my private life were revealed. How does this woman know so much about me? Is she tapping my phone? Has she bugged my house? Tanya said that Townsend grew bitter after going on an Arvon poetry course led by Adrian Henri and Roger McGough, where Henri told her that she was not a poet and never would be after she handed in a poem called A Contemplation Regarding Earwig Defecation:

How to measure earwig poo?

How to know how much they do?

Are there scales to measure it

Those tiny piles of earwig shit?

Townsend then made a hysterical denunciation of modern poetry and ran out of the class and down to the river. She threatened to throw herself in unless Adrian Henri sent her earwig poem to Bloodaxe with a recommendation that they commission a thick volume of her verse. Adrian Henri came to the opposite bank and shouted across the river, "Throw yourself in and give us all a break."

Townsend has hated all men called Adrian since that day. AA Gill is another of her obsessions. Is she the reason my own literary endeavours have come to nought?

Tuesday, February 6

Leicester-born painter Adrian Hemming has fled the country after hearing that Townsend is an admirer of his work. "I heard that she was planning to buy one of my 'wave' pictures and hang it in her bathroom," he said from his hiding place. "I must protect my name."

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Vauxhall split over strike
fields.body:
Vauxhall split over strike

Vauxhall workers were divided yesterday whether to strike in protest over the car group's plan to end vehicle assembly at its Luton plant with the loss of 3,000 jobs.

The Transport and General Workers Union, the main Vauxhall union, voted 58% in favour of a walkout and 78% in favour of industrial action short of a strike.

Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union voted against a strike but in favour of other industrial action while the Manufacturing Science and Finance union was opposed to any disruptive action.

Earlier this week union leaders claimed that the company had sought to influence the ballot by making an early announcement of a £200m plan to build the next generation Vectra model at Ellesmere Port. The Vectra is made at Luton at present.

Lucent called to account

The world's largest telecoms equipment-maker, Lucent Technologies, is under investigation by the US stock exchange authority for accounting irregularities.

The securities and exchange commission is examining whether Lucent violated stock market regulations by claiming an extra $679m in sales revenue for fiscal year 2000 that the company had never put through its books.

Independent auditors PriceWaterhouseCoopers discovered in November that $452m worth of equipment was passed to Lucent's distributors but never sold to customers and $125m was reported by a sales team member without actually being sold.

More lenders cut rates

NatWest and the Woolwich lowered mortgage rates yesterday, following cuts announced by Halifax, Abbey National and Northern Rock on Thursday.

NatWest said it would reduce its standard variable mortgage rate by 0.25% to 7.49%. Woolwich will cut its Open Plan flexible mortgages and traditional mortgages from 7.75% to 7.5%. The Bank of England's monetary policy committee cut rates by 0.25% to 5.75%, which will shave around £10 a month off the average mortgage.

Hear, hear for Microsoft

Audible Inc, which downloads audio versions of books and print publications, said yesterday that Microsoft had boosted its stake in its operations with a $10m investment.

Audible's stock rose 89% in heavy trading and the firm said that the investment would further integrate its spoken content with Microsoft's Windows media technology and wireless platforms.

Microsoft, the world's biggest maker of personal computer software, had held a 7% stake in Audible.

LME goes electronic

The London Metal Exchange yesterday became the latest in a succession of exchanges to embrace electronic trading when it launched a new screen-based trading system.

LME Select will run alongside the exchange's existing open outcry and telephone systems. Electronic systems have tended to overtake traditional floor-based systems when the two operate in parallel but the LME is not pushing one system in favour of another.
fields.bodyText: Vauxhall split over strike Vauxhall workers were divided yesterday whether to strike in protest over the car group's plan to end vehicle assembly at its Luton plant with the loss of 3,000 jobs. The Transport and General Workers Union, the main Vauxhall union, voted 58% in favour of a walkout and 78% in favour of industrial action short of a strike. Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union voted against a strike but in favour of other industrial action while the Manufacturing Science and Finance union was opposed to any disruptive action. fields.headline: How to...
fields.standfirst: ...cross the road
fields.trailText: ...cross the road
fields.body:
As children, we are taught to look right, look left, and look right again. Of course, by the time you've done all this, the one gap in the traffic for the next four hours has gone. A further hazard of all this looking around is that you'll be so dizzy when you cross that you'll probably end up on the same side as you started.

Old ladies, on the other hand, cross roads without looking any way at all. They concentrate on the road four centimetres in front of their shoes, which is always remarkably empty and stays that way all the way across the dual carriageway.

You can cross at zebra crossings, so-called to distinguish them from chicken crossings 10 metres away from the zebra crossing but directly opposite the newsagent where most people cross. Proper crossings have a red man who stands as if he's about to make a parachute jump from the kerb and a green man who is slightly over-striding, as if to say, 'I'm trying to be cool, but that lorry's not braking very hard.'

From the car driver's point of view, those crossing the road are selfish, indecisive and ungrateful people who seem incapable of picking one side of the street and sticking to it. In fact, there are two types of road crossers: people who wave, say thank you and acknowledge what a drag on the economy they are; and the vigilante urban ramblers, who start crossing after the red man has appeared, climb along your front bumper and glare at you as if you're driving a staff car of the Waffen-SS.

Crossing the road at night is dangerous, especially if for some reason you're not wearing a reflective Arctic Parka. Those two tiny lights on the horizon may be the distant headlights of an oncoming car. More probably, though, they're the cigarettes of the driver of the articulated lorry and his mate who are driving so fast they've forgotten to put their headlights on.

There are about 10 drivers in Britain who encourage pedestrians to cross by flashing their headlights. Sadly, a million other drivers will take the flashing to mean they have been given permission to perform the world's most dangerous manoeuvre, which will at some stage inevitably include mowing you down.

Often, people don't bother looking when they cross the road, because they think they will be able to hear the traffic coming. When you cross the road using your ears only, three things happen at once: you step in the world's largest dog turd, you are hit in the legs by a Rolls-Royce Silver Ghost and struck in the head by a low-flying glider.

fields.headline: Something fishy
fields.trailText: It was a big job getting my tired old bod ready for a dirty weekend
fields.body:
Would I like to buy back my old cottage for a quarter of a million? Alas, I am unable even to afford the old Cotswold privy. Shropshire is the next big thing, apparently. At the thought of golden lads and blue hills, a wistful longing creeps over me, too. So, when Fred, my occasional half-hearted bisexual lover, suggests a weekend away, admit that I am shriekin' for the Wrekin.

We drive north-west in his silly, low-slung sports car. Aware I should be a youthful blonde. I'm never quite sure what Fred sees in me. "Fred? What exactly is it you see in me?" I blurt out, as we pass through Craven Arms - a suitable place to lose confidence in a relationship.

"Ha ha ha!" guffaws Fred. "You make me laugh!" "Is it..." I persevere doggedly, knowing I cannot emerge from this sentence with credit, "is it that you fancy effeminate youths and butch old women?"

"Ha ha ha! My dear Dulcie, I fancy all living things." Suppose he's a bio-sexual, then.

Blue hills loom. We are in border country - the perfect place for a bisexual. One foot in England and one in Wales. Yin and Yang. Wales is Yin, obviously - female, shadowy, secret, sly - while England is Yang: "Form an orderly queue, and have your dockets ready!"

We arrive at a small hotel perched high on a blue remembered hillside - I forget which. Our room looks down on a wooded abyss. Thank God I'm only half in love. It was a major job getting my tired old bod ready for a dirty weekend. The shaving alone took hours, as without benefit of HRT I am turning into a fat, harmless old werewolf.

Down to dinner. I order salmon trout - the kind of fish that could swing both ways. Fred orders Welsh lamb. All that bilingual navigating has given me an appetite. However, when the salmon trout arrives I am revolted by its smell: the knickers of Attila the Hun. Somehow, I can't possibly tell Fred, though. Cut tiny bits off and hide them under the watercress. However, there isn't nearly enough watercress for a complete cover-up. Realise I am approaching the humiliation of Watercressgate.

"Fred? It's quite draughty in here. Would you mind fetching my cardigan?" He looks surprised. He knows I am the sort of woman who would not flinch from fetching her own cardigan: tough, independent, able to walk. However, he obliges without a murmur. While he is away, I open my handbag, wrap the fish in my hankie, and whip it in deftly between my chequebook and my comb. Fred returns to find me relaxed and my plate empty. Receive cardigan with rapture, even though I am already boiling.

Eventually, we return to our room. "There's a peculiar smell," comments Fred, sniffing. Hold handbag as shut as possible, under my arm. Oh God! What if he thinks it's me? He shrugs, goes into the bathroom, and locks himself in. My moment has come! Rush to the window, open it, and hurl fish with all my might into the abyss. Hear a faint splash, and conclude fish has been returned to a river, though admittedly not in the fighting form one would have wished.

Handbag still stinks, though, and my comb has become a mermaid's. My chequebook has acquired a fishy odour. Perhaps I should immediately make a political donation. Fred emerges from the bathroom and sniffs again. "It's something out here," he ponders.

"You look for it," I suggest, "while I take a quick bath!" Dive into bathroom, set taps thundering, and wonder if I can possibly tear my handbag to bits with my teeth and flush it down the loo. Then somehow I come to my senses. Unlock door, switch off bath taps, and go out and confront Fred, who is watching Graham Norton. "Fred! I have a confession to make."

Fred looks worried. Briefly confess to the fish saga, identify my handbag as the source of the stink, and beg him to carry it off into the hotel grounds and hurl it into the river, while I lie back in a lavender-scented bubble bath, and gently deodorise my credit cards.

"And that, my dear Dulcie, is precisely what I see in you," Fred announces, with delight. Phew! It's going to be hard work retaining this guy's affection.

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: Malcolm Gluck is on the reds
fields.body:
A delivery man turned up recently smelling strongly of cheroots. I sent him on his way as quickly as I could, but not before he had thrust into my hands a bottle of Domaine de la Citadelle Cabernet Sauvignon 1999 from the Hull merchants, House of Townend. The next day, I opened the wine, expecting no great shakes (it had a ticket tied to its neck saying, 'Try me, please'). I smelled it and thought, 'Hmm, could be a fifth-growth Pauillac in a ripe year, or perhaps a second in a difficult vintage.' Then I tasted it: 'Youthful . . . but marvellous!'

There was an immediate elegance about the fruit, terrific blackberry typicity with a bitter-chocolate undertone cut by a charred richness. (Indeed, I wondered if the fumacious delivery man had not passed on his aroma to the wine.) This was nothing like Bordeaux now. This was a real thrill as it coursed over the tastebuds and caressed the back of the throat. The tannins were civilised and courtly, but what was truly fine about the wine was its texture and weight of attack. It has subtlety yet muscle, litheness yet strength, personality with a delicious, unforced rotundity of expression. It truly was like velvet. If only Bordeaux could widely produce cabernets such as this, for the same money, then it could truly claim to be the greatest in the world.

Domaine de la Citadelle rates 17.5 points out of 20. It is available via the House of Townend website (hotwine.com) for £4.49. This includes VAT, and minimum delivery is a dozen bottles. It s also available by mail-order for £4.99 by telephoning 01482 586582. Or you can get it via House of Townend retail outlets around Hull, whose citizens, in mourning ever since the departure of Larkin, have something to celebrate again.

Majestic also has some highly agreeable new reds. Bethany Grenache 1999 (16 points, £6.49) is unusually dry for an Aussie, but the finish delivers lovely echoes of rich fruitiness. Bethany Shiraz Cabernet 1999 (16.5 points, £7.99) has more tobacco and depth than its grenache cousin - a touch of spice, too. Mas Collet Celler de Capcanes 1998 (17 points, £5.99), from Spain, is a stunning bargain, parading gripping tannins alongside fruit that has overtones of tobacco, dried fruits and coffee. Costers del Gravet Celler de Capcanes 1998 (17 points, £8.99, also available at Oddbins) has more sweet fruit than the Mas Collet, but a touch more elegance and finesse. Lirac Les Esperelles Chteau d'Aqueria 1998 (16.5 points, £6.49) offers an exciting clash of sweet, soft fruit and seriously deep tannins. Montes Limited Selection Cabernet Sauvignon Carmenere 1999 (17.5 points, £6.99), from Chile, is a very complex wine of elegance and bite. It parades coffee, tobacco, cassis, lovely soft leather tannins and a relaxed, lingering finish in which the sum of all these things is deliciously manifest. Last and, indeed, least at Majestic, there is Domaine de Richard Vin de Pays de l'Aude 1999 (14 points, £2.79) which is a bargain. It is a soft-hearted, party wine, overall very supple and attractive for the money.

Somerfield has a trio of 14-point, £2.99 bargains. The non-vintage Valencia Red has thick and chewy fruit, all rich and clinging, and even dares to fling a little tannin at you. The non-vintage Portuguese Red is a perfect marriage with Indian food (its touch of glucosity helps sweeten the union). And for big dishes such as moules marinières with touches of ginger and chilli, there is the freshness and verve of Vin de Pays du Comte du Tolosan Les Chais Beaucarois Blanc 1998, which is also at Kwik Save.

To close this week, some uncharitable business with a charitable ending. My connection with Tesco s Superplonk wine has been criticised of late, and as a result the Guardian and I reviewed the arrangement. All income from this wine, which previously accrued to me with the paper s blessing, will now go to a thoroughly deserving charity called Keeping Kids Co of south London. Within the next few months, my website will feature full details of this affair and my robust response to the outrageous allegations made.

For the latest wine news, or to email Malcolm Gluck, visit superplonk.com.

webTitle: The knowledge - from Russia with love: blini

fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: From Russia with love: blini
fields.trailText: From Russia with love: blini
fields.body:
The subject Little pancakes, officially made with buckwheat flour, though a 50:50 mix of authenticity and wheat works better. Origin: Russia. Singular: blin - blini is the plural. Also spelled bliny in some sources.

The basics Blini are pancakes without peer, a stature deriving from two details. One: they're made with yeast, and therefore have a light, airy texture that's ethereal compared with their syrup-soaked brethren. Two: sour cream goes into the batter, breeding a tangy taste of rare richness. Seek out Borshch To Blinis (ed Lesley Chamberlain, Southwater, £7.95) for more guidance.

The details Blini are on the Knowledge's mind because Valentine's Day is on everyone else's. In four days, lovebirds with the requisite readies will be thinking of feeding each other caviar. Which is often served delicately perched on one of these delectable discs. A smear of sour cream, a soupçonette of eggs, gaze into one another's eyes. But frankly, my dear, caviar's not worth a damn unless you sell your house and buy proper unpasteurised Iranian. Does that mean blanking on blini? Naaaaah. Eggy alternatives include salmon roe (delish) and Avruga, a type of un-dyed herring roe with a devoted and discerning fan club. Little pots of lumpfish roe? Unspeakable in any colour. Egg-less alternatives? Consider smoked salmon, fish tartare or just sour cream with snipped chives. But don't forget: a good blin with good butter is finger-lickin' good - and the fingers you lick need not be attached to your own hands. Order The Knowledge Video Guide To Love And Relationships for more information.

The easy way out Skip the food of love and drink a bottle of champagne. Where to buy Buckwheat flour: health-food shops are the best bet. Caviar and salmon roe: any place catering for people with money. Avruga: swanky food shops and Waitrose.

fields.headline: The questionnaire
fields.standfirst: David Gray
fields.trailText: David Gray
fields.body:
David Gray, 32, was born in Manchester and raised in Pembrokeshire. He began making records at 23, but after three unsuccessful albums with major labels, he retired from the industry. In 1999, he returned with a new hit album, White Ladder, on his own label, and was quickly signed to EastWest Records. He releases an acoustic album, Lost Songs 95-98, on Monday.

What is your idea of perfect happiness?

It's United v Arsenal in the last ever FA Cup semifinal replay. It's one-all, 10 minutes of extra time left, and United are down to 10 men. The ball breaks to Giggs, he scorches half the length of the pitch, dances through the defence and hammers a beauty into the roof of the net. I'm in heaven.

What is your greatest fear?

Keane joins Arsenal.

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?

Road rage.

What is the trait you most deplore in others?

Bad driving.

What is your favourite fantasy?

That millions of people will start buying my records.

What do you most dislike about your appearance?

My ever-expanding midriff.

What makes you depressed?

Wasted time.

How did you vote in the last election?

Labour.

How will you vote in the next election?

Against the Tories.

For what cause would you die?

For love.

Do you believe in monogamy?

Yes.

What or who is the greatest love of your life?

My wife, Olivia.

Have you ever said 'I love you' and not meant it?

I gave it a go when I was about 16, just to hear what it sounded like.

Which words or phrases do you most overuse?

'Cool', 'Brilliant'.

When and where were you happiest?

London, 1992/93, when I met my wife and fell in love.

How do you relax?

I'm not certain that I do.

What single thing would improve the quality of your life?

A baby.

What keeps you awake at night?

Anxiety about life/Ideas for songs or anxiety about songs/Ideas for life etc.

Do you believe in life after death?

No.

How would you like to be remembered?

As someone who loved life.

What is the most important lesson life has taught you?

Negativity is a dead end.
