How did you vote in the last election? Labour. How will you vote in the next election? Against the Tories. For what cause would you die? For love. Do you believe in monogamy? Yes. What or who is the greatest love of your life? My wife, Olivia. Have you ever said 'I love you' and not meant it? I gave it a go when I was about 16, just to hear what it sounded like. Which words or phrases do you most overuse? 'Cool', 'Brilliant'. When and where were you happiest? London, 1992/93, when I met my wife and fell in love. How do you relax? I'm not certain that I do. What single thing would improve the quality of your life? A baby. What keeps you awake at night? Anxiety about life/Ideas for songs or anxiety about songs/Ideas for life etc. Do you believe in life after death? No. How would you like to be remembered? As someone who loved life. What is the most important lesson life has taught you? Negativity is a dead end.

webTitle: The first snowdrops herald the end of winter

fields.headline: Drop zone
fields.standfirst: The first snowdrops herald the end of winter. But that's not the only reason to welcome them, says Christopher Lloyd
fields.trailText: The first snowdrops herald the end of winter. But that's not the only reason to welcome them, says Christopher Lloyd
fields.body:
February is the month of the snowdrop, though in in Scotland it is perhaps more March. Quite when this flower will be out is always uncertain. More and more gardens and woodlands are opening to the public at what they hope will be the best time of year, but anything can happen, including vile conditions on the day.

However, galanthophiles, as they like to call themselves - lovers of galanthus (snowdrop) - are tough, and they are prepared to spend a few hours of acute discomfort examining minute differences between cultivars. Twenty to 30 new ones appear each year, nearly all arising from chance seedlings. They will flatter the owner by being named after themselves or their spouse, their home or village, or some reference point that means a lot to them but nothing to the rest of us. It's all a little too easy, or so it seems to me.

"I think I like my snowdrops straight," garden designer John Codrington once said to me, and one can see his point. They love our climate and in many areas (especially in Scotland) they have become densely naturalised over large acres of woodland. Deer, rabbits and other pests don't touch them; squirrels merely move them around, thereby increasing their territory. Despite its success here as a species, the snowdrop is probably not a true native. (Its ability to establish itself, however, has prompted much debate on the subject.)

The emergence of these flowers is the first wholehearted evidence that winter is on its way out. That said, a few species flower in autumn or early winter, and there is nothing in the way of a cheat about this. It just comes naturally to them. Others flower so late that they may easily run into April. So, one way or another, they give us a good spread and plenty of opportunities on a garden scale to grow them in combination with a number of other early flowers. Or they can bloom with summer-performing perennials, always provided you do not have to replant or in other ways disturb the area too often. Some disturbance every five years or so may actually be beneficial, because some snowdrops, grown in cultivated ground, increase at such a rate that their bulbs diminish in size, push each other out of the ground and eventually kill themselves. The good news is that, when naturalised in turf, the snowdrop's overcrowding problem (if it can be called one) is less obvious.

The early-flowering 'Atkinsii', which is tall, with long, teardrop-shaped flowers, never sets seed but is immensely prolific, so that you can build up stock at great speed. Of course, it is easy to understand how people get hooked. You see a different one that appeals to you and, naturally, want it. But that is different from being bitten by the snowdrop bug and avidly collecting. I might have 20 identifiable kinds, but a genuine nutter might have upwards of 300 and still be far from sated.

The collecting instinct is so natural to many of us (better snowdrops than stamps, I should say) that it would be pointless to be sniffy about it, but galanthophiles can easily become galanthobores. There is a kind of vanity involved. If you can make yourself an expert in your subject, however narrow it may be, you have a vantage point. And if it really means so much to you, chances are that you are, overall, a bit of a bore.

None of which should in any way tarnish the delights provided by snowdrops. They do command pretty colossal prices - £20 for one bulb seems quite a lot to pay. Two enthusiasts, interviewed for an article in the Royal Horticultural Society journal, The Garden, are reported to have said that neither of them "uses any commercial methods of propagation to increase their snowdrop stock. They prefer to rely on nature." That, surely, is sheer snobbery, suggesting that there is, by definition, something a bit underhand about commerce and that its methods are of necessity not nice.

Had these same enthusiasts been trained to be handy with a knife and to practise the basically quite simple techniques for increasing stock more quickly than Dame Nature manages, they would be singing a different tune. The practice of scooping out a bulb's base-plate and then giving it warm, moist conditions, so that it fairly quickly starts to make little bulbils around the rim of the cut, is very old (particularly on hyacinths) and the more rapid increase of valuable stock that it enables is of great benefit to us all. Ignorance has a lot to answer for. It is often inevitable, but nothing to take pride in.

Another point to make about the spate of newly-named snowdrops is that, while they may be curious, they are often downright ugly - far from an improvement.

Nothing will turn me off growing snowdrops. I want more and more of them, and am constantly cudgelling my brains to think of new places where they will be both happy and appropriate. If we want to divide or move them around, there is no better moment than immediately after they have flowered

Drop goals

For success with snowdrops

 Get hold of good-quality bulbs: freshly dug ones are always the best, as dry bulbs will take much longer to flower.

 Plant 7.5cm deep in dappled shade during September/October.

 Snowdrop bulbs are at their happiest in a clay/humus-rich soil that will be damp in winter and spring and dry during the summer. Top dress them lightly with compost or leaf mould.

 For reliability, choose from the more vigorous varieties, such as Galanthus 'S. Arnott', 'Atkinsii' and 'Magnet'.

 If growing snowdrops indoors, keep them on a cool, north-facing windowsill. Heat causes bulbs to go blind (ie, fail to develop flower buds).

 Plant pots from indoors outside, and divide clumps outdoors after flowering.

What to avoid

 Infestation of narcissus flies - their grubs eat developing flower buds.

 Holes left by dying leaves - rake the soil lightly to fill them in. Also, you could try dusting the soil with pirimphos-methyl before planting.

 Very acid, rich or free-draining soil, or thick grassland.

 Bulbs that show any leaf distortion or grey mould.

 Don't dig up bulbs from the wild: snowdrops, like other native flora, have suffered greatly as a result of such thieving.

 Research by Patrick Driscall

fields.headline: Hain's world
fields.standfirst: In the 70s, Peter Hain was the liberal South African firebrand with a taste for civil disobedience. His rise up Whitehall's greasy pole has prompted cries of 'sell-out', not least for his outspoken support of Iraqi sanctions. Is his new job as energy minister a promotion? Or is Tony Blair sidelining one of the few radical minds in his government?
fields.trailText: In the 70s, Peter Hain was the liberal South African firebrand with a taste for civil disobedience. His rise up Whitehall's greasy pole has prompted cries of 'sell-out', not least for his outspoken support of Iraqi sanctions. Is his new job as energy minister a promotion? Or is Tony Blair sidelining one of the few radical minds in his government?
fields.body:
Her Majesty's new minister for energy and competitiveness in Europe sits in his eighth-floor eyrie looking down on Parliament Square. To the right is Westminster Abbey, behind it the House of Commons. To the left lie the distant rooftops of his beloved Foreign Office. It's a grey, blustery London day with the wind running up the river Thames just beyond the Commons.

If Peter Mandelson had not fallen, then the new minister for energy would have been somewhere else on this Monday morning. He would have been in Nigeria, and then Ghana, on a Foreign Office trip. And there were other plans, too: speeches to the UN security council on Iraqi sanctions and, inevitably, slots on Radio 4's Today programme on the assassination of an African leader, or the worsening crisis in the Middle East. Instead, the new in-tray is filling up with briefs on miners' compensation, working party reports on vibration white-finger, the incidence of emphysema in Welsh villages and the distribution patterns of ultra-low sulphur petrol across the United Kingdom.

Scandals and resignations aside, the next British election is two to four months away. Is this, then, the pinnacle of the political career of Peter Hain, "son of Africa", activist, political firebrand of the 60s and, according to what remains of the British left, a "sell-out" and a "war criminal"?

Depending on who you talk to, Hain's shiftto this new post is: a) demotion because of his big mouth, over-aggressive tactics and Robin Cook's annoyance at being overshadowed by his junior minister; b) promotion because miners' compensation is tricky for New Labour and Tony Blair wants a good media performer in the job; c) a sideways shift that will secure Hain sufficient domestic ministerial experience to enter the cabinet after the next election; or d) the penultimate move in a short but contentious ministerial career. Hain, who like his suntan radiates aggressive optimism, adheres to option b), with elements of c) attached: "I got the call at 8.45pm to 'Ring Downing Street'. Tony said, 'I think you've done a great job at the Foreign Office. I want you back in domestic politics. I want my best people there.' I don't think it's exile."

But his shift sideways is still puzzling. Uniquely, Hain was one of only a few Foreign Office ministers in living memory actually to know anything about and be actively involved in the subject of his portfolio - in this case, Africa - before his appointment. "He was an excellent thing in the Foreign Office," said a senior FO official. "He was very popular in Africa with lots of African leaders. Peter was always prepared to talk tough, talk straight. He will be sorely missed."

But nothing is as it seems at Westminster. "Peter has tried to spin this 10 different ways," said one party colleague. "Star Wars, the American Nuclear Missile Defence [NMD] shield, has done him in. Robin Cook does not like him. He upset the mandarins. He is getting promoted before going on to great things: that one is the hollowest lie of all. If he is being promoted, how come he is being sent to the backwater of energy? His star has waned. Nothing is forever in politics, but you've got to ask yourself what was it all for. He prostituted himself for Blair's foreign policy on Iraq, and Blair's 'foreign policy' in Wales. And for what - energy?"

Politics can be a cruel and wounding business, but the depth of enmity towards Hain, half in and half out with Blair, and still a relatively junior minister, is ferocious. In a recent New Statesman article, the journalist John Pilger compared Peter Hain to the Iraqi dictator Saddam Hussein and accused the "murderous policy-maker" of being responsible for the 500,000 civilian deaths that the UN estimates have been caused by the continuing sanctions regime. "He is doing exactly the opposite thing from what he was doing in the 70s when he organised the stop-the-cricket tour," says Pilger. "I know him. I made a film with him in the 70s when he was wrongly arrested for a bank robbery in Putney. I took up his case. This is a guy who understood what the Americans did in Vietnam. And now he has become part of the straight line of US policy. He is an apologist for sanctions and bombing. He has become the fall guy."

In retort, Hain does little to mask his own disdain. "I think, in the old days, Pilger was a good investigative journalist - regrettably, I don't know many people who take him seriously. To compare me to Saddam Hussein is, frankly, beneath contempt." His voice breaks into laughter. "On this issue of sanctions, the left is divided. But the critics end up virtually apologising for Saddam. I have always been an opponent of tyranny. What the critics don't like is that I take the debate to them."

Most MPs struggle against their identikit peers to be selected for their seats and then they struggle in parliament to get promoted, to get noticed, to get ahead. In contrast, Hain has been a political celebrity, whose role as a leading Young Liberal in stopping the 1970 South African cricket tour by threatening direct-action mayhem is burned on the political memories of the over-40s. Hain's tactics were so effective that Labour prime minister Harold Wilson believed further protests would destabilise his government, and so forced the cricket authorities to cancel the tour. It was a significant blow to the apartheid state and the beginning of the worldwide sporting isolation of South Africa. Even today, virtually everywhere Hain goes he is approached by European foreign ministers, photographers, ageing activists and old rugby fans, all eager to share a moment with the first political star they ever saw.

His political path is the antithesis of the New Labourite. Twice, he has ended up on trial at the Old Bailey: once, in 1972, on trumped-up conspiracy charges, and the second four years later on equally dubious but serious bank robbery charges. And twice, after determined legal struggles, he was found not guilty. Being prosecuted at such a level is a devastating event even for an innocent man. "I slept worse than I have ever done, often waking in the night, 'in the witness box', and usually waking early in the morning with the whole incredible affair in my mind," Hain recorded in his book, A Putney Plot?

After he recovered from the ordeal of the trials, Hain helped found the successful Anti-Nazi League (ANL), which in 1976 chased the then-resurgent National Front off the streets and denied fascism a publicly respectable front in British politics. Again, it was one of the most effective direct-action campaigns in postwar British history. Most of the organising power for the ANL came from the Trotskyist Socialist Workers Party (SWP). Hain is unapologetic about his involvement: "I was press officer and steering committee member, and pulled in a lot of people who would not have touched the SWP with a bargepole. They were very impressive in their ability to generate leaflets and organise things almost overnight. They will certainly regard me as a betrayal merchant now."

Conventional political respectability came later, a lot later. It was another 15 years before he was selected for the safe Labour seat of Neath in 1991. "I never imagined I would become an MP," he admits. In fact, I was pretty sceptical of MPs for a long time. I had always seen myself as an extra-parliamentary activist. Politics has become a career where people work to become an MP from when they leave university and then, if they are members of the ruling party, work to become an government ministers. The weakness of the newer generation of MPs and ministers, not all of them, is that they do not have those political and ideological roots."

As a political activist, then, Hain's credentials are impeccable. He is the kind of politician we all think we like. He gets on well with his officials and with journalists. He is open, refreshingly candid and sort of honest. And he speaks his mind. He has called the French policy on Iraq "pretty contemptible", and denounced South African policy on Zimbabwe, while labelling the Zimbabwean government itself as "uncivilised". He is not meanly sectarian; he doesn't defend everything in the New Labour bible.

Hain's entry on to the political stage could hardly have been more tragic or auspicious. Hain was born in Nairobi in 1950, and he grew up in Pretoria, in the heart of apartheid South Africa. His parents, Walter and Adelaine, were members of the non-racial but largely white Liberal party. After the 1960 Sharpeville massacre, the Afrikaner regime systematically crushed all political opposition. The Hains, who had effectively become the Liberal party's main organisers in the very citadel of apartheid, automatically came under suspicion: the family home was raided by the security police, their mail intercepted, their phone tapped, and both parents detained before eventually being "banned" - which made it a criminal offence for them to speak to more than one person at a time or even to enter a public building. Walter Hain was hounded out of his job as an architect and all future prospective employers were warned off.

In opposing apartheid, the Hains represented a tiny, but honourable, minority within the English-speaking white community. Most white "liberals" were anything but - one horrified aunt placed an advert in the local Pretoria News disavowing any connection with the Mrs Hain of the Liberal party, who just happened to be her sister-in-law. But the ideological origins of the family in "liberalism" and not "communism" - most white activists at the time were associated with the South African Communist party and the ANC - would have significant bearing on young Peter's later political development.

The Hains had always opposed the use of violence - which was taken up by the ANC in the early 60s - but members of their political circle joined a small white terrorist group, the Armed Resistance Movement (ARM), that planted bombs. ARM was an amateurish affair, but one bomb exploded at Johannesburg station in July 1964 and killed two passers-by. A family friend, John Harris, 25, was arrested, tortured and confessed to the crime. Harris's wife, Ann, and their young son, David, went to live with the Hains in the run-up to the trial. All pleas for clemency were rejected, and Harris was sentenced to death and hanged at dawn on April 1, 1965. Because his parents were banned from speaking in public, Peter, then 15 and dressed in his school uniform, was conscripted to read Harris's funeral oration that morning. It was his first political speech. Within the hour, he was back at school.

A year later, the family were forced to flee by the apartheid security police. They left for England. The powers of darkness, as Hain wrote in his account of that time, Sing The Beloved Country, were in the ascendancy. Nelson Mandela was in prison, along with the rest of the ANC leadership, and resistance had been all but destroyed. "The apartheid state seemed immortal. We were going for good." The Hains were in exile. They settled in Putney, southwest London, at the time a rather tatty suburb along the Thames. "My father was quite clear: 'What we must do is become members of the community.' There was among South African exiles - true of all exiles - a kind of limbo existence. People were constantly waiting to go back and never settling. One of my best friends, my age, committed suicide a year after coming across. He was very able, a brilliant cricketer, brilliant academically. We [the Hain family] sunk ourselves into domestic politics. We were never going back. I joined the Young Liberals. I stayed in Putney politics until 1991."

In late 1968, the South African government had refused to allow Basil D'Oliveria, a black cricketer, to tour with the English team in South Africa because of his race. The tour was cancelled. Despite the row, the MCC announced that the 1970 tour of England by the South African cricket team would still go ahead. Hain, by now a student of mechanical engineering at Imperial College, London, formed a pressure group, Stop The Seventy Tour (STST), and announced that he and a few others were going to force the tour's cancellation.

Their first move was to disrupt the 1968 Springbok rugby tour. Until then, the division between sport and politics in Britain was sacrosanct and largely unquestioned, but the live TV coverage of protesters messing up the Afrikaners' beloved game of rugby provoked fury in South Africa, and generated immense publicity in Britain. Attempts by the organisers to thwart the demonstrators by switching venues at the last minute only led to further headlines and a deepening crisis. "Direct action" took hold as copycat protests followed the Springbok rugby team around the country - Gordon Brown signed on as Hain's Edinburgh organiser - and a secret inner STST group of activists was formed. They chained themselves to the Springbok team's coach, glued the locks on the players' hotel rooms and threw vivid orange smoke-bombs on to the pitch for the benefit of TV cameras. The final score was STST one, Springboks nil. Next summer, home secretary James Callaghan called the MCC to Downing Street; the 1970 cricket tour was called off.

It was a stunning victory for the broader anti-apartheid movement, and for Hain personally. But the campaign was not without its personal psychological costs to other members of the Hain family. Peter is the eldest of four children. Like his parents, his three siblings, Tom, Jo-Anne and Sally, were caught up in the whirlwind of political activity surrounding the STST. Private family space all but disappeared. "You spend so long thinking about other people's problems that you don't realise that you're not doing enough to sort out your own problems," says Sally Hain, who now works for her brother in his Neath constituency. "We are all scarred by that period. It took ages to get over it."

The hippies who ran on to the pitch as part of the STST campaign also gave a misleading impression of the personal lifestyle of the movement's chief organiser. It may have been the era of free love, rock'n'roll and Lebanese Red, but underneath the long sideburns Hain was a moral puritan. "In my personal life, I have never actually smoked dope - it's a terrible admission," says Hain. "I did not like the idea. I had a fairly traditional South African upbringing. I just was not interested. I found it rather distasteful. I remember one Young Liberal conference, a whole group of people were smoking dope and one came up to me and literally tried to force the cigarette into my mouth: 'Come on, Peter, try it.' I have never had a problem with people smoking pot - I just don't want to do it. I have never had a problem with people getting drunk, I just have never been drunk myself. I'm not saying I've never had too much to drink, but I've never been drunk and out of control. There is something in my constitution. At a party, even if I'm not driving home, it comes to a certain point and I stop enjoying it. I switch to water. It's very boring, I know. I did not wear flares until they had gone out of fashion."

It is an interesting admission. The most dangerous radicals are always personal conservatives; every waking, hangover-free hour is devoted to the cause. Far from being a dropout, Hain was an assiduous student and family man who married young, paid his electricity bills on time, saved for the future, and conscientiously sought the destruction of the apartheid state. His marriage, which produced two sons, lasted for 24 years and ended only last year.

Hain is hyperactive, a morning person who is probably happiest ringing his way through a 30-person-long phone task list at 8.30am. He is the author of 13 books, including the inevitable "political thriller", The Peking Connection. The books are not great, but the sheer volume of them is quite an achievement. Book-writing, particularly political tomes, is a tiresome, laborious business with next to nil financial reward. One of his last acts as Foreign Office minister was to write a 60-page pamphlet, The End Of Foreign Policy, about globalisation. Again, none of the ideas is strikingly original, but since most government ministers already work 80 hours a week, squeezing a few more hours out to produce a political tract is the mark both of a highly disciplined and highly ambitious mind. Peter Hain likes to make his mark.

He joined the Labour party in 1977, and worked first as a political researcher for the Communications Workers' Union and then, in the 80s, twice stood as the Labour party candidate in Putney, which, since he first arrived there, has turned into a rising middle-class enclave where ordinary three-bedroomed terrace houses cost £500,000. The powers of darkness, depending on your political view, were once more in the ascendancy, and Hain was soundly beaten in both the 1983 and 1987 general elections by David Mellor, despite energetic electoral campaigns.

In 1991, the Neath constituency, near Swansea, became vacant. Hain was a metropolitan shoo-in. It was a fix, but not a bad fix. Neath is partially Welsh-speaking, and it rains a lot on the roofs of the old car part factories that are now, like their former workers, redundant. Hain, with his slight South African accent, his smooth couture, his bright suntan and silver locks, is an exotic foreigner, almost an alien species. But he is a determined constituency MP who holds 42 surgeries a year. There is a full-time agent, an office and three secretaries. His majority is 17,000. Peter Hain is not going to lose Neath.

But just being an MP was never enough for Hain, who has a cold but realistic view of the average MP's life in the mother of all parliaments. "It's almost a system for institutionalising failed ambitions. There is enormous scepticism, jealousy and envy bred. It's true whoever you are. You get elected feeling you can change the world, and what you find yourself in is a very competitive, individualised activity where you are in competition for jobs, to ask questions, to do anything. And you find out you only get it if someone else doesn't. I did not have any illusions. I saw people being swallowed up by the system."

Hain's original route into the Labour party was via the left-wing Tribune group of MPs; eventually, he became chair of the Tribune newspaper board. His politics were typical of the time: redistribution of wealth, membership of CND, anti-European Union, pro-trades union, anti-multinationals. One unusual item in his political CV has been his support for the Falklands war. "I supported the invasion. After what happened, I could not see how you could do anything else. You could not have Galtieri and the tyranny he represented just coming over. There did not seem to me to be any proper anti-colonial claim that justified his fascistic government ruling over the Falkland islanders." Hain is no pacifist, but he still retains his membership of CND - a real New Labour no-no, which is why he is careful to explain that he was never more than a rank-and-file member. It's pretty clear that he no longer believes in unilateralism, but his continued CND membership has provided the Tories, not to mention his rivals in government, with convenient ammunition for sniping and parliamentary knockabout. William Hague raised the issue at prime minister'squestions. The row has followed him into his new department, where his brief covers the nuclear industry. Hain's retort to his Tory critics is pithy: "I still pay my £9 a year to Wales CND. I happen not to agree with CND's line on the Nuclear Missile Defence [NMD], but I am not going to turn my back on people in Wales who are doing some good peace work because of some Tory critics. To hell with them, frankly."

More important, his CND membership was at the centre of a professionally damaging leak and subsequent row over the American NMD programme last December that, according to the option a) theory of Hain's over-aggressive tactics, explains his removal from the sensitive Foreign Office portfolio. According to this theory, Hain had blundered into the radioactive political zone of Anglo-American nuclear relations by leaking a memo stating his opposition to NMD in order to curry favour with his old CND mates.

First a bit of background. It's no real secret that Robin Cook, Tony Blair, the British government, the Europeans, the Russians and the Chinese are decidedly luke-warm about the updated version of the American Star Wars programme. But, as the US's most compliant "ally", no one in the British government has the courage openly to tell the Americans that NMD is a foolish idea that could provoke another arms race. The government's policy has been to talk and talk about NMD to the Americans, hope the missile tests all fail, and shut up in public.

Enter the leaked memo, or at least a report of one, between Hain and Cook, where Hain expressed outright opposition to the US missile initiative. In private, the memo was fine, but public knowledge of its existence was a crime. NMD, CND . . . was Hain playing to his old leftie mates on the terraces for personal advancement? That, at least, was the first thought of Cook and his advisers. An immediate leak enquiry was instigated to unmask the traitor. Hain's team, in turn, thought one of Cook's team had done the deed to smear their rising star. Hain is adamant that the leak had nothing to do with him. "Someone in the Foreign Office did it to damage me. I do not think it has anything to do with my switch to a very important job in the Department of Trade and Industry."

Hain's last book, Ayes To The Left, A Future For Socialism, published in 1996, contains much talk of economic inequalities, freedom of information bills and making sure the intelligence services are democratically accountable. It's so far away from the New Labour norm that it reads like the manifesto of an entirely different political party from the one that Hain represents in government. In his time at the Foreign Office, Hain regularly had MI6 reports across his desk and is proud of the fact that he used that intelligence to name in Parliament Angolan sanction busters such as Victor Bout, who trade arms for diamonds.

In a move that every activist dreams of, he even got to discuss his own extensive file with the head of MI5. But nothing changes, does it? To his credit, when I asked him about all those Labour plans for democratic accountability for the intelligence services, he had the grace not to pretend for more than a few seconds that it was any different today than it was 30 years ago, when he himself was under MI5 surveillance.

Initially, he resisted the rise of the New Labour Project, and used the Tribune Group as a platform to challenge Blair's policy revolution. In a counter-attack, Blair and Brown turned up at a Tribune Group election to vote him off the organising committee, install their own placemen and collapse the parliamentary Tribune grouping from within. His card in New Labour terms was marked: "If you are not a true believer in what New Labour is supposed to be about, you will never be trusted," says Mark Seddon, a former Labour NEC member and current editor of Tribune. "To be trusted by New Labour, you have to recant your past. Peter Hain is rather too intelligent and more dangerous to do that."

After his successful 1997 election campaign in Neath, Hain was appointed junior minister in the Welsh Office under Ron Davies - who famously went for a walk on Clapham Common and was forced to resign the next morning amid a frenzy of revelations of homosexual encounters and stolen cars. Davies's spectacular fall blew the Welsh Labour party apart and reopened the leadership battle for the Welsh Assembly. In a move fiercely opposed by the vast majority of the Welsh Labour party, which favoured the popular Rhodri Morgan, Tony Blair appointed Alun Michael as the new national secretary of state for Wales and then sought to have Michael elected as first minister to the forthcoming assembly. Hain was Michael's "corner man" in the battle for leadership in an election that mirrored the Labour London mayoral candidate debacle. It was a bruising, pointless, internecine struggle that raged through the spring of 1999. "If Alun Michael was parachuted in, then Peter was the guy flying the plane," says Welsh Labour MP, Paul Flynn. "He ran the campaign, he moved to the left, then to the right and then back again. He briefed against Rhodri." After lots and lots of New Labour fixing, Michael was eventually elected - only to lose a no-confidence vote and resign a year later. Morgan was duly elected leader in February 2000, and Blair's "foreign policy" in Wales fell apart.

The Alun Michael debacle was not Hain's finest hour, and his reputation in Wales was badly tarnished. "It was one of the least comfortable, least enjoyable, campaigns I have been involved in. And lessons have been learned, as Tony Blair himself conceded," he says rather uncomfortably.

Nevertheless, Hain had clearly proved himself as a Blairista of sorts, and in the summer of 1999 he was brought into the Foreign Office by Robin Cook. Hain was at first regarded a great success and genuinely innovative. But within months he was involved in a whole series of diplomatic shouting matches. The first to blow up was Zimbabwe. Mugabe and Hain initially met in London in October 1999. Famously, Mugabe patted Hain on the knee and told him he was a "son of Africa". Things turned sour two days later, when Peter Tatchell, the gay-rights campaigner, sought to make a citizen's arrest of the African leader at his London hotel for his persecution of homosexuals in Zimbabwe. Overnight, diplomatic relations plunged as Mugabe denounced the Blair government as "gay gangsters".

As Hain and the Foreign Office quickly came to realise, shared past histories of struggle don't count for much. "Mugabe was violently assaulting the opposition and manipulating the land issue, which he had neglected for 10 years, to get re-elected - he was not going to listen to me or anybody else," says Hain, who stridently, and undiplomatically, made a point of denouncing the Mugabe regime and was criticised in particular, as a white South African, for using the term "uncivilised". But his sweetest triumph came last Christmas when Hain took an extended family holiday with his new partner, Elizabeth Howard, and his parents back to South Africa. He spent New Year in the holiest of shrines to the apartheid struggle, in the governor's quarters of Robben Island, the prison-turned-museum where Mandela spent 27 years. "I never imagined being a minister, let alone being minister for Africa. Going back to South Africa seemed miraculous."

Hain has been attacked most vehemently over his outspoken support for a string of military interventions, including Sierra Leone. His biggest battle was over Iraq, where he came under sustained assault from many of those he would have regarded as friends. For a decade, the US and Britain have unilaterally imposed no-fly zones on the Iraqi regime - regularly enforced with bombing raids. And, despite growing opposition from within the UN security council, they have maintained crippling economic blockades over Saddam Hussein's weapons programme and the continued exclusion of UN arms inspectors. Critics argue that the sanctions have done nothing to remove Saddam from power, and have rather inflicted needless suffering on the civilian Iraqi population. "I am totally against sanctions," says Tony Benn. "We have killed half a million Iraqis. Blaming that on Saddam is like blaming Churchill for the blitz. I suppose he could have stopped the blitz by surrendering to the Nazis. It's a crime against humanity."

Hain's defence is typically robust: "Firstly, I was responsible for the policy on Iraq. Secondly, I believe it. I don't think it's a perfect policy - far from it - but then you are dealing with an imperfect world, a horribly intractable position. I would not have started from here. I would have gone all the way to Baghdad and taken Saddam out. The strongest point in the critics' case is the suffering there has been. The weakest is what do you do about it. Their position amounts to a ferocious assault on sanctions to the point where they ignore and deny - which is extraordinary - that he has biological and chemical weapons. And that he has a research and defence capability that, within six or seven years, will probably give him a nuclear weapon. I do not accept that you can lay a charge of betrayal against me for supporting a policy that tries to contain Saddam's threat to the region."

Because of his aggressive stance defending the bombing and sanctions policy on Iraq, Hain has shifted shape, in the eyes of his enemies, from hero to arch betrayer. He vehemently denies he has sold out. "I come from the left, I am proudly on the left. There is an endemic culture of betrayal on the left: waiting for the next leader or spokesperson to sell you out.

"Being in government and trying to move things forward is stressful. Those who try to put pressure on government are always one-sided. But so, too, is the established position and the interests it represents. I am not saying I am no longer an activist, but you assume different roles. I still respect extra-parliamentary activists. I might not agree with them. They can regard me as a sell-out. That is their problem."

Most politicians are nobodies. They come and they go. They rule for a brief hour and they fall and disappear. Hain is another kind of creature. He has been famous for 35 years, ever since John Harris's funeral oration in apartheid South Africa: his schoolboy picture was in the papers the next day. He likes it. He has never had an another existence; he grew up writing press releases, giving interviews, taking command, organising campaigns. He is evidently good at it. He desperately wants to keep doing it. Does he have a future in Blair's next government? Is he on option c), on the path to greater things, or option d), on the way out. No one knows, apart from the true Blairistas in the Downing Street bunker. But there is something about Hain - all that energy and activity - that probably makes him more dangerous to New Labour on the outside than in the fold. Come the summer, I wouldn't be surprised to see him walking down Downing Street on Thursday mornings for that cabinet meeting
fields.bodyText: Her Majesty's new minister for energy and competitiveness in Europe sits in his eighth-floor eyrie looking down on Parliament Square. To the right is Westminster Abbey, behind it the House of Commons. To the left lie the distant rooftops of his beloved Foreign Office. It's a grey, blustery London day with the wind running up the river Thames just beyond the Commons. If Peter Mandelson had not fallen, then the new minister for energy would have been somewhere else on this Monday morning. He would have been in Nigeria, and then Ghana, on a Foreign Office trip. And there were other plans, too: speeches to the UN security council on Iraqi sanctions and, inevitably, slots on Radio 4's Today programme on the assassination of an African leader, or the worsening crisis in the Middle East. Instead, the new in-tray is filling up with briefs on miners' compensation, working party reports on vibration white-finger, the incidence of emphysema in Welsh villages and the distribution patterns of ultra-low sulphur petrol across the United Kingdom. Scandals and resignations aside, the next British election is two to four months away. Is this, then, the pinnacle of the political career of Peter Hain, "son of Africa", activist, political firebrand of the 60s and, according to what remains of the British left, a "sell-out" and a "war criminal"? Depending on who you talk to, Hain's shiftto this new post is: a) demotion because of his big mouth, over-aggressive tactics and Robin Cook's annoyance at being overshadowed by his junior minister; b) promotion because miners' compensation is tricky for New Labour and Tony Blair wants a good media performer in the job; c) a sideways shift that will secure Hain sufficient domestic ministerial experience to enter the cabinet after the next election; or d) the penultimate move in a short but contentious ministerial career. Hain, who like his suntan radiates aggressive optimism, adheres to option b), with elements of c) attached: "I got the call at 8.45pm to 'Ring Downing Street'. Tony said, 'I think you've done a great job at the Foreign Office. I want you back in domestic politics. I want my best people there.' I don't think it's exile." But his shift sideways is still puzzling. Uniquely, Hain was one of only a few Foreign Office ministers in living memory actually to know anything about and be actively involved in the subject of his portfolio - in this case, Africa - before his appointment. "He was an excellent thing in the Foreign Office," said a senior FO official. "He was very popular in Africa with lots of African leaders. Peter was always prepared to talk tough, talk straight. He will be sorely missed." But nothing is as it seems at Westminster. "Peter has tried to spin this 10 different ways," said one party colleague. "Star Wars, the American Nuclear Missile Defence [NMD] shield, has done him in. Robin Cook does not like him. He upset the mandarins. He is getting promoted before going on to great things: that one is the hollowest lie of all. If he is being promoted, how come he is being sent to the backwater of energy? His star has waned. Nothing is forever in politics, but you've got to ask yourself what was it all for. He prostituted himself for Blair's foreign policy on Iraq, and Blair's 'foreign policy' in Wales. And for what - energy?" Politics can be a cruel and wounding business, but the depth of enmity towards Hain, half in and half out with Blair, and still a relatively junior minister, is ferocious. In a recent New Statesman article, the journalist John Pilger compared Peter Hain to the Iraqi dictator Saddam Hussein and accused the "murderous policy-maker" of being responsible for the 500,000 civilian deaths that the UN estimates have been caused by the continuing sanctions regime. "He is doing exactly the opposite thing from what he was doing in the 70s when he organised the stop-the-cricket tour," says Pilger. "I know him. I made a film with him in the 70s when he was wrongly arrested for a bank robbery in Putney. I took up his case. This is a guy who understood what the Americans did in Vietnam. And now he has become part of the straight line of US policy. He is an apologist for sanctions and bombing. He has become the fall guy." In retort, Hain does little to mask his own disdain. "I think, in the old days, Pilger was a good investigative journalist - regrettably, I don't know many people who take him seriously. To compare me to Saddam Hussein is, frankly, beneath contempt." His voice breaks into laughter. "On this issue of sanctions, the left is divided. But the critics end up virtually apologising for Saddam. I have always been an opponent of tyranny. What the critics don't like is that I take the debate to them." Most MPs struggle against their identikit peers to be selected for their seats and then they struggle in parliament to get promoted, to get noticed, to get ahead. In contrast, Hain has been a political celebrity, whose role as a leading Young Liberal in stopping the 1970 South African cricket tour by threatening direct-action mayhem is burned on the political memories of the over-40s. Hain's tactics were so effective that Labour prime minister Harold Wilson believed further protests would destabilise his government, and so forced the cricket authorities to cancel the tour. It was a significant blow to the apartheid state and the beginning of the worldwide sporting isolation of South Africa. Even today, virtually everywhere Hain goes he is approached by European foreign ministers, photographers, ageing activists and old rugby fans, all eager to share a moment with the first political star they ever saw. His political path is the antithesis of the New Labourite. Twice, he has ended up on trial at the Old Bailey: once, in 1972, on trumped-up conspiracy charges, and the second four years later on equally dubious but serious bank robbery charges. And twice, after determined legal struggles, he was found not guilty. Being prosecuted at such a level is a devastating event even for an innocent man. "I slept worse than I have ever done, often waking in the night, 'in the witness box', and usually waking early in the morning with the whole incredible affair in my mind," Hain recorded in his book, A Putney Plot? After he recovered from the ordeal of the trials, Hain helped found the successful Anti-Nazi League (ANL), which in 1976 chased the then-resurgent National Front off the streets and denied fascism a publicly respectable front in British politics. Again, it was one of the most effective direct-action campaigns in postwar British history. Most of the organising power for the ANL came from the Trotskyist Socialist Workers Party (SWP). Hain is unapologetic about his involvement: "I was press officer and steering committee member, and pulled in a lot of people who would not have touched the SWP with a bargepole. They were very impressive in their ability to generate leaflets and organise things almost overnight. They will certainly regard me as a betrayal merchant now." Conventional political respectability came later, a lot later. It was another 15 years before he was selected for the safe Labour seat of Neath in 1991. "I never imagined I would become an MP," he admits. In fact, I was pretty sceptical of MPs for a long time. I had always seen myself as an extra-parliamentary activist. Politics has become a career where people work to become an MP from when they leave university and then, if they are members of the ruling party, work to become an government ministers. The weakness of the newer generation of MPs and ministers, not all of them, is that they do not have those political and ideological roots." As a political activist, then, Hain's credentials are impeccable. He is the kind of politician we all think we like. He gets on well with his officials and with journalists. He is open, refreshingly candid and sort of honest. And he speaks his mind. He has called the French policy on Iraq "pretty contemptible", and denounced South African policy on Zimbabwe, while labelling the Zimbabwean government itself as "uncivilised". He is not meanly sectarian; he doesn't defend everything in the New Labour bible. Hain's entry on to the political stage could hardly have been more tragic or auspicious. Hain was born in Nairobi in 1950, and he grew up in Pretoria, in the heart of apartheid South Africa. His parents, Walter and Adelaine, were members of the non-racial but largely white Liberal party. After the 1960 Sharpeville massacre, the Afrikaner regime systematically crushed all political opposition. The Hains, who had effectively become the Liberal party's main organisers in the very citadel of apartheid, automatically came under suspicion: the family home was raided by the security police, their mail intercepted, their phone tapped, and both parents detained before eventually being "banned" - which made it a criminal offence for them to speak to more than one person at a time or even to enter a public building. Walter Hain was hounded out of his job as an architect and all future prospective employers were warned off. In opposing apartheid, the Hains represented a tiny, but honourable, minority within the English-speaking white community. Most white "liberals" were anything but - one horrified aunt placed an advert in the local Pretoria News disavowing any connection with the Mrs Hain of the Liberal party, who just happened to be her sister-in-law. But the ideological origins of the family in "liberalism" and not "communism" - most white activists at the time were associated with the South African Communist party and the ANC - would have significant bearing on young Peter's later political development. The Hains had always opposed the use of violence - which was taken up by the ANC in the early 60s - but members of their political circle joined a small white terrorist group, the Armed Resistance Movement (ARM), that planted bombs. ARM was an amateurish affair, but one bomb exploded at Johannesburg station in July 1964 and killed two passers-by. A family friend, John Harris, 25, was arrested, tortured and confessed to the crime. Harris's wife, Ann, and their young son, David, went to live with the Hains in the run-up to the trial. All pleas for clemency were rejected, and Harris was sentenced to death and hanged at dawn on April 1, 1965. Because his parents were banned from speaking in public, Peter, then 15 and dressed in his school uniform, was conscripted to read Harris's funeral oration that morning. It was his first political speech. Within the hour, he was back at school. A year later, the family were forced to flee by the apartheid security police. They left for England. The powers of darkness, as Hain wrote in his account of that time, Sing The Beloved Country, were in the ascendancy. Nelson Mandela was in prison, along with the rest of the ANC leadership, and resistance had been all but destroyed. "The apartheid state seemed immortal. We were going for good." The Hains were in exile. They settled in Putney, southwest London, at the time a rather tatty suburb along the Thames. "My father was quite clear: 'What we must do is become members of the community.' There was among South African exiles - true of all exiles - a kind of limbo existence. People were constantly waiting to go back and never settling. One of my best friends, my age, committed suicide a year after coming across. He was very able, a brilliant cricketer, brilliant academically. We [the Hain family] sunk ourselves into domestic politics. We were never going back. I joined the Young Liberals. I stayed in Putney politics until 1991." In late 1968, the South African government had refused to allow Basil D'Oliveria, a black cricketer, to tour with the English team in South Africa because of his race. The tour was cancelled. Despite the row, the MCC announced that the 1970 tour of England by the South African cricket team would still go ahead. Hain, by now a student of mechanical engineering at Imperial College, London, formed a pressure group, Stop The Seventy Tour (STST), and announced that he and a few others were going to force the tour's cancellation. Their first move was to disrupt the 1968 Springbok rugby tour. Until then, the division between sport and politics in Britain was sacrosanct and largely unquestioned, but the live TV coverage of protesters messing up the Afrikaners' beloved game of rugby provoked fury in South Africa, and generated immense publicity in Britain. Attempts by the organisers to thwart the demonstrators by switching venues at the last minute only led to further headlines and a deepening crisis. "Direct action" took hold as copycat protests followed the Springbok rugby team around the country - Gordon Brown signed on as Hain's Edinburgh organiser - and a secret inner STST group of activists was formed. They chained themselves to the Springbok team's coach, glued the locks on the players' hotel rooms and threw vivid orange smoke-bombs on to the pitch for the benefit of TV cameras. The final score was STST one, Springboks nil. Next summer, home secretary James Callaghan called the MCC to Downing Street; the 1970 cricket tour was called off. It was a stunning victory for the broader anti-apartheid movement, and for Hain personally. But the campaign was not without its personal psychological costs to other members of the Hain family. Peter is the eldest of four children. Like his parents, his three siblings, Tom, Jo-Anne and Sally, were caught up in the whirlwind of political activity surrounding the STST. Private family space all but disappeared. "You spend so long thinking about other people's problems that you don't realise that you're not doing enough to sort out your own problems," says Sally Hain, who now works for her brother in his Neath constituency. "We are all scarred by that period. It took ages to get over it." The hippies who ran on to the pitch as part of the STST campaign also gave a misleading impression of the personal lifestyle of the movement's chief organiser. It may have been the era of free love, rock'n'roll and Lebanese Red, but underneath the long sideburns Hain was a moral puritan. "In my personal life, I have never actually smoked dope - it's a terrible admission," says Hain. "I did not like the idea. I had a fairly traditional South African upbringing. I just was not interested. I found it rather distasteful. I remember one Young Liberal conference, a whole group of people were smoking dope and one came up to me and literally tried to force the cigarette into my mouth: 'Come on, Peter, try it.' I have never had a problem with people smoking pot - I just don't want to do it. I have never had a problem with people getting drunk, I just have never been drunk myself. I'm not saying I've never had too much to drink, but I've never been drunk and out of control. There is something in my constitution. At a party, even if I'm not driving home, it comes to a certain point and I stop enjoying it. I switch to water. It's very boring, I know. I did not wear flares until they had gone out of fashion." It is an interesting admission. The most dangerous radicals are always personal conservatives; every waking, hangover-free hour is devoted to the cause. Far from being a dropout, Hain was an assiduous student and family man who married young, paid his electricity bills on time, saved for the future, and conscientiously sought the destruction of the apartheid state. Book-writing, particularly political tomes, is a tiresome, laborious business with next to nil financial reward. One of his last acts as Foreign Office minister was to write a 60-page pamphlet, The End Of Foreign Policy, about globalisation. Again, none of the ideas is strikingly original, but since most government ministers already work 80 hours a week, squeezing a few more hours out to produce a political tract is the mark both of a highly disciplined and highly ambitious mind. The powers of darkness, depending on your political view, were once more in the ascendancy, and Hain was soundly beaten in both the 1983 and 1987 general elections by David Mellor, despite energetic electoral campaigns. "It's almost a system for institutionalising failed ambitions. There is enormous scepticism, jealousy and envy bred. It's true whoever you are. You get elected feeling you can change the world, and what you find yourself in is a very competitive, individualised activity where you are in competition for jobs, to ask questions, to do anything. And you find out you only get it if someone else doesn't. I did not have any illusions. I saw people being swallowed up by the system." The Alun Michael debacle was not Hain's finest hour, and his reputation in Wales was badly tarnished. "It was one of the least comfortable, least enjoyable, campaigns I have been involved in. And lessons have been learned, as Tony Blair himself conceded," he says rather uncomfortably. Nevertheless, Hain had clearly proved himself as a Blairista of sorts, and in the summer of 1999 he was brought into the Foreign Office by Robin Cook. Hain was at first regarded a great success and genuinely innovative. But within months he was involved in a whole series of diplomatic shouting matches. The first to blow up was Zimbabwe. Mugabe and Hain initially met in London in October 1999. Famously, Mugabe patted Hain on the knee and told him he was a "son of Africa". Things turned sour two days later, when Peter Tatchell, the gay-rights campaigner, sought to make a citizen's arrest of the African leader at his London hotel for his persecution of homosexuals in Zimbabwe. Overnight, diplomatic relations plunged as Mugabe denounced the Blair government as "gay gangsters". As Hain and the Foreign Office quickly came to realise, shared past histories of struggle don't count for much. "Mugabe was violently assaulting the opposition and manipulating the land issue, which he had neglected for 10 years, to get re-elected - he was not going to listen to me or anybody else," says Hain, who stridently, and undiplomatically, made a point of denouncing the Mugabe regime and was criticised in particular, as a white South African, for using the term "uncivilised". But his sweetest triumph came last Christmas when Hain took an extended family holiday with his new partner, Elizabeth Howard, and his parents back to South Africa. He spent New Year in the holiest of shrines to the apartheid struggle, in the governor's quarters of Robben Island, the prison-turned-museum where Mandela spent 27 years. "I never imagined being a minister, let alone being minister for Africa. Going back to South Africa seemed miraculous." Hain has been attacked most vehemently over his outspoken support for a string of military interventions, including Sierra Leone. His biggest battle was over Iraq, where he came under sustained assault from many of those he would have regarded as friends. For a decade, the US and Britain have unilaterally imposed no-fly zones on the Iraqi regime - regularly enforced with bombing raids. And, despite growing opposition from within the UN security council, they have maintained crippling economic blockades over Saddam Hussein's weapons programme and the continued exclusion of UN arms inspectors. Critics argue that the sanctions have done nothing to remove Saddam from power, and have rather inflicted needless suffering on the civilian Iraqi population. "I am totally against sanctions," says Tony Benn. "We have killed half a million Iraqis. Blaming that on Saddam is like blaming Churchill for the blitz. I suppose he could have stopped the blitz by surrendering to the Nazis. It's a crime against humanity." Hain's defence is typically robust: "Firstly, I was responsible for the policy on Iraq. Secondly, I believe it. I don't think it's a perfect policy - far from it - but then you are dealing with an imperfect world, a horribly intractable position. I would not have started from here. I would have gone all the way to Baghdad and taken Saddam out. The strongest point in the critics' case is the suffering there has been. The weakest is what do you do about it. Their position amounts to a ferocious assault on sanctions to the point where they ignore and deny - which is extraordinary - that he has biological and chemical weapons. And that he has a research and defence capability that, within six or seven years, will probably give him a nuclear weapon. I do not accept that you can lay a charge of betrayal against me for supporting a policy that tries to contain Saddam's threat to the region." Because of his aggressive stance defending the bombing and sanctions policy on Iraq, Hain has shifted shape, in the eyes of his enemies, from hero to arch betrayer. He vehemently denies he has sold out. "I come from the left, I am proudly on the left. There is an endemic culture of betrayal on the left: waiting for the next leader or spokesperson to sell you out. "Being in government and trying to move things forward is stressful. Those who try to put pressure on government are always one-sided. But so, too, is the established position and the interests it represents. I am not saying I am no longer an activist, but you assume different roles. I still respect extra-parliamentary activists. I might not agree with them. They can regard me as a sell-out. That is their problem." Most politicians are nobodies. They come and they go. They rule for a brief hour and they fall and disappear. Hain is another kind of creature. He has been famous for 35 years, ever since John Harris's funeral oration in apartheid South Africa: his schoolboy picture was in the papers the next day. He likes it. He has never had an another existence; he grew up writing press releases, giving interviews, taking command, organising campaigns. He is evidently good at it. He desperately wants to keep doing it. Does he have a future in Blair's next government? Is he on option c), on the path to greater things, or option d), on the way out. No one knows, apart from the true Blairistas in the Downing Street bunker. But there is something about Hain - all that energy and activity - that probably makes him more dangerous to New Labour on the outside than in the fold. Come the summer, I wouldn't be surprised to see him walking down Downing Street on Thursday mornings for that cabinet meeting

fields.headline: Small, but perfectly formed
fields.standfirst: Poppy seeds may be limited in the ways you can use them, but they have a great effect
fields.trailText: Poppy seeds may be limited in the ways you can use them, but they have a great effect
fields.body:
Fennel seed is a sadly neglected spice, for no apparent reason. It may simply be that, as a native of Europe and of the British Isles, the seeds have little of the extraordinary glamour that surrounds the famed spices of the east. Or that, like any herb or spice, when used injudiciously, they will bully all subtlety and taste from a dish.

Even so, their almost complete absence from our food is hard to comprehend, for when used with a sure hand fennel seed is highly aromatic and seasons food quite deliciously. These seeds are used perhaps most famously in the sausages and salamis of Italy, notably the finocchiona of Tuscany. There is a fair amount of reference in my culinary library to the use of fennel fronds in British cooking, but practically none concerning the seeds.

This is as annoying as it is odd, for fennel seeds flavour cream in so delicate a manner that they are suitable both for fish cookery and for desserts, and are also a quite brilliant match with orange, not to mention pork. They also marry well with poppy seeds, those curious, very hard, tiny little seeds that so resemble Lilliputian shot. Beloved of northern and eastern European cooking, of Jewish cooking and of northern Italian cooking, for baking in and on all manner of breads and pastries, poppy seeds may be rather limited in the ways you can use them, but they have a great effect.

All recipes serve six.

Polenta cake

I have rarely enjoyed the sight, let alone the taste, of creamy gateaux, and it is most disheartening to see the average baker's window full of foul confections topped with great blobs of aerated, canned, whipped cream. I am of the school where butter and almonds combine to give a rich crumble cake with true depth of flavour. Both Italy and Spain have a love of almonds reflected in a huge variety of delicious biscuits, cakes and pastries, a testament to their shared moorish influences. This recipe makes a cracking good cake that is splendid for a chomp with a cup of coffee during the day or with a spoonful of preserved or poached fruit and freshly churned ice cream of a dinner time. The fennel and poppy seeds each add a quite individual note to the flavour. It is worth warming the cake slightly if serving as a dessert.

375g unsalted butter
375g caster sugar
360g ground almonds
5 very fresh large eggs
1 tsp vanilla extract
2 tbsp poppy seeds
1 heaped tsp fennel seeds
4 oranges, juiced and zested
1 tsp baking powder
150g polenta
Salt

Preheat the oven to 175C/350F/gas mark 4, and line a deep cake tin with silicon paper. Cut the butter into small pieces, and beat with the sugar until pale and creamy. Stir in the ground almonds. Crack the eggs into a jug and beat them with a fork. Beating the butter and sugar mixture continuously, slowly add the egg and then the vanilla extract, fennel seeds (bash them up a bit first in a mortar and pestle, the better to release the flavour within), poppy seeds, orange juice and zest, baking powder, polenta and a pinch of salt. Mix together and decant into the prepared cake tin. Bake for 50 minutes to one hour. Leave to cool in the tin.

Olive oil and fennel seed biscuits

Flecks of pungent anise are common in Italian biscotti; fennel seeds, meanwhile, add a milder flavour, and have just as much appeal. It is unusual for a spice to sit as comfortably at the end of a meal as it does at the beginning. The pairing of fennel and olive oil in this recipe has the unnerving quality of turning the dough a most alarming green. I hasten to add that this is the one odd property of these delicious and most unusual biscuits. I have asked Andrea, the pastry chef at Blue Print, if one might add poppy seeds to the recipe, but his curled lip was answer enough - he is Italian, after all. Nonetheless, I tried them out at home and they were delicious (and quite splendid when served with orange ice cream). Anyway, the Italians, particularly those from the north, use poppy seeds to great effect in quite a few biscuit and cake recipes.

350g plain flour
100g caster sugar
1 egg
80ml Marsala
250ml olive oil
Salt
12 fennel seeds
One orange, zest finely grated

Preheat the oven to 175C/350F/ gas mark 4. Sieve the flour, mix in the sugar and add a pinch of salt. Beat the egg in a cup and add to the flour, along with the orange zest, fennel seeds (bruise them a little first), Marsala and olive oil. Mix the ingredients, then knead them lightly to form a dough. Cover the dough and refrigerate for half an hour. Take small pieces of dough and flatten them into roughly shaped rounds, then scatter them lightly with some more caster sugar and place on baking sheets.

Bake for 12 minutes or so, until the edges turn golden, lift the biscuits out of the tray and leave them to cool on a wire rack. They will keep well in a sealed container for a few days.

Roast pork with fennel seed

Market shopping is a part of daily life throughout continental Europe, where such gatherings seem to hold their own against the corporate giants, unlike those in Blighty. In all of them, there is always food on offer to be eaten while you are shopping. In Umbria, they do a really good suckling pig stuffed with fennel - pork has a great affinity with fennel, which makes it all the more puzzling that this combination of meat and herb does not appear on menus more often. I can still remember some that I tasted, sold from a van at Orvieto market, much as they sell hamburgers outside our football grounds (only without the grease and rancid onions). This recipe uses belly pork, which, though not authentic, still makes for a fabulous dish.

1 belly of pork
2 tbsp fennel seeds
1 tsp picked fresh rosemary leaves
tsp picked fresh thyme
10 cloves garlic
Sea salt and black pepper

Lightly score the skin of the pork with a sharp knife. Remove the ribs from the underbelly, then carefully remove the skin in one piece. Render the fennel seeds and garlic to a paste in a pestle and mortar or coffee grinder, and add the herbs and plenty of seasoning. Spread this mix over the bare meat, then lay the skin back in place on top of the paste. Roll tightly and secure with butcher's string.

Put the rib bones in the bottom of a roasting pan, and place the belly on top. Cook at the lowest temperature for the longest time - say, three hours at 135C/275F/gas mark 1. Leave the meat to rest for half an hour to 45 minutes before transferring it to a serving plate. Carve with pride.

Roast potatoes with fennel seeds

These go well with the pork.

6 large potatoes, such as King Edwards
1 head garlic
1 level tsp fennel seeds
1 sprig rosemary, picked
6-8 tbsp olive oil (or goose or duck fat, if available)
Sea salt

Scrub the potatoes and place them in a pan of cold water. Bring to a boil and simmer until the potatoes are fully cooked and the skin remains unbroken. Drain the potatoes and, when cool enough, peel them. Heat a roasting tray in the oven, add the olive oil (or fat) and then the potatoes, broken roughly into biggish pieces. Separate the garlic into cloves, and place these among the potatoes. Add more oil if required, then roast for 15-20 minutes at the top of the oven in which you are cooking the pork. Remove from the oven, turn the potatoes and return to the oven. Repeat thus until the spuds have a well-coloured crust outside and are still moist within. Scatter over the fennel seeds and rosemary, liberally season with sea salt, then carefully turn the potatoes in the oil to ensure that all the seeds are attached evenly. Serve at once

 Jeremy Lee is chef at Blue Print Cafe, Butlers Wharf, London SE1.

webTitle: Flaws that may ruin master of spin

fields.headline: Flaws that may ruin master of spin
fields.standfirst:
Mandelson in his darkest hour shows the menace and the vulnerability that may finally destroy what remains of his reputation

Special report: Peter Mandelson
fields.trailText: Mandelson in his darkest hour shows the menace and the vulnerability that may finally destroy what remains of his reputation
fields.body:
In his darkest hour Peter Mandelson has displayed two distinct sides of his character which, if he is not careful, will destroy what remains of his reputation.

Amid a media scrum in his Hartlepool constituency yesterday an arrogant, and at times slightly menacing, Peter Mandelson was in evidence. As he toured his constituency, a respected local radio presenter was treated with barely concealed contempt as he tried to put the concerns of ordinary constituents to him.

Behind this unfortunate public image, a slightly more endearing side of Mr Mandelson's character has been on display in private. Over the past week, a vulnerable Mr Mandelson has toured newspaper offices to pour out his heart over the unjust way in which he was removed from office.

The master of spin hopes that this twin approach will help him clear his name. In public, he hopes to present himself as a dedicated constituency MP striving to improve life in Hartlepool. In private, he will mount the fight of his life to clear his name.

But his tactics appeared to backfire. In his interview with BBC Radio Cleveland - his first since resigning - Mr Mandelson was torn apart by the veteran presenter Alan Wright as he tried to cast himself as a dedicated local MP.

Armed with the morning newspapers, which recorded the thoughts of Mr Mandelson's "friends", the presenter repeatedly cut across him. At one point, he accused Mr Mandelson of having a "brass neck" to suggest he had no hand in the speculation that he might like to become European commissioner.

Downing Street, which has been careful to avoid a public slanging match, could only look on in despair as Mr Mandelson inflicted more damage on the party he professes to love.

The Mandelson camp insisted yesterday that his media campaign is proving a success. His supporters say he is ignoring pleas to remain silent because the former Northern Ireland secretary believes he is the victim of a grave injustice. His friend, author Robert Harris, underlined the depths of his despair when he compared his plight to the French Captain Dreyfus who was exiled to Devil's Island in the 1890s over trumped-up charges that he was a German spy.

Mr Mandelson is fearful that he may not secure the official pardon which Dreyfus eventually won. He believes that unless he mounts his own vigorous defence through the media, the official inquiry into the Hinduja passport affair may leave a permanent cloud over his name.

There is a deep suspicion in the Mandelson camp that the inquiry, which is to be chaired by the former government solicitor Sir Anthony Hammond, is a Home Office "stitch up". Mr Mandelson was removed from office by what friends have described as a Downing Street "hanging bench" after a dispute with the Home Office over his involvement in the Hinduja passport application.

The Home Office insists that he spoke to its minister, Mike O'Brien, about the application in 1998. But Mr Mandelson says he did not speak to Mr O'Brien. His failure to provide cast iron proof on this point sealed his fate when he was summoned to Downing Street on the morning of 24 January.

His camp believe Sir Anthony will not investigate this area, even though a memo prepared by Mr Mandelson's former officials in the Northern Ireland Office raises doubts over the Home Office account.

One Mandelson supporter said: "The Hammond inquiry is likely to be a Home Office stitch-up. He may not pass judgment on anything other than whether proper procedures were followed over the passport application. Hammond may feel that touching on this would be like taking a light to a petrol station."

It is this doubt which prompted Mr Mandelson to spin his side of the story. His first move came in the Sunday Times four days after his resignation when he produced a lengthy account which raised more questions than it answered.

The Mandelson camp struck again last weekend. A Northern Ireland Office memo, which said Mr O'Brien did not remember how Mr Mandelson raised the Hinduja passport, appeared in the Sunday Times.

On the same day, the Independent on Sunday reported that Mr Mandelson was planning to "keep on fighting". This was prompted by a message, left on the editor, Janet Street Porter's mobile answerphone, in which he declared: "I have got to clear my name."

The next day Mr Mandelson returned to London, promising to remain silent. Behind the scenes, however, he was hard at work.

On Wednesday he held separate meetings with senior executives of the Financial Times and the Times. This led to lengthy pieces in both papers on consecutive days which were generally favourable to Mr Mandelson. The Times concluded that his resignation "was at best a careless occurrence and at worst a panicky one" by Downing Street.

The following day he made what may prove to be his most serious mistake. On the day that Tony Blair delivered his most important speech since the Labour conference, Mr Mandelson held lengthy meetings with Labour's bitterest enemies - the Daily Mail and the Daily Telegraph.

He spent 90 minutes on Thursday at the Kensington offices of the Daily Mail. From there, he was driven to the Canary Wharf office of the Daily Telegraph for a meeting with senior executives, including the editor, Charles Moore.

This ensured the Telegraph, the Times and the Mail devoted more space to his fightback than to Mr Blair's speech. To Alastair Campbell, it may prove to be his greatest offence.

'There is no point in complaining about the media. You take the rough with the smooth'

Peter Mandelson interviewed by Alan Wright on BBC Radio Cleveland

PM: If there are any of the people who have left flowers, cakes and cards for me who are listening to me this morning I just want to thank them. I love the flowers, I've enjoyed the cakes and the cards and the letters are very, very reassuring for me. They are very comforting at a time of some distress for me.

AW: You've got someone listening today who is on the verge of redundancy from Corus. They'll be going through distress. They don't have the option of coming to Hartlepool for a night, then going to a party in London and then going to the US to recover. Is that an indication of how far you can get removed?

PM: I don't know why you're putting that in that very perjorative way.

AW: It's what happened.

PM: It isn't actually.

AW: It is what callers to our programme have said they don't like.

PM: It isn't actually what happened. It's what you think happened. If you think I am going to trawl over what I did two weekends ago after I resigned then I'm afraid I am going to disappoint you. What I will say to you is that I have a reputation in Hartlepool for attending very diligently to my constituents' needs.

AW: Can you put on record that there is not an intention to use the Hartlepool seat, if elected, as an avenue to become a European commissioner as some people have been saying?

PM: Who is saying that?

AW: Some of the press this morning.

PM: Some of the press is it? You're joking? You're not saying the press are speculating about that along with a whole number of things about me day in day out. I can't believe it Alan.

AW: Is the speculation untrue?

PM: Speculation by definition is untrue. Newspapers have got to fill their pages. I wish they would fill it with things that are of real direct concern and based on fact. But there is no point in a politician complaining about the media. It is like a sailor complaining about the weather. Sometimes it is very stormy and sometimes it is beautifully still. You have to take the rough with the smooth and that is what I am doing.

AW asked about his brush with a BBC cameraman

PM: I came into this completely dark church yard... suddenly all the lights came on, blinding me and all the people around me.
