One Mandelson supporter said: "The Hammond inquiry is likely to be a Home Office stitch-up. He may not pass judgment on anything other than whether proper procedures were followed over the passport application. Hammond may feel that touching on this would be like taking a light to a petrol station." It is this doubt which prompted Mr Mandelson to spin his side of the story. His first move came in the Sunday Times four days after his resignation when he produced a lengthy account which raised more questions than it answered. The Mandelson camp struck again last weekend. A Northern Ireland Office memo, which said Mr O'Brien did not remember how Mr Mandelson raised the Hinduja passport, appeared in the Sunday Times. On the same day, the Independent on Sunday reported that Mr Mandelson was planning to "keep on fighting". This was prompted by a message, left on the editor, Janet Street Porter's mobile answerphone, in which he declared: "I have got to clear my name." The next day Mr Mandelson returned to London, promising to remain silent. Behind the scenes, however, he was hard at work. On Wednesday he held separate meetings with senior executives of the Financial Times and the Times. This led to lengthy pieces in both papers on consecutive days which were generally favourable to Mr Mandelson. The Times concluded that his resignation "was at best a careless occurrence and at worst a panicky one" by Downing Street. The following day he made what may prove to be his most serious mistake. On the day that Tony Blair delivered his most important speech since the Labour conference, Mr Mandelson held lengthy meetings with Labour's bitterest enemies - the Daily Mail and the Daily Telegraph. He spent 90 minutes on Thursday at the Kensington offices of the Daily Mail. From there, he was driven to the Canary Wharf office of the Daily Telegraph for a meeting with senior executives, including the editor, Charles Moore. This ensured the Telegraph, the Times and the Mail devoted more space to his fightback than to Mr Blair's speech. To Alastair Campbell, it may prove to be his greatest offence. 'There is no point in complaining about the media. You take the rough with the smooth' Peter Mandelson interviewed by Alan Wright on BBC Radio Cleveland PM: If there are any of the people who have left flowers, cakes and cards for me who are listening to me this morning I just want to thank them. I love the flowers, I've enjoyed the cakes and the cards and the letters are very, very reassuring for me. They are very comforting at a time of some distress for me. AW: You've got someone listening today who is on the verge of redundancy from Corus. They'll be going through distress. They don't have the option of coming to Hartlepool for a night, then going to a party in London and then going to the US to recover. Is that an indication of how far you can get removed? PM: I don't know why you're putting that in that very perjorative way. AW: It's what happened. PM: It isn't actually. AW: It is what callers to our programme have said they don't like. PM: It isn't actually what happened. It's what you think happened. If you think I am going to trawl over what I did two weekends ago after I resigned then I'm afraid I am going to disappoint you. What I will say to you is that I have a reputation in Hartlepool for attending very diligently to my constituents' needs. AW: Can you put on record that there is not an intention to use the Hartlepool seat, if elected, as an avenue to become a European commissioner as some people have been saying? PM: Who is saying that? AW: Some of the press this morning. PM: Some of the press is it? You're joking? You're not saying the press are speculating about that along with a whole number of things about me day in day out. I can't believe it Alan. AW: Is the speculation untrue? PM: Speculation by definition is untrue. Newspapers have got to fill their pages. I wish they would fill it with things that are of real direct concern and based on fact. But there is no point in a politician complaining about the media. It is like a sailor complaining about the weather. Sometimes it is very stormy and sometimes it is beautifully still. You have to take the rough with the smooth and that is what I am doing. AW asked about his brush with a BBC cameraman PM: I came into this completely dark church yard... suddenly all the lights came on, blinding me and all the people around me. fields.headline: Dear Weekend
fields.trailText: Letters
fields.body:
A few years ago, the British Journal of Photography published a series of articles comparing results from a low-priced Chinese 6x6cm format stills camera with those from a professional quality 35mm camera. Shortly after Stanley Kubrick's death, the series author, technical expert Geoffrey Crawley, revealed that the idea for the exercise had come from his friend Kubrick, whose passion for stills photography and its technology (Eyes Wide Open, February 3) lasted right up to his death.

Chris Gent
Nottingham

'Emptying the term genocide of its very real meaning' is exactly what Paul Flewers achieved by equating 'meaning' with comparative numbers killed in Bosnia and Armenia (Dear Weekend, February 3). Genocide is a legal term, not an emotive one. Its meaning has nothing to do with the numbers killed in one conflict compared with another. Genocide is an organised act, an intention to destroy a group, whether defined by nationality, ethnicity, race or religion, not for what they have done but for what they are. To deny that what happened in Bosnia is a genocide because only '50,000-200,000' died is a lasting insult that cannot be accepted.

Simon Mears
mearsx@yahoo.com

Three letters on Julie Burchill's opinion of the All Saints and two on the annihilation of the Armenians (Dear Weekend, February 3). Was this a proportionate representation of the postbag for that week? If so, then I finally understand the lengthy coverage your paper gave to the phenomenon of dumbing down.

Kate Searle
London N16

Readers must be increasingly bored with Julie Burchill pursuing the kind of vendetta against her local council that is usually the preserve of bitter local newspaper columnists. The only difference between the two is Burchill's lack of local knowledge. Brighton & Hove Council's alleged 'lidocide', whereby we supposedly 'abolish any rogue patch of water', manifested itself in 1998 in our £300,000 restoration of Saltdean Lido.

In 1999, a new £45,000 paddling pool opened at Hove Lagoon, thanks to a joint scheme by the council and local businesses. And the 'huge, glorious paddling pool near the West Pier' was, in fact, a child-hostile, 30s concrete bunker probably responsible for the painful removal of more kids' front teeth than all the local dentists put together. We're building a new £1 million paddling and play facility 50 yards away, which will open this year as part of an acclaimed seafront redevelopment. I can only suggest Ms Burchill gets out more - even if it is only to the journalism course at Brighton College of Technology.

Tony Miller
Head of communications
Brighton & Hove Council

Hours after receiving a summons for jury service, I read Guy Browning's How To... Do Jury Service (February 3). Just in case I'm on a roll, could he devote next Saturday's column to How To Do Lottery/Pools wins?

David Cuthell
Hereford

My mate Karl wants to know if Phil Rumney's Melanie, 'the most beautiful woman in the world', has a sister (Dear Weekend, February 3).

Shirley Squires
Hull

webTitle: Leader: Mandelson not loyal to Labour

fields.headline: On the warpath
fields.standfirst:
No way to fight for the party one loves

Special report: Peter Mandelson
fields.trailText: No wonder his colleagues get so exasperated. No wonder some call him devious. "Nothing I ever do," Peter Mandelson told the Independent on Sunday last weekend, "will be designed to harm the government or the party."
fields.body:
No wonder his colleagues get so exasperated. No wonder some call him devious. "Nothing I ever do," Peter Mandelson told the Independent on Sunday last weekend, "will be designed to harm the government or the party." He said it at greater length in an interview for Monday's Guardian. "No doubt the Tory party would like me to be in a dangerous and volatile mood," he told us, "but I am going to disappoint them."

He would do nothing to harm the party. "The party's interests mean everything to me; they always have done." Nor did he echo friends who had indicated that the Hammond inquiry was not to be trusted. "I believe I can be confident in the objectivity of the Hammond inquiry," he insisted. This was Mr Mandelson speaking, not some shadowy friend, declaring on the record that he was ready, despite his anger and hurt, to await the verdict of the inquiry rather than launching further media assaults.

That was on Sunday. Four days later, as Tony Blair went to Enfield to launch his pitch for a second term, Mr Mandelson was closeted in the offices of the Daily Mail and Daily Telegraph - the two newspapers, as many people in the party will note, least likely to come out for Labour at the election. The Mail and the Telegraph have developed strong sympathies for the fallen minister, not least - as such a perceptive student of newspapers must surely have realised - in the hope of using his case to discredit Tony Blair.

The results of his visits were plastered across yesterday's papers, utterly overshadowing Mr Blair's big moment at Enfield - as such a perceptive student of newspapers should have foreseen. As he read them, Mr Mandelson may just have asked himself how far these reports served the interest of the party he is pledged not to harm, and whether the Tory party he had promised to disappoint would be feeling that disappointed. If he didn't, he should have.

There are two questions now about Mr Mandelson. The first is whether Mr Blair and senior colleagues judged him unjustly. The only answer to that is that we still do not know; we have to hope the Hammond inquiry will tell us. Anything less than a verdict of guilty as charged would be good for Mr Mandelson and unreservedly bad for Mr Blair. A straightforward "not guilty" finding would demonstrate that the Labour leader was driven by panic to treat him with shabby injustice. We must simply wait and see.

The second issue is the way Mr Mandelson continues to stir up public debate. That is plainly bad for the party, but it is probably also injurious to Mr Mandelson too. Such sympathy as he has in the party (not much) is ebbing away with each media blast. Still worse is the way that, according to the Mail and Telegraph, Mr Mandelson's "friends" are saying that a place on the European Commission would be some fitting recompense.

"There is ill-disguised disappointment," the Mail reported, "in senior Labour circles that the present commissioneers, former Labour leader Neil Kinnock and former Tory chairman Chris Patten have failed to make much impact." "He believes," the Mail also said, again quoting "friends", "he is ideally suited to the challenge of shaking up the cumbersome and corruption-ridden bureaucracy at the heart of the EU."

And maybe he is. But now that someone's gone public, giving the job to him would look like a payoff stipulated by him and meekly delivered by the PM. Our advice remains as it was at the start of the week. If he means what he says about loyalty, he and his "friends" should try to keep their tongues firmly under control until Hammond has spoken.

webTitle: GM rice promoters 'have gone too far'

fields.headline: GM rice promoters 'have gone too far'
fields.standfirst: Special report: GM debate
fields.trailText: Claims by the biotech industry and some US politicians that genetically engineered "golden rice" would save the sight of 500,000 children a year are exaggerated, according to the Rockefeller Foundation, which is funding the rice's development.
fields.body:
Claims by the biotech industry and some US politicians that genetically engineered "golden rice" would save the sight of 500,000 children a year are exaggerated, according to the Rockefeller Foundation, which is funding the rice's development.

The project, which has been used worldwide by supporters of genetically modified crops as a justification for the technology, appears likely to generate only a fraction of the additional vitamin A intake it once promised. Vitamin A helps prevent eye disease.

If consumers were on a diet of 300g (11oz) of the GM rice a day - the average consumption of an Asian adult - it would provide only 8% of the required daily intake of the vitamin, according to independent scientists.

An adult would, in effect, have to eat 9kg of cooked rice (the equivalent of 3.75kg of uncooked rice) a day to satisfy the required intake and a pregnant woman would need twice that amount.

The Rockefeller Foundation says that the public relations campaign based on golden rice has "gone too far".

Syngenta, the agribusiness company which owns many of the patents on the rice, has in the past claimed that a single month of marketing delay would cause 50,000 children to go blind.

The main deficiency problem is found in India, Bangladesh, Indonesia, Vietnam, Thailand and the Philippines where the lack of vitamin A in a rice diet causes childhood blindness and up to 1m deaths a year. Adding beta-carotene to rice, which the body turns into vitamin A, turns it yellow, hence the name golden rice.

The rice's development has provided a powerful propaganda tool for the GM industry. The then US president Bill Clinton said last year: "If we could get more of this golden rice, which is a genetically modified strain of rice especially rich in vitamin A, out to the developing world, it could save 4,000 lives a day, people that are malnourished and dying."

A number of bio-tech firms, including Syngenta and Monsanto, were credited with licensing patents on golden rice which would allow the technology to "be made available free of charge for humanitarian uses in any developing nation".

Charlie Kronick of Greenpeace said: "It is clear that the GM industry has been making false claims about golden rice. It is nonsense to think anyone would or could eat this much rice, and there is still no proof that it can provide any significant vitamin benefits anyway.

"Our view is that the billions of pounds that has been spent developing this rice and the false hopes it has raised has diverted valuable resources away from more sensible ways of tackling VAD deficiency.

"Far from saving children's sight, 'golden rice' is preventing other more certain methods being developed."

In response to a report by Vandana Shiva, an Indian campaigner against GM foods, Rockefeller Foundation spokesman Gordon Conway said: "First it should be stated that we do not consider golden rice to be the solution to the vitamin A deficiency problem. Rather it provides an excellent complement to fruits, vegetables and animal products in diets, and to various fortified foods and vitamin supplements."

He said that for poor families lacking, for example, 10%, 20% or 50% of the required daily intake of vitamin A, golden rice could be useful, although even the best lines of rice produced by the bio-tech companies, reported in the journal Science, could contribute only 15% to 20% of the daily requirement.

He added: "I agree with Dr Shiva that the public relations uses of golden rice have gone too far.

"The industry's advertisements and the media in general seem to forget that it is a research product that needs considerable further development before it will be available to farmers and consumers."

Mr Conway added, however, that he still thought that golden rice has the potential to make an important contribution to reducing vitamin A deficiency.

fields.headline: Vaz 'broke code of conduct'
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The fate of embattled Europe minister, Keith Vaz, is hanging in the balance while the divided Commons standards and privileges committee decides whether to uphold a guilty verdict that he broke the MPs' code of conduct in recommending an honour to a Labour donor.
fields.body:
The fate of embattled Europe minister, Keith Vaz, is hanging in the balance while the divided Commons standards and privileges committee decides whether to uphold a guilty verdict that he broke the MPs' code of conduct in recommending an honour to a Labour donor.

The parliamentary commissioner, Elizabeth Filkin, the Guardian has learnt, has found that the minister broke the code by not revealing a financial connection with City solicitor, Sarosh Zaiwalla. Ms Filkin in her report to the standards committee has cleared the minister of more than 10 other charges.

In a similar, but more clear-cut case a year ago, MPs on the committee ruled against Tony Baldry, Conservative MP for Banbury. Mr Baldry had to apologise to the Commons.

However the circumstances - which both involve recommending an honour for Mr Zaiwalla - are considerably different.

In breach of the MPs code of conduct, Mr Baldry failed to disclose he was the personal beneficary of a £5,000 loan from Zaiwalla when he put his name forward to the Lord Chancellor's department . Mr Vaz's financial involvement totalled not more than £450 and was paid to his office in donations in 1993 and 1994. In both cases Mr Zaiwalla said he had no knowledge he had been recommended.

Mr Vaz has been cleared by Ms Filkin on everything else - including the most serious complaint brought by Andrew Milne, a former solicitor in Mr Zaiwalla's firm, that the minister received and failed to declare up to £2,000 donations in the parliamentary register of interests.

The sticking point emerged earlier this week when Mr Zaiwalla gave evidence to the committee and protested his innocence over his recommendation for an honour. It has added to the delay by the committee in reaching a decision whether to endorse Ms Filkin's report. Mr Zaiwalla told the Guardian: "I had no idea I had been recommended for an honour by Mr Vaz and I think he is completely innocent as well."

Last night the Guardian obtained two letters sent to Ms Filkin by Mr Zaiwalla - revealing in detail his version of his relationship with Mr Vaz and protesting about Mr Milne's motives about raising the allegations against the minister.

In a letter dated February 8 last year sent to Ms Filkin and copied to Tony Blair, Lord Irvine, the lord chancellor, Betty Boothroyd, the then speaker, and Mr Vaz, Mr Zaiwalla says: " I have at no time made any payments to Mr Vaz MP or his parliamentary office."

Five months later in another letter to Ms Filkin he redraws the statement saying his accounts department paid £250 to Mr Vaz's office in January 1993 which he says is shown as a donation. He also discloses in September 1994 he made a payment of £200 to Wildberry for advertising in a calendar "which was connected with Mr Vaz".

In his first letter he says that he has known the minister for 15 years. "I have sponsored or taken a table at various Asian and charity events which Mr Vaz has also supported. I believe in 1993 or 1994 Mr Vaz asked me if I would help out one such charity. I agreed to make a contribution of £1,000.

The code of conduct requires MPs "in carrying out public business, making public appointments, awarding contracts, or recommending individuals for rewards and benefits, holders of public office should make choices on merit".

Mr Vaz's lawyer Geoffrey Bindman said yesterday: "In fairness to Mr Zaiwalla, it should be made clear that he has been consistent throughout the inquiry in stating that he has never made any cash payment to Mr Vaz or any other payment to him personally or for his personal benefit. Mr Vaz, of course, has confirmed that he has never received any such payment."

The parliamentary commissioner, Elizabeth Filkin, the Guardian has learnt, has found that the minister broke the code by not revealing a financial connection with City solicitor, Sarosh Zaiwalla. Ms Filkin in her report to the standards committee has cleared the minister of more than 10 other charges. In a similar, but more clear-cut case a year ago, MPs on the committee ruled against Tony Baldry, Conservative MP for Banbury. Mr Baldry had to apologise to the Commons. However the circumstances - which both involve recommending an honour for Mr Zaiwalla - are considerably different. In breach of the MPs code of conduct, Mr Baldry failed to disclose he was the personal beneficary of a £5,000 loan from Zaiwalla when he put his name forward to the Lord Chancellor's department . Mr Vaz's financial involvement totalled not more than £450 and was paid to his office in donations in 1993 and 1994. In both cases Mr Zaiwalla said he had no knowledge he had been recommended. Mr Vaz has been cleared by Ms Filkin on everything else - including the most serious complaint brought by Andrew Milne, a former solicitor in Mr Zaiwalla's firm, that the minister received and failed to declare up to £2,000 donations in the parliamentary register of interests. The sticking point emerged earlier this week when Mr Zaiwalla gave evidence to the committee and protested his innocence over his recommendation for an honour. It has added to the delay by the committee in reaching a decision whether to endorse Ms Filkin's report. Mr Zaiwalla told the Guardian: "I had no idea I had been recommended for an honour by Mr Vaz and I think he is completely innocent as well." Last night the Guardian obtained two letters sent to Ms Filkin by Mr Zaiwalla - revealing in detail his version of his relationship with Mr Vaz and protesting about Mr Milne's motives about raising the allegations against the minister. In a letter dated February 8 last year sent to Ms Filkin and copied to Tony Blair, Lord Irvine, the lord chancellor, Betty Boothroyd, the then speaker, and Mr Vaz, Mr Zaiwalla says: " I have at no time made any payments to Mr Vaz MP or his parliamentary office." Five months later in another letter to Ms Filkin he redraws the statement saying his accounts department paid £250 to Mr Vaz's office in January 1993 which he says is shown as a donation. He also discloses in September 1994 he made a payment of £200 to Wildberry for advertising in a calendar "which was connected with Mr Vaz". In his first letter he says that he has known the minister for 15 years. "I have sponsored or taken a table at various Asian and charity events which Mr Vaz has also supported. I believe in 1993 or 1994 Mr Vaz asked me if I would help out one such charity. I agreed to make a contribution of £1,000. The code of conduct requires MPs "in carrying out public business, making public appointments, awarding contracts, or recommending individuals for rewards and benefits, holders of public office should make choices on merit". webTitle: Floods bring new tide of misery

fields.headline: Floods bring new tide of misery
fields.standfirst:
Villages still drying out from October floods are hit again

Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: As householders across south-east and north-east England were evacuated from their homes yesterday amid rising floodwaters, residents of Yalding in Kent were contemplating their seventh serious flood in the past four months.
fields.body:
For the people of Yalding it is becoming depressingly familiar. As householders across south-east and north-east England were evacuated from their homes yesterday amid rising floodwaters, residents of the Kent village were contemplating their seventh serious flood in the past four months.

Two serious flood warnings remained in force in Kent last night on the rivers Teise, Lesser Teise and Beult, with 67 other warnings in the south, East Anglia and North Yorkshire, said an environment agency spokesman.

In Yalding buildings in the centre of the village - which lies at the confluence of the Beult, Teise and Medway - remained under a metre of water yesterday evening. The organic gardens, a local attraction, lay waterlogged and abandoned.

At the Anchor pub on the riverside the landlady, Anne Long, 68, was holding her breath as water crept to within inches of her front door, which has been closed to customers since the October floods.

"It's the high tides at one in the morning that you have to watch - none of us are going to bed before 2am," she said. "But you can't fight water. It will find its way in regardless of what you do."

At Herne Bay in Kent soldiers from the Royal Irish Regiment helped evacuate several homes, and a spokeswoman for Kent fire brigade said a couple had been rescued from a stranded car. In the village of Boughton Monchelsea, near Maidstone, another fire crew was called in to help families pump water from their homes, and other houses were evacuated in Petts Level, near Hastings in East Sussex.

The waters were receding yesterday evening in the south-east, and evacuees began to return to clear up the damage - but met office forecasters warned that they would have only a temporary breathing space. After a dry interval overnight, rain and snow was predicted in the western half of the country this morning, with rain reaching all parts later in the day and continuing until Monday.

Disruption to transport services looked set to continue, with parts of the Connex operated London to Brighton line closed for the weekend in an effort to repair flood damage. At the Eurostar terminal at Ashford in Kent some travellers returned from the continent to find their cars in danger of floating away.

In Yorkshire the flooding frustrated the return home of those still living in temporary accommodation following October's floods. Yesterday St James's Palace announced that the Prince of Wales would rearrange a visit to the region on Monday in order to visit Stockbridge, outside Keighley in West Yorkshire, where more than 100 households remain in temporary accommodation.

The Yorkshire flood defence committee ended a two-month deadlock yesterday by agreeing to a £1.65m increase in the flood defence levy on local authorities. The 10% increase - £4.7m less than the increase demanded by the environment agency - brings flood defence funding in the region worst hit by last year's floods to £18.1m.

webTitle: Leader: Whitehall's secrecy culture lives on

fields.headline: Chronic conditions
fields.standfirst:
Secrecy and departmentalitis live on

Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: The 16-volume report of the inquiry into BSE exposed many government shortcomings and two notorious, but familiar, Whitehall diseases: obsessive secrecy; and departmentalitis.
fields.body:
The 16-volume report of the inquiry into BSE exposed many government shortcomings and two notorious, but familiar, Whitehall diseases: obsessive secrecy; and departmentalitis. The cost of this massive administrative bungle is now well documented: 5m slaughtered cows; £5bn compensation to farmers and meat renderers; and the destruction of a thriving high quality meat export industry.

More serious still, some 94 humans have caught the human form (vCJD) of the degenerative animal brain disease, 86 of whom are already dead - with many more hundreds of victims, given the long incubation period, expected to follow. Yesterday, in an interim response to last October's report, ministers set out their reactions to the inquiry's 167 findings.

How much progress has been made? There is now much more openness on health hazards and less "sedation", to use the inquiry's term, of public anxieties. A new independent food standards agency (FSA), set up before the report, is breaching the Berlin wall separating agriculture from health officials.

Remember, pet food manufacturers were told about BSE jumping species before health officials were. The FSA meets in public and seeks to publish its advice and contracted research findings. In its response to the recent scare about BSE jumping to sheep, its response was exemplary: publishing details of the potential risk (which is low) on its website and openly talking to journalists. It was less good on possible GM contamination of oilseed rape, leaving it to ministers to announce a possible risk.

True to Whitehall's put-it-in-writing tradition, yesterday's report devotes 100 pages to progress in handling risk, scientific uncertainty, and changing civil service behaviour. But anyone who believes the two main "diseases" have been contained is wrong. Departmental infighting continues. Secrecy shrouds Whitehall's soul. Given a new infectious disease jumping from animals to man, Whitehall could still restrict publication, despite the new open government act.

The same is true of drugs. The American regulatory authority has published its research data on adverse effects of new drugs for years; yesterday's report only concedes a review of current British secrecy. Yet encouragingly, the scientists have become bolder. We report today their call for restrictions on organ donations to reduce the risk vCJD cross infection. To make government listen, however, they may need to be bolder still.

webTitle: Women who lived high life jailed for £500,000 fraud

fields.headline: Women who lived high life jailed for £500,000 fraud
fields.trailText: A con woman and her partner were yesterday jailed for their part in a fraud valued at more than £500,000.
fields.body:
A con woman and her partner were yesterday jailed for their part in a fraud valued at more than £500,000.

Evelyn Burton, 57, and Lyla Andre, 50, who had been a brothel owner in Australia, became the toast of top horse racing and show jumping events. They rubbed shoulders with the Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh after creating an illusion of wealth.

The pair gained access to seats in the royal box at the Royal Windsor Horse Show four years ago by pledging £176,000 sponsorship.

The cheque bounced, Wood Green crown court in north London was told, because the pair had woven a patchwork of lies to fund an extravagant lifestyle that included stays at London hotels such as the Berkley in Knightsbridge.

Burton posed as an international banker and travelled in either a chauffeur-driven gold Rolls Royce or a stretch limousine.

Together with an American lawyer, Daniel Wright, who has not been prosecuted but has been investigated by the FBI, she persuaded members of the wealthy set to invest in her US registered company, Westgate Development Corporation, by offering them bumper returns on investments of around $300,000, or £200,000.

The list of victims included Michael Bullen, a former equerry to the Queen, who is the only victim to have had his £60,000 investment returned by Burton's associate, Wright.

Two Swedish businessmen, Mats Anderson and Goran Agneuk, lost £185,000; Frank Wright and Ed Vogel from the US lost £184,000; and Belfast businessmen Henry Curry and James Morrison lost £93,000, as did Norfolk farmer Kevin Childerhouse. The money, which Burton promised to invest in bonds, was spent on horses and high living as well as finding its way into the bank account of Andre. The total losses added up to £557,000, the court heard.

The pair came to the UK from Australia in 1995 after being wanted by police there.

Dorian Lovell-Pen QC, defending Andre, Burton's partner of 20 years, said that she was not party to conning investors and had lived as Burton's virtual housewife.

"The only area where she was successful was in high class prostitution," he said. "She is regarded in Australia as a highly discreet and successful operator with a socially impressive clientele."

Burton, who was said to suffer from a list of health problems was sentenced to five years in prison after pleading guilty to one charge of conspiracy to defraud between October 1996 and March 1998.

Andre was sentenced to three years and eight months after admitting one charge of retaining a wrongful credit and two of evading a liability by deception.

The last two offences concerned the deception of the Right Honourable Mary Ann Wragg, a former president of the Arab Horse Society, and one of its members, Margaret Morgan, out of promised winnings at the annual show held at Haydock Park racetrack.

The court was told that the two fled to New Zealand , where they were arrested in 1999 and extradited at the request of the serious fraud office.

Judge Peter Ader said: "It was a well planned and executed fraud that was highly successful. It required a ruthlessness in dealing with investors and a callous indifference to those they duped."

webTitle: Body found in hospital boiler room

fields.headline: Body found in hospital boiler room
fields.trailText: A body found decomposing in a hospital boiler room was that of a man who vanished after being discharged by doctors from accident and emergency with a minor head injury.
fields.body:
A body found decomposing in a hospital boiler room was that of a man who vanished after being discharged by doctors from accident and emergency with a minor head injury.

A member of staff at the Royal Berkshire hospital in Reading stumbled on the body of James Condon, 54, more than six weeks after he went missing. He was last seen walking near the underground heating oil tank storeroom after he had been treated for an abrasion and hypothermia.

A Thames Valley Police spokesman, Nigel Morgan, said it was thought Mr Condon collapsed and possibly died from a heart attack, although a postmortem examination was inconclusive. He added: "There is no suspicion of foul play.".

A hospital spokeswoman, Julie Fleet, said Mr Condon had received "appropriate" treatment. An investigation had been launched and security procedures were being reviewed.

webTitle: Gainsborough kept in Britain goes on show display

fields.headline: Gainsborough kept in Britain goes on show display
fields.trailText: A huge painting by Thomas Gainsborough, saved from export after Marlborough College put it up for auction, will resurface on public display for the first time next week, at a gallery in Bath.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
A huge painting by Thomas Gainsborough, saved from export after Marlborough College put it up for auction, will resurface on public display for the first time next week, at a gallery in Bath.

The mystery buyer, who is thought to have paid £3m for the painting, has been revealed as Andrew Brownsword, a businessman who lives in Bath. He became a multi-millionaire when he sold his greeting cards company to the American giant Hallmark in 1994 for £165m.

He acquired the painting through a newly formed charity, the Andrew Brownsword Arts Foundation, and has given it, on extended loan, to the Holburne Museum in Bath, the city where Gainsborough lived while he perfected his trade as a portrait painter.

Mr Brownsword's seven line preface to the exhibition catalogue is the only public statement he is ever likely to make about his purchase. It begins: "The opportunity to return the Byam Family to Bath in a manner in which it could be enjoyed by many was a unique proposition for me and my fellow trustees..."

Two years ago Marlborough College's decision to sell the painting caused an outcry from former pupils, including National Portrait Gallery director Charles Saumarez Smith, and the family of the donor Henry Hony.

Mr Hony was a descendant of Selina, the little girl peeping from under her mother's magnificent blue satin flounces in the Byam Family painting.

The huge canvas, one of the largest Gainsborough ever painted, was too big for his house. He first lent it to the school for safekeeping in the war and then made it a gift in the 1940s.

Relatives said he believed it would stay in the school for ever. But the school governors said insurance costs were too expensive. No British gallery could afford the portrait, valued at between £3m and £5m, and it seemed certain to go abroad until Mr Brownsword's offer stopped the sale.

The curator of the Bath exhibition, where the picture will be seen beside other Gainsboroughs, is Hugh Belsey, keeper of the Gainsborough House Museum in Suffolk. He said yesterday: "It is wonderful that the painting will go on display at last and that it has been so beautifully restored, but that does not change the fact that the sale was a betrayal, something that went completely against the original spirit of the gift."

The restoration work has revealed that the Byams were, in Mr Belsey's words, "the clients from hell". Several years after the original painting, in 1762, they had Gainsborough repaint their clothes and hair to reflect the latest fashions - and add their daughter.

webTitle: Fair trade inquiry into cost of CDs

fields.headline: Fair trade inquiry into cost of CDs
fields.trailText: The music industry came under further pressure yesterday to reduce the price of compact discs when the office of fair trading began an inquiry into alleged price fixing.
fields.body:
The music industry came under further pressure yesterday to reduce the price of compact discs when the office of fair trading began an inquiry into alleged price fixing.

The investigation could result in a substantial cut in the price of CDs, and has its sights set on some of the biggest names in music publishing. The OFT cited the UK arms of seven companies: Sony, Universal, EMI, BMG, Warner, Virgin and Pinnacle - the UK's largest independent record distributor.

The inquiry follows swiftly on from the opening of a European commission investigation into the world's big five music companies to establish why European consumers pay so much more than in the United States.

According to the Consumer's Association the average chart CD in London is £14.16 - compared with £11.82 elsewhere in the EU and £10.77 in the US.

The association welcomed the OFT's inquiry and accused the industry of "blatantly and abusively overcharged UK consumers".

Its principal policy adviser, Phil Evans, said: "UK consumers have paid far too much for far too long for CDs, and we have never accepted that there is good reason for it. We will be following both the OFT and EC investigations with great interest."

The OFT said it had "reasonable grounds" for suspecting the companies named were working together to limit the import of cheaper CDs from Europe.

An OFT spokeswoman said: "In order to get cheaper CDs retailers have been importing them from European wholesalers rather than buying them from British ones.

"We are looking at how and why this is happening, and whether the record companies are putting pressure on the retailers to stop doing this and use British wholesalers instead."

If the companies were found guilty of abusing their market power or operating a cartel they could face a fine equivalent to 10% of their sales over the past three years.

An EMI spokeswoman confirmed that it had received a request for information from the OFT. "We will co-operate fully but beyond that we can't say anything," she said.

The companies have been given two weeks to respond. The inquiry could last up to six months. The European investigation could last up to two years. It is also looking at why CDs cost a third more than cassettes.

Brussels was encouraged by a similar investigation in the US that concluded consumers had paid £320m too much for their CDs since 1997 because of collusion between the big five music firms.

An inquiry in Britain in 1994 found that CD prices were acceptable.

webTitle: Gas users face higher bills as wholesale prices double

fields.headline: Gas users face higher bills as wholesale prices double
fields.trailText: Consumers face larger gas bills after British Gas yesterday announced price rises averaging 4.7% from April 1.
fields.body:
Consumers face larger gas bills after British Gas yesterday announced price rises averaging 4.7% from April 1.

Eastern Energy confirmed an average rise of 8%, while gas-only customers with NPower will see an increase of 4.5%.

Utility giant Centrica, which owns British Gas, said its in crease would mean an extra £14 on the average yearly bill for mains gas customers.

Wholesale gas prices are index-linked on the continent to oil prices and have more than doubled in the last year. British Gas, whose prices have been capped by the regulator Ofgem until April 1, said it has no choice but to pass on the rise to domestic customers.

Customers with prepayment metres, already charged a premium and among whom are some of the poorest users, will face a slightly lower rise of 4.4%, when Ofgem removes price controls in the spring.

There are 20m domestic gas customers in the UK but only 6m have switched to one of the 15 other suppliers since competition was introduced; the rest remain with British Gas. Many consumers who could get cheaper energy have been deterred from changing supplier by the complexity of pricing structures.

The Office of Fair Trading is conducting a preliminary investigation into whether there are problems with competition.

webTitle: Art's old masters draw the queues

fields.headline: Art's old masters draw the queues
fields.trailText: It is enough to make a pickled shark weep. In the new millennium, with contemporary art universally touted as the new rock'n'roll, a huge international survey shows that people may not know much about art, but they know what they like: old pictures.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
It is enough to make a pickled shark weep. In the new millennium, with contemporary art universally touted as the new rock'n'roll, a huge international survey shows that people may not know much about art, but they know what they like: old pictures.

The National Gallery director, Neil MacGregor, who emerged from the survey as organiser of one of the world's most popular exhibitions, saw no contradiction. "Old master paintings speak powerfully to a contemporary audience," he said yesterday.

In a survey by the Art Newspaper, in city after city, from Melbourne to Athens, from London to New York, the pattern was the same: the exhibitions people queued around the block to see were of old masters or of long dead craftsmen. The nearest to a contemporary artist in the international top 10 is Picasso.

In Britain dead artists trounced all the most hyped contemporary shows, including the opening exhibition at Tate Modern, the Royal Academy's shocker Apocalypse, and Tracey Emin's rumpled Bed at Tate Britain, which was part of the most heavily publicised Turner Prize exhibition in decades.

Seeing Salvation is the most startling statistic from the survey. The exhibition of images of Christ, at the National Gallery, was not only by far the most popular exhibition in Britain, with more than 5,000 visitors a day, it was the fourth most popular in the world.

In comparison, a super trendy exhibition on Andy Warhol's Factory - at the Bilbao Guggenheim, which vies with Tate Modern as the most hyped new gallery in the world - only made it to 14th place, with 3,529 visitors a day.

The success of Seeing Salvation was a triumph for Mr MacGregor, who co-curated the exhibition and produced a book and a television series on artists across the centuries trying to create a physical image of Christ.

It had been regarded as such box office poison, and so sensitive in terms of offending people of other religions or none, that none of the gallery's potential commercial sponsors would touch it.

In the end was sponsored by a charity and admission was free. Within a day staff knew they had a phenomenom. People were queueing for hours to get in, moving at a snail's pace because visitors spent so long studying the works.

Mr MacGregor said: "Seeing Salvation investigated a theme that has shaped western art through the centuries. This historical approach to familiar material clearly captured the public's imagination."

One of the most obscure exhibitions ever staged by the gallery also did staggeringly well, coming in two places above the Royal Academy's huge Apocalypse show, in the British top 10.

Painted Illusions was an exhibition of Cornelius Gijsbrecht, of whom almost nothing is known except that he worked for a few dazzling years at the Danish royal court and then vanished without trace from history. The show, two small rooms containing almost the entire known work of the artist, attracted a stunning 1,947 visitors a day.

Total visitor numbers for big exhibitions of varying length can be deceptive, but the Art Newspaper's survey tries to measure true popularity by giving average daily numbers.

This revealed that the Royal Academy's dead painters show, Art at the Crossroads, recreating a famous international exhibition of 1900, attracted almost twice as many daily visitors as Apocalypse, with its sculpture of the Pope felled by a meteorite and the Chapman Brothers' swastika landscape of tiny tortured and mutilated figures.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Patient critically ill after jab error | Students end occupation | Two more held after club killing | Driver bailed over deaths | Bird habitat is UK's largest | Brink's-Mat hunt extended
fields.body:
Patient critically ill after jab error

A patient is critically ill in the Royal Sussex County hospital in Brighton after a doctor mistakenly injected a local anaesthetic into a vein rather than the spine during an operation. Experts said the error could result in heart and other organ failure and cause brain damage. The consultant involved has been suspended and the hospital has launched an inquiry.

Students end occupation

More than 50 Oxford University students, including William Straw, son of home secretary Jack Straw, yesterday ended their occupation of the historic Bodleian Library after being served with a high court injunction by the university. They are protesting over tuition fees and the possible expulsion of non-payers.

Two more held after club killing

Two more men have been arrested following the murder of a British soldier in Innsbruck last weekend. Corporal Derek Osborne, 31, from Barrow-in-Furness, Cumbria, was kicked to death outside a nightclub by five men after an argument. The arrested men are thought to be of Serbian descent and in their 20s. Three other men, including two reported to be Austrian soldiers, were arrested earlier.

Driver bailed over deaths

A man accused of causing the deaths of six people in a motorway crash was bailed until April 27 at York crown court yesterday. Brian France, 54, of Birdwell, Barnsley, is charged with six counts of causing death by dangerous driving on the A1(M), near Boroughbridge, North Yorkshire, last November.

Bird habitat is UK's largest

Britain's largest protected bird habitat was created yesterday. The government designated more than 40% of the north Pennine moors a special protection area. The 147,000 hectares (367,000 acres) is home to breeding birds such as the Hen Harrier, Peregrine, Merlin and Golden Plover.

Brink's-Mat hunt extended

Detectives investigating the £26m Brink's-Mat robbery were last night preparing to search a second yard in Hastings, East Sussex, for stolen gold bullion. An earlier warehouse search failed to reveal anything.

Death crash sentence cut

A German businessman, Helmut Jordan, 57, had a three year prison sentence for causing death by dangerous driving reduced to six months at Exeter crown court yesterday.

Judge Graham Cottle said that in sentencing a fortnight ago he had neglected mitigation - the defendant's character and his remorse over the head-crash on the North Devon link road in which a journalist died.

Pacemaker for pregnant mare

A pregnant mare with a heart condition has been fitted with a pacemaker at the Royal Veterinary College's Queen Mother's hospital for small animals.

The seven-year-old, Xena, and foal, were said to be doing well three days after surgery.

Frigate in drugs investigation

Members of the 280 crew aboard HMS Sheffield were yesterday being investigated over possible drugs misuse.

The frigate had left Plymouth on Thursday for a six-month voyage that will include anti-drug patrols in the Caribbean.

Student dies on diving lesson

Peter Vause, 29, a student at the Fleetwood Nautical College in Lancashire, died after breathing difficulties during a lesson at a diving centre in Capernwray.

Police said he was given mouth-to-mouth resuscitation, but died on the way to hospital.

Queen honours Scots painter

Elizabeth Blackadder, 68, was yesterday appointed by the Queen as the first woman to hold the 300-year-old position of Her Majesty's Painter and Limner in Scotland. There is no English equivalent.

The Edinburgh artist was nominated by Donald Dewar, Scotland's late first minister.

fields.headline: Prisoner of conscience
fields.trailText: The case of Stephen Downing (After 27 years Downing is freed, February 8) highlights the sad anachronism in the British penal system that prisoners are ineligible for parole if they continue to proclaim their innocence.
fields.body:
The case of Stephen Downing (After 27 years Downing is freed, February 8) highlights the sad anachronism in the British penal system that prisoners are ineligible for parole if they continue to proclaim their innocence.

Irrespective of the particulars of Mr Downing's case, there is no doubt that the courts make mistakes and that there are innocent people in British jails. In effect, Mr Downing's refusal to acknowledge guilt has resulted in him being a prisoner for the last decade.

Surely this points to the need to abolish admission of guilt as a criterion for parole. Instead parole should be judged solely on good behaviour and risk of repeated offence.
Mark Sutton
Edinburgh

What kind of justice is offered by a system which treats a person erroneously convicted but protesting his innocence, more harshly than a erroneously convicted person who is prepared to declare his guilt falsely.

The object of a judicial system should surely be to ensure that the guilty person is convicted. Any system which encourages people to declare themselves guilty, when they are innocent, can only result in those who are guilty escaping justice completely.
Alan Leach
Alston, Cumbria
AlanandRikki@wardway.fsnet.co.uk

fields.headline: On meritocracy's merits
fields.trailText: The real significance of Tony Blair's pre-election speech may lie not, as your leader (February 9) suggests, in his articulation of "a meritocratic brand of egalitarianism", which is not new, but in his acknowledgment that meritocracy is "insufficient".
fields.body:
The real significance of Tony Blair's pre-election speech may lie not, as your leader (February 9) suggests, in his articulation of "a meritocratic brand of egalitarianism", which is not new, but in his acknowledgment that meritocracy is "insufficient".

His call for recognition of talent in all its forms, coupled with "a platform that recognises the equal worth of all our citizens" is welcome. The next step is to accept that recognition of "the equal worth of all our citizens" is incompatible with the savagely unequal society that Britain has become.

Genuine recognition of equal worth in any meaningful sense is not really possible when society is so polarised between rich and poor. Thus a commitment to redistribution is still essential. Likewise, "recognition of talent in all its forms" raises questions about reward structures, which allow "winners to take all" while those in the caring services, for instance, receive only a pittance.

It is unhelpful to brand such ideas as old Labour. Instead, they are critical to the achievement of New Labour's "meritocratic brand of egalitarianism" and of its ideals of opportunity and social justice.
Prof Ruth Lister
Loughborough University
M.R.Lister@lboro.ac.uk

Your leader states that Tony Blair is advancing a meritocratic brand of egalitarianism but that this is not a Darwinian notion awarding the spoils to "the fittest". However, this is exactly the outcome of a social policy resting only on equality of opportunity. Although the latter is a necessary condition for a fair and decent society it cannot be sufficient.

The race of life, as you put it, cannot produce 100% winners, however these are to be defined. What is to be done for the also-rans? The Labour party's traditional concept of equality required some just redistribution of wealth, to narrow the gap between rich and poor. Without this there is no hope of creating a more contented and less crime-ridden society.
Hugh Crawley
Abingdon, Oxon

I wonder what kind of meritocracy Tony Blair has in mind. (Blair offers new school revolution, February 9) He could mean a society that rewards things like self-sacrifice, kindness, honesty and modesty. I don't think any of us will be surprised, however, when it turns out that merit continues to be interpreted as greed, ruthlessness and indifference to other peoples' problems.
Peter Robbins
London

People who call for more advances towards "meritocracy", and politicians who boast that that's where they are taking us, don't seem to know that the book which introduced the word into widespread usage (Michael Young's Rise of the Meritocracy, published in the 1950s) was not calling for it, but warning against it.

Already by that time, some people could see that making commercial values paramount, and a belief in "competitiveness" as if it was an end in itself, was an inane distortion of social aims.
Dr Roger Schafir
London

What is the moral basis of a meritocracy? Why should those who are born clever be disproportionately rewarded any more than those who are born rich?
PL Hurst
London

Specialist schools don't specialise in good teaching; 138 heads of specialist schools told LSE researchers that their specialism was not the school's strongest teaching area. What specialist schools are really good at is raising money, and when they do that well the government rewards them by giving them some more.

Tony Blair's vision involves 40% of schools winning this particular lottery, while 60% remain in the "failed comprehensive system". Wouldn't it be simpler to split the two groups of pupils with a "world class test", taken at the age of 11? I know exactly what we could call it ...
Paul Francis
Much Wenlock, Shropshire

If "four in 10 secondary schools" are to be outside the comprehensive system, then there is no comprehensive system. If comprehensive education has "failed", it is clearly because of the rampant and unchecked growth of selection for the few, inevitably coupled with "bin-schools" for the many.
Peter McKenna
Manchester Metropolitan University
omickiam@lineone.net

Tony Blair announces "We will offer three new specialisms: engineering, science, business and enterprise". I can't decide which concerns me more - the idea that engineers do not need to learn about science or business, or the fact that arithmetic will obviously not be in the curriculum at all.
Alasdair Beal
Leeds

webTitle: Letters: Barbarella, pop songs and passports

fields.headline: A passport to pleasure
fields.trailText: Joan Smith (All talk, no action, G2, February 9) has her sci-fi sex machines in a twist. The Ogasmatron was not the execution-by-orgasm machine in Barbarella. It was a booth-like item in Woody Allen's Sleepers.
fields.body:
Joan Smith (All talk, no action, G2, February 9) has her sci-fi sex machines in a twist. The Ogasmatron was not the execution-by-orgasm machine in Barbarella. It was a booth-like item in Woody Allen's Sleepers used by futuristic hippies, into which they disappeared for ultra-safe sex, emerging in a blissed-out state. The villain of Barbarella, called "Duran Duran", merely refers to his electric piano-like device as a "pleasure machine". It undoubtedly gave rise to many a male fantasy, though. The 80s pop group who took Duran Duran's name doubtless fantasised that the erotic pleasures of pop-musical orgasm were theirs to command. How wrong can you be?
Paul Barlow
South Shields, Tyne and Wear
paul.barlow@unn.ac.uk

As a serious contribution to the debate, may I point out that the machine couldn't handle Jane Fonda, and Woody Allen couldn't handle the machine?
Barry Hankey
Pontypool, Gwent
HANKEBR@CAERPHILLY.GOV.UK

Cliff Richard (Letters, February 8)? Pah! The true pop prince of darkness is Bobby Vee. fields.headline: What Eminem means
fields.trailText: Writing about Eminem's show in Manchester (Reviews, February 9) Dave Simpson suggests the rapper's "use of words like 'bitch' and 'faggot' is unfortunate, but in US hip-hop these are put-downs, with less of the inflammatory ramifications they have here." How naive is he?
fields.body:
Writing about Eminem's show in Manchester (Reviews, February 9) Dave Simpson suggests the rapper's "use of words like 'bitch' and 'faggot' is unfortunate, but in US hip-hop these are put-downs, with less of the inflammatory ramifications they have here." How naive is he? The use of those words in hip-hop carries exactly the same connotations, that is why they are used.

I have lived in Philadelphia for the last seven years, and at present much resentment is directed at Allen Iversen, a basketball star who plays in this city, because of his foray into the rap world. His lyrics are also laden with the words 'faggot' and 'bitch' and they have exactly the same inflammatory ramifications that they carry in the UK.

Eminem and Iverson are keen to hide behind the idea of free speech, or to claim that their words come from behind specially created personae. This, however, does not alter the purpose and use of 'faggot' and 'bitch', nor is the usage excused by the kind of cultural divide that Dave Simpson seems to believe in. If anything, the connotation they carry here, where 'faggot' has been a derogatory term in regular usage for much longer than it has in the UK, is even more inflammatory.

I wonder, along with a lot of other people in the US, whether critics would be so keen to be apologists for Eminen if he was black rather than a platinum blond?
Keith Gumery
Philadelphia
kgumery@msn.com

fields.headline: Jail break
fields.trailText: On the day you proclaim (Leader, February 7) the need to retain Sir David Ramsbotham as chief inspector of prisons, your jobs section advertised his post "on his retirement". The ideal solution would be for Martin Narey (Jail chief threatens to resign, February 6) to take over as chief inspector and Sir David to take Narey's job as head of the prison service.
fields.body:
On the day you proclaim (Leader, February 7) the need to retain Sir David Ramsbotham as chief inspector of prisons, your jobs section advertised his post "on his retirement". The ideal solution would be for Martin Narey (Jail chief threatens to resign, February 6) to take over as chief inspector and Sir David to take Narey's job as head of the prison service. The advantages are obvious. Sir David is a proven leader who would quickly root out the bullying, control freakery and inefficiency of prison service HQ while ensuring that HQ was supportive of governors.

Martin Narey on the other hand could become a valuable challenger of the system and might learn that a session of this and a course of that is not the whole story. Prisoners need civilising surroundings. He could then report with diplomacy but without responsibility.

Each would occupy roles far more suited to their training and background and, more importantly, the prison service, at least the establishments, would feel led rather than over-managed.
HE Crew
York

fields.headline: Trouble in global village
fields.trailText: One thing George Monbiot fails to mention (Comment, February 8) is the curious fact that in our "globalised" world curbs on the movement of capital are becoming more and more negligible while curbs on the movement of people become increasingly stringent.
fields.body:
One thing George Monbiot fails to mention (Comment, February 8) is the curious fact that in our "globalised" world curbs on the movement of capital are becoming more and more negligible while curbs on the movement of people become increasingly stringent.

Jack Straw's latest plan to reduce the ability of asylum seekers to find true refuge is mirrored by the latest move by capital, which can go anywhere it likes without notice or hindrance while leaving devastation in its wake. The community of Welsh steelworkers is left to pick up the pieces following the decision by the former British Steel to transfer its production elsewhere. The government is powerless to stop it and remains ideologically committed to its powerlessness.
Russell Davies
London
russelldavies@writing.demon.co.uk

George Monbiot is right that "steel workers and global warming campaigners have discovered that they are on the same side".

At present that side tends to emphasise the anti. It's now time to propose alternatives. One other demand beginning to emerge is for the protection and rebuilding of local economies, worldwide. Policies to achieve this would indeed help steel workers and climate change activists.

Tariff barriers and a "site here to sell here" policy would ensure a future for a manufacturing base, while enabling governments to rein in and tax big business adequately. This in turn would allow governments to tax energy to the level required to slash carbon emissions and to help fund transport, health, education and pension needs.
Colin Hines
East Twickenham, Middlesex
chines@dial.pipex.com

webTitle: Navy pilots to get £50,000 to stem tide of leavers

fields.headline: Navy pilots to get £50,000 to stem tide of leavers
fields.trailText: Sea Harrier pilots are to be given a £50,000 bonus to persuade them to stay in the navy under a special pay package announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Sea Harrier pilots are to be given a £50,000 bonus to persuade them to stay in the navy under a special pay package announced yesterday.

The award is a one-off payment for up to 16 pilots in the Fleet Air Arm which faces a crisis, the Ministry of Defence said, and follows the recommendations of the armed forces pay review board.

RAF air crew will also receive special pay increases of up to £10,000 a year in an attempt to stop resignations. Many pilots have been enticed by the higher salaries offered by commercial airlines.

Under the financial retention incentives schemes, RAF pilots and navigators who have been flying for three years and who have attained the rank of squadron leader or flight lieutenant will receive an annual £10,000 bonus. Other ranks who have been serving for 16 years or who have turned 37 will receive the same amount.

And specialist air crew who decide to continue flying rather than take the offer of a promotion to a role on the ground will be given an additional £10,000 if they are 38 to 40, £7,500 if they are 41 to 49, and £5,000 if they are 50 to 53.

The moves were announced yesterday as ministers also accepted an inflation-beating pay rise of 3% but following a five-year old Labour pledge they will continue to take less than their full entitlement.

The rise, for all MPs from April 1, was in line with the recommendations of the senior salaries review body which awarded the same increase to 3,000 senior civil servants at a cost of £6.5m.

MPs' pay has been linked to the senior civil service automatically for several years, to avoid the Commons having to vote itself for any uprating.

A backbencher's salary will go up to £49,822 from £48,371 and may increase further when a separate independent review of MPs' pay and allowances is published next month.

The government also accepted a recommendation from the board for a 3.7% rise for 1,700 judges, costing £6m, and a recommendation from the armed forces pay review body for a 3.7% rise for 119 senior officers and 210,000 regular armed forces personnel.

One of the curious side-effects of ministerial denial is that William Hague will earn more than a cabinet minister. His salary rises from £109,030 to £112,301 while senior ministers will take £99,793 out of an entitlement of £117,969.

Ministers, including Mr Blair, have not taken their full pay since coming to office and that tradition will continue at least until the report in March, No 10 said yesterday.

Mr Blair currently takes £112,951 of the £158,658 he is entitled to and that will increase to £116,339 - with the entitlement increased to £163,418.

Junior ministers' pay will rise from £82,697 to £85,178 and parliamentary under secretaries of states' from £74,424 to £76,657.

In the Lords, ministers of cabinet rank who now take £72,729 of the £85,983 they are entitled to will get £74,911 of an £88,562 entitlement.

Lord Irvine, the Lord Chancellor, the highest paid member of the government, will see his pay increase by 3% on his current £167,760 salary.

Unison, the country's biggest union, said it did not begrudge the MPs their pay rise. But a spokeswoman said: "If MPs are worth that much money, surely the minimum wage should be increased to £5 an hour."

Jeff Masters of the low pay unit pointed out that the 1.5m workers on the minimum wage had had only one pay rise of just 10p an hour in almost two years.

New pay

Junior minister £85,178

Under secretary of state £76,657

Brigadier up to £74,135

Wing cdr up to £56,586

Lieutenant up to £24,973

Private up to £22,101

High court judge £132,603

Circuit judge £99,420

fields.headline: Dead body zone shocks Germans
fields.trailText: Professor Günther von Hagens has been referred to as Frankenstein, the modern Mengele and the Galileo of anatomy. When asked how he would describe himself he pauses for a moment, then says: "Inventor - call me Mr Plastinator."
fields.body:
Professor Günther von Hagens has been referred to as Frankenstein, the modern Mengele and the Galileo of anatomy. When asked how he would describe himself he pauses for a moment, then says: "Inventor - call me Mr Plastinator."

The youthful 57-year-old anatomist has Berlin holding its breath. Today his highly controversial exhibition Körperwelten - or Bodyworlds - opens in the German capital.

Two hundred preserved human corpses and body parts will be on display for six months in east Berlin's old postal depot and a million visitors are expected.

Twenty years ago "Mr Plastinator" discovered a method by which bodily fluids could be replaced after death with silicone, epoxy or polyester polymers, thus preserving every single body part in its original form down to the last sinew, cell and vein.

Plastination has enabled the professor, he says, to "democratise anatomy" and bring it to the masses.

The corpses are obtained through a donor system from people who bequeath their bodies to Prof von Hagens to "plastinate" when they are dead.

At first glance the exhibits resemble clinical medical models. But a closer look reveals how real they are: a woman in the fifth month of pregnancy, her slashed abdomen revealing the curled up foetus, her lungs blackened by years of smoking, her blue eyes starring out of mascaraed eyelashes.

Next to her stands a naked man, his muscles and bones exposed as he carries his entire skin over his arm like a coat. Further down the room, a brown-haired tattooed male is cut vertically into five sections and hangs from a frame.

Other exhibits include tumorous lungs, alcoholics' livers, a seated corpse playing chess, and a skin-stripped man on a horse, offering up his brain in his right hand, the horse's in his left.

At the entrance to a back room a notice reads: "Anatomical Cabinet. Think before you enter here, because plastinations are on display that could seriously hurt your feelings."

Inside, glass cases show real foetuses, some severely deformed, from 13 to 33 weeks old. The centrepiece is a reclining pregnant woman in the eighth month of pregnancy.

This is the most controversial aspect of the entire exhibition and has caused an outcry from the Roman Catholic and evangelical churches many of whose members have called for it to be banned.

"From the Christian perspective the Bodyworlds exhibition throws up questions that the exhibition itself cannot deal with, and from its popular scientific perspective simply does not want to deal with," says Reinhard Lampe, spokesman for the evangelical church.

He describes the exhibition as yet another attempt in German history to redefine human dignity.

"The Nazis tried to define it so that the majority of people were no longer even humans and could therefore be destroyed, suppressed, and experimented on. Professor von Hagens is beginning again to create a new definition."

In response, a requiem mass for the souls of the dead in the exhibition is being held in Berlin next Wednesday, and the two churches have organised a series of alternative events called "My Body", which they hope will explore some of the questions raised.

Prof von Hagens, who describes himself as agnostic, responds by saying that his opponents "fail to respect the feelings of the donors".

"The church thinks it has a monopoly on what should happen to our bodies when we die," he says. "I'm offering them another way."

To support his claim, he produces the signed testament of a particular female donor, born in May 1949. "The sense of my being must not end with my death," she wrote.

"The thought that after my death I could be part of a museum is comforting and fascinates me. What a shame that I'll never discover how my dead body will be used."

Prof von Hagens says that, for legal reasons, he will not be drawn on which exhibit the woman has now become.

In 1968 the professor was jailed by the East German authorities for attempting to flee communist repression. After two years in jail he was "bought" by the west .

The experience, he says, greatly shaped his life and motivated him to openly express his opinion and allow others to share in his plastination.

Over a period of 15 years, 3,200 bodies - mainly German - have been received, and an average of five bequests now arrive every day.

Prof von Hagens says he is still waiting for his first English corpse but hopes he will have one by the time he brings Bodyworlds to London early next year.

webTitle: Rio ready to roll in Champions League

fields.headline: Rio ready to roll in Champions League
fields.trailText: Leeds, Manchester United and Arsenal have taken advantage of the new registration window for the Champions League to increase their squads for the resumption of the second group stage next week. Uefa have allowed clubs to add a maximum of three players to the 25-man squads named in August.
fields.body:
Leeds, Manchester United and Arsenal have taken advantage of the new registration window for the Champions League to increase their squads for the resumption of the second group stage next week. Uefa have allowed clubs to add a maximum of three players to the 25-man squads named in August.

For Leeds it means that Rio Ferdinand, whose £18m move from West Ham was completed on the day of their 2-0 home defeat by Real Madrid in November, will be eligible to make his debut in the competition against Anderlecht at Elland Road on Tuesday.

Sir Alex Ferguson, whose side are at Valencia on Wednesday, has called up the England Under-21 winger Luke Chadwick, who made his United debut in October.

Arsenal, away to Lyon on Tuesday, have added the Brazilian Edu, signed last month from Corinthians, who will add strength to the left side of their midfield.

Taribo West has agreed to stay with Derby until the end of the season. Doubt was cast over the Nigerian defender's future at Pride Park when he failed to return on time following a World Cup qualifier against Sudan. But, having reappeared five days later, he has now confirmed he will stay to help in the battle against relegation and is expected to play at Leeds today.

The Premier League has announced a 7% increase in annual turnover for the season ending in July 2000. It rose to £244.4m from the 1999 total of £228.2m.

Newcastle hope to agree a fee with Sheffield United for the left-back Wayne Quinn who is due to end a five-week loan spell at St James' Park against Charlton today. He is likely to cost Newcastle about £1m.

fields.headline: Wenger condemns TV trials
fields.trailText: The Arsenal manager has called for a complete overhaul of the Football Association's video advisory panel, arguing that top players taking part in high-profile matches are far more vulnerable to this big brother-style retribution.
fields.body:
Arsenal's manager Arsene Wenger has called for a complete overhaul of the Football Association's controversial video advisory panel which is currently convened to judge potential disciplinary incidents that referees miss.

Twenty-four hours after Patrick Vieira escaped at a disciplinary commission with a one-match ban despite being charged on the video panel's unanimous advice Wenger admitted his midfielder was relieved not to have suffered greater punishment. Under the Football Association's new disciplinary code, he should have received at least a three-game suspension.

But Wenger took a slightly different tack on trial by camera. He believes that top players taking part in high-profile matches - especially those shown live on television - are far more vulnerable to big brother-style retribution.

Wenger asked: "Would he have been charged if he were not on Sky News every five minutes?

"You have to ask yourself if players are more likely to be punished if their matches are on TV. For me it can only be right if everybody is put under the same scrutiny."

In Wenger's native France a video panel reviews film of all matches every weekend and reacts accordingly to misbehaviour, making decisons and imposing penalties without recourse to a further panel who may then judge quite differently.

Wenger added: "I'm not saying that the FA must do that here but what we have now in England are only guidelines, not rules. And it can be very confusing. You just don't know whether you are going to be done or not."

Enic has taken the first steps towards selling their 20.2% stake in Rangers now that they have taken control of Tottenham. The Ibrox shareholding carries a current book price of almost £19m but its real market value is thought to be more than £30m.

But the Rangers chairman David Murray insisted the sports, entertainment and media group, whose managing director Daniel Levy is on the Ibrox board, would not sever their ties with the club completely.

Enic's chairman Stephen Davidson said: "Following completion of the proposed purchase of 26.9% of Tottenham Hotspur and the purchase of an option to acquire a further 13.2%, Enic will hold interests in two British clubs.

Fans across the globe have the chance to buy tickets for the 2002 World Cup when they go on sale on the internet next Thursday. As well as applications for seats at the 20 venues throughout Japan and South Korea, supporters will also have the opportunity to purchase team-specific tickets.

Ticket applications will be available on the tournament's official website www.fifaworldcup.com.

webTitle: Audio review: Religion, Scriptures & Spirituality, read by Ben Kingsley

fields.headline: Religion, Scriptures & Spirituality, read by Ben Kingsley
fields.standfirst:
Simon&Schuster, £20 , 720mn
Buy it at a discount at BOL
Hear an extract
You will need RealPlayer to listen to this clip. You can download it here free
fields.trailText: If only followers of the faiths charted here could have co-existed as snugly as these six cassettes in their cases
fields.body: If only followers of the faiths charted here could have co-existed as snugly as these six cassettes in their cases. To trace the divergent paths of Catholicism, Orthodox Christianity and Protestantism and their Judaic parent is inevitably a battlefield tour. These admirable potted histories are read in suitably solemn tones by Ben Kingsley. The schisms and differences are explained with clarity, and there's a useful guide to those great councils of the early church. The unnamed author deserves credit, but the production is marred by dire musical punctuation - there is hardly a shortage of good Christian music, for instance, so why not use it? The effect is also dented by the comic voices used by the readers of textual excerpts. It's absurd and distracting to have early patriarchs or popes speaking English with the accents of modern Germans, Greeks or Russians.

fields.headline: Air to water
fields.standfirst: John Dugdale on Corsairville by Graham Coster, The Shocking History of Phosphorus by John Emsley, and Memoirs by Lorenzo Da Ponte
fields.trailText: John Dugdale on Corsairville by Graham Coster, The Shocking History of Phosphorus by John Emsley, and Memoirs by Lorenzo Da Ponte
fields.body:
Corsairville
Graham Coster
(Penguin, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

A beguiling book that uses a geographical quest - to trace where the Corsair crash-landed in Belgian Congo in 1939 - to make a journey in time, recapturing the era when planes capable of landing on water provided the fastest routes from Britain to Africa and America. Corsairville, the name given to the village that grew up around the marooned craft, hence also becomes an almost-forgotten "place on a psycho-historical map". Coster writes with flair, and his boyish enthusiasm and skill in evoking the personalities of the old flying-boat hands he meets animate what could otherwise be just another phoney pretext for a travel book.

The Shocking History of Phosphorus
John Emsley
(Pan, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Yet another pop-science book seemingly inspired by Longitude , Emsley's loosely structured compendium lacks the novelistic narrative of Dava Sobel's study but boasts the same mixture ofquirky characters and memorable historical detail. The vivid story of the discovery that phosphorus could be extracted from urine - made by 17th-century alchemists, with Leibnitz and Boyle also playing key roles - soon gives way to chapters setting out the fiery element's Jekyll-and-Hyde duality: benign and vital in the soil and DNA, but stealthily toxic when mistakenly used as medicine, and diabolical in the nerve gas sarin and the firebombing of Hamburg.

Memoirs
Lorenzo Da Ponte
(NYRB Classics, £8.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

If a writer today achieved the equivalent of writing the libretti for The Marriage of Figaro , Don Giovanni and Cosi Fan Tutte , he could count on a life of revered prosperity. Not so Da Ponte, for whom the years of astonishing collaboration with Mozart in Vienna were a brief intermission in a career spent fleeing debts and enemies, and ending up (after stints as priest, gambler, bordello owner and grocer) as an Italian teacher in New York. Though not without longueurs, his autobiography at its best has a wonderful rollicking brio, looking back to 18th-century picaresque fiction and forward to the gifted adventurers of Stendhal.

fields.headline: The Baobab and the Mango Tree, by Nicholas Thompson & Scott Thompson
fields.trailText: Through the narrow focus of two "bellwether" countries - Thailand and Ghana - that have suffered economic crisis at different stages in their development, the authors search for lessons on a wider scale.
fields.body:
The Baobab and the Mango Tree
Nicholas Thompson & Scott Thompson
(Zed Books, £17.95)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Through the narrow focus of two "bellwether" countries - Thailand and Ghana - that have suffered economic crisis at different stages in their development, the authors search for lessons on a wider scale. Follow Thailand's boom and bust, they say, and "risk homogenization along with global environmental implosion"; "de-develop" like Ghana, and face "starving in an environment compromised by failure". Despite the gravity of its subject matter, the Thompsons' incisive analysis is inspiring and even, at times, wittily playful.
