fields.headline: Full house
fields.standfirst: Isobel Montgomery on Observatory Mansions by Edward Carey, The Naturalists by Diane Smith, The Chateau by William Maxwell, If I Told You Once by Judy Budnitz, and McKenzie's Friend by Philip Davison
fields.trailText: Isobel Montgomery on Observatory Mansions by Edward Carey, The Naturalists by Diane Smith, The Chateau by William Maxwell, If I Told You Once by Judy Budnitz, and McKenzie's Friend by Philip Davison
fields.body:
Observatory Mansions
Edward Carey
(Picador, £9.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

A once-ancestral pile now divided into flats and encircled by roads, Observatory Mansions is a dark and musty place whose blueprint is Gormenghast. Its characters' eccentricities are so far beyond ordinary oddity that, again, Peake's creations are their closest ancestors. Francis, the narrator and youngest resident, keeps the Law of the White Gloves, never touching another object with bare hands. He works as a living statue and collects objects for his "exhibition of love". Unexpectedly, a new resident moves in. Anna Tap is the catalyst who breaks the stasis, though the mysterious Porter also has a plan. Some will this debut fanciful; others will see a brilliantly imagined landscape.

The Naturalists
Diane Smith
(The Women's Press, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Although it's set in Yellowstone National Park, Smith's "botanical novel" is a gentle comedy of manners after the fashion of E M Forster. A E Bartram is accepted by Prof Merriam on his field trip on the mistaken assumption that she is a man, but that is almost incidental to the narrative that unfolds through the letters Bartram, Merriam and their companions write home. Academic rivalries, environmental threats, a nature poet, a lady ornithologist and an American Indian family all play a part in forcing Bartram and Merriam to see themselves and their credo anew. The Naturalists camouflages an entire sub-species of serious ideas under humour.

The Chateau
William Maxwell
(Harvill, £7.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Harold and Barbara Rhodes are the kind of couple you know instantly. From Henry James onwards they have sailed, steamed or flown across the Atlantic, eager to embrace the culture of Europe, only to be left confused or broken by its subtleties. Maxwell sends the Rhodes as paying guests to the Chateau Beaumesnil in 1948. They know that they must bring their own sugar to the table, but cannot fathom why the after-dinner conversation turns from the Nazis to the Americans in some "invariably quite disconnected remark". Maxwell shades nuanced relationships in a way reminiscent of Elizabeth Bowen. It is surprising that this rich novel has had to wait until his death to be reprinted.

If I Told You Once
Judy Budnitz
(Flamingo, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

In a semi-mythical land of almost bestial poverty and endless winter lives a young girl whose one dream is not to follow her mother's circular path from stove to bed to childbirth. Ilana's escape is successful: mother and shtetl are abandoned for the New World, but her fate is to beget a daughter, a granddaughter and a great-granddaughter who all share her dream. A familiar 20th-century history and a universal mother/ daughter experience are given a new resonance by Budnitz's use of folklore and fairy tale in a way that readers of Angela Carter will readily recognise. It is an original combination that succeeds in refreshing a tired theme and style.

McKenzie's Friend
Philip Davison
(Vintage, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

It is the old story: the hero is trying to pick up the pieces of ordinary life when across the bar, the road or the lake a face from the past hoves into view and drags our man off the straight and narrow. Davison's hero, Harry Fielding, used to do freelance work for MI5; now he wants to go fishing with his old dad. But Alfie, crooked of the Yard, has a job offer, and Harry is too weak to resist. Naturally, there is a woman, a failed marriage and some hyper-bleak places to go before Harry finishes the job. Davison knows how to play at retro violence, but it is a genre that is better seen than read.

fields.headline: Labysheedy (The Silken Bed)
fields.trailText:
I'd make a bed for you

in Labysheedy...
fields.body:
I'd make a bed for you
in Labysheedy
in the tall grass
under the wrestling trees
where your skin
would be silk upon silk
in the darkness
when the moths are coming down.
Skin which glistens
shining over your limbs
like milk being poured
from jugs at dinnertime;
your hair is a herd of goats
moving over rolling hills,
hills that have high cliffs
and two ravines.
And your damp lips
would be as sweet as sugar at evening and we walking
by the riverside
with honeyed breezes
blowing over the Shannon
and the fuschias bowing down to you
one by one. The fuschias bending low
their solemn heads in obeisance to the beauty
in front of them
I would pick a pair of flowers as pendant earrings
to adorn you
like a bride in shining clothes.
O I'd make a bed for you
in Labysheedy,
in the twilight hour
with evening falling slow
and what a pleasure it would be
to have our limbs entwine
wrestling
while the moths are coming down.

The fuschias bending low their solemn heads in obeisance to the beauty in front of them I would pick a pair of flowers as pendant earrings to adorn you like a bride in shining clothes. webTitle: A life in writing: Manuel Rivas

fields.headline: The healer of wounded words
fields.standfirst: Manuel Rivas tells Michael Eaude about his language's fragile beauty
fields.trailText: Manuel Rivas tells Michael Eaude about his language's fragile beauty
fields.body:
Manuel Rivas lives in a village on the Costa del morte, the wild coast of shipwrecks and gales between Cape Finisterre, the ancients' end of the world, and A Coruña - the Corunna of Sir John Moore's famous retreat and tomb - in Galicia in North-west Spain. "But do not think Galicia is remote," Rivas tells me. "This is a land of emigration. The biggest gallego cemetery in the world is in Havana, the biggest gallego city in the world is Buenos Aires. And so much emigration has made Galicia cosmopolitan. I remember looking in the suitcases of emigrants returned from overseas. The whole world was inside. They were like books."

Rivas, born in 1957, writes in Galician. His novel, The Carpenter's Pencil , just out from Harvill, is the first to have been translated directly into English without going through the intermediary of Castilian Spanish.

He was brought up in the workers' barrio of A Coruña, a city on a rocky peninsula shaped like a boat pushing out to sea. "The streets we played in were in a triangle formed by the prison on one side, the cemetery on the other full of drowned sailors, and the Tower of Hercules lighthouse on the cliff above us." From the lighthouse, the street-children watched the daily ships full of emigrants fleeing Franco's Spain. An emigration that created the famous saudade , or longing melancholy, so present in Galician culture.

"The children sought not to look towards the prison, which held the painful memory of the Republicans imprisoned at the start of the civil war, then killed by torture squads," Rivas says. The Carpenter's Pencil tells the cruel fate of these prisoners, and particularly one of them, the noble and lucky Dr da Barca, and his jailer, the assassin Herbal, who saves him.

Rivas loves to tell stories, and laughs with sheer pleasure at an idea or a glistening image. "I am disperse," he says. He explains his intimate relationship to his minority language: "To talk gallego was a social tattoo. It was a sign you weren't cultured. For me gallego is not just an instrument of writing. It has its own smell and colours, it is a felt relationship, acquired in the field of life, it is the language of the home, of my parents, of the old people, of games. Workers, fishermen, country people talked gallego , but never the bourgeois. I never learnt gallego in school or church, and that's why I cherish it: its words are like wounded birds that need healing."

Rivas talks of words as if they were material objects. "There are big words, that sound very nice, such as love, soul, hatred, fatherland, present in all cultures. But they're words with worms inside them, deteriorated by falsehood and use, like formal speeches where no one notices if the speaker jumps a line . . . I have tried to recover the meaning of words. For example, the soul, a beautiful word distorted by religion and philosophers, can be, for example, the guitar of a kid playing in the metro".

His stories and books are full of objects: a loaf of bread, a butterfly's proboscis, a desk, a cart, a cork, that stand out on the page as if in relief. He is a novelist not of ideas, but sensations. Or rather, the ideas are transmitted through the intensity of his evocation of things.

"Galicia has a mainly peasant population, the highest percentage in Europe. As such there is a lot of folklore, but I am not writing out of nostalgia. Simply we are witnesses to a destruction. My grand father was a travelling carpenter, but in his spare time he made ox-carts, works of art using 47 different pieces of wood. The ox-cart tracks now are overgrown with undergrowth - they have become tracks of memory."

With three volumes of stories and two novels in the 1990s, Rivas's reputation as a fiction-writer spread. Three stories from the 1995 volume Que me queres amor? were skilfully knitted by Rafael Azcona, one of Spain's most famous scriptwriters, into Butterfly's Tongue , José Luis Cuerda's lyrical, ferocious and beautiful film about the defeat of the Spanish Republic.

The Carpenter's Pencil , first published in gallego in 1998, has been a publishing phenomenon, with queues forming at Rivas's book-signing sessions. In gallego it has sold over 50,000 copies, a phenomenal number in a country of fewer than 3 million. It is a story that he had in his mind for several years, after going to interview an old man returned from exile. "I arrived at 10 am and didn't leave till three the next morning." Many years later, it was his carpenter grandfather's pencil which gave him the oblique approach that allowed him to tell a great love story without falling into sentimentality. Like most of Rivas's writing, the novel is a number of interlinking stories, with tangents, stories within stories, and numerous vivid secondary characters.

The civil war is the context of the novel. "It is the metaphor of all wars. We may not be conscious of it, but all the winds of history whirl round furiously in it." But he denies it is a historical novel; his interest is the present and how the past of Galicia illuminates its now.

Rivas's fiction effectively places side by side the modern and the ancient. Galicia is traditionally a land of mists and ghosts, of emigrants and shipwrecks, with the long sea-fjords penetrating deep into the interior, with men tilling the sea while women till the land. Yet it is also a cosmopolitan society of emigrants, a frontier to Europe and America.

"There are two worlds living at the moment side by side. The old world has not died. For example, you can have a peasant girl in a tiny village listening to Madonna on a Walkman who names her cows after rock stars."

"But do not think Galicia is remote," Rivas tells me. "This is a land of emigration. The biggest gallego cemetery in the world is in Havana, the biggest gallego city in the world is Buenos Aires. And so much emigration has made Galicia cosmopolitan. I remember looking in the suitcases of emigrants returned from overseas. The whole world was inside. They were like books." Rivas, born in 1957, writes in Galician. His novel, The Carpenter's Pencil , just out from Harvill, is the first to have been translated directly into English without going through the intermediary of Castilian Spanish. He was brought up in the workers' barrio of A Coruña, a city on a rocky peninsula shaped like a boat pushing out to sea. "The streets we played in were in a triangle formed by the prison on one side, the cemetery on the other full of drowned sailors, and the Tower of Hercules lighthouse on the cliff above us." From the lighthouse, the street-children watched the daily ships full of emigrants fleeing Franco's Spain. An emigration that created the famous saudade , or longing melancholy, so present in Galician culture. "The children sought not to look towards the prison, which held the painful memory of the Republicans imprisoned at the start of the civil war, then killed by torture squads," Rivas says. The Carpenter's Pencil tells the cruel fate of these prisoners, and particularly one of them, the noble and lucky Dr da Barca, and his jailer, the assassin Herbal, who saves him. Rivas loves to tell stories, and laughs with sheer pleasure at an idea or a glistening image. "I am disperse," he says. He explains his intimate relationship to his minority language: "To talk gallego was a social tattoo. It was a sign you weren't cultured. For me gallego is not just an instrument of writing. It has its own smell and colours, it is a felt relationship, acquired in the field of life, it is the language of the home, of my parents, of the old people, of games. Workers, fishermen, country people talked gallego , but never the bourgeois. I never learnt gallego in school or church, and that's why I cherish it: its words are like wounded birds that need healing." Rivas talks of words as if they were material objects. "There are big words, that sound very nice, such as love, soul, hatred, fatherland, present in all cultures. But they're words with worms inside them, deteriorated by falsehood and use, like formal speeches where no one notices if the speaker jumps a line . . . I have tried to recover the meaning of words. For example, the soul, a beautiful word distorted by religion and philosophers, can be, for example, the guitar of a kid playing in the metro". His stories and books are full of objects: a loaf of bread, a butterfly's proboscis, a desk, a cart, a cork, that stand out on the page as if in relief. He is a novelist not of ideas, but sensations. Or rather, the ideas are transmitted through the intensity of his evocation of things. "Galicia has a mainly peasant population, the highest percentage in Europe. As such there is a lot of folklore, but I am not writing out of nostalgia. Simply we are witnesses to a destruction. My grand father was a travelling carpenter, but in his spare time he made ox-carts, works of art using 47 different pieces of wood. The ox-cart tracks now are overgrown with undergrowth - they have become tracks of memory." With three volumes of stories and two novels in the 1990s, Rivas's reputation as a fiction-writer spread. The Carpenter's Pencil , first published in gallego in 1998, has been a publishing phenomenon, with queues forming at Rivas's book-signing sessions. "It is the metaphor of all wars. We may not be conscious of it, but all the winds of history whirl round furiously in it." But he denies it is a historical novel; his interest is the present and how the past of Galicia illuminates its now. Rivas's fiction effectively places side by side the modern and the ancient. Galicia is traditionally a land of mists and ghosts, of emigrants and shipwrecks, with the long sea-fjords penetrating deep into the interior, with men tilling the sea while women till the land. Yet it is also a cosmopolitan society of emigrants, a frontier to Europe and America. "There are two worlds living at the moment side by side. The old world has not died. webTitle: Review:  The Tiananmen Papers, eds Andrew Nathan and Perry Link

fields.headline: Whispers of democracy
fields.standfirst: The Tiananmen Papers, edited by Andrew Nathan and Perry Link, throws new light on the events of 1989. By John Gittings
fields.trailText: The Tiananmen Papers, edited by Andrew Nathan and Perry Link, throws new light on the events of 1989. By John Gittings
fields.body:
The Tiananmen Papers
eds Andrew Nathan and Perry Link
558pp, Little, Brown, £20
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The sound of machine-gun fire woke me three days after the Beijing massacre, in my empty hotel on the Avenue of Everlasting Peace. Rolling out of bed, I saw through the window an army column that had just crossed the junction below. A gunner on the tail truck had fanned his machine gun, spraying a sparse crowd with fire. By the time I reached ground level, the army had disappeared and several bodies were being rushed away. All that remained was a satchel of books on an abandoned bike, some bloodstains and projectile holes, and two suitcases belonging to a man who had just walked up from the railway station. His friend urged me to note down that "he came from Qiqihar" in the north-east. This casual episode of military brutality, which I witnessed on the morning of June 7, 1989, dramatised in miniature the huge shock three nights earlier when much larger army units barrelled into Tiananmen Square, shooting down protesters and bystanders on the way. How, asked the citizens of Beijing, could the People's Army treat the people like this?

The Tiananmen Papers , which claims to be based on original documentation of the time, may help us find a fuller answer to this question. The present volume is an edited selection with commentary, containing only a small percentage of the "several thousand" documents to which the pseudonymous compiler Zhang Liang - described as an ex-civil servant - says he had access. Putting doubts aside, I have found several gripping passages which may explain why "the man from Qiqihar" was mown down.

The 38th Group Army, which did most of the killing on June 3-4, submitted a self-justifying report to the Central Military Commission giving a very partial account of its advance from the east into Tiananmen Square. It hailed the bravery of its officers and soldiers faced with "rioters with clubs and steel reinforcing bars". It said (correctly, I believe) that "in clearing the square the officers and soldiers . . . did not kill a single person with rifle fire". But it was silent about the people it had killed on the way. All armies of all nationalities lie when reporting to their superiors. Information from security agents is usually more reliable, because informing is their job. The most illuminating material here comes from agents of the State Security Ministry, who sometimes seem to show sympathy for the students. In their version of the slaughter, the protesters hurled bricks and rocks, and pushed trolley buses and other vehicles in the army's way. The troops then "turned their weapons on the crowd . . . People began crumpling to the ground."

Soon, there were "no more lulls in the shooting". Whenever rocks were hurled, or verbal insults were shouted, the soldiers "fired into the crowd". Did the man from Qiqihar, or some other bystander on that grey morning of the 7th, utter a "verbal insult"? Did the tail gunner imagine he spotted someone with a rock? There is another clue in a report from Martial Law headquarters to the ruling Communist Party Politburo three days before the massacre. It admitted that "the troops . . . are entering an urban centre [for the first time]". Perhaps the tail gunner was a raw peasant recruit and simply panicked.

The Tiananmen Papers allows us to follow much more closely than before the tangled sequence of events over the previous two months that led China's "Party elders" to order in the troops. The students had first occupied the square after the death of the popular pro-reform ex-Party secretary General Hu Yaobang, sacked two years before by the ageing conservatives who feared the pace of change. The elders, headed by Deng Xiaoping, were officially retired, but continued to be "consulted". When the Politburo Standing Committee split over how to handle the protest, the elders took over.

The documents confirm that there was considerable sympathy for the students among more liberal Party leaders. The conciliatory position of Hu's successor Zhao Ziyang - eventually sacked by the elders - is well known. But several others favoured dialogue, too. "We should take a sober look at what has caused the strong rebellious streak in the popular mood," argued the ex-worker Li Ruihuan. "I still believe that the great majority . . . mean well," said Vice-Premier Wan Li, who was heavily leant on to prevent him taking their side.

Yet it is also clear that the learning curve that the student protests inflicted upon the Party elders was simply too steep and too swift. Their sympathy towards the original complaints about corruption waned as calls for democracy grew. What was China coming to when thousands joined in a "demonstration by bicycle" and students from the Beijing Fashion College suggested officials should wear bikinis "to increase the transparency of government"? The enthusiasm of the foreign press - which enjoyed during those weeks a freedom it has never since recovered - also alarmed the leaders. They were even more alarmed when the students began to "network" across the country, bringing back memories of the Red Guards. They were disconcerted by the hunger strike in the square, and baffled when student leaders confessed that they could no longer control their own supporters.

The most wounding blow to the elders came after a failure to persuade the students to clear the square for the visit of Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev. This historic summit of reconciliation between the former "fraternal Parties" was turned into farce. "What do we look like if the square's a mess?" Deng Xiaoping complained. Yang Shangkun, a relatively moderate figure, exploded that "pretty soon we won't be able to call this capital our own any more". The Gorbachev fiasco led directly to the decision to declare martial law. This in turn stiffened the students' determination and brought thousands of outraged Beijing citizens to their side.

In retrospect, the sending in of the tanks after two weeks of stalemate seems inevitable. In theory, the leadership struggle between Zhao Ziyang and then Premier Li Peng - broadly speaking, a struggle between moderates and hardliners - could have gone the other way. But the documents show that from the perspective of 40 years of Party rule, Li's arguments were bound to prevail. It had become a question of "us or them". Losing patience, Deng decided that the west was "stirring up turmoil" by its support for people who were "the scum of the Chinese nation". Ex-general Wang Zhen said: "Anyone who tries to overthrow the Communist Party deserves death and no burial." A preliminary attempt to infiltrate army units peacefully was frustrated by the Beijing citizens who chased them away, allowing Mr Li to insist that "we have to be absolutely firm". The Beijing military commander told the elders that his troops were "swallowing their anger and fuming inside". The decision to send in the troops authorised the use of force, although not under any circumstances in the square itself. As Wang Zhen again put it: "If it causes deaths, that's their own fault."

The Tiananmen Papers is billed as "an astonishing account . . . from inside the heart of the Politburo itself". The documents said to have been brought out by Zhang Liang have been culled, according to the US editors, to highlight "the decision-making process". Though fascinating in detail, the only area on which they cast significant new light is the way that Jiang Zemin (now supreme leader), who had handled protests in Shanghai firmly but without bloodshed, was secretly chosen by the elders to replace the discredited Mr Zhao.

Sooner or later, China is going to "reverse the verdicts" on what happened in June 1989. The Tiananmen Papers has brought the issue back into focus at the right time, when the leadership is facing a new round of change in the next two to three years. Yet we cannot gloss over the problems raised by the documents. Firstly, we do not yet have the original Chinese texts. Although Zhang Liang wanted the book to be published in Chinese first, he was overruled. A fuller edition in Chinese will be published, we are told, in March or April. More seriously, the quotes given above may not be real quotes at all. Mr Zhang "has combined information [from different sources] to reconstruct most of the accounts of conversations throughout the book"; the editors have used quotation marks because the materials come from "immediate participants" and are "often mutually corroborative". To put it mildly, this is not best scholarly practice.

Also very serious - as acknowledged by the distinguished editors, Andrew Nathan and Perry Link - is the fact that they have not seen a single photocopy of an original document. In a careful postscript on authentication, another well-known US China academic, Orville Schell, says that Mr Zhang clung to a distinction between passing on original documents (which would be "unpatriotic") and "merely [passing] the reformatted contents on to foreigners like us and hence to the world at large". The editors thought this was "illogical" but decided to respect Mr Zhang's "terms of the game". I find this touching, but a shade naive. It also raises another question: how did Mr Zhang manage to "reformat" what we are told were "several thousand documents" - apparently chosen from an even larger number - in a situation where he risked execution for copying even one?

The character of Mr Zhang himself, as revealed in his brief preface, is also puzzling. We are told that he is or was an insider who speaks for a much broader pro-reform constituency in the Party. Yet on the very first page of the book, he writes much more like an outsider, recalling "the blood of thousands of young people spilled on the streets" of Beijing. This is hyperbole, not history, and dated hyperbole too. I believe these documents are, broadly speaking, "genuine", but within limits which no one can yet clearly define. The next step should be to produce the full texts of the documents. If they already exist in a "reformatted" version, Mr Zhang has only to deposit them on a website for everyone to read. Millions of Chinese would be the gainers - and some sympathetic but concerned China scholars too.

webTitle: Review: England: The Making of the Myth by Maureen Duffy

fields.headline: 1066 and all that
fields.standfirst: Sean O'Brien on England: The Making of the Myth, Maureen Duffy's gallop through English history
fields.trailText: Sean O'Brien on England: The Making of the Myth, Maureen Duffy's gallop through English history
fields.body:
England: The Making of the Myth
Maureen Duffy
192pp, Fourth Estate, £13.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Who do the English think they are, and why? One contemporary response might be another question: apart from Norman Tebbit, who cares? Select one of the following. The English are a) a busted flush, a nation stripped of empire, a bulletheaded tribe of pasty racist dimwits herded into call centres and hypermarkets, pissed all weekend, crap at sport and frequently a howling embarrassment both to themselves and to their perennially sinister neighbours. Only the Ulster Protestants want to be like them, which speaks for itself.

Alternatively, the English are b) fair-minded, eager to help in a crisis, modest, self-effacing, ironic, brave, stronger in the second half, with profound reserves of romantic feeling, pastoral sensibilities and an unrivalled fund of poetry. Or c) they live in Scunthorpe and Coalville, mind their own business and do not care to be characterised in any way. Now you have a go, reader. If my England takes place in flat-vowelled, coal-fired murk, a perpetual 1950s lit only by black-and-white war movies, what about yours? Pony Club camps and farm holidays? Boarding school? I see.

The writer studying mythologies of Englishness is, to put it mildly, spoilt for choice. Myth is an understandable and necessary modus vivendi , a way for people to characterise themselves to themselves and then to the world of all the Others, but it cannot be neutral. To entertain it, even ironically, may involve becoming part of it. English parodies of English attitudes serve, at times, to reinforce them. The octopus of national myth is the dread and cunning beast faced by the distinguished novelist Maureen Duffy in England: The Making of the Myth . Duffy undertakes to follow the emergence of ideas and feelings of Englishness from pre-Roman times to the present. The vigilance needed to make such a book work is, unfortunately, eroded by this march-of-time approach, in which One Damn Thing After Another is seen rushing past like the tail of a comet.

There are several distorted echoes of 1066 and All That - Bad King John, the treasure lost in the Wash, the problematic fact that the Roundheads were right but the Cavaliers were romantic. For all Duffy's breadth of interest - language, politics, social history, the lives of women, class, literature, music - this is history in captions. She cites E P Thompson's The Making of the English Working Class , for example, but must gesture in a few pages at the scope of his 800-odd. At some points the method is reminiscent of Olivier's speech as Nelson to Lady Hamilton on a balcony in Naples in some dire old movie, in which he is obliged to list every event of the Napoleonic period in order and pretend he talks like this all the time. Despite the author's mild radicalism, we are in pageant territory, the land of compromise where revolution almost never comes.

The author's seeming awareness of this problem doesn't really help. What's needed is aphorism, but what we get is hurried journalism, with some unfortunate simplifications. Turning to Shakespeare, for example, Duffy reads Gaunt's deathbed speech in Richard II with such flat scepticism about its presentation of "Englishness" as to miss its dramatic complexity entirely. She is also a subscriber to the "Shakespeare must have known/done x, y and z" approach, which is like mythology squared and which places her weirdly in the beery company of late-19th-century inventors of literary Englishness. Turning to the present, her assertion that most English people dislike racism is either optimistic or wishful.

Many readers of this newspaper will find much to agree with in Duffy's gallop through history from woad via Wotan to Blair/ Brown plc. At the same time, they may wonder at a book that is so clearly misconceived. Though England reads for the most part like an earnest remedial textbook for a period ignorant of history, Duffy's prose is at times also the jittery, distracted, powerless descendant of the great English essay tradition that links Johnson, Hazlitt, Carlyle, Virginia Woolf and Orwell. In its threadbare style and its unwitting subjugation to some of the habits it seeks to describe, it provides, by a sort of anti-eloquence, a grim picture of the plight of contemporary writing, never mind Englishness. If Englishness cannot strike sparks off its own language, then it is done for; we are left holding the contemporary left/ liberal version of the Dictionary of Received Ideas in Flaubert's Bouvard and Pécuchet .

Too often limply conventional in its interpretations and dull in its expression, England reveals passions become habitual and seriousness grown stale. Even the great themes of class, industry and warfare sound weary. If this book speaks for England, the place needs waking up. Not for the first time lately, here is a book that owes more to fear of the reader's ignorance than to respect for his or her curiosity.

It could have been very different. Duffy quotes E M Delafield's assertion that the English have great powers of self-delusion - and neither possess, nor wish to possess, any power of imagination at all. This would be an interesting starting point. One of those intellectual-aesthete types of whom the English are proverbially so suspicious might observe that it is not so much that the English have no imagination as that they have worn it out by inventing themselves, and telling everyone else about it, ad nauseam.

Discuss.

At some points the method is reminiscent of Olivier's speech as Nelson to Lady Hamilton on a balcony in Naples in some dire old movie, in which he is obliged to list every event of the Napoleonic period in order and pretend he talks like this all the time. Despite the author's mild radicalism, we are in pageant territory, the land of compromise where revolution almost never comes. The author's seeming awareness of this problem doesn't really help. What's needed is aphorism, but what we get is hurried journalism, with some unfortunate simplifications. Turning to Shakespeare, for example, Duffy reads Gaunt's deathbed speech in Richard II with such flat scepticism about its presentation of "Englishness" as to miss its dramatic complexity entirely. She is also a subscriber to the "Shakespeare must have known/done x, y and z" approach, which is like mythology squared and which places her weirdly in the beery company of late-19th-century inventors of literary Englishness. Turning to the present, her assertion that most English people dislike racism is either optimistic or wishful. Many readers of this newspaper will find much to agree with in Duffy's gallop through history from woad via Wotan to Blair/ Brown plc. At the same time, they may wonder at a book that is so clearly misconceived. Though England reads for the most part like an earnest remedial textbook for a period ignorant of history, Duffy's prose is at times also the jittery, distracted, powerless descendant of the great English essay tradition that links Johnson, Hazlitt, Carlyle, Virginia Woolf and Orwell. In its threadbare style and its unwitting subjugation to some of the habits it seeks to describe, it provides, by a sort of anti-eloquence, a grim picture of the plight of contemporary writing, never mind Englishness. If Englishness cannot strike sparks off its own language, then it is done for; we are left holding the contemporary left/ liberal version of the Dictionary of Received Ideas in Flaubert's Bouvard and Pécuchet . Too often limply conventional in its interpretations and dull in its expression, England reveals passions become habitual and seriousness grown stale. Even the great themes of class, industry and warfare sound weary. If this book speaks for England, the place needs waking up. Not for the first time lately, here is a book that owes more to fear of the reader's ignorance than to respect for his or her curiosity. It could have been very different. Duffy quotes E M Delafield's assertion that the English have great powers of self-delusion - and neither possess, nor wish to possess, any power of imagination at all. This would be an interesting starting point. One of those intellectual-aesthete types of whom the English are proverbially so suspicious might observe that it is not so much that the English have no imagination as that they have worn it out by inventing themselves, and telling everyone else about it, ad nauseam. Discuss.

webTitle: Review: The Hitler of History by John Lukacs

fields.headline: One hundred Hitlers
fields.standfirst: Dominick Donald  discovers the biographers' Führer in The Hitler of History by John Lukacs
fields.trailText: Dominick Donald discovers the biographers' Führer in The Hitler of History by John Lukacs
fields.body:
The Hitler of History: Hitler's Biographers on Trial
John Lukacs
279pp, Weidenfeld, £25
Buy it at a discount at BOL

In its 1997, American edition this book described David Irving as an admirer of Hitler and attacked his scholarship, accusing him of twisting documentary sources. Irving put Lukacs's British literary agent on notice that he would take advantage of this country's more plaintiff-friendly libel laws if it saw publication here. Only when the allegations were upheld in an associated case in the High Court last year could publication of the book go ahead in Britain - though what has emerged is a much less incisive attack on Irving. The publisher appears to have made the emollient changes before the High Court judgment.

In itself, this book is an example of historiography: the history of the study of history. But anyone alarmed by reminders of dreadful set texts at school or university can calm their beating hearts. Though The Hitler of History has its arid moments, it reads more like a lively biography than anything else. Much of the historiography proper - and the academic sniping - is reserved for the footnotes. The book addresses the key questions about the character and phenomenon of Hitler by comparing the material of more than 100 biographies of him, and the picture it draws is convincing.

The key to Hitler's ideology, and his shift from colourless insignificant to dangerous charismatic, lies in the failed Bolshevik republic in Munich in 1919, rather than Vienna, pre-war Bavaria or the trenches. He was a revolutionary rather than a reactionary, closer to socialism than to conservatism, and he used his sense of the progressive to retain massive German popular support until the end. He also understood the importance of Christianity to the German people. An essentially secretive man, he always tailored his message to his audience and yet was able simultaneously to believe in two or more explicitly contradictory ideas. He was a product of German history, though not an inevitable one.

Other questions, Lukacs acknowledges, remain unanswerable. How did Hitler spend the three months of Bavaria's Red Terror? Did he ever give an order for the Final Solution? Above all, whence came his apparently utterly irrational loathing of Jewish people?

Lukacs's intelligence and mastery of his sources provide a far more nuanced, convincing Hitler than most of the biographers he examines, but his vision fails him in his assessment of Hitler as strategist. Yet here, too, there are shafts of insight. The idea that Hitler fought on after December 1941 believing that a victory of annihilation was impossible for either side - and so directed his strategy at causing one of the three principal Allies to make a negotiated peace - rings true, as does the assessment that Hitler's true strategic gift was in his instinct for others' weakness. But much of the rest of this chapter strikes one as wrong.

For instance, he credits Hitler with correctly understanding the novel supremacy of land power over maritime, made possible by military motorisation. But it was exactly this understanding that doomed the Third Reich. Hitler could not win the war if he lost the battle at sea; the Allies could not win it if they failed to defeat the Axis on land. By gradually shifting resources away from the only battle that might conceivably have driven Britain and America to peace - the Battle of the Atlantic - Hitler ensured his eventual defeat.

Meanwhile, Lukacs's explanation of one of the most baffling questions - why did Hitler declare war against the US in December 1941? - is frankly feeble. He says Hitler could hardly renege on his alliance with Japan by refusing to abide by its first article, a simultaneous declaration of war. But Hitler had always ignored agreements that had served their purpose, and his dealings with Tokyo had none of the strong personal and ideological ties that caused him to launch disastrous enterprises on Mussolini's behalf. If he had let the Japanese fight the USA on their own, Roosevelt would eventually have turned on Germany; but the intervening period would have provided the breathing space Hitler so desperately needed.

Yet the book's major flaw remains the fault of the publishers rather than the author. Since its original publication, David Irving's libel suit and Daniel Goldhagen's Hitler's Willing Executioners have twice brought historiography into the British headlines. Ian Kershaw's massive, widely hailed two-volume biography has also shed considerable light on Hitler. It would have been interesting to get Lukacs's take on all these issues, yet none - not even the Irving trial, probably the most exciting thing ever to happen in historiography - gets a mention. And the book is subtitled Hitler's Biographers on Trial .

Anyone who wants an intelligent, cohesive, generally convincing analysis of Hitler's character through the medium of those who have written about him will be entirely happy with The Hitler of History as it stands. Anyone who wants context for the news events of the last four years should wait for another edition.

webTitle: Pick of the week: Poet to Poet Series

fields.headline: Pocket pals
fields.standfirst: Let us go then, you and I...Nicholas Lezard on Faber's Poet to Poet series
fields.trailText: Let us go then, you and I...Nicholas Lezard on Faber's Poet to Poet series
fields.body:
Poet to Poet Series
(Various eds, Faber, £4.99)

It seems to be very much the thing these days for publishers to pillage their backlists and reprint them on the cheap. This is fine, as long as it is something to shout about. And this series is. Here we have a clutch of tiny, pretty little poetry paperbacks, which will fit into all but the snuggest pockets, for a fiver; and, with one exception, selected, and with new introductions by, contemporary poets.

The most noteworthy, I propose, are: Michael Longley choosing Louis MacNeice; Michael Hofmann on Robert Lowell; Derek Mahon for Jonathan Swift. (Others include Seamus Heaney on Wordsworth, Don Paterson on Robert Burns, and Ted Hughes on Emily Dickinson, all of whose poems can, strangely enough, be sung to the tune of "The Yellow Rose of Texas", which spoils them somewhat; plus Alan Hollinghurst on A E Housman, a poet I unfortunately cannot read without giggling.)

It's an admirable exercise, and although you might find yourself initially baffled that the poems appear without either their dates of publication or composition, and with only the scantest of annotation, it does force you to read the work without distraction.

The cheekiest, and yet at the same time the most surprisingly fascinating of the reprints is the very slim volume, Prufrock and Other Observations . Eliot, like Eminem, has been having a rough ride of late, with various commentators denouncing him for anti-Semitism in particular and establishment snobbery in general; the contumely has shaken the foundations of his reputation. For those more sympathetic to him, his widow's hawklike attention to, and protection of, his residua has begun to irritate scholars and the ordinarily curious. (When's that second volume of letters coming out, eh? And will all the good stuff be kept out of it?)

So with this book we go back to first principles; the collection with which he made his mark. No introduction, no notes, no help with the epigraph from Dante that ushers us into "The Love Song of J Alfred Prufrock". So you read it all through, straight, and the enigmatic force of his early poetry strikes you again, and you begin to get an idea of how the first readers of the work must have been utterly disoriented in 1917, if they were on the ball enough to pick up the Egoist press edition. (Faber first published him in 1925.)

What would they have made of it? Echoes from all strata of lyrical art, from Dante and Shakespeare to popular songs ("Is it perfume from a dress/ That makes me so digress?") to Edward Lear: I defy you not to hear the cadences of "The Courtship of the Yongy Bongy Bo" in these lines from "Portrait of a Lady": "We must leave it now to fate./ You will write, at any rate./ Perhaps it is not too late." The facile conclusion may well have been that here was a poet with only a slippery grip on his own sanity; and this indeed may have been the case.

But what is useful and remarkable about reading it like this, so stripped of context, is that you no longer feel compelled to read them as a student (which is probably how most people come to them in the first place). No symbol-hunting, no anxious marginal notes ("NB imagery", etc), just a concentration on the sense the words reveal, bit by bit. It is striking how contemporary the poems still seem; they haven't dated, and they survive all the countless imitations of his work that have appeared in the intervening century.

fields.headline: Et cetera
fields.standfirst: Steven Poole  on  Emotion: The Science of Sentiment, by Dylan Evans, Crypto, by Steven Levy, and The World of Caffeine, by Bennett Alan Weinberg & Bonnie K Beale
fields.trailText: Steven Poole on Emotion: The Science of Sentiment, by Dylan Evans, Crypto, by Steven Levy, and The World of Caffeine, by Bennett Alan Weinberg & Bonnie K Beale
fields.body:
Emotion: The Science of Sentiment
Dylan Evans
(Oxford, £9.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Gushy New Age people who insist that "feeling" is superior to reason obviously want punching, since by definition arguing reasonably is not going to get you anywhere. Yet Evans's dinky, pink-jacketed survey shows that reason can be impotent without the passions. You may not have had access recently to an emotion known to the Gururumba people of New Guinea, that of "being a wild pig" (although it could come in useful at literary parties), but some emotions (fear, disgust) are hard-wired survival tools. Others (love or embarrassment) are "higher cognitive emotions" that enable us to function socially. What Evans calls "evolutionary rationality" suggests how the emotions might work to help us point our reason in the right direction in the first place. An admirably clear, intelligent and witty introduction.

Crypto
Steven Levy
(Penguin, £18.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Here's the saga of how a bunch of ill-kempt hacker eccentrics defeated the forces of the US National Security Agency and brought to light the principles of public-key cryptography, a system of exchanging messages in a code that is to all intents and purposes unbreakable. (The system had actually been invented first at GCHQ by a Brit, but no one knew.) Levy is a master at zippy, cyberpunk storytelling, and he takes it up to the heated modern debates between governments and their citizens: one side arguing that unbreakable crypto protects terrorists, the other side arguing that it protects the basic human right of privacy. It's odd to see just how ideologically close the radical techno-left in America are to the far-right survivalists. While not exactly a light read, studded of necessity with formidable acronyms, this is an important subject, and Levy's looks to be the definitive history.

The World of Caffeine
Bennett Alan Weinberg & Bonnie K Bealer
(Routledge, £16.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

After our false alarm a few weeks ago with the promisingly entitled Java Man , here at last is a lavishly produced history of the world's favourite mood enhancer, from Mayan chocolate to the Japanese tea ceremony. A fascinating final few chapters (here's the science part) proves that coffee makes you cleverer and better at driving cars, although it can also instil hypersomnia and delirium. What the hell - it's worth the risk for a nice cappuccino on a morning like this.

webTitle: Review: Managing the Human Animal by Nigel Nicholson

fields.headline: Zoo management
fields.standfirst: Dylan Evans finds business to be a jungle in Managing the Human Animal by Nigel Nicholson
fields.trailText: Dylan Evans finds business to be a jungle in Managing the Human Animal by Nigel Nicholson
fields.body:
Managing the Human Animal
Nigel Nicholson
310pp, Texere, £16.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

In the past few years, evolutionary psychology (or EP as it is known) has given the chattering classes a lot to chatter about, but hasn't had much impact in the world of business. However, that may be about to change. A new book by Nigel Nicholson, professor of organisational behaviour at the London Business School, promises to transform EP from a debating topic into a practical tool for management.

According to Nicholson, executives have been misled by decades of utopian management education. They have been encouraged to believe that they can re-engineer their companies in any way they want, eliminating turf wars and sexism along the way. Such fantasies, however, take no account of the enduring features of human nature, which stubbornly resists the new visions imposed upon it. No wonder so many great new management ideas fail as soon as they move from the business school to the boardroom.

The solution, argues Nicholson, is to construct a new approach to management based on EP. As the first truly scientific account of human nature, EP can teach managers how to work with the grain rather than against it.

Take the emotions, for example. A lot of previous management thinking downplayed the role of the emotions in decision-making. In line with Plato and a whole host of western thinkers since, emotions were seen as at best harmless luxuries and at worst outright obstacles to rational action. Only recently have managers begun to realise that emotional intelligence is vital to business success. EP provides a firm scientific basis for this new trend in management thinking, seeing emotions as complex mechanisms that can enhance rationality in the right circumstances. As Nicholson explains in a fascinating chapter on "playing the rationality game", managers who view emotions - in themselves or in their workforce - as mere obstacles are wasting one of their greatest potential resources.

Nicholson's prose is racy and down-to-earth, and he illustrates the main ideas of EP and their relevance to the business world with well-chosen examples. The story of how Nick Leeson brought down Barings Bank, for example, is put to good effect as an object lesson in the psychobiology of risk-taking. Leeson's desperate loss-chasing in his last bout of trading no longer seems quite so bizarre when placed in the context of biology; as Nicholson notes, zoologists have often observed that the closer an animal gets to the survival boundary, the more chances it will take to secure vital resources.

Such comparisons with animal behaviour will no doubt enrage those who think that all scientific claims should be hedged with multiple caveats and disclaim ers. On the other hand, for those who are fed up with the repeated calls for "safe science" and other forms of political correctness, Nicholson's pragmatic bent is refreshing. In fact, his approach resembles that of the practising scientist much more than the sanitised prescriptions of the safe-science brigade do. He takes a theory that has been neither effectively established nor conclusively refuted, and advises managers to try it out. A theory may sometimes be tested more decisively in the crucible of business than in the university laboratory.

EP may not get tested at all any more, unless it is used to shape policy and corporate strategy. There is currently a small but vociferous group of academics who proclaim that EP is so fundamentally flawed that further testing is superfluous. It can, moreover, lead you to become a genetic determinist and, even worse, a reductionist. The very possibility of such a terrible fate is enough to strike fear into the minds of many liberal intellectuals, and dissuade them from putting EP to further scientific test. Thankfully, however, these philosophical worries are not usually uppermost in the average manager's mind. Executives are more often worried about more mundane matters, such as the figures on the bottom line. And so, even if EP is denied a fair hearing in the dining rooms of the intelligentsia, it may get a better chance in the boardroom.

It would be premature, then, and most unscientific, to pre-judge Nicholson's hypothesis. Whether he is right, or whether his own brand of management thinking will go the same way as those he decries, only time will tell. If the managers who take on board the ideas of EP perform better than those who don't, Nicholson's gambit will have paid off.

fields.headline: Weird science
fields.standfirst: Lisa Jardine  meets an Elizabethan eccentric in Dr Simon Forman: A Most Notorious Physician by Judith Cook, and The Notorious Astrological Physician of London by Barbara Howard Traister
fields.trailText: Lisa Jardine meets an Elizabethan eccentric in Dr Simon Forman: A Most Notorious Physician by Judith Cook, and The Notorious Astrological Physician of London by Barbara Howard Traister
fields.body:
Dr Simon Forman: A Most Notorious Physician
Judith Cook
228pp, Chatto & Windus, £18.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The Notorious Astrological Physician of London: Works and Days of Simon Forman
Barbara Howard Traister
250pp, University of Chicago Press, £19
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The notoriety of self-taught physician and amateur astrologer Simon Forman is almost entirely posthumous. Four years after his death in 1611, his name came up in the sensational trial for murder of Frances Howard, Countess of Essex, and Robert Carr, Earl of Somerset, who was a favourite of King James I. Forman, it was alleged, had been consulted on Howard's behalf by one of her ladies, Anne Turner, in search of a love potion to ensure the continued attentions of Carr and a concoction to ensure the impotence of her husband. If Howard knew where to procure prescriptions from quack doctors, the prosecution argued, she was capable of getting hold of the arsenic with which she and her lover had allegedly murdered the man who stood in the way of their marriage, Thomas Overbury. As is the way with such media scandals, the story was soon amplified to make Forman the supplier of the poison, so it was just as well he was safely dead. Poor Anne Turner was hanged for her part in the conspiracy; Howard and Robert, however, were eventually pardoned by the King.

It was the popular historian A L Rowse, digging deep into the Elizabethan archives, who found and published Simon Forman's "Casebooks" in 1974 under the title Sex and Society in Shakespeare's Age . He introduced the general public to a man with a colourful career as a brewer of exotic potions and a sexual appetite to rival that of another famous diarist, Samuel Pepys. Both men seemed to have a charming disregard for the background of their sexual conquests, as well as for the location of consummation - which Forman refers to in a somewhat transparent code as "haleking".

Rowse discovered Forman's manuscripts while in pursuit of the "dark lady" of Shakespeare's sonnets, whom he identified as the poet Aemilia Lanyer. Lanyer had asked Forman to cast her husband's horoscope prior to a business venture, and had subsequently, like a number of other female clients, had a brief affair with the doctor. The diaries were a revelation to a public accustomed to thinking of Elizabethan life as strait-laced and austere, and their publication produced a rash of academic articles relishing their explicit promiscuity.

They record, for instance, an erotic dream Forman had in which he was walking with Queen Elizabeth herself, who was all "unready", wearing only a shift and a petticoat. When they trailed in the mud Forman lifted them and lewdly asked if he could "wait upon" her, "that I might make this belly a little bigger". Even 400 years ago, a man with something of an inferiority complex might compensate in his dreams with fantasies of bedding the monarch.

Shakespeare scholars have long treasured Forman's diaries as rare first-hand records of visits to the London theatres, including details of performances of Macbeth , The Winter's Tale and Cymbeline . He was not, however, very good at remembering how the plot went - in his version it is Macbeth rather than his wife who attempts vainly to wash the imagined blood of Duncan from his hands.

Yet Simon Forman has always been a footnote - an afterthought in other people's stories. The purpose of these new books is to retrieve the "real man" behind the anecdotes and innuendo, and to argue that Forman's professional life as a medical man and caster of horoscopes was more serious and interesting than hitherto believed.

Judith Cook's is an avowedly popularising romp through Elizabethan England which constructs around the armature of Forman's writings a sentimental "life and times" recalling the film Shakespeare in Love - all street noise, colour and smells. Her strategy is to move surreptitiously from an entry in Forman's diary to events in London around that date - in none of which is there any evidence that Forman was involved. So an entry for 1599 telling us that he "bought much harness and weapons for war, swords, daggers, muskets, corselets and furniture, staves, halberds" becomes the occasion for a digression on the impending Essex rebellion, after which Cook remarks that he "had more on his mind than Essex's expedition" and returns to a colourful story of a paternity suit.

Traister, in her far more serious and thorough book, is careful to remind her reader that the only basis for reconstructing a more three-dimensional Simon Forman is the profusion of manuscripts, diaries and letters. Separating the tittle-tattle from the documented evidence, she excludes most of the salacious stories from her account. Basing her study squarely on Forman's papers, she conveys the inconsequential diversity of his writings, ranging from graphic notes on childbirth to inventories of expenses. Traister's Forman is an altogether less sensational character, and she goes some way towards persuading us that in spite of his absence of formal training, Forman did develop a respectable medical practice over the years, and that details of this can help us to understand the diversity of early modern medicine.

The most interesting consequence of Traister's lively and readable account is that we discover a thoroughly eccentric type of late-16th-century intellectual who has built up his stock of usable knowledge entirely through his own resourcefulness. Like the autodidact miller in Carlo Ginzburg's classic The Cheese and the Worms , Forman builds an entire worldview grounded in herbal remedies, superstition, astrology and occult practices. These sustain him through a relatively successful and active life. This may be the eve of the scientific revolution, but an ordinary thinking man like Simon Forman still bases the crucial decisions that shape his life on dream-interpretation and fortune-telling, with the odd aphrodisiac potion thrown in.

fields.headline: Big in crime
fields.standfirst: Maxim Jakubowski on Voluntary Madness by Vicki Hendricks, Right As Rain by George P Pelecanos, A Cold Day in Paradise by Steve Hamilton, Iced by Jenny Siler, Buddha's Money by Martin Limon, and The Mind Game by Hector MacDonald
fields.trailText: Maxim Jakubowski on Voluntary Madness by Vicki Hendricks, Right As Rain by George P Pelecanos, A Cold Day in Paradise by Steve Hamilton, Iced by Jenny Siler, Buddha's Money by Martin Limon, and The Mind Game by Hector MacDonald
fields.body:
by Maxim Jakubowski

For a writer as fierce as Vicki Hendricks - whose previous novels of Miami mayhem offered heroines who were both deadlier and more lust-fuelled than any testosterone-driven male - Voluntary Madness (Serpent's Tail, £8.99) is a walk on the tender side of life. That is, if lesbian gropes with white witches, breaking into Hemingway's house and holding up fancy restaurants for food (and later money and jewellery) answer your definition of tenderness. Juliette and Punch are a latter-day pulp version of Bonnie and Clyde, on the rampage in the Florida Keys. Punch has failing health but charisma to spare, while Juliette, less than half his age, is a slut with a heart. They have a suicide pact to live life to the full until he has written his masterpiece; she is his muse, acting out her wildest impulses to provide him with inspiration. A bittersweet ending is on the cards, but the ride is exhilarating and endearing as these two misfits sparkle and burn into overdrive. A love story with a difference and an affectionate criminal caper.
Buy it at a discount at BOL

George P Pelecanos is another crime writer with an acute sense of empathy for characters steeped in everyday reality. Right As Rain (Orion, £9.99) begins a new series, once again set in Washington DC, and paints a relentless portrait of the city, its inhabitants and the harsh environment contaminated by drug culture. Gruff black investigator and former cop Derek Strange is hired by a distraught mother to reopen the case of a white cop exonerated for the accidental killing of a black colleague. He soon finds himself in a strange partnership with the cop in question, Terry Quinn, and on a mutual quest for the obscured truth. This is a wonderful book in which very little happens in terms of action, but which always feels psychologically true, with a pointillist evocation of the music of the times, the drug-strewn streets and underworld characters of a society left to its own wilderness. But, above all, it is a story of ordinary - and often evil - people, written with an acute understanding of human frailties. There are no small subjects or themes, and Pelecanos cleverly draws you, slowly but surely, into his web of deceit.
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Steve Hamilton's A Cold Day in Paradise (Orion, £9.99) is an impressive American award- winning debut which offers a real touch of class among the current morass of serial-killer-by-numbers books. Still threatened by a bullet lodged less than a centimetre from his heart, former Detroit cop Alex McKnight has moved to the small town of Paradise, Michigan, leaving the past nemesis who shot him and killed his partner rotting in the state penitentiary. But then a series of murders occurs with exactly the same modus operandi as those of the jailed killer; he is obliged to question the facts of the previous case and is drawn into a veritable nightmare. A gripping thriller set in the cold hinterlands of America; brooding, dangerous and hypnotic in tone and execution.
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Her first novel Easy Money established Jenny Siler as a worthy new talent in the realm of tough-girl crime fiction, with a quirky central character who attracted trouble like a magnet. She stays true to form in Iced (Orion, £9.99), albeit with a different heroine and locale. Meg Gardner is a hard-living, whisky-drinking repo woman from Montana, just out of prison for stabbing her boyfriend. Naturally she is soon in the midst of mounting problems when she stumbles on a crime scene. A labyrinthine plot peopled with extravagant larger-than-life characters churns along with unrelenting pace to a massive finale in which Meg finally extricates herself from danger, with a sigh of relief from the reader. Complex, rugged and entertaining.
Buy it at a discount at BOL

In Martin Limon's Buddha's Money (Serpent's Tail, £6.99), Bascom and Sueno are US army investigators walking the wild side of Seoul. Their beat is a colourful one, with cheap sex and other temptations abounding for the servicemen who visit this dubious paradise. Herman "the German" Burkowicz has retired from the US Army in favour of a more lucrative career smuggling Korean artefacts, but a deal gone bad ends with the kidnap of his foster daughter Mi-Ja. Advised by our heroes to pay the ransom - a priceless skull carved out of jade - Herman finds himself with a problem: he no longer has it. Exotic and dirtily realistic, this is a fast-moving thriller by an author familiar with his unusual settings after 20 years spent in the military in Korea.
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The Mind Game by Hector MacDonald (Michael Joseph, £9.99) is an ingenious debut from a young British thriller writer, with twists to spare. An Oxford student is talked into participating in an innovative scientific experiment which allows him to wallow in the African sun with a beautiful older girlfriend. But paradise is too good to be true, and when things go wrong, they go atrociously so. The nightmare that follows turns his life inside out, with friends, teachers and lovers all proving duplicitous in the extreme. A splendidly engineered tale of deceit and illusion, this is undoubtedly heading for the bestseller lists.
Buy it at a discount at BOL

fields.headline: Adams has Seagulls soaring again
fields.trailText: Just four years ago Brighton and Hove Albion were homeless, had one foot in the Conference and on the brink of extinction. Now they are back in Brighton and flying high as they seek promotion from the Third Division.
fields.body:
It is four years since Brighton and Hove Albion, on the brink of extinction, began their revival. Bottom of the Football League, soon to be homeless and with a vitriolic campaign against their unpopular chairman Bill Archer in full cry, 10,000 football supporters became "Fans United" at the Goldstone Ground to lend Albion their support.

Brighton were inspired that day and won 5-0. Many believe it was an epochal moment and the catalyst for the club's regeneration.

After two years of playing "home" matches at Gillingham, the Seagulls are back in Brighton and really flying, second in the Third Division. Today they face third-placed Cardiff City. Pending investigations at the leaders Chesterfield, however, the match could be seen as a battle for the top.

Kerry Mayo, the sole first-team survivor from that epic day at the Goldstone, believes the club owes far more to two other "defining moments": the recruitment of Micky Adams as manager and his subsequent purchase of Bobby Zamora from Bristol Rovers.

Adams arrived in May 1999 and instigated a wholesale clearout in the belief that too many players at the club were "using Gillingham as an excuse for poor performances." Zamora was his most costly signing at £100,000. Yet his 19 goals this season have attracted the attention of Premiership sides and his rumoured value is now around £2m.

Today's opponents, managed by Adams's old friend Alan Cork, have had a £1.2m bid rejected for Zamora to star alongside their own top scorer Robert Earnshaw, who will not play today following a knee operation.

Adams, who will be best man at Cork's wedding later this year, enjoyed denying Cardiff his prize asset: "I gambled on Bobby and it seems to have paid off. We had an offer for him that was over a million pounds. We turned it down. That is how far we have come."

Yet he thinks Brighton are still a long way behind the Welsh club, where Sam Hamman is now chairman: "Cardiff are this league's fat cats. As the season goes on and, because of all the postponements, we get fixture congestion. Cardiff will be all right as Sam will just open his chequebook. They have got to be favourites for promotion."

Brighton's current board of directors, chaired by the advertising mogul Dick Knight, are still far from wealthy. Their current ground, Withdean stadium, holds supporters on only three sides and a planning application for a new venue at Falmer, next to their training ground at the University of Sussex, is yet to be submitted.

"We are only able to get several thousand in to watch us at the moment and that is costing us. If we were at the Goldstone this year, we would be getting 12-15,000 every week," Adams said.

The sale of Zamora, who still has three years on his contract, therefore must be an attractive prospect for the board.

Adams fears such a situation: "I don't want people to think: 'Micky bought this lad for £100,000 and turned him into a £1.5m player. Let's sell him and Micky will do the same again.' That won't happen. I have unearthed a little gem and there aren't that many around."

Zamora, 20, appears unfazed by the big-money speculation surrounding him. "Micky Adams was a big factor in me coming here and promotion under him would be a fairy tale; a fairy tale I want to be part of."

Zamora's story might also have an ironic twist if Brighton win promotion and Rovers, struggling in the Second Division, are relegated. Zamora was told by Ian Holloway, Rovers' former manager, that he would "play no first-team football this season" and the striker now feels he is proving a point.

"If you look at Rovers' top scorer this season, I think they only have five or six goals. So I do wonder sometimes," said Zamora. Nathan Ellington is in fact Rovers' top scorer with nine but that will not appease Rovers fans who have watched several talented forwards leave and thrive elsewhere.

Meanwhile Brighton's fans, hardened by the dark days of 97, are enjoying every minute of Zamora's blockbusting season. They have even adapted a song for him, to the tune of Dean Martin's That's Amore.

"When the ball hits the goal/ It's not Shearer or Cole/ That's Zamora," run the reworked lyrics. Hope on the south coast springs eternal.

fields.headline: White's week
fields.standfirst: Flabby Ginola is Gregory's fallguy
fields.trailText: Flabby Ginola is Gregory's fallguy
fields.body:
What a pity for Vanessa Feltz that she wasn't a footballer. Then, in her bid to regain popularity, she wouldn't have needed to go through her recent detox diet and all its associated pain, the nausea, the acne, the halitosis. Because in football, there are few things the fans appreciate more than a tubby. Anyone who saw Neville Southall turn out for Bradford last season will remember how hugely he added to the occasion.

Not that a player has to be in the Southall class to qualify as a footballing blimp. It may be a feminist issue off the pitch, but in football, fat is a relative term. Players like John Hartson and Paul Gascoigne, when encountered off the pitch would seem paragons of sleekness. But when up against the greyhound physique of the average player, where excess bloating is confined to the calves, they are deemed fat, their chunkier outline speaking of a hinterland of pies and lager.

Dr Stephen Hawking, however, would be required to explain the degree of relativity which recently saw David Ginola branded stout. The last time any of us saw his torso, albeit enclosed in his grandad's cast-off vest, after he had removed his shirt in a goal celebration, vast swathes of the television audience swooned (and quite a few of them were women). The man is sculpted, there is more fat on a tree than on his washboard stomach. Yet, here was his manager, John Gregory, mocking him as a porker.

Gregory clearly has a problem with Ginola. This week, the newly fat Frenchman was obliged not only to turn out for Aston Villa's reserve team in a game against Newcastle's stiffs, but to play as sweeper. As his infamous performance in France's 1993 World Cup qualifier against Bulgaria proved - when he gave away the ball in the final minute, and with it a goal and qualification - last line of defence is not his strength. True to form, on Wednesday night a misplaced backheel led directly to an opponent scoring.

"It was certainly not my idea," Ginola said after the game, which Villa lost 3-1. "You'll have to ask other people."

Gregory was swift to deny responsibility, suggesting the decision to humiliate Ginola in that position was taken by Villa's reserve team coach, Kevin MacDonald. Even so, the player would not need to have been on Paul Merson's old stimulant of choice to feel paranoid right now.

Alex Ferguson, it is always said, needs an external enemy in order to motivate his troops. John Gregory prefers the Margaret Thatcher approach to man management, requiring instead an enemy within. Remember Stan Collymore, who the manager mocked publicly for his depression?

Now there is Ginola. Gregory's public hounding of the player - he doesn't try, doesn't contribute to the team, closes his eyes going up for headers, is a laughing stock among the crowd - began almost from the moment he arrived at Villa Park last summer. The latest complaint is about Ginola's attitude to being subbed during a recent game against Liverpool.

"He took his substitution quite calmly and that disappointed me," said Gregory, who clearly likes his players to react like Benito Carbone did in the FA Cup semi-final last season, by kicking over a drinks bucket and then marching to the dressing room up the wrong tunnel, only to emerge shamefaced a couple of minutes later.

In many ways Ginola is an absurd character, with his hair, his modelling, his cod philosophising ("I am Zen," he said, by way of explanation for his calmness at being subbed). But he was double player of the year only two seasons ago, and, as he showed for Villa against Manchester City, is still capable of disturbing the back of the opposition's net. Gregory, one suspects, isn't concerned about that, focusing on issues beyond the well-being of the team. His real reason for taking against Ginola was revealed when he hinted this week that he hadn't even seen the player's contract.

The implication was clear: Ginola was bought not by the manager, but by the chairman, Doug Ellis. Thus by humiliating Ellis's trophy purchase, calling him fat and playing him in the reserves in a position where he knows he will mess up, Gregory may be seeking to make a point in his long-running battle with the chairman.

Poor Ginola: as rocks and hard places go, Gregory and Ellis are among the more unpleasant. Still he has his friends.

His chum Peter Beardsley sprang to his defence this week. "To label him fat was outrageous," said Beardo. "I wish I had a physique to match David's."

As anyone who has seen the increasingly rotund Beardsley these days would concur. Send that man the Vanessa diet video immediately.
