webTitle: It's all Greek to Newcastle's Nobby

fields.headline: It's all Greek to Newcastle's Nobby
fields.trailText: Solano's stock is soaring despite passport puzzle.
fields.body:
Nolberto Solano has plenty on his mind. There is Newcastle's unlikely yet dogged pursuit of a Uefa Cup place; his ongoing negotiations for a new four-year contract at St James' Park; not to mention the controversy over the Peruvian's Greek passport which could yet see him deported.

He also has to try to arrange another trumpet lesson. "I practise whenever I have time, but my teacher plays in the Newcastle Symphony Orchestra so it is hard to fix up," he grins, the words tumbling out of his mouth in broad Julio Geordio. "I'm well into my salsa."

Not that Solano will be blowing his own trumpet before tomorrow's trip to Charlton. The 26-year-old, signed from Boca Juniors in 1998, has limited his performances to the pitch after serenading his team-mates before a Worthington Cup tie with Birmingham in November. "I played a bit for the lads with Gary Speed on guitar," he adds. "It was difficult though; a clash of styles." The football followed suit with Newcastle losing 2-1.

Bobby Robson's side visit the Valley hoping to lay a humiliating hoodoo to rest. Since goals from Temuri Ketsbaia and Jon-Dahl Tomasson beat Crystal Palace in December 1997, the Geordies have gone 23 matches without winning in the capital - a sequence that includes two FA Cup finals and a semi-final at Wembley. Leyton Orient of the Third Division held the Toon earlier this season, while the malaise has even spread to the juniors, who were knocked out of this year's FA Youth Cup by Palace.

"My experiences in London are not so good," said Solano, who has never returned with anything more than a few postcards to send back to Lima. "I'm sure it's a lovely place, but we always come home with nothing. If we really want to reach the Uefa Cup then we need to win there eventually and this is our last chance this season."

But against Charlton, Solano might be forgiven for having other matters on his mind. The Peruvian is one of 80 footballers currently under investigation by the Home Office over their eligibility to claim dual nationality. The midfielder was granted a work permit on his arrival in the north-east but allowed it to expire in 1999 having acquired a Greek passport, courtesy of a Greek grandmother. However, only a parent originating from Greece can confer dual nationality on their child.

"Don't mention your passport, Nobby," screams Warren Barton from the other side of the pitch. Solano complies but smiles in weary resignation. Newcastle's first-team squad fly to La Manga after tomorrow's match for a training week in the Spanish sun. With the furore continuing, his team-mates are unlikely to pass up a chance of some banter at passport control.

Robson faces a catch 22 over his No15. Solano, a former national captain who made his Peru debut at 19, regularly returned jaded and leaden-footed from international duty last season. His manager, keen that his most inventive attacking force retains his sparkle, therefore welcomed the news that he had retired from playing for his country after a clash with Peru's coach Julio Cesar during a World Cup qualifier against Bolivia in October. Yet, should the Home Office rule that Solano does not qualify for dual nationality, he would have to play in 75% of his country's internationals to obtain a work permit.

"I need to talk to Cesar," said Solano. "He was new to the job but I hardly spoke to him after the incident. We just had a difference of opinion. Maybe we can reach a solution and I'll be back playing for Peru. I know Newcastle wouldn't be happy because I would have to travel around the world, but it is my country."

Solano's form this season has undoubtedly been international class. Linking up with Kieron Dyer on his inside - the pair share an almost telepathic relationship on the pitch, tearing down the right flank with canny interchanges and clever flicks - he remains the team's main goal supply line. He has sublime touch; against Leeds at Elland Road recently he gracefully controlled a crossfield pass and caressed the ball in one smooth motion to Shola Ameobi where others would have been happy merely to cushion the pass. The young striker scored and Newcastle won 3-1.

"I know I can play well here now," he said. "In South America you have so much time on the ball, but here players are up and down the pitch, charging forward whenever they can. It's more physical; I'm surrounded by big guys (Solano stands 5'9"). But I love it - the fighting spirit took time to adapt to, but you have to be strong. I have more confidence now.

"That is down to Mr Robson. He's a great manager, a wise old man who's been with England, Barcelona and Porto - all great teams. He has brought a bit of those clubs to Newcastle. This season we've had so many injuries, but he knows how to adapt to such situations, giving confidence to youngsters like Shola. He's so clever."

While Robson's ability to maintain a European challenge with negligible funds and a crippling injury list has been astonishing, Solano has taken added responsibility on his shoulders. In seven glittering seasons with Sporting Cristal, Alianza Lima and Deportivo Municipal in Peru and Argentina's Boca he hit more than 50 goals. Robbed of his team's focal point - Alan Shearer returns to full training on Monday after a two-month absence - Solano has rediscovered that scoring touch.

There have been six goals already, including a stunning volley against Aston Villa in the FA Cup, a delicate lob against the same opposition in the league and a blistering free-kick to help beat Leeds on Boxing Day. "I look upon free-kicks in the same way as penalties," he says. "When the games are so tight, you have to take your chance. If I miss I'm as disappointed as when I miss a penalty, but I don't mind that pressure.

"I learned a lot from Diego Maradona when we were together at Boca. He was very nice to me; an excellent man, a good man. I had seen him on the television at the 1986 and 1990 World Cups.

"Then, at my first training session with Boca, we were practising free-kicks and he told me: 'You are a master.' I said to him: 'In my country, we think you are the master.' He taught me when I should be looking to bend the ball over the wall, or trying to find one of my team-mates in the area."

Maradona later christened Solano "the little maestro". Few on Tyneside would disagree.

webTitle: Rich get richer as Tigers roar with pain

fields.headline: Rich get richer as Tigers roar with pain
fields.trailText: Glum faces by the Humber, smiles and handshakes in Manhattan. The juxtaposition of Man Utd's marketing deal with the Yankees and the lockout at Hull has re-emphasised the ever-widening gulf that exists between the haves and have-nots of English football.
fields.body:
It seems an unlikely marriage and the respective products undoubtedly appeal to widely differing tastes, but surely few can argue with the imagination, enterprise and sense of adventure behind the latest merging of Anglo-American business interests.

Yes, Bob the Builder and Barney the Dinosaur seem set for a lucrative future together. On the other hand Manchester United's marketing deal with the New York Yankees has been greeted with a degree of scepticism by financial experts.

Maybe United should have paired up Becks with Tyrannosaurus Rex. At least that would have found some common ground with the kids.

It is not as if much can be done with the Damn Yankees angle. This is the musical based on the Faust legend but United had already sold their merchandising souls to Nike.

Yet the anxious players and supporters of Hull City could do worse than take their cue from one of the show's hit numbers - the one where a baseball coach attempts to inspire his squad by singing "You've gotta have heart, miles and miles and miles of heart . . . You've gotta have hope, miles and miles . . . etc."

Brian Little has never come across as the type of manager to rouse his players through song, yet when the gates at Boothferry Park were locked against them this week Little and his team were left with nothing much else but heart and hope. While United were going to market with the Yankees, the Tigers were becoming an even more endangered species.

The administrators attempting to sort out Hull's financial problems have been given a fortnight to produce an acceptable rescue package before the high court issues a winding-up order stemming from £500,000 of unpaid VAT.

Altogether the club are thought to be £2m in debt but at least they will have the key of the door for today's home game against Leyton Orient. David Lloyd, former Davis Cup captain and the club's ex-chairman who still owns Boothferry Park, earlier this week ordered the lockout until he was paid £45,000 back rent. He has since played a let and allowed Hull back in.

Glum faces by the Humber, smiles and handshakes in Manhattan, the juxtaposition of these events has re-emphasised the ever-widening gulf that exists between the haves and have-nots of English football. To some extent United are in a plutocracy of one but it is also a fact that the Premier League as a whole now looks down on the Nationwide League much as the World Trade Centre towers over City Hall.

The financial comparisons are becoming more and more bizarre. Hull owe in tax what it takes Roy Keane fewer than 10 weeks to earn at Old Trafford, and in rent less than the United captain's weekly wage.

The Third Division club are hardly unique in this respect. For the majority of their contemporaries in the lower divisions the gate receipts of one match at Old Trafford would pay the wages bill for a season.

While there have always been wide differences between the well-off and not-so-well-off clubs in English football there was a time when a sense of egalitarianism sustained the league from top to bottom. And Hull were once typical of the well-run clubs forming a solid bedrock below the old First Division.

In the late 40s, while United finished runners-up in the league with average gates of 46,000, Hull won promotion from the Third Division (North) with an average of 36,000. Later Harold Needler, the Hull chairman and a lifelong supporter, settled £200,000 worth of shares in his quarry company on the club and from this base emerged a successful team with a ground to match.

This week anyone old enough to remember the invigorating football played by the Hull side of Chris Chilton, Ken Houghton and Ken Wagstaff in the 60s will have felt a pang of anxiety at the thought of the Tigers going to the dogs. Fortunately, and despite the gloomiest prognostications, English football clubs are often at their most tenacious when clinging to existence.

Hull supporters can console themselves with the thought that if Brighton can be carpetbagged, forced to play five motorways away at Gillingham and survive not only to return home, albeit not to the Goldstone Ground, to push for promotion then all things are possible. And it is not that long since Middlesbrough were locked out of Ayresome Park by the official receiver.

Hull will carry on, there seems little doubt of that, and out of the present crisis may come the sort of renewed determination, from inside and outside the club, which saw Charlton Athletic reborn after several seasons of exile from the Valley. Nothing concentrates the minds of a football community so much as the possibility that its team will disappear.

Yet with a transfer system which is the lifeblood of the Hulls, Hartlepools and Halifaxes about to disappear and uncertainties about the form of compensation that will take its place, this is a bad moment to be caught by the taxman. Football clubs owe each other money all the time but there are some creditors with whom it is never wise to dally.

For Hull, settling the argument over a £6,000 bill at Mr Chu's Chinese restaurant in the city would be a start. Surely even the Beckhams would not order that much chop suey.

fields.headline: The long goodbye
fields.standfirst: Alex Clark on a life in the balance in Milwaukee, Bernice Rubens's 22nd novel
fields.trailText: Alex Clark on a life in the balance in Milwaukee, Bernice Rubens's 22nd novel
fields.body:
Milwaukee
Bernice Rubens
198pp, Little, Brown, £16.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Whether we cherish notions of the afterlife or believe only in the chilly solitude of oblivion, the importance of dying well - with scores settled and final farewells taken - remains a pressing concern for the vast majority. And with the narrative paradigms offered by mythology, psychology and fiction, the "good death" is often expanded to include the "good life", a story understood and completed, its ends neatly tied to give us the closure denied in the random meanderings of the everyday.

This is the theme of Bernice Rubens's 22nd novel, set in a sketchily realised hospice where Annie Dawson, only in her 60s but felled by a swift and uncompromising illness, has come to spend her last two months. Her lifelong friend, Clemmie, visits her daily, but consistently rounds down the amount of time that has already passed when Annie demands to know how long she has been there. Clemmie understands that Annie has undertaken one last grand project: to proceed once again through her unhappy life and to exorcise as many of its demons as she can; to seek and to bestow forgiveness; and to achieve, through catharsis, a smoother passage for her body and soul into eternity.

Unfortunately for Annie, and for the verisimilitude of Rubens's complicated back story, her demons seem to be the principal figures in her life. Told in episodes that correspond to Annie's own determined hikes down memory lane, the book plunges us into a miserable and convoluted tale of treachery and abandonment.

First, she is rudely deflowered by a departing GI in the back of an army truck and then, as a pregnant schoolgirl, ostracised by her tyrannical father and betrayed by her weak mother. With her father safely dead - the shock of social disgrace strikes him down on the golf course - she seems to salvage some happiness, marrying the accommodating Freddie.

So far, so palatable, as Annie muses during her death-bed rememberings. But the story takes a savage turn for the worse. Annie's monstrous mother, keen to expunge the shame of Mary's birth, tells the child that she is the issue of a war hero; when Mary grows up and announces her decision to visit her father's grave, Annie reveals the truth and unleashes the wrecking ball on her own and everybody else's life.

The story unfolds with all the inexorability of Greek tragedy and the overblown melodrama of an American mini-series. There are screaming matches and venomous allegations; the appearance of "Milwaukee" himself, an impostor chancing his arm in the family nest; accusations of rape, another baby of uncertain paternity and a private detective. Annie's life story seems set to end in inconclusion and loneliness. Attacked by mother and daughter, abandoned by her husband, she is accompanied only by her unshakable sense that she acted for the best in an unwinnable competition.

Rubens's evocation of the onset of urgency amid the desperate longueurs of the hospice is so fine that it barely needs the frantic activity of the past to support it. One constantly itches to get back to the present: the small-scale deceptions of doctors, solicitors and friends as they simultaneously will their charges on to the end and collude to create an air of stability is drama enough. By contrast, the story of Annie's former life, riddled with casual brutality and disappointment, seems almost pedestrian. It is an obvious truth that characters in novels do not behave like real people, but the novelist must conceal that fundamental distortion. Here, one simply recoils in disbelief at the horrific inadequacy of the characters, each intent on creating their own, impregnable life story, and reacts with frustration at Annie's impotence to control her own.

If it is true - or at least, a truly consoling prospect - that what remains of us is love, then Annie's delirium-fuelled hopes for a last reconciliation with her daughter seem to fall heart-breakingly short of the mark. In animating that inalienable desire, Rubens comes tantalisingly close to capturing the pathos and futility of the dying fall. If she had managed to keep faith with it, she would have written a book more devastating in its impact.

And with the narrative paradigms offered by mythology, psychology and fiction, the "good death" is often expanded to include the "good life", a story understood and completed, its ends neatly tied to give us the closure denied in the random meanderings of the everyday. This is the theme of Bernice Rubens's 22nd novel, set in a sketchily realised hospice where Annie Dawson, only in her 60s but felled by a swift and uncompromising illness, has come to spend her last two months. Her lifelong friend, Clemmie, visits her daily, but consistently rounds down the amount of time that has already passed when Annie demands to know how long she has been there. Told in episodes that correspond to Annie's own determined hikes down memory lane, the book plunges us into a miserable and convoluted tale of treachery and abandonment. First, she is rudely deflowered by a departing GI in the back of an army truck and then, as a pregnant schoolgirl, ostracised by her tyrannical father and betrayed by her weak mother. fields.headline: Diary  Mike Ticher
fields.standfirst: Numb bum is all part of the Vicarage Road service
fields.trailText: Numb bums at Vicarage Road
fields.body:
In what is almost certainly the season's most pointless exercise, Watford's co-chaplain (they need two, apparently) the Rev Andrew Cowley is aiming to sit in all 22,000 seats at Vicarage Road on February 27. Though not while a match is in progress, you understand. It's all to help raise money for the charity SCORE, which aims to "meet the ever-growing demand for quality chaplaincy in sport". Only about 22,000 more deserving causes spring instantly to mind.

A curious twist on the traditional "On this day" feature from Leyton Orient's programme. Not content with recording football events, they are also keen to remind fans of what happened in the wider world. Last week's extensive selection included the following. "1893: Birthday of American comic Jimmy Durante, whose large nose became part of his highly successful act." And "1955: Thousands of armed South African police begin evicting 60,000 black citizens from their homes in Sophiatown near Johannesburg, with bulldozers flattening the township in their wake." Relevance to Leyton Orient v Halifax Town: unknown.

Torquay fans on their way to Chesterfield two weeks ago stopped at Tamworth services on the M42 (this item gets more interesting as it goes along). There they were delighted to come across the Gulls manager Wes Saunders - playing a video arcade game called Fatal Assignment. Torquay lost 3-0.

In another corner of crazy Watfordworld, the club's website reports on this week's reserve game against Ipswich. "It took 77 minutes for the deadlock to be broken, Fabian Forde converting a penalty after the Horses' keeper had been dismissed . . ." The Horses? Well, it's on their badge, and if anyone's campaigning for it to replace the tiresome Tractor Boys we'll be the first to sign up.

Ahem. Four of last week's diary tips crashed in a heap of smouldering rubble, to the tune of one goal for, 21 against. A big hand to Athletic Bilbao, in particular, who were 6-0 down at half-time against Barcelona. However, and this is the beauty of our system, Sporting Braga's come-from- behind 2-1 win at Sporting Lisbon salvaged the whole weekend and after two weeks we've turned $100 into $107. This week's sacrificial victims are Cologne, Atalanta, Real Sociedad, Samsunspor and plucky amateurs Fontenay-le-Comte in the French Cup. All at a chancy 9-2 or better.

Look out for the former Stockport County triallist Joel Cantona - Eric's brother - playing the part of a legionary in the new French film, Asterix et Cleopatre. He'll be the one falling over his feet.

This week's Jewish Chronicle took exception to recent comments by the Blackburn manager Graeme Souness on negotiations with Eyal Berkovic over his move to Ewood Park. Souness, renowned for contributions to international diplomacy throughout his career, said: "Clearly Eyal is a professional who wants to earn as much money as possible. But you must understand that he is Jewish and I am Scottish so it will be difficult for us to reach a financial agreement."

Fans of Chelsea, Tottenham and Stan Collymore may be cheered by the record of his new club, Real Oviedo. In their 10 league games away from home so far this season, not only have Raddy Antic's lads not won, they haven't so much as scored. "It's just one of those things that happens in football," Antic said after last week's 1-0 defeat at Las Palmas. Or doesn't happen, in their case.

webTitle: Terry takes command of the Bridge

fields.headline: Terry takes command of the Bridge
fields.standfirst: The young English defender is fired for the visit of Manchester United.
fields.trailText: The young English defender - the only homegrown talent now sure of a place in the Chelsea side - is fired for today's visit of Manchester United, the team he supported as a boy.
fields.body:
Surprisingly for a club at which Dennis Wise is such an influential presence, Chelsea's dressing room will, as always, be noise free, or at least music free, in the final minutes before the players run out to face Manchester United today.

As someone who only left his teens behind two months ago, John Terry would be the last one to object if Wise brought in his old Wimbledon ghetto blaster to help him get his blood pumping before games, though he has developed his own methods of turning himself from mild-mannered young man to eyes-bulging Premiership footballer.

"I am totally different people on and off the pitch," Terry said. "I am very quiet off the pitch but on it, I am definitely up for it. I don't go round head-butting walls in the dressing room or anything like that but I do psyche myself up mentally."

Terry somehow managed to support both Chelsea and Manchester United as a boy and at one time trained at Old Trafford, travelling from east London to Manchester in the same car as David Beckham. Maybe that was a factor in him plumping for Chelsea as a 14-year-old, despite the fact that his dad and grandad are both United fans.

Terry, who also had a spell with West Ham as a youngster, says: "Although I was a fan of United's, when I was offered schoolboy forms on my 14th birthday, I made my decision as a potential professional footballer rather than a supporter. My dad was brilliant, not putting any pressure on me, and I decided that Chelsea were a better club, they just had a nice feel to them."

At 6ft 1in and 12st 13lb of English manhood, Terry - the only homegrown talent now sure of a place in the Chelsea side - is built like old-fashioned former centre-halves at the club such as Micky Droy or Joe McLaughlin. But you do not get to split the World Cup-winning partnership of Marcel Desailly and Frank Leboeuf simply by treading on people's toes and kicking a few opponents in the air. Nor by being the shy and retiring type on the pitch.

Leboeuf, who seems likely to surrender his shirt to a fit-again Terry today, is at least satisfied that it is going to a deserving home, saying: "He's a fantastic player. As well as being a great defender, he reads the game, which is very important because even if you are quick, if you are stupid, you arrive at the wrong time. He's got a good technique, too, so has everything to be a good defender. I told him two years ago he had to be patient because his time would come. Now I think it is coming."

And Leboeuf, it seems, may be going, having already come close to joining Monaco. Although he has since pledged his loyalty to the club, one cannot imagine a man of Leboeuf's ego and sense of his own worth playing second fiddle to a 20-year-old for long.

The sight of Terry playing in a reserve game against Coventry was the high spot of manager Claudio Ranieri's first day in London last September. He was so impressed that he later had a quiet word with the lad, letting him know that he was in his plans for the future.

Terry, who played twice last season, says: "People kept telling me to be patient and I was prepared to wait until I was 21 or 22 to get in the first team because Marcel and Frank are both World Cup winners and both world class." He did not, however, have to wait long, finding himself alongside Desailly in a Worthington Cup tie against Liverpool at Anfield in November when Leboeuf was suspended.

By the following month, he was a regular, playing 10 successive games before flu caused him to miss the last two matches, though it is United's attackers who may catch a cold against him this afternoon.

As Leboeuf points out, Terry is a well brought up young man with respect for his elders. He demonstrates this by praising the two French defenders for helping him with his game, sometimes simply by example. "If you can take little bits from their game and add it to yours, you've got to be a better player," he says.

Growing up he was convinced he would be conducting the midfield orchestra, his heroes were Bryan Robson, Paul Ince and Eric Cantona. According to Gwyn Williams, Chelsea's assistant manager, he arrived at the club as a midfield player who never made a tackle. But as his frame filled out and grew, he was asked to fill in as a defender for a youth match against Barnsley and never looked forward, so to speak.

His dad and grandad will both be at Stamford Bridge today, though feeling rather sheepish about supporting Manchester United. Terry will have no feelings for United, not even hard ones about missing the chance to join a club that has enjoyed non-stop success since he turned them down.

Nor will he and his Chelsea team-mates suffer any inferiority complex, especially not after the 5-0 hammering of United at Stamford Bridge last season. He says: "Too many teams worry too much about the opposition and if you do that, you're going to lose."

In any case, Chelsea's form at the Bridge has been good all season. It is only their appalling away form that has made their task of qualifying for the Champions League so difficult, though Terry says: "I don't think that's a tall order if we can sort out our away form." Or to put it another way, if they can all starting singing from the same song sheet away from home.

fields.headline: Pop poetry
fields.trailText: You know, it really doesn't take long to find a job if you've got the right connections
fields.body:
 You know, it really doesn't take long to find a job if you've got the right connections. A scanty fortnight after her resignation from the Express and unrelated appearance on the Whitbread pundits' panel, Rosie Boycott finds herself chairing this year's Orange Prize. For company, she's joined by musician Suzanne Vega, novelist Emily Perkins and the BBC's Kate Adie - who at least, it might be noted, already has a flak jacket.

 The Loafer's eye is drawn to a fantastic advertisement for an awesomely ambitious project. "The Best Poetry Album in the World . . . Ever!" doesn't just bring you Richard Briers reading If. It doesn't stop short at Hugh Grant comparing thee to a summer's day. It goes the whole hog, and lets loose Dale Winton on Kubla Khan and John Donne's The Flea. Rumours that he stops midway and commands the listener to unleash the balls are, as yet, unsubstantiated.

 "The Plant has furled its leaves for the time being," announces Stephen King, by way of explanation for the abrupt disappearance of the e-book's first six instalments from his website. Readers will remember that the experiment has not been judged a complete success. King's accounts, however, reveal that the net profit amounts to $463,832.27 - not exactly mere beer money.

 What has Jonathan Cape debut novelist Dan Collins - author of the fragmentary Cannibals - got against journalist Henry Porter? According to its narrator, "Henry Porter wants to drink my blood. The Henry Porter . . . In my dreams Henry Porter quaffs my blood." To satisfy the fictional Porter's vampiric demands, the narrator despatches him a used tampon in a jiffy bag. Will "Porter" disappear from this early proof copy? I think we should be told.

webTitle: Review: The Hesperides Tree by Nicholas Mosley

fields.headline: Implausible monsters
fields.standfirst: 'The literature of the genetically modified lab rat.' Robert Potts on The Hesperides Tree by Nicholas Mosley
fields.trailText: 'The literature of the genetically modified lab rat.' Robert Potts on The Hesperides Tree by Nicholas Mosley
fields.body:
The Hesperides Tree
Nicholas Mosley
320pp, Secker & Warburg, £15.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

In 1991, the compulsory Booker Prize brouhaha was provided by Nicholas Mosley, who resigned from the judging panel after the shortlist meeting. Mosley had been backing Allan Massie's The Sins of the Father , which none of the other judges favoured; indeed, not one of his choices had made the shortlist. Mosley, writing about the affair in the Times , commented that "the other four judges complained that my chosen books were novels of ideas, or novels in which characters were subservient to ideas . . . My point was that humans were beings who did have ideas, who were often influenced by ideas, to whom ideas were important. If they were not, then there was some lack in being human."

Mosley's novel Hopeful Monsters had been a success in 1990, when it won the Whitbread Prize. It is certainly a novel of ideas; Darwinism, Marxism, psychoanalysis and quantum physics are all kicked about, against backdrops of major 20th-century political events - the Spanish Civil War, Nazi Germany and so on. Two curious children, Max and Helena, are drawn together in a charming love story that also uses evolutionary theory as a metaphor for human and political possibility; "hopeful monsters" are genetic aberrations that turn out to be fortuitously equipped for subsequent changes of environment.

Mosley's latest novel, The Hesperides Tree , has a less schematic yet even more implausible plot than its predecessor. An unnamed narrator, the soft-skulled offspring of a maker of scientific documentaries and a psychotherapist, goes on a trip to Ireland for his father's work. There he falls in love with a girl, Julie; stumbles upon some gun-running; learns about a bird colony on an offshore island where the birds seem to be evolving faster under environmental pressures than Darwinian science might allow for; and discovers also that in the Dark Ages, hermits settled on the same offshore island. On the dustjacket of the proof copy, a summary of the first part of the plot was followed by the despairing line "He tries to imagine how these ways of life might be connected", which is sensibly absent from the bound copy.

Back in England, this heady brew is supplemented by the narrator's university switch from English literature to biology, his unlikely impregnation of a lesbian feminist, his friendship with a gay computer hacker (whose father once had an affair with the narrator's mother), the approaching millennium . . . But the plot - a series of contrived accidents and deliberately wild coincidences - is scarcely the point. The point is to assemble a cast of characters who can discuss political violence, evolutionary science, the internet, religion - the big ideas. They are scarcely credible, even as caricatures; their actions are frequently inexplicable and the dialogue stinks to high heaven, veering between banality and apparent telepathy. The narrator's mental health sometimes seems borderline, and he communicates in an idiot savant manner that makes his eerily fertile love life even less credible than it might have been. This is the literature of the genetically modified laboratory rat.

When our narrator explains his decision to switch subjects from literature to science, there is a clue as to how Mosley has come to make such odd and unsuccessful stylistic choices in this book: "literature seemed to treat humans no differently than science did; as characters predestined to behave in the way they did, very occasionally happening by chance to change, but with no awareness of autonomy. Their brains produced no more than a stream of consciousness or rather unconsciousness because they contained no feel of how humans might be creative. Thus literature became a chronicle of humanity's oddities and crimes and follies, peopled by characters with no virtue except that of being quaint. This was decked out indeed often enough in glorious or subtle language which gave the impression of empowerment; but there was little feel of this in the characters portrayed."

This, of course, travesties literature: what it does, and what it can do. Half the faults diagnosed are made, in any case, by Mosley himself, apparently unwittingly. The difference is only that there is no linguistic glory or subtlety as his experiment plays out. Some of the ideas in this book are, indeed, important; the questions behind them certainly are. But Mosley fails to establish the importance of playing out those questions and ideas in a novel and, dismayingly, fails to write a satisfying novel in which to entertain them. I loved Hopeful Monsters ; it was one of my favourite novels of the early 1990s, and deserved the Whitbread Prize. The Hesperides Tree is easily one of the worst novels I have read in the last 10 years, and pages 77 to 79 would merit the Bad Sex Award.

There he falls in love with a girl, Julie; stumbles upon some gun-running; learns about a bird colony on an offshore island where the birds seem to be evolving faster under environmental pressures than Darwinian science might allow for; and discovers also that in the Dark Ages, hermits settled on the same offshore island. On the dustjacket of the proof copy, a summary of the first part of the plot was followed by the despairing line "He tries to imagine how these ways of life might be connected", which is sensibly absent from the bound copy. Back in England, this heady brew is supplemented by the narrator's university switch from English literature to biology, his unlikely impregnation of a lesbian feminist, his friendship with a gay computer hacker (whose father once had an affair with the narrator's mother), the approaching millennium . . . But the plot - a series of contrived accidents and deliberately wild coincidences - is scarcely the point. The point is to assemble a cast of characters who can discuss political violence, evolutionary science, the internet, religion - the big ideas. They are scarcely credible, even as caricatures; their actions are frequently inexplicable and the dialogue stinks to high heaven, veering between banality and apparent telepathy. The narrator's mental health sometimes seems borderline, and he communicates in an idiot savant manner that makes his eerily fertile love life even less credible than it might have been. This is the literature of the genetically modified laboratory rat. When our narrator explains his decision to switch subjects from literature to science, there is a clue as to how Mosley has come to make such odd and unsuccessful stylistic choices in this book: "literature seemed to treat humans no differently than science did; as characters predestined to behave in the way they did, very occasionally happening by chance to change, but with no awareness of autonomy. Their brains produced no more than a stream of consciousness or rather unconsciousness because they contained no feel of how humans might be creative. Thus literature became a chronicle of humanity's oddities and crimes and follies, peopled by characters with no virtue except that of being quaint. This was decked out indeed often enough in glorious or subtle language which gave the impression of empowerment; but there was little feel of this in the characters portrayed." This, of course, travesties literature: what it does, and what it can do. Half the faults diagnosed are made, in any case, by Mosley himself, apparently unwittingly. The difference is only that there is no linguistic glory or subtlety as his experiment plays out. Some of the ideas in this book are, indeed, important; the questions behind them certainly are. But Mosley fails to establish the importance of playing out those questions and ideas in a novel and, dismayingly, fails to write a satisfying novel in which to entertain them. I loved Hopeful Monsters ; it was one of my favourite novels of the early 1990s, and deserved the Whitbread Prize. The Hesperides Tree is easily one of the worst novels I have read in the last 10 years, and pages 77 to 79 would merit the Bad Sex Award.

webTitle: Old Firm told to turn down the heat

fields.headline: Old Firm told to turn down the heat
fields.trailText: The Scottish Premier League has issued a plea for calm ahead of tomorrow's Old Firm derby at Parkhead, after three players were sent off during last Wednesday's CIS Cup semi-final between the two clubs.
fields.body:
Before last Wednesday's CIS Cup semi-final the Rangers manager Dick Advocaat was complaining about having to play two Old Firm matches in a week. Anyone who did not already share his views had probably been persuaded by the time the 90 minutes were up, having seen three players sent off in the third stormy instalment of this season's Glasgow derbies, won 3-1 by Celtic.

The Scottish Premier League has issued a slightly wan plea for calm ahead of tomorrow's league match at Parkhead. "While passion and energy are essential to football, those involved . . . have a responsibility to the wider community to ensure everything good about Scottish football is on display," a spokesman said.

Some hope. In the three games between the two sides this season there have been 24 bookings and six red cards, while the legitimate action has been no less explosive, with 18 goals, three of them penalties. On Wednesday Slovakia, the United States and Holland added their names to the rapidly lengthening list of countries which can claim an Old Firm sending-off, thanks to the dismissals of Lubo Moravcik, Claudio Reyna and Michael Mols. All three will miss tomorrow's game after Rangers yesterday lost their appeal against Mols's dismissal.

Reyna kicked out at Celtic's Neil Lennon even after he had been sent off and more post-match dissent meant he ended up with no fewer than five cards on the night - three yellow and two red. "I'd say it was a normal local derby, nothing special," Rangers' Jourg Albertz said.

Hugh Dallas, who was felled by a coin thrown from the crowd in the league game between the two sides at Parkhead in May 1999 (nine booked, three sent off), will again be in charge. "It is widely known that he is one of the best referees not just in Scotland, but in Europe," an SFA spokesman said. "With that kind of experience he is just the person to handle everything that will arise on Sunday."

The Scottish Football Association said yesterday that foreign referees might be brought in for future Old Firm games.

The SFA could have done without this week's controversy over the visit of the Irish prime minister Bertie Ahern to Glasgow. Ahern was due to attend the game before unveiling a memorial to victims of the potato famine of the 1840s, but cancelled his plans after a local MP raised fears about the possibility of sectarian violence around the game.

Meanwhile, back at the football, Celtic will see the match as a chance to quash Rangers' hopes of a late title charge. Celtic are nine points ahead and must start clear favourites after Wednesday night's win.

The loss of Mols and Reyna has depleted Rangers' already thinning squad. With Barry Ferguson also suspended and eight other players out injured, Advocaat may turn to Fernando Ricksen, who was substituted after only 23 minutes in Celtic's 6-2 win in the first derby at Parkhead, in August.

Ricksen said on his website this week that he thought Rangers could beat Celtic, who have an unblemished home record this season, "if we can match them for fighting spirit". It seems unlikely there will be any shortage of that.

fields.headline: Hick flick
fields.standfirst: David Mamet's new film is an intelligent satire on the venality of the movie business. If only he'd remembered to include some jokes, says Joe Queenan
fields.trailText: David Mamet's new film is an intelligent satire on the venality of the movie business. If only he'd remembered to include some jokes, says Joe Queenan
fields.body:
Last year Woody Allen made a movie about a small-time crook who opens an upscale cookie store next to a bank so that he and his henchmen can burrow inside. The tunnelling operation is a disaster, but the cookie business is such a hit that he and his wife can retire from the malfeasance racket for good. On the surface, this seemed like a can't-miss premise. But Small Time Crooks turned out to be one of Allen's least successful movies for the pure and simple reason that he forgot to write any good jokes.

Though hardly a disaster, David Mamet's State And Main falls into the same general category. The movie's premise is not unpromising: a motion picture crew turn up in a small, picture-perfect town in rural Vermont and announce that they are there to make a heartwarming film about redemption. The movie people are the usual calculating egomaniacs from Los Angeles, and the rustics are the usual clueless rustics. In theory, the cultural collision between the ostensibly good (ordinary people) and the indisputably evil (the movie crew) should translate into tons of chuckles and everyone should go home with a spring in their step and a song in their heart.

Unfortunately, Mamet forgot to write the jokes. The result is a charming, generally amusing, refreshingly intelligent movie, definitely a worthwhile rental on a depressing late summer afternoon. But unlike Shadow Of The Vampire, which is also a humorous movie about the making of a movie, State And Main never achieves lift-off. It just sort of lies there.

The story runs as follows: a film crew headed by the reliably deranged William H Macy have fled from their previous shooting locale because of an unspecified contretemps. They now descend upon Waterford, Vermont, which suits their needs because it is quaint and has an old mill, and because the name of their quaint film is The Old Mill. Initially, the townspeople are happy to see them; initially, townspeople always are. Then problems start. The nervous, goofy screenwriter (Philip Seymour Hoffman) falls in love with the eccentric bookstore owner (Rebecca Pidgeon), who is also director of the local theatre group. The theatre group falls apart because the locals would rather be non-speaking extras in a real, live motion picture than bit players in some crummy local production of Hamlet or Pal Joey.

After the male lead (Alec Baldwin) despoils the finest jailbait in the tri-state area (Julia Stiles), Pidgeon's jilted fiancé, a small-time politician, decides to shake down the film producer (David Paymer) for money. Meanwhile, the bimbo female lead (Sarah Jessica Parker) wants an extra $800,000 to reveal her breasts on camera; this seems a bit pricey. Finally, in a real capper, it turns out that the town has no mill; it burned down 40 years ago.

These conceits are funny enough, but for an enterprise like this to work, the pacing has to be manic. The story has to race along from one disaster to the next, Billy Wilder-style. It does not. It just kind of chugs along. For the first time in memory, Mamet seems to be out of his element. Mamet's best work (House Of Games, The Spanish Prisoner, Homicide) is dark, cruel and clever. It is full of scamsters, con artists, stool pigeons. It is a milieu populated by grifters played with consummate untrustworthiness by Joe Mantegna and JT Walsh. In these movies, well-meaning people tend to get taken to the cleaners, and when they do, Mamet does not invite our sympathy. Like Alfred Hitchcock, he seems to delight in depicting the misfortune of the innocent. If you're a sap, you're a sap.

In State And Main, this dark vision of the world is muted. This time out, Mamet decides to play it quirky. The town physician is quirky. The farmers reading the current box-office grosses in Variety are quirky. The female lead (Pidgeon) is mega-quirky. Not since the days when Bob Newhart rode tall in the saddle has New England-based quirkiness had such a field day. After a while, it becomes a bit cloying.

To his credit, Mamet has not filmed the usual malarkey in which the city slickers learn the real values in life from salt-of-the-earth types who live out in the back end of nowhere. No, in Mamet's world, the city slickers are cool, calculating, sophisticated types who would sell their first child to the Bedouins if they could turn a profit on the deal, and the country bumpkins are unsophisticated rubes who would do exactly the same thing, but would probably feel a bit guilty about it. But the satire Mamet uses here is so broad and obvious - the nitwit local police chief, the social-climbing mayor, the star-struck hotel manager - that it all seems kind of stilted and clunky.

Several years ago, when I saw Gus Van Sant's remorselessly upbeat Good Will Hunting, I argued that this mushy couscous of working class clichés was a well-camouflaged satire, subversively poking fun at movies where dysfunctional proles grow up to win the Nobel Prize. Having seen State And Main twice, I am willing to advance the same theory here. The ridiculous miscasting of the plump, awkward Hoffman in the role Kyle MacLachlan or John Cusack was born to play can only be explained by a desire to ridicule the traditional Boy Meets Girl cinematic archetypes.

So perhaps in State And Main, a film in which good does not ultimately triumph over evil, Mamet was trying to parody all those films about wise, lovable rustics, just to turn the tables on the charming bucolics for a change. But frankly I doubt it. Both times I saw State And Main, I came away with the feeling that it was a film that honestly wanted to be heartwarming, but couldn't pull it off, because in the end it had no heart.

• State And Main is out on Friday

fields.headline: Rickie Lee Jones
fields.standfirst:
Jazz Cafe, London
****
fields.trailText:
Jazz Cafe, London
****
fields.body:
Rickie Lee Jones is something of an anomaly. Her latest album, It's Like This, has just been nominated for a Grammy - but how many people know it's out there, or that she's touring, or that she even still exists and has done anything since Chuck E's In Love, oh, 22 years ago? Never mind that she has one of the Great Voices extant...

In her mid-40s, she suffers from rock's innate misogyny à la Hollywood (which reserves its starring roles for perky daughters rather than wise mothers) and from the fact that she can't be pinned to an easy genre definition. Folksy feminist? Beat angel? Ex drug-life visionary?

Tonight, in a rare UK appearance, she could be an ageless elder poet - Anne Sexton with a low-slung Gibson, spinning tales of flightless birds and cabbalistic maps. And then, with her dirty giggle, she's the eternal Younger Sister - the one who dyed her hair purple before her time, or put obscene angels on the Christmas tree.

Dressed down in sweats and shades and sandals, she initally seems out of sorts, sniffly, sniffy, withdrawn, and at odds with her own songs' strange, jack-in-the-box time signatures. It takes a fidgety while for her to warm (and tune) up, and settle down into the delicate logic of a career-encompassing set. The band (including her long-time collaborator Sal Bernadi) also start in playing-by-numbers style, as if infected by their leader's distracted air.

But then out of these doldrums leap sudden spots of coherence and surges of beauty - notably on her own Atlas's Marker, and a generously dark reading of My Funny Valentine that hushed the room. The serpentine Cloud of Unknowing hit an astral jazz groove like mid-period Tim Buckley; and by the time she took a staggeringly confident hipsway through The Street Where You Live you knew you were privy to something rare - the kind of delicate yet gutsy vocal performance one might have thought dead and buried with the ghosts of Torch Song past.

The Magazine was prefaced with an illuminating rap about her street-drug past - an anecdotal frame for the song's rueful self-inventory. A Cubano shimmy through Steely Dan's still-acid Show Biz Kids might stand as a manifesto, except Jones negotiates it like a piece of blues erotica rather than a poison dart to the gestalt.

She seemed to grow in poise and purpose just as the end drew near, finishing with a note-perfect Satellites, its valedictory lines - "Don't quit: code the world with a fugitive light!" - proffered like a motto.

And then she was gone, with a radiant smile, but no encores - a disservice to her jewel box catalogue.

In equal parts frustrating and unfeasibly sublime. There really is no one like her.

The band (including her long-time collaborator Sal Bernadi) also start in playing-by-numbers style, as if infected by their leader's distracted air. But then out of these doldrums leap sudden spots of coherence and surges of beauty - notably on her own Atlas's Marker, and a generously dark reading of My Funny Valentine that hushed the room. The serpentine Cloud of Unknowing hit an astral jazz groove like mid-period Tim Buckley; and by the time she took a staggeringly confident hipsway through The Street Where You Live you knew you were privy to something rare - the kind of delicate yet gutsy vocal performance one might have thought dead and buried with the ghosts of Torch Song past. The Magazine was prefaced with an illuminating rap about her street-drug past - an anecdotal frame for the song's rueful self-inventory. A Cubano shimmy through Steely Dan's still-acid Show Biz Kids might stand as a manifesto, except Jones negotiates it like a piece of blues erotica rather than a poison dart to the gestalt. She seemed to grow in poise and purpose just as the end drew near, finishing with a note-perfect Satellites, its valedictory lines - "Don't quit: code the world with a fugitive light!" - proffered like a motto. And then she was gone, with a radiant smile, but no encores - a disservice to her jewel box catalogue. In equal parts frustrating and unfeasibly sublime. There really is no one like her.

fields.headline: Blood flows at Newbury's Watermill
fields.standfirst:
Rose Rage
Watermill, Newbury
***
fields.trailText:
Rose Rage
Watermill, Newbury
***
fields.body:
We are in the abattoir. The hooks and trusses await the carcasses, rubber gloves are at the ready. The cast are fully gowned and masked. There is the sound of knives being sharpened. Be in no doubt - the slaughter is about to begin.

Initially, Rose Rage seems a trite title for Edward Hall's reduced, all-male version of Shakespeare's Henry VI trilogy that takes us on a bloody historical rollercoaster ride from the death of Henry V through the War of the Roses. But when the nobility begin their pointless squabbles and corpses pile up as ordinary people get caught up in the madness, the title is desperately apt. This is like watching an entire country turn insane, the red and white roses of Lancaster and York coming violently together like red blood on the alabaster white skin of a corpse. Hall's achievement is to capture both the absurdity and full horror of this conflict.

These are young men's plays, action plays, written by Shakespeare in his 20s, and Hall directs them with the thrust and vigour they demand. You may not experience the epic sweep of the plays, as you do if you watch the whole trilogy, but seen over an afternoon and evening they plunge you straight into the heart of the bloody conflict.

The violence is both precise and distanced, scary and macabre. There is a high body count, but Hall applies a grisly comic touch. Every murder is played out in graphic detail but the bodies receive no blows or cuts. Instead animal entrails are sliced and gored, giant cabbages axed and cleaved. Soon a faint, sickening smell of offal pervades the theatre. It is hard to look at what is happening on stage, harder still to avert your eyes.

The cutting and compacting of the plays sometimes leaves you wanting and, although Hall has very successfully used male actors in female roles in the past, it doesn't entirely work for Henry's wife, the "she-wolf" Margaret. Robert Hands is good at first but fails to capture her cruelty or venom as the conflict escalates. He is too emotionally restrained, perhaps afraid of seeming camp. But there are some really fine performances, with Vincent Leigh's scheming Earl of Suffolk and Richard Clothier's Richard Duke of Gloucester (later Richard III) particularly catching the eye.

With its use of traditional catches and airs, sense of time passing from early Edwardian England to the 1930s and seething volcanic violence, this production speaks honestly, vividly and with commendable simplicity and modernity to its audience about a time when England's green and pleasant land was polluted by blood.

It is a pity the Arts Council did not have the vision to fund a tour so that a much wider audience could be reminded of the realities of civil war.

 Until March 17. Box office: 01635 46044.

fields.headline: Cohabitants
fields.standfirst:
Clore Studio, London
**
fields.trailText:
Clore Studio, London
**
fields.body:
In the glossy world of classical ballet, where Sylvie Guillem and Swan Lake regularly top the global box office, it seems increasingly hard for young choreographers to take their chances and junior dancers to step out of the corps de ballet and create new roles.

One exemplary project of the rebuilt Royal Opera House has been to offer the Linbury Theatre and Clore Studio as platforms for small works, with the artists' development initiative sponsoring them. Currently benefiting are Tom Sapsford (dancer with the Royal Ballet) and Cathy Marston (creator of several works for the Royal's Dance Bites series), whose joint programme, Cohabitants, is showing at the Clore.

It would be pleasing to herald their works as triumphs - Cinderella dance pieces that the big company will unhesitatingly whisk into its main house repertory. But, while both have interesting features, neither feels like a serious proposition.

In Last Days at the Empire, Sapsford has taken iconic characters and speciality acts from the 19th-century music hall and twisted them into odd, disconnected versions of themselves, the performers like ghosts caught in an old theatre. Their acts include neat pastiches - a mirror dance performed by near identical chorus girls, a mimed marionette dance, a sweetly cracked rendition of She Was Poor, but She Was Honest - but for the piece to be more than a series of diverting turns, the dance framework must be more fully evolved.

Marston's Traces, set to a distractingly polyglot score by Yann Tierson, begins with a fine fury. A group of men leap and twist in tight-knit competition. They are watched by four women and, as the piece evolves, the dancers pair off into a series of on-off relationships. Time is encapsulated, as if we were watching a speeded-up weather film.

But the piece is let down by Marston's reliance on extraneous emoting - sad looks and pouting shrugs - rather than registering feeling through the dynamics of the dance. This is bad choreography and it makes the dancers look prissy. Yet the closing duet for Edward Watson and Jenny Tattersall lifts the piece right back to where it started, a sustained piece of grown-up dancing full of information about grown-up people.

 Until February 14. Box office: 020-7304 4000.

fields.headline: Dealing with reality
fields.standfirst: Trading shares over the internet can make huge savings but it leaves traditionalists nervous. Marianne Curphey has a guide for the novice
fields.trailText: One of the advantages of the internet is the huge saving on dealing costs when trading shares online. The most common experience when buying shares over the internet, however, is that it doesn't feel "real".
fields.body:
One of the advantages of the internet is the huge saving on dealing costs when trading shares online. The most common experience when buying shares over the internet, however, is that it doesn't feel "real".

The traditional way of selling shares - filling out forms to send by post, or telephoning a stockbroker to give instructions - may be more time-consuming, but it does make you feel as though you are committing real funds.

On the internet you see the share price quote, have 30 seconds to decide whether to buy or sell, hit the button and the deal is done. Some sites have a timer in the corner of the screen counting down the 30 seconds before your real-time price quote be comes invalid. Don't let this rush you - you can always request another quote.

As trading online can feel "unreal" it is important to think about why you are buying or selling a share before you log on. Advisers suggest before you buy you should:

Know why you are buying the share;

Decide the maximum price you are going to pay, if you are buying, and check whether a share is rising or falling before you confirm the quote. Decide at what price you will sell;

Use the interactive charts available on many sites to check the spread (the difference between the buying and the selling price) and whether the volumes (the number of trades taking place in the market that day) are high or low;

If you are trading in a low-volume environment with few buyers or sellers, then the spread is likely to be much wider. This will effectively be just another cost, as you will be paying much more for a share than you would receive were you to sell it back immediately;

Don't think you have to buy at the price quoted. You can come back later and ask for another quote. A few minutes of cool deliberation is not going to hurt.

How to open an online trading account.

You'll need bank account details (and National Insurance number if you want to open an individual savings account). You'll be asked to choose a password and user name.

Most sites allow you to open an account without charge, although they may charge you a fee for more de tailed market information. Charles Schwab www.schwab-europe.com will provide registered customers with streamed real-price information.

Once you've registered, you'll be sent some forms by post that you need to fill in and return. You'll also be asked for some ID in terms of recent bank statements and utility bills.

The quickest way to start trading is to send a cheque to be credited to your trading account when you return the initial forms.

Your account should be set up and ready to trade after about a fortnight if you return your postal forms as soon as you get them.

Many sites have share price charts, details of how many people are buying or selling that share and a portfolio tool which shows you how your existing share holdings are performing. The best and most useful trading tools tend to be available only to people who have registered or are account-holders.

Once you have opened a trading account you are allowed into the secure part of the site and can get real-time share prices. Most brokers offer the same services.

BBC finance www.bbc.co.uk/finance and DLJdirectwww.dljdirect.co.uk have a share price "ticker" which constantly updates, You have to be on the inter net to view this ticker.

Some sites offer free information, like Market Eye www.marketeye.co.uk, Big Charts www.bigcharts.com and Hemmington Scott www.hemscott.net while UK Invest www.uk-invest.co.uk has a good market report which is updated twice-daily.

It can be cheaper to use an online broker but only if you think first about how often you plan to trade, what additional facilities you want from the broker's site, and whether youwant telephone support from time to time.

The cheapest brokers tend to have low fees for individ ual trades but charge a quarterly or annual management fee. Others have slightly higher dealing fees but that is the only charge you pay. It is worth checking what rates of interest are on offer. Some pay only 1% on small sums deposited while others pay a flat rate of 4.25%.

If you trade small sums of money infrequently you are better off opting for a slightly higher commission rate and no annual fee. If you trade regularly, or your trades are worth £5,000 or more, you may be better off opting for a flat fee per trade or regular trader's account.

One of the best ways to calculate which broker will offer the best trading facility is to visit the Interactive Investor site (www.iii.co.uk) and use the interactive broker calculator in the section entitled "online trading". It will tell you which broker offers the cheapest deal for your trade. Registration is free.

E-asy as one, two, three

This is an extract from E-cash, a step by step guide to managing your money online by Marianne Curphey. Find out how to control your own finances, search for a mortgage online, move bank accounts, submit your tax form online, invest in shares and find the best websites for financial information.

E-cash is published by Pearson Education and is available at bookshops or via www.bol.com.

Marianne Curphey is editor of Money, the personal finance website of the Guardian and part of the GuardianUnlimited website. Find out more about banking, share dealing and homebuying online at www.theguardian.com/money.

fields.headline: Hallé/ Skrowaczewski
fields.standfirst:
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester
***
fields.trailText:
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester
***
fields.body:
Composers who felt unappreciated in their own lifetime invariably consoled themselves with the conviction that their time would eventually come, even if they did not live to see it. Bruckner, though at times tormented by self-doubt, cherished a deep conviction that his music would survive him. He has been proved right. Yet the same criticisms that dogged him in life - his orchestration was poor, his structures too rigid - are still voiced, and many conductors prefer those versions of his symphonies that were "improved" by his pupils over Bruckner's originals.

By choosing the 1890 version of the Third Symphony - the one most altered by Bruckner's pupils - Skrowaczewski (who made a few alterations of his own to the orchestration) went for the streamlined option. In many ways, this was welcome: conductors who emphasise the block-like textures and form risk sounding four-square and losing momentum. Skrowaczewski was never in danger of that; in fact, parts of the scherzo in particular didn't sound like Bruckner at all. The gentle Austrian dances that punctuate its opening whirlwind theme were brilliantly infused with the colours and inflections that Mahler was later to painstakingly notate.

The pros and cons of interpreting music "backwards" in this way are legion, but on this occasion it was a revelation. Every change of tone was imaginatively characterised; the finale's slow polka almost grotesquely inflected, sounding as it if was rising from a vault rather than from a party. The Hallé played magnificently, with principal flautist Andrew Nicholson on especially fine form.

Chantal Juillet's crystalline sound is ideally suited to the luminous textures and enchanted moods of Szymanowski's First Violin Concerto. Weaving its way through the sumptious orchestral texture like silver thread, her high tessitura was exquisitely rounded with an intense vibrato, each note swelling like a raindrop but never breaking. Skrowaczewski and the Hallé were sensitive partners in a delicately coloured and nuanced performance.

A slight disappointment came in Wagner's Tannhauser overture, where the mellow but sometimes weak Hallé strings were overwhelmed by full-bodied brass and bass sections. Perhaps placing the double basses behind the wind and brass contributed to a booming sound; this mattered most towards the end, where a more robust string sound was badly needed.

webTitle: Interview: James Crosby, chief executive, Halifax

fields.headline: Actuarial artistry
fields.standfirst:
James Crosby, chief executive, Halifax

Money site
fields.trailText: Interview: James Crosby, chief executive, Halifax
fields.body:
James Crosby is a bundle of energy as he rushes into an ultra-modern meeting room offering panoramic views of the City. This 44-year-old, bespectacled chief executive of Halifax has just completed the purchase of Equitable Life after seeing off the finance arm of the vast American company, General Electric.

He refuses to admit to fatigue after arduous talks to clinch the purchase of a mutual insurer almost every other potential bidder has refused to touch. He is running late, due to a two-hour delay to yesterday morning's flight from his home in Yorkshire .

Not that the minor irritation of a late flight or the major headache of a £1bn acquisition that GE Capital tried to spoil was likely to slow him down. "The organisation can move no faster than the people at the top. If the people at the top are making decisions about what happens today but not about what's going to make a difference in a year, then there isn't anything happening in a year's time," he says.

The deal to buy Equitable Life - on which GE Capital only gave up its advances late on Thursday night - is one that could help to further transform Halifax from a lumbering mortgage bank to a financial services firm that is as much about selling life insurance as it is about selling mortgages.

The mutual business, says Crosby - who was described by one commentator last week as having a brain so big that it had pushed out his hair - is good for his shareholders and good for Equitable's long suffering policyholders, who are caught between the 90,000 who hold guaranteed annuities and the 1m who do not.

Allegation

An actuary by training, Crosby is ideally suited to unpicking Equitable's dilemma. One allegation against Equitable was that its actuaries got their sums wrong and left it with a potential £1.5bn hole - something which the Halifax deal addresses by enabling Equitable to mount a scheme limiting the billion-pound bill to honour guaranteed annuities. Of course, the policyholders still have to agree.

"It gives them the opportunity to vote for a scheme that puts the fund on a new financial footing. It's a big prize," he says, convinced that Equitable will muster the support it needs from policyholders, some of whom accuse Equitable of acting too quickly in accepting Halifax and want others bidders to be considered again - although they admit that is now unlikely.

As a student of maths, Crosby believes logical arguments will win over the policyholders who pointed at Halifax's share price rise last week as evidence that the bank is getting a good deal. Yesterday the shares were still stuck below the 774p at which they made their debut when the Halifax building society floated four years ago, but at 713p they were well above the 410p they sank to this time last year.

Crosby wants to boost Halifax's shares by persuading the City that it is more than just mortgages - a market that is facing fierce competition and where Halifax is historically the biggest lender. He aims to set Halifax apart as a champion of the consumer, hence the decision to set Howard Brown, the fish-carrying bank cashier, on to an unsuspecting national TV audience to try to lure customers for its 4% interest-bearing current account.

Brown is now something of a celebrity, and Crosby recounts a tale where the winner of the internal talent competition received a standing ovation at a recent sales conference and was besieged by colleagues seeking his autograph and ignoring their chief executive. "I can't sing," Crosby chortles when asked why he is not fronting the campaign in the way Sir Peter Davis did when running the Prudential.

Crosby, despite his Yorkshire roots, is not blunt enough to say what he really thinks about the "big four" - Lloyds TSB, HSBC, NatWest and Barclays - with their more than 70% share of the current account market. He refuses to say they rip off their customers with their 0.1% rate.

Instead, he says: "It makes no sense in today's world for the clearing banks to offer 0.1%. That is a complete anachronism, and it is basically saying to the customers we'll give you 0.1% because you won't leave. It doesn't make any sense compared to any other financial product."

The ad campaign has prompted people to go into Halifax branches and ask for a "Howard account". Refusing to be precise about how many new accounts the bank has added to its 2m share of the 30m account current market before the bank's profits announcement in a fortnight, he admits to being "OK" with progress so far.

Now two years into the job, Crosby was virtually unknown to the City when he took the helm after the sudden departure of Mike Blackburn. This is despite the fact that the fast-talking sports enthusiast had been instrumental Halifax's acquisition of Clerical Medical just before the building society floated on the stock market.

There is no sign that he would ever encourage Halifax to move its head office from the eponymous Yorkshire town. He admits to holding a long-standing prejudice against living and working in London, instead chosing Ilkley, where he lives with his wife Una and four daughters - one of whom he delivered - aged 10, eight, six and two.

The Equitable deal - which his wife has banned him from mentioning - is part of the diversification strategy away from Halifax's traditional market, in which it has a share of 20% that every financial institution wants to steal. The upmarket insurance business, St James's Place, as well as the "right here, right now" Intelligent Finance and the signing up of Peter Wood, the Direct Line multimillionaire, to create an online insurance operation, are also part of this diversification drive. Crosby admits the launching of Intelligent Finance provided both his highs and lows last year but he is not one to dwell on mistakes - an early lesson in his career when he was a fund manager at Scottish Amicable in Glasgow, in the early 1980s.

"The ability to say, 'hey, that was wrong' and move on to the next game quickly, rather than get involved in bureaucratic processes where everybody says 'it wasn't my fault' - you learn that from fund management," he says.

Persuasion

Yet, even though Halifax's traditional market is under siege from competitors, Crosby refuses to give up on it. The bank is writing to 1m customers to persuade them to stay - part of Crosby's belief that keeping customers is crucial.

"Banking in the last 10 or 15 years has been far too much about making profits in the belief the customer won't leave you. The customer will leave you. The customer will vote with his feet. The excitement is all about how do you grow the business by providing better value for customers and working with them," he says.

To the City this means lower profit margins, and Crosby has yet to answer those who question whether attempts to woo customers today could leave Halifax in a jam in a year with badly dented profits.

Crosby says he has already warned his investors that he expects these margins to be depressed this year. Some in the City think that could force him to seek out a big acquisition or become a target, but he insists he does not believe in the big acquisitions of the kind being fought out between his closest rival, Abbey National, with Bank of Scotland and Lloyds TSB.

"If you really are making yourself more retail and value focused, the morale of the people in the front line is critical to your ability to grow," he says. This 44-year-old, bespectacled chief executive of Halifax has just completed the purchase of Equitable Life after seeing off the finance arm of the vast American company, General Electric. He refuses to admit to fatigue after arduous talks to clinch the purchase of a mutual insurer almost every other potential bidder has refused to touch. He is running late, due to a two-hour delay to yesterday morning's flight from his home in Yorkshire . Not that the minor irritation of a late flight or the major headache of a £1bn acquisition that GE Capital tried to spoil was likely to slow him down. "The organisation can move no faster than the people at the top. If the people at the top are making decisions about what happens today but not about what's going to make a difference in a year, then there isn't anything happening in a year's time," he says. One allegation against Equitable was that its actuaries got their sums wrong and left it with a potential £1.5bn hole - something which the Halifax deal addresses by enabling Equitable to mount a scheme limiting the billion-pound bill to honour guaranteed annuities. "I can't sing," Crosby chortles when asked why he is not fronting the campaign in the way Sir Peter Davis did when running the Prudential. fields.headline: Arditti Quartet
fields.standfirst:
St John's, London
***
fields.trailText:
St John's, London
***
fields.body:
The most surprising thing about the Arditti Quartet's concert of string quartets by Leos Janacek and new pieces by Adrian Jack was that Janacek's 70-year-old music sounded the more modern, extreme and uncompromising. The Ardittis played Jack's Third String Quartet, and gave the first ever performances of his Fourth Quartet and 08.02.01, a separate movement dedicated to the Ardittis' leader Irvine Arditti, on his birthday.

Jack's language is a well-mannered synthesis of 20th century styles. The second movement of the Third Quartet was a volatile scherzo, expertly versed in the extended harmonic palettes of Ravel and Debussy. The finale began as a quiet procession of diatonic chords, which eventually flowered into a lively unison passage. Finally, the piece returned to the translucent textures of the opening movement, as Jack integrated this static, reflective music within an organic argument. Yet for all Jack's compositional elegance, this quartet told an old, even hackneyed, story.

The three movements of the Fourth Quartet were still more conventional. Jack's slow movement created a subtle drama of continuity and interruption, as a series of gently rocking chords were fragmented into faltering, staccato phrases. However, there was nothing fresh or startling about this music, and the Ardittis' performances of all of Jack's quartets were uncharacteristically remote and uninvolving. Even the celebratory 08.02.01 was more enervating than exciting.

The title of Jack's 08.02.01 may have been a reference to Janacek's Piano Sonata 1.X.1905, one of the most famous pieces to be named after a date. But Janacek's two string quartets inhabit a totally different expressive world from Jack's. The Ardittis' account of Janacek's First String Quartet was full of their typical energy and elan, but this was a curiously unfocused performance.

However, the performance of Janacek's Second String Quartet which concluded the concert was brilliantly intense. In the codas to the first and fourth movements, Janacek seems to write against the grain of the instruments, producing sounds and raw noises of extraordinary force. The Ardittis are used to breaking limitations in the contemporary repertoire, a practice for which they are famous. Yet there was nothing complacent about their playing of this venerable masterpiece. The shocking juxtapositions felt as visceral as they must have done at its premiere.

fields.headline: Jonathan Gee Quartet
fields.standfirst:
Bonington Theatre, Nottingham
****
fields.trailText:
Bonington Theatre, Nottingham
****
fields.body:
Pianist Jonathan Gee is clearly in love with his own music. As he beavers away at the keyboard, face contorted into a grimace of ecstasy, his band rally round him with a combination of gentle intelligence and blissed-out fervour.

Touring to promote his new album, recorded live at Ronnie Scott's, Gee has surrounded himself with stellar talent, including Courtney Pine's former drummer Winston Clifford, and ex-Loose Tubes sax man Tim Whitehead. Gee has found his soulmate in Clifford: the powerful-looking percussionist has an understated delicacy that perfectly propels these thoughtful and finely wrought compositions. He effortlessly throws subtle samba grooves into the stew, plays his solos with the tips of his fingers and occasionally sings along in a quietly keening falsetto.

Meanwhile, Whitehead confidently navigates the emotional labyrinth of Gee's musical creations, blowing from side to side with his eyes closed, set afloat by the swinging buoyancy of Steve Rose's bass.

Gee's compositions are unfailingly melodic, packed with riffs, motifs and tune fragments that could all form the basis for some attractive and inventive pop songs. As a pianist he evokes the spirits of Herbie Hancock, Claude Debussy and Bill Evans, carefully balancing a light-footed funkiness with a sensuous enjoyment of colour and dynamics. Even when he is tempted to play a million notes per second the effect is curiously meditative, and the rhythmic unpredictability of his playing never interferes with the groove.

The group are at their most powerful when playing incredibly softly, tiptoeing through an intricate series of stops and starts, carefully making their mark in space with a quietly glowing intensity. At one point they evoke the softly shimmering melancholia of times gone by so effectively that they stand stock still with expressions of regret on their faces, as if contemplating all that they have ever loved and lost.

In many ways it's a shame that Gee chooses to work in such a traditional jazz quartet format. His music is endlessly inventive, harmonically and rhythmically, and although it is being played by superb musicians you can imagine it arranged for a more unusual line-up. Could he not perhaps take a leaf from Django Bates's book and hire a string quartet, a couple of samplers and a beautiful female vocalist? He would get a bigger audience.
