fields.headline: Showbiz rage from bad boy Eminem
fields.standfirst:
Eminem
Manchester Arena
***
fields.trailText:
Eminem
Manchester Arena
***
fields.body:
Eminem's reputation as the world's number one bad boy rapper precedes him. Prior to this opening night of his UK visit, Manchester council and police force placed restrictions on the show. Outside, gay-rights groups are up in arms about the singer's lyrical use of violent imagery and supposed homophobia. In front of police lines, people distribute leaflets claiming: "Eminem has gone too far."

Casual bystanders may wonder why a pop star provokes such fury. Anthony Hopkins stalks our screens as Hannibal the cannibal, but no one thinks the actor really eats humans for supper. Yet in pop there is an identification of the singer with the song. There is nothing to suggest Eminem's murderous, misogynist characters such as Slim Shady are any more real than Hammer horror or Sir Cliff's satanic Devil Woman.

Eminem (aka Marshall Mathers) is primarily a fantasist, pop's own Stephen King, producing art that is repellent but compelling. His use of words such as "bitch" and "faggot" is unfortunate, but in US hip-hop these are put-downs, with less inflammatory ramifications than here. Eminem appears as bemused by the fuss as his fans, from all ages, colours and genders, who are actually civil, but enjoy the thrill of music that gets outsiders hot under the collar.

Sixteen thousand of them give the thumbs-up to a show rooted in cinematic horror. Eminem - as Slim - recreates the Texas Chainsaw Massacre (in accordance with officialdom, the saw is not plugged in) and appears in an electric chair. Much of the rest is a standard rap show. The contentious lyrics are often inaudible. On record Eminem comes across as a genuinely anti-social nihilist, but live he is a good old-fashioned crowd-pleaser.

Of course, few escape his cartoon rage - from his mum to the thousands of "bitches" in the audience who cheer his homicidal threats. It helps that the bad boy is very cute. At one point, he gets the entire audience to shout that they're "drug addicts". Really? Noticeably, he draws the line at racism. As a white rapper who has fought hard for the respect of the rap community, he places his instinct for self-preservation above that for shock.

On record, Eminem is a master of complex psychological games. His detractors have not noticed that his glorious hit Stan explores unrequited male to male adoration".

The vaunted homophobia? One of Eminem's rappers wields a rubber phallus, but it is more pantomime than sinister. A more dicey moment is when Eminem mentions the weapons charges facing him in the US, but it becomes just a way of introducing his tune Criminal. Eminem is playing some dangerous games, but the bottom line is showbiz.

 Eminem is at the Dockland Arena, London E14 (020-7538 1212), tonight. A version of this review appeared in later editions of yesterday's paper.

fields.headline: Dublin play scratches at Irish scabs
fields.standfirst:
Foley
Civic Theatre, Dublin
****
fields.trailText:
Foley
Civic Theatre, Dublin
****
fields.body:
Considering the situation in Northern Ireland, it is rather impolite to point up historical or class differences between Catholics and Protestants in the Irish Republic. So playwright Michael West scratches at fairly uncomfortable scabs with this literary monologue of one George Foley, the last of a lineage stretching back through 300 years of Protestant, land-owning ascendancy.

This is an extremely odd critique of the last vestiges of a decaying Anglo-Irish "big house". The musing, childless Foley is poisoned by the legacy of his great-great-grandfather, who shot a Catholic peasant robbing his orchard. Even Foley's irascible gentleman-farmer father routinely refers to Catholics as "poachers".

Foley, played by Andrew Bennett, stands alone in life, abandoned by his wife and remembering his childhood in a family whose impeccable manners sheathed an unconscionable rudeness. To spite them, he married a Catholic and converted - as he says, "about the most Protestant thing I ever did in my life".

With visionary theatrical shorthand, Bennett distractedly evokes the menagerie of the family: doting aunt Hilda constantly asking for her dead pug-dog; a snot-lisping cousin; the questionable child's memory of his parents icily bonking on the kitchen table.

West's purple prose is far from ideal for the stage, but Bennett carries you along with his measured, basso profundo delivery. His often distasteful, provocative playing delivers irresistible stabs of humour, both high and low, such as the caricature of the hapless Irish cook, forever having an accident with the potatoes.

Bennett's intensity also coughs up some nicely unmoored gems of pathos, such as the Equus-like bareback horse ride across the benighted fields; or the death at 13 of his life-enhancing sister, Beah, from heart failure - as though she were some fragile thing, ill-equipped to survive in the airless "big house".

Such moments are heightened by Vincent Doherty's live, delicate piano, and Annie Ryan's momentarily stylised direction. Even so, West's play often seems better suited for radio, or even the page. His self-conscious fussing with language, and contradictory, metafictional touches, are extremely distracting, and Foley seems to invent his memories as he goes along, causing you to doubt the veracity of anything he says.

All that aside, this is a strangely affecting 75-minute piece. Crucially, it hinges on Bennett's performance - all the way to Foley's unreliable vision of the past.

 Ends tonight. Box office: 00-353-1-4627477. Then tours.
